come into existence only after they rolled off the Ve Ë™nkateÅ›vara, Va Ë™ngavÂ¯

asÂ¯Ä±, or

other 19th and early 20th century presses of India. Even if mss of â€˜completeâ€™

PurÂ¯

an.as exist, these are often to be considered as conflated products. How should we proceed when we want to produce a critical edition of such elusive material? This question was posed by Bonazzoli in an article in 1983 and a brave solution was proposed in a sample-edition of the Garud

. apurÂ¯

an

. a, handed

out and discussed at the Sixth World Sanskrit Conference in Philadelphia October 1984. 23

Alas, apart from problems of lay-out, which are considerable, I think the proposed procedure is unsatisfactory, since no text edited in this new way can lay any claim to authenticity. In fact it is a new creation which could be best designated as a vulgate, and of vulgate editions we have already enough. It is a â€˜ collectio lectionumâ€™ ( op. cit. 2), which, in itself, is of course a useful thing, but it is of doubtful value for historical research. It takes as the standard text the readings â€˜that have been accepted by the majority of the mss and editions ( op. cit. 4) and presents the variant-readings in sub-lines, on the parallel page, and in a critical apparatus. The decision to abandon the concept of the â€˜originalâ€™ text is to be welcomed, yet the replacement of a pedigree as the guiding principle by only a single rule, viz. that of the lectio plurium codicum potior, might lead to a phenomenon that the connoisseurs of football may know: the world-team composed of the best players of the globe looks respectable and trustworthy, yet it fails to do the trick, due to the incompatibility of its members. Besides, how can we determine what should still be included? Is there a minimum of mss required for a text-portion to be accepted or will every ms that in its colophon claims to belong to the Garud

. purÂ¯

an

. a be taken into account?

It is my conviction that as long as critical editions of puranic literature aim at presenting such artificial compilations as â€˜complete PurÂ¯

an.asâ€™ the results will

remain arbitrary. For reasons just mentioned, in the majority of cases reconstruction of an archetypal version is out of the question, 24 compilatory editions as now proposed by Bonazzoli seem inadequate to the demands of historical (e.g. AmbikÂ¯

akhan

. d

. a, Utkalakhan

. d

. a, KÂ¯

aÅ›Â¯Ä±khan

. d

. a, KedÂ¯

arakhan

. d

. a), whereas evidently no

attempt was made to compile or transcribe a â€˜completeâ€™ SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a comprising all

(i.e. more than one) parts ( khan

. d

. as/ sam

. hitÂ¯

as) (cf. Aufrecht, Catalogus Catalogorum

s.v.).

The manuscript referred to would become ms S1 of our critical edition of the â€˜originalâ€™

SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a (see below, p. 185 ff.).

22 Bonazzoli 1983, 255 ff.

23 Bonazzoll 1984.

24 An exception is to be made for some of the early PurÂ¯

an

. as like e.g. the Vis.n

. upurÂ¯

an

. a,

which shows a homogeneous structure and gives the impression of being composed by a single (group of) author(s). This seems to be borne out by the critical edition of this PurÂ¯

an

. a by M.M. Pathak (Baroda 1997â€“99). Another instance of a homogeneous original PurÂ¯

an

. a text is the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a preserved in some early Nepalese mss (see

below, p. 185 ff. and the Prolegomena to SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, SP I.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

182

Hans Bakker

research, synoptic editions of all versions and recensions are more often than not practically unrealizable, and also critical editions of only one recension may mostly appear unattainable owing to the fact that what a recension is can only be defined by comparing it with the text-material that deviates or does not belong to it. 25

The solution I would suggest is to build on the principles of Kirfel and Hacker, that is to start from the basic materials or components out of which the network of puranic literature is built up and to forget about the superstructure of â€˜completeâ€™ PurÂ¯

an.as for the time being. An assessment of a khan.d.a or PurÂ¯an.a as a whole can be made when all its components are critically evaluated. The joint editions of the components can be seen as constituting the critical edition of the whole.

The proposed method entails the dissolution of the traditional texture of MahÂ¯

a- and UpapurÂ¯

an.as, and though the resulting fragmentation might appear confusing on first sight, it could be the only way to disclose the historical structure of this type of literature. Study of a component should be accompanied by an edition of it, because only the collation of all related ms evidence can reveal the particular text-tradition of the component. It may appear that the recension included in a certain PurÂ¯

an.a represents merely one stage of its textual

history. A synoptic edition of all recensions pertaining to this tradition may intersect one or more PurÂ¯

an.as since, as it would seem, many a re-composition

remained outside the Smr.ti compilations.

The critical edition of the AyodhyÂ¯

amÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya

To illustrate the proposal I may adduce my investigation into the history of the holy town of AyodhyÂ¯

a (Bakker 1986). The starting point of my research

was the AyodhyÂ¯

amÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya (AM) as it occurs in the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a.

A collation of all available ms material that was somehow related to the AM, among which were texts bearing other titles such as KoÅ›alakhan

. d

. a or AyodhyÂ¯

a-

khan

. d

. a, yielded three different text-groups as well as an epitome. 26 First there is the recension that is found in the printed SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a and that is secured

by Dharmanibandha testimony (the â€˜Vais.n.avakhan.d.a recensionâ€™). Then there is a second recension that extends the text-material and re-composes it. In the colophon of some of its mss it claims to belong to the RudrayÂ¯amala, probably the most chimeric of all anonymous literature. 27 The third group contains longer and shorter versions, both having only very few Â´

slokas in common with

25 Cf. Bedekar 1969, 213.

26 Bakker 1986 II, vii ff.

27 Cf. Goudriaan 1981, 47.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

9 / Some Methodological Considerations

183

the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a recension though they appear structurally akin to it. The texts pertaining to this group could, on text-critical grounds, be proven to have been meant as a kind of supplement to the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a recension. They lost their relevance when the second recension was composed which includes most of the materials of the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a recension and its supplements.

This recension was, again, abridged in an epitome. The relative chronology of the text-groups was established by virtue of text-critical arguments only.

In order to avoid a petitio principii, inferences from the texts regarding the historical development of the town were based on this chronology, which was subsequently given an absolute foundation by connecting it with independent evidence. 28

The three basic text-groups are presented in three parallel columns. Although this gives a certain amount of duplication and sometimes triplication of the text-material, it seems justified by the fact that a proper assessment of the historical purport of one recension can only be fully grasped by means of a scrupulous comparison with the other versions. It is especially the, often minute, differences between the texts that lend significance to their contents.

A problem that this type of editing brings with it is that each composition has its own sequence in which pericopes or chapters are organized. The problem is solved by accepting the sequence of the most comprehensive recension as the standard one, by splitting this text in its textual units, and presenting these along with the parallel versions of the other text-groups. To enable the reader to read the units of a text-group in their original sequence references are given at the beginning and end of each chapter to the page on which the linking text can be found. The original sequence can also be recovered with the help of detailed concordances.

A close examination of the ms evidence revealed that none of the versions was directly based upon another. They seem to represent three more or less independent re-compositions of a basic stock of text-materials. These compositions were handed down in more than one ms so that a critical edition of each of them could be attained. Comparison of several abrupt transitions and obscure references in the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a recension with the supplementary texts revealed that both must have drawn on the same source and that the Skanda- or Vais.n.avakhan.d.a recension actually forms a selection and first redaction of this original pool of text-materials. 29 The latter may have been the MÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya as it evolved and was transmitted locally. This was not necessarily a well-defined text, something that could be called â€˜ â€™, an archetype in the strict sense. Rather it would have been in a fluid state, modified and supplemented according to changes in local circumstances. Hence I prefered to designate it as an â€˜ -type-of-textâ€™. The composer of the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a may 28 Bakker 1986 I, 125 ff.

29 Bakker 1986 II, xxvii ff.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

184

Hans Bakker

have had access to this pool and have given it definite form. 30

If, as may well be assumed, the three other regional MÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmyas contained in

the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a appear just as accurate and detailed descriptions of local circumstances as the AM proved to be, it seems impossible that the composer of the khan

. d

. a himself created the texts. He might, however, have done the same as the editor of the modern TÂ¯Ä±rthÂ¯

a Ë™nk, viz. solliciting local communities

to provide him with the basic materials. 31 Presumably the local tradition did not breakdown after it had issued its first acknowledged Smr.ti product, but continued to generate text-materials which finally resulted in a new composition at the time the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a recension was felt to be antiquated. Thus the second recension came into being, too late to find recognition in the traditional Smr.ti literature. It was hoped that the assignment to the RudrayÂ¯amala would do.

The given scheme of text-evolution confirms the well-known fact that the contents of the components of puranic texts may be considerably older than the respective khan

. d

. as or PurÂ¯

an.as in which they are included. These embry-

onic components may have evolved and been transmitted in local or religious communities, in the form of a pool of text-materials that we have called â€˜ -

type-of-textâ€™, to which the PurÂ¯

an.a composers had recourse. It is only on this

level of the textual history of puranic literature that the question of oral versus written tradition becomes significant. Are the texts that were incorporated in a puranic superstructure the first redactions in writing? Was the genetic process of â€˜composition-in-transmissionâ€™, which no doubt took place by means of writing, continuously sustained by small-scale oral traditions? The present state of our knowledge does not allow a general answer to these questions. However, the glimpses of the â€˜ -type-of-textâ€™ that we obtained through analysing the ms evidence of the AM showed textual fluidity as well as formularity to such a degree as to make at least the hypothesis that postulates local or religious communities as the oral fountain-heads of puranic literature worthy of further investigation.

30 The nature of this â€˜poolâ€™ and how it evolved into an organized text is the subject of an essay included at the end of this volume (below, pp. 601 ff.).

31 The composer of the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a may have been active in the 14th century. On the basis of independent evidence, the Vais.n.avakhan.d.a recension of the AM reflects the historical situation in the 13th century. This tallies with the date given to the Purus.ottamaks.etramÂ¯ahÂ¯atmya contained in the same khan.d.a, viz. c. ad 1300 (COJ pp. 36, 54, 170).

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s Svayam

. varaâˆ—

Studies in the SkandapurÂ¯

an.a I

Introduction

As has been reported in various international meetings and in Indo-Iranian Journal (IIJ) 37 (1994), 325â€“331, a team at the University of Groningen (consisting of R. Adriaensen, H. Isaacson and the present author) is currently working on the critical edition of the oldest extant text that calls itself SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a. Apart from the passage discussed below there seem to be few textual links between the vulgate SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a and the text we are presently editing.

The oldest document on which this edition is based is a Nepalese palm-leaf manuscript dating from ad 810 (our siglum S ).1 It contains a SkandapurÂ¯an 1

. a

(further referred to as SP) that does not yet consist of khan

. d

. as. Of this text

three recensions are known. The oldest recension is the one found in three (incomplete) Nepalese palm-leaf mss (our sigla S , S , S , jointly S).2 A later 1

2

3

recension is found in a ms that in its colophon calls itself the RevÂ¯akhan.d.a of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a (our siglum R), but that is entirely different from the printed RevÂ¯

akhan

. d

. a. 3 The third and probably latest recension is found in mss that in their colophons style themselves as the AmbikÂ¯

akhan

. d

. a of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a.

Of these we have collected to date four manuscripts (our sigla A , A , A and 1

2

3

A , jointly A). 4 Our edition aims at reconstructing the S recension as far as 4

possible, while the variants of the R and A recensions will be presented each in a separate register of the critical apparatus. 5 The editio princeps of the SP

(abbreviated as SPBh) was prepared by Kr.s.n.aprasÂ¯ada Bhat.t.arÂ¯aÂ¯Ä± and appeared

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Wiener Zeitschrift fÃ¼r die Kunde SÃ¼dasiens und Archiv fÃ¼r indische Philosophie XL (1996), 5â€“43.

1 For this ms see Haraprasad Shastri 1905, p. lii (reprinted with a concordance by Reinhold GrÃ¼nendahl 1989); T. R. Gambier-Parry 1930, 22â€“25; Br.hatsÂ¯

presented us with a colour film of this ms.

Hans Bakker

in Kathmandu in 1988 (in the apparatus referred to by our siglum Bh). For further details concerning the mentioned mss and editions the reader is referred to the Prolegomena and Introductions to our edition (SP I, II A, II B, III, IV). 6

The wedding of Åšiva and PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯

Ä±

The aim of the present study is to illustrate the value of our text for the investigation of Sanskrit literature and the mythology of Hinduism by discussing a text passage in adhyÂ¯

aya 13. This chapter is concerned with the wedding of Åšiva and PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±. Four more texts appear to be relevant to this topic; they are discussed below and, together with the passage in SP 13, presented at the end of this article. In the four critical apparatuses I have only given those variant readings that may be significant for the comparison of the texts. For more variae lectiones of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a text the reader is referred to adhyÂ¯

aya 13

in SP I.

The myth of the wedding of Åšiva and PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± is well known to Indologists

from many Sanskrit texts as well as from numerous works of art. 7 It is all the more suprising that the version of this myth that occurs in the printed texts of the BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a (abbreviated as BrP; in the critical apparatus siglum Bpur), Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a (abbreviated as LiP) and the MÂ¯

aheÅ›varakhan

. d

. a of the vulgate

SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a (abbreviated as MKh; in the critical apparatus siglum Mkh), in which PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± is allowed to choose her husband in a svayam

. vara, has attracted

little attention of researchers of puranic literature and Åšaiva mythology; at least we have neither found a reference to it in the secondary literature which we have consulted directly, nor in the indices of the unsurpassed TÃ¼bingen Epic and PurÂ¯

an

. ic Bibliography.

The myth of PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s svayam

. vara is, however,

discussed by some historians of Indian art in order to explain images of a critical reconstruction. This modification does not directly effect the material presented here, but it may be useful to repeat the view expressed in the Prolegomena (SP I, 42).

Our aim in the edition has therefore been to establish a readable text based primarily on the early palm-leaf manuscripts. But we have also attempted to go at least to some extent beyond their readings to recover, to the best of our abilities, an earlier form of the text. That such an earlier form existed cannot be called into question, nor, in our view, that one should attempt, with all due caution, to reach it. We have emended (or adopted the reading of one or both other recensions) in cases where the Nepalese manuscripts offer a reading which we had good reason to think the result of, mainly involuntary, transmissional (i.e. scribal) error or variation.

6 The text of SP 13.28â€“57 adopted in this article conforms to the one presented in our critical edition of SP 13.28â€“57, which was published in 1998 (SP I, pp. 192â€“97).

7 For an elaborate survey the reader may be referred to the MA thesis (1991) of Ms Martina Stoye (Freie UniversitÃ¤t Berlin), Die textlichen Grundlagen zu Darstellungen der Hochzeit von Åšiva und PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± in der indischen Kunst, which is as yet unpublished.

(lying) woman with child. 8 It is this svayam

. vara version of the holy wedding

that is found in adhyÂ¯

arata appears also to be

of relevance, although it does not at first sight deal with PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s â€˜self-choiceâ€™.

Â´

Sivaâ€™s exclusion from the sacrifice

We may start our investigation by having a closer look at this chapter (173) of the Dron

. aparvan. After the death of Dron.a and the shattering of the Kauravas, Arjuna asks VyÂ¯

asa who was the man with the lance who marched in front of him and caused such havock on the battle field. VyÂ¯

asa answers that Arjuna had

seen Åšam

. kara; VyÂ¯

asa reveals Åšivaâ€™s nature in a famous eulogy, in which, among other things, reference is made to his retaliation against the gods when he is not allowed his share in the sacrifice (MBh 7.173.37â€“51). Then VyÂ¯

asa broaches

another subject. He tells how the gods asked Åšiva to break the power of the three cities of the asuras and how Åšiva accomplished this by one three-pronged arrow when an auspicious (astronomical) conjunction of the three heavenly cities had occurred (MBh 7.173.52â€“58). The next Â´

sloka makes a very harsh

transition. Apparently without any connection with the fore-going the text proceeds,

After herself placing the little child with five tufts of hair on her lap, UmÂ¯

a, as

she wished to know (who he was), asked the gods â€˜who is this?â€™ (MBh 7.173.59) 9

This verse is directly followed by another one, not less bewildering in its abrupt-ness.

The lord immobilized the arm of the infuriated Åšakra that held the vajra; this bountiful god, lord and ruler of the entire universe. (MBh 7.173.60) Two themes are juxtaposed here which, on first sight, seem to have very little to do with one another: (1) Åšivaâ€™s transformation into a little child and (2) his immobilisation of Indra who, it would seem, leads the gods in an act of aggresion. The origin of both themes can be traced back to the BrÂ¯

ahman.a

literature and a short survey of their evolution may help to clarify the text.

Discussing the function of the brahmÂ´

an priest, the Kaus.Â¯Ä±taki BrÂ¯ahman.a

teaches:

Then, when the gods thereupon performed the sacrifice, they put the fore-portion ( prÂ¯

aÂ´

sitra) aside for Savitr.; it cleft his hands. They restored to him two golden 8 My attention was drawn to this by the MA thesis of Ms Britta Zehmke (Freie UniversitÃ¤t Berlin), published in 1994: Die liegende Frau mit Kind in der indischen Steinplastik.

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s svayam

. vara.

(hands). Therefore he is celebrated as â€˜the one with golden handsâ€™. They put it aside for Bhaga; it gouged out his eyes. Therefore they say â€˜Bhaga is blindâ€™. They put it aside for PÂ¯

189

Thus Rudra partly takes over Indraâ€™s position as the god to whom this dangerous first portion of the sacrificial offering belongs; unlike Indra, however, he does not â€˜appeaseâ€™ it (this function is taken over by Savitr.), but, on the contrary, he is seen as the cause of the mutilation of the sacrifice and consequently of the gods.

The theme returns in the Sauptikaparvan 18 of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata, where it

is connected with Åšivaâ€™s exclusion from the sacrifice in general. 14 When the gods have divided among themselves their share ( bhÂ¯

aga) in the sacrifice, Rudra

seizes his bow, and runs towards them. Cosmic phenomena come to a halt.

Sacrifice ( yajËœ

na) is shot in the heart while fleeing to heaven in the form of an antelope ( mr.ga).15 The gods are baffled.

The infuriated Tryambaka cut off ( vyaÂ´

sÂ¯

atayat) the arms of Savitr., (and knocked

out) the eyes of Bhaga and the teeth of PÂ¯

us.an with the point of his bow

( dhanus.kot.i). Then the gods and a Ë™ngas of the sacrifice ran away all together; some rolled about on that very spot and became as if they breathed their last. But after he had put that entire (assembly) to the rout, Åšitikan.t.ha laughed, arrested the point of the bow and halted the gods. Thereupon the cry ( vÂ¯

ac) uttered by the

immortals snapped the string of his bow and, due to the shock, O king, the bow, its string broken, quivered. Thereupon the gods along with sacrifice approached the foremost of the gods, who was without bow (now), and took refuge; and the lord showed compassion. 16

Chapter 32 of the SP, followed by i.a. the Li Ë™nga- and ÅšivapurÂ¯

an

. as, applies the

theme to the description of Åšivaâ€™s exclusion from Daks.aâ€™s sacrifice. Here Indra and Vis.n.u are added to the group of explicitly mentioned gods that fall victim to the anger of Åšiva, in this case represented by his factotum Haribhadra. The arms raising their weapons are immobilized ( stambhana), just as the other inhabitants of heaven are said to be transfixed.

And Haribhadra, inflamed and without dismay, immobilized Åšakraâ€™s hand when he raised (it); and likewise (he immobilized the hands) of the other gods. (And) before (their) eyes he, with anger on his face, knocked out Bhagaâ€™s eyes and PÂ¯

us.anâ€™s teeth,

striking with the point of (his) bow. And without dismay he immobilized that dreadful discus of Vis.n.u, which shone like the apocalyptic sun, and it, (remaining) in his hand, did not move (forth). 17

So much for Åšivaâ€™s mutilation of the gods.

Siva as the cosmic child

The origin of the other theme, viz. Åšivaâ€™s transformation into a little child, can also be traced back to the Kaus.Â¯Ä±taki BrÂ¯ahman.a, in which PrajÂ¯apati begets a (grand)son through his four sons and daughter Us.as (Kaus.Br 6.1â€“3). This infant (?), â€˜of a thousand eyes, of a thousand feet, with a thousand fitted (arrows on his bow)â€™, 18 asks his (grand)father to bestow upon him eight names. 19

A new version of this myth is found in the PurÂ¯

an

. apaËœ

ncalaks.an.a,20 which tells

that at the dawn of creation, in the first kalpa, MahÂ¯

adeva Rudra engendered

a son in his own likeness ( Â¯

atmanas tulyam

. sutam). This little â€˜blue-redâ€™ boy

( kumÂ¯

aro nÂ¯Ä±lalohitah

. ) appeared in the lap of BrahmÂ¯

a and cried ( ruroda) terribly

( ghoram). He asked BrahmÂ¯

a to give him a name, and BrahmÂ¯

a names him

Rudra. The child kept crying until altogether eight namesâ€”the same as given to PrajÂ¯

apatiâ€™s son in the Kaus.Â¯Ä±taki and Åšatapatha BrÂ¯

ahman

. asâ€”were given to him,

the final one being MahÂ¯

adeva. Thereupon the â€˜blue-redâ€™ boy requested BrahmÂ¯

a

to bestow a domain ( sthÂ¯

ana) or body ( tanu) to each name, which resulted in the following combinations: Rudra obtained the sun, Bhava the waters, Åšarva earth, Â¯IÅ›Â¯

ana wind, PaÅ›upati fire, BhÂ¯Ä±ma Â¯

akÂ¯

aÂ´

sa, Ugra the initiated brahmin, and

MahÂ¯

adeva the moon. In this way the divine, primordial child in BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™s lap

was made to personify Åšivaâ€™s cosmic dimension, his eight embodiments ( as.t.a-mÂ¯

urti), encompassing the entire phenomenal universe.

When we return to the two verses in the Dron

. aparvan, we may observe

that it is probably this primordial, cosmic child that sits in UmÂ¯

aâ€™s lap (MBh

7.173.59); his five tufts of hair ( paËœ

ncaÂ´

sikha) may symbolize his embodiment of

the five elements that build the material world.

This being so, one may rightly ask what, if any, is the function of the appearance of the cosmic child in PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s lap at this junction of Tripuraâ€™s de-

sitra is described (see above,

ahman

. a,

apatiâ€™s seed, is the first issue ( prÂ¯

aÂ´

sitra) of PrajÂ¯

apatiâ€™s

(self-)sacrifice. If we keep this identity in mind the relevance of the statement (Kaus.Br 6.10.7â€“8) that introduces the concluding part of adhyÂ¯

becomes clear: â€˜PrajÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s Svayam

191

struction? And why do the infatuated gods, represented by Åšakra, to whose rescue Åšiva had just come and to whose wish, viz. the destruction of the triple city of the asuras, Åšiva had just complied, why do these gods try immediately to kill their benefactor, from which evil they are only kept by the childâ€™s magic powers (MBh 7.173.60)? Even if we accept, as we are supposed to do, that the gods were struck by blindness (MBh 7.173.61), it is hard to see why the sight of UmÂ¯

a with a child on her lap immediately provoked such aggresion, exactly at the moment that the world is rescued from a demonic threat. And what is she doing there anyway? 21 And how is it possible that UmÂ¯

a herself, mother

of the world, apparently does not recognize the child? BrahmÂ¯

a is the only one

who recognizes Åšiva and bows for him (MBh 7.173.62), whereupon Åšiva undoes his spell (MBh 7.173.63).

Evidently we are concerned with a conflation of at least three mythsâ€”Åšivaâ€™s destruction of Tripura, his appearence as the cosmic child, and the godsâ€™ assault on him and their subsequent immobilisationâ€”which, since they are all concerned with Åšivaâ€™s majestic powers, were somehow, rather awkwardly, combined in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata text, making the latter prone to further involuntary corruption.

PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s svayam

. vara

The relevance, alluded to earlier, of the svayam

. vara myth in SP 13 for the

exegesis of the MBh passage at issue becomes evident when we study this myth in more detail. The events leading to the svayam

. vara in SP 13 are told

in SP 12. In short the story is as follows.

In SP 12.1â€“20 BrahmÂ¯

a prophesies that PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± (UmÂ¯

a) will obtain a husband of her

choice when she stops practising tapas. PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± ceases her tapas and resorts to the

aÂ´

soka tree that has grown at the entrance of her dwelling. Hara (Åšiva) approaches her in the form of an ugly dwarf, who announces that he wishes to marry her.

Thanks to her yogic powers PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± perceives that Åšam

. kara has come to her and

says that he should ask her father. Åšiva, still in disguise, asks Himavat for the hand of his daughter, but Himavat, recognizing Rudra, becomes uneasy and foolishly, due to a curse, declares that he already intended to hold a svayam

. vara for his

daughter.

Åšiva returns to PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±, tells her about her fatherâ€™s intention and is about to take his leave, when PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± assures him not to despair, since she will choose him. If he has any doubt, she will choose him right there. PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± plucks a flowering branch

from the aÂ´

soka tree and laying it on his shoulder says â€˜you have been chosen by meâ€™. 22

192

Hans Bakker

In SP 13.1-27 Himavat, though aware of the engagement of his daughter with Devadeva, proceeds to organize the svayam

. vara, considering that, after all, it would

bring him most honour if ParameÅ›Â¯

ana would be chosen in front of all the gods.

The latter, headed by Indra, assemble in the house of Himavat. PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± enters the

arena in a vimÂ¯

ana and takes a garland of flowers to place at the feet of the man of her choice (SP 13.28). At that very moment, in order to test his bride to be ( devyÂ¯

a jijËœ

nÂ¯

asayÂ¯

a), Åšiva assumes the form of a child in her lap (SP 13.29). Due to her yogic powers she recognizes the god to whom she had pledged her word and is pleased (SP 13.30â€“31).

When the gods, however, see the maiden of the wedding contest with a child in her lap they, understandably enough, are bewildered, fly into passion and try to attack him (SP 13.32). Åšiva repels the assault by immobilizing and mutilating the offenders (SP 13.33â€“38). BrahmÂ¯

a is the only god who sees through Åšivaâ€™s

disguise, and he informs the other gods about their mistake (SP 13.39â€“50). The gods take refuge with Åšiva (SP 13.51). Åšiva is pleased and lifts the spell (SP 13.52).

He assumes his supreme form, seen by the gods only after receiving a divine eye (SP 13.53â€“54), and is elected by PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± as her husband (SP 13.56), after which

the wedding is celebrated. The cosmic order, sealed by Åšivaâ€™s and PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s holy

wedlock, is confirmed.

It is clear that the SP story of PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s svayam

. vara combines the two mytholog-

ical themes at issue, viz. (1) Åšivaâ€™s taking the form of a little child (in PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s

lap), and (2) Åšivaâ€™s immobilisation/mutilation of the gods, though now applied in a situation in which revenge of the incest or exclusion from the sacrifice is no longer the direct cause of his anger. In contrast with the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata

text, however, the encompassing myth of PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s svayam

. vara unites these

two themes into a new, meaningful and logical whole. PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± stands the test,

as one would expect, and does not need to ask who the child is; the ignorant gods, however, go astray. Not recognizing Åšiva, they are embarassed by the childâ€™s presence at the svayam

. vara. They become angry and consequently are immobilized/mutilated. When their delusion is removed by BrahmÂ¯

a, they have

no choice but to recognize Åšivaâ€™s superiority and to accept that he is PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s

choice. In this way the Åšaiva cosmic order proved to be superior to the ancient world represented by the Vedic gods. The latter were crippled and, to bring out the contrastâ€”and this distinguishes the epic and puranic versions from those of the BrÂ¯

ahman.asâ€”this was effected by the supreme lord in the form of a newly born child.

The BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a, Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a and MÂ¯

aheÅ›varakhan

. d

. a tell basically the

same myth as SP 13. In the BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a the svayam

. vara episode forms part

of the â€˜story of UmÂ¯

a and Åšam

. karaâ€™ ( umÂ¯

aÂ´

sam

. karayoh

. pun

. yÂ¯

am

. kathÂ¯

am, BrP

34.55), which the BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a has taken over from the SP in its entirety.

The BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a follows the text of the SP rather closely, showing only minor variantsâ€”often adaptation due to the fact that BrahmÂ¯

a has supplanted

SanatkumÂ¯

ara as the narratorâ€”in addition to occasional omissions and corruptions. From the latter it is clear that the BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a is the borrower, the

SP the â€˜originalâ€™. The borrowed chapters in the BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a, viz. 34.56 to

38.12 (= SP 11.1 to 15.12) fit neatly in between the preceding passage borrowed from the SÂ¯

. d

. a. A comparison with the SP may

help to restore its meaning. It ensues from a collation that the Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a

. a goes back to an

. vara was not wholly unknown. It might actually have been the source whence the diaskeuast derived both themes, namely Åšiva (Rudra) as a child and the injury of the gods, unified by PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s pivot role. 24

These may have been lifted out of their context and incorporated in the eulogy of Rudra to illustrate his greatness.

With the destruction of Tripura they

evidently lack any intrinsic relation.

. vara myth

its variant readings are given in the critical apparatus ad the text of SP. 25 The text of MBh 7.173 actually recurs in MBh 13.145; the major variant readings of the reprise have been given in the apparatus (the sigla are those of the Critical Edition). When we turn our attention again to MBh 173 verse 59 we see in the apparatus that a part of the Southern Recension inserts before this verse a significant hemistich: â€˜Listen to another event, O Dhanam

. jaya, (which happened) at

PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s svayam

. vara.â€™ The insertion of this hemistich may have been prompted by the harsh transition from the Tripura battle scene to Åšivaâ€™s transformation into a child. Since this hemistich is only found in the Telugu and some of the Grantha mss, it may be secondary and not have formed part of the original MBh text, but, all the same, it could represent a reminiscence of the original context to which the myth told in the following verses might have belonged.

Another significant variant is found ad 59c. This reading, although the editors of the Critical Edition have relegated it to the apparatus, is supported by a substantial part of the northern and southern mss as well as by some of the mss at MBh 13.145.30c, and would correspond much better with the story as told in SP. According to this reading Åšiva changes into a little child â€˜to test UmÂ¯

The editors of the MBh may have been tempted into accepting this, probably corrupt version of 59c in the critical text on account of the fact that the MBh text as we have it does not explicitly state that UmÂ¯

a stands the test and rec-

ognizes Åšiva and because Åšiva as the subject of abravÂ¯Ä±t in 59d seems rather odd as we would expect ko â€™ham iti. However, also the reading of 59d is far from certain. That UmÂ¯

aâ€™s knowledge of the childâ€™s true nature was (originally) taken as understood may be deduced not only from the fact that the gods altogether ignore her question, but also from the fact that only they manifest their ignorance in the story that follows (MBh 7.173.61). 28 And neither does BrahmÂ¯

a,

who knows the truth, inform UmÂ¯

a; on the contrary, UmÂ¯

a, together with Åšiva,

is the object of veneration in verse 63, directly after BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™s discovery in

verse 62. The conclusion seems inevitable that v. 59 as a whole is corrupt beyond reliable restoration and a wavy line under the entire verse in the edition would not have been superfluous. The (later) Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a and MÂ¯

aheÅ›vara-

khan

. d

. a have replaced the (probably) original feature of â€˜UmÂ¯

aâ€™s trialâ€™ by the

traditional platitude that it is just Åšivaâ€™s game ( krÂ¯Ä±d

. Â¯

artham, LiP 1.102.28d,

MKh 2.25.100d).

Due to textual corruption MKh 101â€“102 has become difficult to understand, which may have led the pandits of the Ve Ë™nkat.eÅ›vara Press to their note given in the apparatus ad 100cdâ€“101. The tasya in MKh 102b and tasyÂ¯

a in LiP 29d

lack an obvious antecedent (SP reads devyÂ¯

a). The two pÂ¯

adas MKh 101cd make

the impression of an interpolation, the connection of which with the immediate context is difficult to determine. The relevance of the word jaya is obscure and may point to another context, perhaps the exegetical tradition concerning the famous verse that opens the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata and, for instance, the MÂ¯

aheÅ›vara-

khan

. d

. a. 29

In SP 34â€“38 (BrP 36.33â€“36ab), LiP 31â€“39 and MKh 104â€“110 (missing in MBh) the theme of the mutilation of the gods is worked out, adding to the immobilized Indra other victims such as Bhaga (not in LiP) and PÂ¯

us.an (not

in BrP), known as such already from the BrÂ¯

ahman.a literature. A very striking

elaboration is presented in SP 36, which is without parallel in the MÂ¯

aheÅ›vara-

khan

. d

. a and significantly different in Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a, whereas BrP (36.36cd) has

Then in MBh 62, SP 39â€“40 (BrP 36.36cdâ€“39ab), LiP 40â€“41 and MKh 111â€“

112ab BrahmÂ¯

a sees what Åšivaâ€™s game is and starts praising him. Of the five

Â´

slokas that follow in SP 41â€“45 (BrP 36.39cdâ€“44ab) and LiP 42cdâ€“47, in which BrahmÂ¯

a reveals Åšivaâ€™s true nature and coaxes him into undoing his spell, the MKh has retained only one (112cdâ€“113ab), while the Northern Recension of the MBh includes three different, though appropriate verses after 62, relegated to the apparatus by the editors. The effect of this is that according to the text of the Critical Edition the gods never are informed about the true nature of the child, which again makes it unlikely that, in spite of that, they suddenly are able to satisfy ( prasÂ¯

adayÂ¯

amÂ¯

asur) UmÂ¯

a and Rudra in v. 63.

The next passage, SP 46â€“47 (BrP 36.44cdâ€“45) and LiP 48â€“49, has also been transmitted incompletely in the MKh (113cdâ€“114). The equivalent of SP 46

and LiP 48, in which BrahmÂ¯

a turns to the gods, has been omitted, as a re-

sult of which the text has become unintelligible as it is no longer clear who are addressed. The corruption may have had its starting point, however, in the alternative sandhi mÂ¯

ud

. hÂ¯

a stha for mÂ¯

ud

. hÂ¯

. stha (SP 13.47a), which we find

sipivis.t.akr.te vis.n.or. About the term Å›ipivis.t.a we remarked in the annotation ad loc. (SP II B, 45):

The surprising fate of Vis.n.u is actually modelled on a Vedic reference, as in the case of Bhaga and PÂ¯

â€˜baldâ€™.

10 / PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s Svayam

. vara

197

BrP and MKh. The vocative devatÂ¯

ah

. in SP was accordingly interpreted as

a nominative and the nominative plural masculine of the subject, sarve (â€˜you allâ€™), was taken as attributive to devatÂ¯

ah

. and adjusted to a nominative plural

feminine, sarvÂ¯

as (â€˜all the deitiesâ€™) in BrP, LiP and MKh.

In short, the transcriptive and intrinsic probability of the corruptions point to successive stages, of which the MKh represents the last. Thanks to the SP

we are now in the position to understand what the BrP, LiP and MKh were supposed to convey.

SP 48â€“49 show the acquaintance of BrahmÂ¯

a (and the authors of the ancient

SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a) with the symbolic meaning of the child as the embodiment of Åšivaâ€™s cosmic dimension, which meaning is now revealed to the Vedic gods. In addition to epithets such as kapardimat, Â¯

atman, aja etc., we encounter seven

of the eight names of the as.t.amÂ¯urti; only Bhava appears to be missing or may be considered to be replaced by another name such as Åšam

. kara or De-

vadeva. This revelation of the childâ€™s eightfold nature has become lost in the course of transmission as the omission of these two verses in BrP, LiP and MKh attests. The absence of the childâ€™s qualification as paËœ

ncaÂ´

sikha in LiP 28d

and MKh 100d should probably be viewed in the same light. At the instance of BrahmÂ¯

a the still petrified gods turn their minds towards Åšarva ( pran

. emur

manasÂ¯

a Â´

sarvam

. , 34 whereas a minor textual inconsequence in the MKh permits them to bow ( pran

. atÂ¯

ah

. ) at that as well (MKh 115ab). The MÂ¯

aheÅ›varakhan

. d

. a

then inserts a stotra, in which the gods apologize for their behaviour (MKh 115cdâ€“121ab), which does not occur in the other versions and therefore may be considered an accretion.

In MBh 63, SP 52 (BrP 36.48), LiP 53 and MKh 121cdâ€“122ab the texts converge again: the satisfied Åšiva restores the gods to their normal condition.

With this ends the episode in the MBh, which continues with its eulogy of Rudra.

The SP, BrP, LiP and MKh continue their story of UmÂ¯

aâ€™s svayam

. vara. The

MKh inserted 5 Â´

slokas (122cdâ€“127ab) in which the daityas in their turn express their ignorance. By pronouncing the bÂ¯Ä±ja

Â´

hum

. Siva drives them back to their

own city where they forget about the svayam

. vara, a fate that, unfortunately,

did not remain restricted to that city and its inhabitants.

In the following verses the great god drops his disguise and manifests himself in his supreme body ( vapus), which can only be seen by the gods after having received a supreme eye. It is noteworthy that according to the Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a and MÂ¯

aheÅ›varakhan

. d

. a versions also the Goddess (BhavÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä±) needs such

an eye, 35 whereas in SP 13.54 (BrP 36.50cdâ€“51ab)â€”consistent with SP 13.30

(BrP 36.29), which verse has no parallel in LiP and MKhâ€”she evidently possesses this capacity (by virtue of her yogic powers). Yet, the superiority of the Goddess over the gods is acknowledged in the Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a and MÂ¯

aheÅ›vara-

34 SP 51, BrP 36.47, LiP 52.

35 LiP 1.102.57b, MKh 2.25.130d.

198

Hans Bakker

khan

. d

. a versions as well, when in these two texts â€˜BrahmÂ¯

a and so forthâ€™ are

said to bow before Åšiva as well as before the Goddess. 36

In SP 56 (BrP 36.52cdâ€“53ab), LiP 61cdâ€“62ab and MKh 134cdâ€“135ab DevÂ¯Ä± finally chooses Åšiva as her husband by placing the wreath at his feet. In the next verse(s) the gods express approval by exclaiming â€˜hail, hail!â€™ The words saha devyÂ¯

a in LiP 63a (MKh 136a) could be construed with sarve devÂ¯

ah

. in 63c

(MKh 136c), which would imply that the Goddess is herself honouring instead of being honoured as is the case in SP 57. Apart from the fact that the Sanskrit construction is rather cumbersome, this does not fit the situation, all the less so, since taking saha devyÂ¯

a with the subject of namaÂ´

scakruh

. would normally

entail that the Goddess is also part of the subject of sam

. procya in LiP 62c and

MKh 135c, which, however, is undesirable as it is totally inappropriate. If, on the other hand, we take saha devyÂ¯

a with the object clause LiP 62d, MKh

135d, this would also result in an awkward construction ( tayÂ¯

a along with saha

devyÂ¯

a). 37

In a nutshell, the reformulation and elaboration of the final verses in LiP

and MÂ¯

aheÅ›varakhan

. d

. a is rather unfortunate and illustrates once more the value of the critically edited SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a (SP) for the understanding of these two

vulgate PurÂ¯

an.a texts.

Conclusion

Summarizing, we may say that the corruptions and elaborations in the second part of the text which is without counterpart in the MBh confirm the tentative conclusion reached above, viz. that the MÂ¯

aheÅ›varakhan

. d

. a represents a later

version of the myth as told in LiP, whereas the wording of the latter deviates again from the text as preserved in the ancient SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, without

improving upon it, however, in any respect. On the contrary, the collation clearly shows that the corresponding text portions of the Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a and

MÂ¯

aheÅ›varakhan

. d

. a successively derived from an archetype that represented a corrupted version of SP. The BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a version of the myth is an inde-

pendent copy of the SP text, which does not seem to have a direct connection with the archetype from which the Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a and MÂ¯

aheÅ›varakhan

. d

. a derived.

Corruptions and omissions show the dependency of the BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a on SP

36 LiP 1.102.58cd, MKh 2.25.134ab; the reading of BrP 36.52a, MSNep and MKh 134a, menire, looks like a corruption (metathesis) of the text as found in SP and LiP, whereas the reading of LiP 58d seems a corruption of the reading as found in MKh 134b, possibly caused by LiPâ€™s transposition of this hemistich. Our placing of this hemistich after 61ab, however, does not solve the problem (note that MSNep reads digÂ¯Ä±Â´

svarÂ¯

ah

. to avoid the

awkwardness). LiP 61c has preserved the no doubt correct reading hr

. s.t.Â¯

a of SP 56a,

while MKh reads dr

. s.t.vÂ¯

a (134c), echoing the mistaken conception underlying LiP and MKh, viz. that the Goddess has only just now, after receipt of a supreme eye, seen her future spouse.

37 The commentary of Gan

. eÅ›a NÂ¯

atu is equally ambiguous on this point, although it seems most natural to me that he construes saha devyÂ¯

a with the subject. The dan

. d

. a after

Â´

sirobhih

. is misplaced anyway.

10 / PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s Svayam

. vara

199

and not vice versa. The textual distortions that the BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a has in

common with the Li Ë™ngapurÂ¯

an

. a and MÂ¯

aheÅ›varakhan

. d

. a, notably in the passages

SP 35â€“38 and SP 48â€“49, seem to point to a slightly altered version of the S

recension of SP that is not, or only partly represented in our ms material.

The wording of the SP, in its turn, does not show direct dependency on the MBh, but nevertheless elucidates it considerably, since it preserved the context from which the verses in the MBh may have been borrowed. We thus have stumbled upon a layer in the process of composition of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata that

has been transmitted incompletelyâ€”and consequently incomprehensiblyâ€”in the ms tradition of the epic. One explanation of this phenomenon could be that in the course of this ms transmission, at an early stage, for one reason or another, a significant text passage had been lost and that only the Telugu and Grantha traditions preserved a vestige thereof. However, the hemistich devyÂ¯

ah

. svayam

. vare vr.ttam

. Â´

sr.n.us.vÂ¯anyad dhanam

. jaya ( ad MBh 7.173.58) makes

the impression of being secondary, i.e. of being an explanatory interpolation.

A copyist of the Telugu and Grantha lines of transmission may have known the myth through the PurÂ¯

an.a tradition.

On the other hand, the textual incongruity at issue could itself have been caused by an early infelicitous interpolation in the text of the Dron

. aparvan.

The interpolator may have known the myth of PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s svayam

. vara and may

have carelessly used elements of it to embellish the eulogy of Åšiva, an example of what I elsewhere have called â€˜composition-in-transmissionâ€™ (above, p. 177). If this were the case, it probably was a very early interpolation, not only because the passage is found in all major mss, but also in the reprise in book 13.

A third possibility is that a diaskeuast who worked on the Dron

. aparvan

composed his text by drawing upon disparate texts and that one of these texts contained the myth of PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s svayam

. vara. In this connection the question

arises how we should conceive of the nature of this text, a question that may also be formulated as follows: how did the redactor of this part of the Dron

. aparvan

proceed? Did he have written texts at his disposal or did he collect his material from memory, that is, was he acquainted with a corpus of orally transmitted mythology out of which corpus he selected those parts that he could use? In view of the Vedic roots of two of the themes of the svayam

. vara myth, it seems

likely to me that the myth of PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±â€™s svayam

. vara circulated before it found

its place in the SP, or in its garbled form in the MBh for that matter. Whether this circulation had an oral or written basis, or was actually an interplay of the two, is a question that has a direct bearing on our understanding of the process of composition of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata itself, a question that falls beyond

the scope of the present investigation. 38

38 A tentative answer to this question, not regarding the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata, but the Skanda-

purÂ¯

an

. a itself is formulated in the last essay of this volume (below, pp. 601 ff.).

Moks.adharma 187 and 239â€“241 Reconsideredâˆ—

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

Preamble

In his Untersuchungen zum Moks.adharma (Die sÂ¯am

. khyistischen Texte) and

in the chapter on SÂ¯

am

. khya of his Geschichte der indischen Philosophie

Erich Frauwallner has shown chapters MBh 12.187 and MBh 12.239â€“241 of the Moks.adharma in the ÅšÂ¯

antiparvan of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata to be of crucial

importance for understanding the development of the SÂ¯

am

. khya-system. 1 The

great Viennese scholar dealt with yet another chapter (MBhB 12.286), which however has been omitted in the critical edition, but is preserved in the critical apparatus to MBh 12.187. Conceived as different versions of one and the same

â€˜Grundtextâ€™, they must, Frauwallner argued, have been held to be of great significance at the time and probably led an independent existence before they were included in the collection of doctrines of the Moks.adharma. Frauwallner attempted a reconstruction of this â€˜Grundtextâ€™ by sorting out words and passages that were judged by him not to have belonged to this text originally.

He succeeded in giving a clear description of a distinctive philosophy, which he denominated â€˜die epische Urform des SÂ¯

am

. khyaâ€™. 2 An important conclusion

of his reconstruction is that the so called â€˜evolution theoryâ€™ had not yet been developed; according to Frauwallner the evolution theory was adopted by the SÂ¯

am

. khya later from circles that taught an evolution out of Brahman. 3

Van Buitenen (1956) also stressed the importance of these texts, but contrary to Frauwallnerâ€™s conclusions, he maintained that an evolution theory can be traced in them. Out of both texts he reconstructed a small tract, which

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Asiatische Studien/ Ã‰tudes Asiatiques LII.3 (1999), 459â€“472. [= Proceedings of the â€˜Conference SÂ¯

am

. khya and Yogaâ€™, UniversitÃ©

de Lausanne, November 6â€“8 1998.]

1 Frauwallner 1925b; 1953. Frauwallner uses a different numbering, based on the Bombay edition of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata: MBhB 12.194 (= MBh 12.187) and MBhB 12.247â€“249 (=

MBh 12.239â€“241). MBh 12.239â€“241 is also transmitted as part of the BrahmapurÂ¯

an

. a:

BrP 237.43â€“238.14.

2 Frauwallner 1953, 288â€“299.

3 Two texts according to Frauwallner have been a major influence upon the development of the evolution theory: MBh 12.224 and the first book of the Manusmr.ti (Frauwallner 1925a). Cf. Hacker 1961b and RÃ¼ping 1977.

223

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

224

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

somehow had come to be included in this text-group. He recovered this tract by isolating and arranging those verses in which the term bhÂ¯

ava has apparently

an other meaning than it has in the rest of the texts. 4 He emphasized the evolution process taught in this tract, which, as he put it, has a â€˜horizontal patternâ€™ in contrast to a â€˜vertical patternâ€™: â€˜Not buddhi into manas, manas into senses etc., but buddhi into manas, buddhi into sensesâ€™. 5 Bakker (1982) accepted van Buitenenâ€™s reconstruction as a â€˜working-hypothesisâ€™, but criticized the interpretations of some passages; moreover he questioned van Buitenenâ€™s claim to have discovered an authentic text. He drew attention to an agreement of the reconstructed tract with the teachings of Kaus.Â¯Ä±taki Upanis.ad 3.6

Three themes

From all these different interpretations we may infer that the chapters under discussion contain a diversity of ideas, which are not necessarily consistent with each other. In this paper we want to look at three themes central to both texts that are relevant to the question put forward by van Buitenen, viz. whether or not we encounter an evolution theory in these chapters. It will be shown that this question is related to a difference between both texts with respect to their conception of buddhi. The three themes are the following: 7

1

A teaching about the five elements and their respective differentiation into sense-organ, sense-faculty and sense-impression. 8

4 Van Buitenen 1956, 153:

When we read through the two versions we are struck by the fact that the term bhÂ¯

ava

occurs in two altogether different situations: first in connection with such â€˜sensations, qualities and conditionsâ€™ as sukha/prÂ¯Ä±ti, duh

. kha/Â´

soka, moha, prahars.a etc., atus.t.i etc., aviveka etc.; secondly in connection with a process by which the buddhi modifies itself into manas as its bhÂ¯

ava.

5 Van Buitenen 1957a, 22.

6 Bakker 1982b, 144:

[. . . ] The most striking agreement of the epic with the Upanis.ad appears from the fact that the act of consciousness itself, when it has actualized the senses, evolves the objects (epic: artha /Kaus.U.: bhÂ¯

utamÂ¯

atra) of the latter. Or rather, at the very

moment buddhi (or prajËœ

nÂ¯

a) actualizes the senses it evolves (epic: vikurute /Kaus.U.: abhivisr

. jate) the object that is apprehended.

7 In addition to these three, there may be distinguished three more themes (in both texts): an introductory question concerning the self ( adhyÂ¯

atman) which forms the beginning of

both texts (MBh 12.187.1â€“3; 239.1â€“2), a teaching about the three bhÂ¯

avÂ¯

as (â€˜states of

mindâ€™) sattva, rajas and tamas (MBh 12.187.14, 21â€“35; 239.16, 20â€“25; 240.6cdâ€“8, 10â€“

11) and a soteriology (MBh 12.187.44â€“47, 51â€“60; 240.13â€“15; 241.5â€“14). Many of these themes, or parts of them, have parallels in other chapters of the Moks.adharma; so, for example, part of the teaching about the three bhÂ¯

avÂ¯

as is found also in MBh 12.212.25â€“31.

Study of these parallels may throw light on the composition and transmission of the Moks.adharma, as, mutatis mutandis, the NÂ¯arÂ¯ayan.Â¯Ä±ya-Studien by Peter Schreiner and others (1997) has demonstrated.

8 MBh 12.187.4â€“10; 239.3â€“12.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

11 / Moks.adharma 187 and 239â€“241 Reconsidered 225

2 A teaching about the intellect ( buddhi) and its relation to the â€˜knower of the fieldâ€™ ( ks.etrajËœna), the mind ( manas) and the senses ( indriyÂ¯an.i).9

3 A teaching about the relationship between the sattva and the ks.etrajËœna.10

The five elements

The first theme forms a coherent whole, which can be distinguished quite easily from the rest of the texts. The five elements are regarded as the (material) cause of all sentient beings. They evolve into three modifications ( gun

. a): a sense-

organ, a sense-faculty and a sense-impression. So, for instance, the element

Â¯

akÂ¯

aÂ´

sa evolves into the ears, hearing and sound. 11 The characteristic feature of this treatment of the elements is the epistemological point of view, which entails that the essential qualities of the elements are characterized by their impression on the senses. 12

In addition to the five elements as the material cause, this section speaks of the bhÂ¯

utakr.t (â€˜creator of beingsâ€™) as a kind of efficient cause (Appendix: A).13

The bhÂ¯

utakr.t appears to cause the differentiation of the elements into the triple modification of sense-organ, sense-faculty and sense-impression (MBh 187.7; MBh 239.6â€“7). The conclusion seems justified that in this section of both texts a consistent doctrine is presented, which considers the elements to be the material out of which sentient beings ( bhÂ¯

uta) are made, a process set in motion

by a bhÂ¯

utakr.t. This section forms a teaching of its own; this is evident also from the fact that none of the words playing a key role in the rest of the texts, such as ks.etrajËœna, buddhi, manas, bhÂ¯ava and sattva, are used here.

The intellectual apparatus

The transition to the next theme can be illustrated by MBh 187.10cdâ€“11ab (Appendix: B). Whereas 10cd enumerates the five elements with the manas as sixth, the following verse 11ab enumerates the five senses and the manas; the buddhi and the ks.etrajËœna being respectively the seventh and the eighth (11cd). 14 These verses indicate a transition in both texts: nothing is said about the elements any more, the senses are given and the teaching about 9 MBh 12.187.11â€“20; 239.13â€“15, 17â€“19; 240.1â€“6ab, 9â€“10ab, 12.

10 MBh 12.187.37â€“43, 48â€“50; 240.19â€“22; 241.1â€“4.

11 MBh 12.187.8ab: Â´

sabdah

. Â´

srotram

. tathÂ¯

a khÂ¯

ani trayam Â¯

akÂ¯

aÂ´

sayonijam |

12 This epistemological perspective remains in classical SÂ¯

am

. khya, where the five elements

are considered to originate from the so called â€˜subtle elementsâ€™ ( tanmÂ¯

atra).

These

tanmÂ¯

atrÂ¯

as, in fact, are the sense-impressions: Â´

sabda, sparÂ´

sa, rÂ¯

upa, rasa and gandha.

13 The Appendix contains the text of some passages of the critical edition. It is meant to facilitate comparison: the left column contains a passage of MBh 12.187, the right column contains the parallel of MBh 12.239â€“241 and vice versa. A blank means there is no parallel for a passage.

14 That we are here concerned with a break is also evident from the parallel passage which omits 187.11ab, and instead of mahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

utÂ¯

ani paËœ

ncaiva (MBh 187.10c) reads indriyÂ¯

an

. i

nare paËœ

nca (MBh 239.14a).

226

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

their origin out of the elements seems to be forgotten. Whereas up to this point we had a description of material nature, after it both texts seem to be dealing with ideal nature only.

Although the following teaching about the

buddhi does not form such a clear section as the foregoing teaching about the elements, the verses which we consider to belong to this teaching all have one thing in common: they deal with a psychic or ideal principle distinct from the (material) elements.

The teaching starts with an enumeration of eight principles: the five senses, the manas, the buddhi and the ks.etrajËœna.

Their respective functions are

given:

The eye is for seeing, the mind causes reflection, the intellect serves determination, the knower of the field is called the onlooker. 15

While both texts agree on these functions they disagree about the relationship between the buddhi and the ks.etrajËœna. This disagreement can be deduced from a small, but important variation in the parallel passages 187.20 and 240.6

(Appendix: C). According to both passages the â€˜invisible oneâ€™ governs the senses, but whereas 187.20 uses the masculine adr.Å›yah. , 240.6 uses the feminine adr.Å›yÂ¯a.16 Therefore in 187.20 the term â€˜invisible oneâ€™ refers to the ks.etrajËœna, whereas in 240.6 it refers to the buddhi. In the parallel passages 187.13 and 239.18 (Appendix: D) there is a similar variation. Both verses deal with the question: who is the one that sees everything that is above the soles of the feet and inhabits all this? 187.13 seems to teach that it is the ks.etrajËœna, as in the preceding verse the ks.etrajËœna is called the onlooker. 239.18 however explicitly states it is the buddhir uttamÂ¯

a (â€˜supreme intellectâ€™). These variations indicate a difference with respect to the relationship between the buddhi and the ks.etrajËœna.

Whereas according to 187 the buddhi and the ks.etrajËœna are utterly distinct, in that the one is the active knowledge-principle responsible for the activity of the senses and the other an absolute, non-active onlooker or subject, in some parts of 239â€“241 the buddhi and the ks.etrajËœna seem to be two sides of one and the same principle.

The difference between the two texts can be illustrated by comparing those verses that explain the relation of the buddhi to the senses (appendix: E). In 187.18â€“19 the senses are characterized as instruments which the buddhi employs for apperception:

The eye is what it sees with, what it hears with is called the ear, the nose they say is what it smells with, with the tongue it experiences flavour and with the skin it feels touches.

In the parallel passage of 240.4â€“5, however, it is not the instrumental case ( yena paÂ´

syati) that is used, but the active present participle together with the finite verb bhavati:

15 MBh 12.239.15: caks

. ur Â¯

alocanÂ¯

ayaiva sam

. Â´

sayam

. kurute manah

. | buddhir adhyavasÂ¯

anÂ¯

aya

sÂ¯

aks.Â¯Ä± ks.etrajËœ

na ucyate k

.Â´

syah

. . No manuscript of 187.20 reads adr

.Â´

syÂ¯

a.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

11 / Moks.adharma 187 and 239â€“241 Reconsidered 227

While hearing it becomes hearing, while touching it is called touch, while seeing it becomes sight, while tasting it becomes taste, while smelling it becomes smell.

The buddhi does not employ the senses as instruments, but it is or becomes itself the senses. The word indriyÂ¯

an

. i used in both text passages (187.20; 240.6) does not seem to have exactly the same meaning: in 240 it denotes the sense-faculties, whereas in 187 its connotation seems to encompass the sense-organs as well. 17 In 240 a sense is not so much an instrument, as a modification of the buddhi, viz. a state of mind characterized by sense-perception. In this way it is said that the buddhi evolves the complex of the senses, just as a tortoise sticks out its limbs (239.17).

However, despite this occasional ambiguity, the verses in this section do not deal with material nature, but with ideal nature. The buddhi is therefore not looked upon as a material entity as it is in classical SÂ¯

am

. khya. In this

connection some remarks have to be made on Frauwallnerâ€™s observationâ€”in the introduction to his translation of the reconstructed â€˜Grundtextâ€™, published in his Nachgelassene Werke II â€”to the effect that the buddhi in this text-group is ranked among material nature.

Besondere Bedeutung kommt in ihm [viz. the â€˜Grundtextâ€™] der Psychologie zu.

Weltseele und Materie sind nÃ¤mlich nach ihm scharf getrennt. Dabei werden nicht nur die Sinnesorgane, sondern auch die psychischen Organe, Denken ( manah

. ) und

Erkennen ( buddhih

. ) der Materie zugerechnet. 18

In our opinion this is certainly not true for some passages in adhyÂ¯

aya 240.

This becomes evident when we consider MBh 240.3 (Appendix: F). After the progressive enumeration of the indriyÂ¯

an

. i, the arthÂ¯

as, the manas, the buddhi

and the Â¯

atman, which we also encounter with some variations in the Kat.ha Upanis.ad,19 it is said that:

The intellect is the self of man; the intellect indeed is the essence of the self; when it produces a bhÂ¯

ava it is / becomes mind. 20

17 In classical SÂ¯

am

. khya the indriyÂ¯

an

. i as faculties are explicitly distinguished from the organs, which are called their â€˜seatsâ€™ ( adhis.t.hÂ¯anÂ¯ani)â€”e.g. in the YuktidÂ¯Ä±pikÂ¯a (YD ad SK

26cd, p. 197):

ucyate: adhis.t.hÂ¯anÂ¯ad indriyapr.thaktvam

. Â´

saktiviÂ´

ses.opalambhÂ¯at | yathÂ¯a Å›arÂ¯Ä±rÂ¯asambha-

vino vis.ayavyavasÂ¯ayalaks.an.asya Å›aktiviÅ›es.asyopalambhÂ¯ad arthÂ¯antaram

. buddhir anu-

mÂ¯Ä±yata evam adhis.t.hÂ¯anÂ¯asambhavino vis.ayagrahan.alaks.an.asya Å›aktiviÅ›es.asyopalambhÂ¯

ad arthÂ¯

antaram indriyam iti |

The use of the term in these texts of the Moks.adharma, however, is ambiguous. Thus in MBh 12.239.11cd the â€˜complex of the sensesâ€™ ( indriyagrÂ¯

ama) is described as â€˜derived

from the five elementsâ€™ ( paËœ

ncabhautika), thereby implying its material nature, whereas MBh 187.20 seems to conflate the adhis.t.hÂ¯anÂ¯ani and the indriyÂ¯an.i.

18 Frauwallner 1992, 78.

19 Kat.ha Upanis.ad III.10â€“11; VI.7â€“8a.

20 MBh 12.240.3:

buddhir Â¯

atmÂ¯

a manus.yasya buddhir evÂ¯atmano â€™tmikÂ¯a | yadÂ¯a vikurute bhÂ¯

avam

. tadÂ¯

a bhavati sÂ¯

a manah

. k

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

228

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

The buddhi is regarded as the essence of the self in this verse. In the preceding verse however the self is stated to be higher than the buddhi. Consequently the buddhi seems to exist in two ways: 1) as an absolute, non-intentional self, corresponding to the ks.etrajËœna; 2) as an empirical, intentional activity, when it evolves through the manas into the senses. In the latter case the buddhi exists as a bhÂ¯

ava, i.e. in a â€˜state of modificationâ€™. It is obvious that this doctrine differs materially from the one found in MBh 187, where the buddhi is treated as an hypostasis of empirical intellect, fundamentally distinct from the transcendental subject, ks.etrajËœna, as well as separated from the senses.21

Sattva and ks.etrajËœna

The difference between the two texts can be illustrated further by comparing the passages that deal with the relationship between sattva and ks.etrajËœna (Appendix: G). If we understand sattva here, not as referring to a material principle comparable to the prakr.ti, but as referring to the buddhi,22 a remarkable agreement with the foregoing appears. According to both texts the sattva creates ( sr.jate) the gun.Â¯as, whereas the ks.etrajËœna is only their observer. The gun.Â¯as are to be interpreted here as the modifications of the buddhi, just as in the teaching about the elements the word gun

. a denotes the modification of the elements.

The difference between the two texts lies in the relationship of ks.etrajËœna and sattva to the self ( Â¯

atman). For, whereas 187.40cd states that the self is the one who observes the gun

. Â¯

as (i.e. is the ks.etrajËœna) but wrongly thinks himself to be their creator, according to the parallel passage 240.19ab the self in reality ( yathÂ¯

atatham) is both, the observer ( paridras.t.r. ) and the creator ( sras.t.r. ) of the 21 This difference may also explain the parallel verses 187.23 and 240.8. According to 187.23

the essence of the buddhi consists of the three bhÂ¯

avÂ¯

as (viz. sattva, rajas and tamas) and it never transcends them; according to 240.8 however it does transcend the three bhÂ¯

avÂ¯

as,

although its essence is said to consist in them ( bhÂ¯

avÂ¯

atmikÂ¯

a). In both chapters the passage

at issue has variant readingsâ€”some manuscripts of 187.23 read ativartate instead of nÂ¯

ativartate, while some manuscripts of 240.8 read nÂ¯

ativartate instead of ativartateâ€”yet

this variance may be significant and point to an original difference of doctrine rather than being due to mere textual corruption. In 187.23 the buddhi does not transcend the three bhÂ¯

avÂ¯

as, because only the â€˜invisible oneâ€™, viz. the ks.etrajËœ

na, transcends them.

In 240.8 the buddhi does transcend them, since it is equated to the absolute self and as such is the transcendental â€˜invisible oneâ€™.

22 Frauwallner (1992) translates sattva in this part of the texts with â€˜die GÃ¼teâ€™; Edgerton (1965) translates it with â€˜essential (material) realityâ€™. Van Buitenen (1957b, 95) distinguishes five meanings of the word sattva in the context of proto-SÂ¯

am

. khya: â€˜1. sattva as

the material counterpart of the ks.etrajËœ

na; 2. as the buddhi; 3. as a bhÂ¯

ava of the buddhi;

  1. as a state of well-being amounting to release; 5. as the first of the three gun

. Â¯

asâ€™.

Although van Buitenen takes sattva here in the first meaning, he observes that there is no real difference between the first and the second meaning: â€˜In these early forms of SÂ¯

am

. khya creation does not necessarily start from a higher principle than the buddhi, e.g., avyakta, pradhÂ¯

ana or prakr

. ti, but from the buddhi itself; nor has the aham

. kÂ¯

ara

yet taken over the evolutionary functions of the buddhi. As the buddhisattva is indeed creation and thus the â€˜materialâ€™ counterpart of the unaffected ks.etrajËœ

naâ€™ (1957b, 96â€“97).

Cf. also Johnston 1937, 50â€“51.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

11 / Moks.adharma 187 and 239â€“241 Reconsidered 229

gun

. Â¯

as. The doctrine underlying MBh 240 therefore seems to be that ks.etrajËœna and sattva are two aspects of one and the same principle, viz. the buddhi, which is defined as the Self of man (MBh 240.3ab). If our analysis of these chapters is correct, it may explain a statement in the AnugÂ¯Ä±tÂ¯

a.

Some wise men who are well established in knowledge declare the identity of the ks.etrajËœ

na and the sattva, this is not correct. 23

This verse may be taken to refer to those passages of 239â€“241 that teach the unity of the ks.etrajËœna and the sattva within the self. This unity appears as two aspects (dialectical moments) of the buddhi: on the one hand as the transcendental subject, styled â€˜ ks.etrajËœnaâ€™, on the other hand as the phenomenality (intentionality) of consciousness, styled â€˜ sattvaâ€™ (â€˜beingâ€™), that is intellect ( buddhi) as activity, which comprises manas, the senses and their objects.

The â€˜evolution theoryâ€™

We now return to the â€˜evolution theoryâ€™ that van Buitenen found in his reconstructed tract. The verses van Buitenen used for his tract are those that deal with the modification of the buddhi. However, he mixes passages from 187 and 239â€“241, thereby blurring the difference between them. Frauwallner also conflates the texts, selecting material from all three dialogues and blending them into one â€˜Grundtextâ€™. The unacceptable consequences of this conflation can be seen when we look at the important difference between the buddhi using the sense-organs in 187 and the buddhi becoming the sense-faculties in 240, which difference is obliterated in the verses 18â€“19 of his â€˜Grundtextâ€™.

Wodurch es sieht, das ist das Auge. HÃ¶rend wird es GehÃ¶r genannt. Riechend wird es zum Geruch. Schmeckend ist es der Geschmack. Mit der Haut berÃ¼hrt es die BerÃ¼hrung. Vielfach wandelt sich das Erkennen. Wenn es etwas begehrt, dann wird es zum Denken. 24

However, Frauwallner was right in his observation that the evolution theory of the SÂ¯

am

. khya is not attested in this text-group. Frauwallner has given three features of the evolution theory:

Die Vorstellung der Urmaterie ( prakr.ti), die Lehre von den drei Eigenschaften ( gun

. Â¯

as) der Urmaterie und die Lehre von den 25 Wesenheiten. 25

23 MBh 14.48.9: Â¯

ahur eke ca vidvÂ¯

am

. so ye jËœ

nÂ¯

ane supratis.t.hitÂ¯ah. | ks.etrajËœ

nasattvayor aikyam

ity etan nopapadyate k

24 Frauwallner 1992, 82â€“83. Frauwallnerâ€™s eclectic translation finds some support in MBhB

12.286.19â€“20, since this text also seems to be a mixture of both theories (cf. Frauwallner 1992, 82, n. 34â€“36):

yena paÂ´

syati tac caks.uh. Å›r.n.vatÂ¯Ä± Å›rotram ucyate |

jighratÂ¯Ä± bhavati ghrÂ¯

. am

. rasatÂ¯Ä± rasanÂ¯

a rasÂ¯

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

230

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

We find none of them in these texts. What van Buitenen has styled a â€˜horizontal evolution theoryâ€™ is different from what Frauwallner called an â€˜evolution theoryâ€™.

We would prefer to call the former a â€˜teaching about the modification of the buddhiâ€™. This teaching does not have a cosmological but a psychological status: it explains how the buddhi evolves the manas as its bhÂ¯

ava and subsequently dif-

ferentiates into the sense-faculties. The ontological implications of this teaching conflict with the teaching about the elements in the first part of both texts, where it is said that not only the sense-organs and the sense-impressions, but also the sense-faculties have their origin in the elements. These texts therefore do not contain a consistent philosophy, but display the same diversity as so much of the Moks.adharma.

The Moks.adharma: a plurality of views

The above analysis raises a number of questions, whichâ€”though, admittedly, they cannot all be answeredâ€”need to be addressed, if any progress into the early history of the SÂ¯

am

. khya philosophical tradition is to be made. These

questions are closely connected with the source material from which we have to reconstruct that history; in this particular case: how do we conceive of the coming into being of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata text corpus, especially its largest book,

the ÅšÂ¯

antiparvan. Frauwallnerâ€™s hypothesis of one â€˜Grundtextâ€™ that had been transmitted independently for a long time, had consequently developed into three different recensions, before the latter were included in the text of the Moks.adharma by one or more redactors, only to be further mutilated in the course of transmission, that hypothesis proves untenable. As we have shown there are clearly different views underlying the dialogues of Yudhis.t.hira and BhÂ¯Ä±s.ma ( adhyÂ¯aya 187) on the one hand, and that of Åšuka and VyÂ¯asa ( adhyÂ¯ayas 239â€“241) on the other. An irreconcilable discrepancy had also been van Buitenenâ€™s starting point, but to explain it this scholar applied basically the same method as Frauwallner, though in more textual detail, when he constructed a new, smaller text out of both dialogues: â€˜simply a text legitimately restored on the basis of two incomplete and corrupt versionsâ€™. 26

However, instead of postulating or â€˜restoringâ€™ a â€˜Grundtextâ€™, we may make another assumption, namely that the redactor(s) of the Moks.adharma was acquainted with various guru-traditions (see below, p. 511), which he aimed to represent in different dialogues. These philosophical lineages may have been closely related, enough to employ the same jargon, including technical terms, expressions, metaphors and even verses; but within them different techniques to obtain inner tranquillity ( yoga) may have developed, and accordingly different views to account for these experiences.

26 Van Buitenen 1956, 156.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

11 / Moks.adharma 187 and 239â€“241 Reconsidered 231

A scenario opposite to the one proposed by Frauwallner may be envisaged: in the course of composition, redaction, transmission, further revision, and fix-ation of the Moks.adharma a tendency may have been at work to straighten out contradicting views. If this were the case, the starting point may not have been one â€˜Grundtextâ€™ that degenerated into various distorted representations, but rather a plurality of theories and views that found textual expression and was amalgamated in a parvan or sub- parvan, which became gradually more homogeneous in a process of composition-in-transmission (cf. above, p. 177).

This process may have been concomitant with the rise of the classical school of SÂ¯

am

. khya. In other words, rather than for an underlying unity we should search for diversity behind the apparent homogeneity. Paradoxically, greater philosophical homogeneity may have been accomplished at the cost of more textual inconsistencies. This genetic model would imply that, though the Moks.adharma as we have it offers already a bewildering diversity of often contradicting views, the historical reality at the time of its first composition was still more complexâ€”each ashram, so to speak, having its own competing version of proto-SÂ¯

am

. khya philosophy and being keen on having it canonized in the Smr.ti.

An original plurality may not only account for the essential differences between both dialogues, but also for unsolved philosophical problems within each.

How does the theory of the five mahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

utas and their differentiation within sen-

sitive beings concord with the psychological or ideal world treated in the rest of both dialogues? We are here apparently concerned with a cosmological theory in which God, the bhÂ¯

utakr.t mentioned in 187.7 and 239.6, plays a key role.27

This same theory is found in other chapters of the Moks.adharma, which by Frauwallner are not styled â€˜epische Urform des SÂ¯

am

. khyaâ€™.

This brings us to our final point. What justification, if any, is there to annex the two dialogues at issue to the SÂ¯

am

. khya tradition and not, for instance, the

dialogue between Manu and Br.haspati? If the hallmark of SÂ¯am

. khya is a rift

between the material and ideal world, all three dialogues may be said to belong to the same multifarious stream from which classical SÂ¯

am

. khya emerged.

27 Cf. MBh 12.121.55, 12.175.16.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1
