Observations on the History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosalaâˆ—

Fifth to Seventh Centuries ad

Introduction

The historiography of the region called Daks.in.a Kosala, nowadays generally known as Chhattisgarh, is beset with difficulties of a predominantly chronological nature. Apart from quite a number of inscriptions, we do not possess written sources that can help us to unravel its early history. The chronological problems are due to the fact that, with one isolated exception, the charters of its kings are dated in regnal years. Moot questions, such as the dating of the kings of Åšarabhapur, the relation, if any, between the PÂ¯

an.d.ava dynasties

of MekalÂ¯

a and Kosala, or the date of King TÂ¯Ä±varadeva, have been discussed again and again by a number of scholars during the last fifty years, a debate that has been dominated by three eminent Indian epigraphists, V.V. Mirashi, D.C. Sircar, and A.M. Shastri. A first reading of this facinating corpus of learned articles gives the uncomfortable feeling that these three scholars disagree among themselves on almost every issue. Only laborious study makes one realize that in this debate a large body of historical evidence has been disclosed and evaluated, as a result of which we know to date considerably more about the history and culture of this region than half a century ago. Still, many inscriptions await publication and this is, unfortunately, in particular true for those on stone. Unlike copperplate charters, stone epigraphs often inform us about particular historical circumstances and details beyond the official royal records. They are less formal and regulated, but they are usually more difficult to decipher and this may have hampered their publication.

It seems a whim of fate that the only inscription belonging to this period and said to be found in this area that is dated in a known era, scil. the Gupta Era, has no apparent connection with any of the other data. I refer to the

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Balbir, Nalini & Joachim K. Bautze (eds.), Festschrift Klaus Bruhn zur Vollendung des 65. Lebensjahres, dargebracht von SchÃ¼lern, Freunden und Kollegen. Inge Wezler Verlag fÃ¼r orientalistische Fachpublika-tionen, Reinbek 1994. Studien zur Indologie und Iranistik. pp. 1â€“66.

235

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

236

Hans Bakker

Â¯

Ara Ë™ng Copper-Plate of BhÂ¯Ä±masena II. Though in this case the era is known, there is uncertainty with regard to the reading of the year. Hiralal, who edited the inscription (EI IX, 342â€“345), read 282, which would mean ad 601/2. This would make it the latest record dated in the Gupta Era in an area in which Gupta influence had virtually disappeared one century earlier. 1 Mirashi has vigorously argued against this interpretation, which was accepted by Sircar and Shastri, and has made it plausible that we should read 182 instead of 282. 2

This would place BhÂ¯Ä±masena of the ÅšÂ¯

ura family in that phase of the history of

Daks.in.a Kosala, in which it emerged as a politically and culturally autonomous state. BhÂ¯Ä±masena may therefore be seen as a figure who, in the turmoil of the age, hoped, by pledging allegiance to the once mighty Guptas, to secure a dominant position in the political arena of his days. However, Gupta support no longer amounted to much, and BhÂ¯Ä±masena and his dynasty disappeared from the scene without leaving a trace. 3 His inscription can therefore not be used for absolute dating of the dynastic history of Kosala, 4 and hence we have left it out of account in the following reconstruction.

There is another important source of the history of Kosala, viz. the archaeological materials in which this region abounds. Major contributions to their systematic and coherent treatment were made by Donald Stadtner in his thesis Sirpur to Rajim: the Art of Kosala During the Seventh Century, 5 and by Krishna Deva in the Encyclopedia of Indian Temple Architecture (II.1, Chapter 18, 1988). But whereas the archaeologists and historians of art concentrate on the abundance of material remains, and the historians and epigraphists on a sizeable corpus of inscriptions, very few attempts have been made to an integral treatment. Although, in my opinion, only such a study can really deepen our understanding of the cultural history of this region, the present article does 1 â€˜The Sumandal copperplate inscription of King Pr.thivÂ¯Ä±vigraha who was the ruler of Kali Ë™

nga, refers to the sovereignty of the Guptas in the year 250, i.e. A.D. 569/70. This was perhaps the last flicker of an extinguishing lamp.â€™ (Agrawal 1989, 269). Cf. Bakker 2014, 60.

2 EI XXVI, 227; see also many of Mirashiâ€™s later publications.

reported to have been found in Arang, this seems by no means certain. The place of issue, Suvarn

. anadÂ¯Ä±, is identified by Sircar as the River Son, though the MahÂ¯

anadÂ¯Ä± might

be another possibility. The characters of the inscription, according to Sircar ( op. cit.

342), â€˜belong to the Northern class of alphabetsâ€™.

3 A king named HarirÂ¯

aja, son of Nis.t.hurarÂ¯aja, grandson of BhÂ¯agraharÂ¯aja (?), said to belong to the ÅšÂ¯

ura family, is known from a copperplate charter found in VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an

. asÂ¯Ä±. The

open nail-headed letters of this inscription point to Central India (possibly Daks.in.a Kosala), which led Michael Willis (2014, 109) to conclude that â€˜this plate, although belonging to the fifth century, was found outside of its first geographical contextâ€™. King HarirÂ¯

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala

237

not have that pretention. It was written after a short visit to Chhattisgarh and touches only on a fraction of its historical wealth. What it does hope to illustrate, however, is that the methodology employed, consisting in utilization of sources of various sorts with the aim of cross-fertilisation, is in principle a sound and fruitful one. Whether this is borne out by the following essay is up to the reader to decide.

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala 241

VyÂ¯

aghrarÂ¯

aja is the younger brother of a chieftain ( manujapati) Pravarabhat.t.Â¯araka, a son of Jayabhat.t.Â¯araka, who is without title except for the honorific

Â´

srÂ¯Ä±. The family to which they belong is said to be that of AmarÂ¯

arya, 16 on

which Sircar passes the following remark,

The expression Amar-Â¯

arya looks like a Brahmanical personal name and names of the same type are often met with in South Indian records. It may be supposed that JayarÂ¯

ajaâ€™s [i.e. Jayabhat.t.Â¯arakaâ€™s, H.T.B.] queen who gave birth to Pravara I

[i.e. Pravarabhat.t.Â¯araka, H.T.B] and VyÂ¯aghra was the daughter of a person named Amar-Â¯

arya or was born in a family of which a person of that name was believed to have been the progenitor, since South Indian rulers sometimes represented themselves as belonging to the family from which their mother sprang. (EI XXXIV, 48)

If Sircar is right, the AmarÂ¯

arya family was partly of South Indian origin; ap-

parently through affiliation with a family of Kosala, they came to belong to the aristocratic circles of that country. In this way they attained to the status of local chieftains in the â€˜umbrageousâ€™ residence Prasannapur on the bank of the River Nid.ilÂ¯a, â€˜the waters of which were divided through being struck by the round hips of the concubines of Pravara (/ of distinguished lovely women)â€™. 17

Town and river are as yet not been identified. 18

The charter of VyÂ¯

aghrarÂ¯

aja, provided with his own seal, 19 reading Â´

srÂ¯Ä±-

vyÂ¯

aghrarÂ¯

ajah

. , is stylistically very different from the inscriptions of the so-called ÅšarabhapurÂ¯Ä±yas. Despite these differences Sircar argued in favour of an identity 16 amarÂ¯

aryakulÂ¯

ambaraÂ´

saÂ´

sinah

. [. . . ] Â´

srÂ¯Ä±pravarabhat.t.Â¯arakasya. In view of the comparatively few pretentions voiced in this charter, it seems rather unlikely that a â€˜divineâ€™ ( amara) origin of the family was envisaged.

19 Sircar & Bhattacharya in EI XXXIV, 45:

The surface of the seal, which is 1.9 inches in diameter and is much corroded, has a thick line dividing it into two halves. The section above the line exhibits three symbols, viz. the side view of a cakra in the left, the head of an animal (probably a lion) to front in the middle, and a conch-shell in the right. The legend below the line, written in Southern characters similar to those employed in writing the text of the document on the plates, reads Â´

ajah

. . There is another symbol below the

ajaâ€™s seal is totally unlike the seal of the ÅšarabhapurÂ¯Ä±ya kings [. . . ].

. a)â€™ instead of a lion, and a lotus flower

instead of an elephant.

242

Hans Bakker

of the two dynasties. Ajay Mitra Shastri (1987, 179 ff.), on the other hand, who convincingly refuted Sircarâ€™s hypothesis, thinks the AmarÂ¯

arya family to

be one of independent rulers â€˜contemporaneously with the later kings of the Åšarabhapur family in a part of Kosala not included in the dominions of the

Â´

SarabhapurÂ¯Ä±yasâ€™. 20 The last clause, however, is unlikely to be true. There is little in VyÂ¯

aghrarÂ¯

ajaâ€™s inscription that points to a sovereign royal dynasty.

Admittedly, the charter does not refer explicitly to an overlord, but we should keep in mind that it was not issued by the manujapati himself, of whom we do not possess any inscription, whereas VyÂ¯

aghrarÂ¯

aja may have thought it

sufficient to mention only his direct superior, his elder brother. Anyhow, they must have ruled very near to the kings of Åšarabhapur, whose charters are also found in Malhar.

The name of the residence, Prasannapur, seems to indicate that this town belonged to the dominions of the ÅšarabhapurÂ¯Ä±ya king PrasannamÂ¯

atra, an issuer of

repoussÃ© gold coins, or his successor JayarÂ¯

aja. Shastri himself rightly remarks,

â€˜that PrasannamÂ¯

atra was a powerful ruler [who] had thrown off the yoke of the Guptas and started ruling as a sovereign monarch for all intents and purposesâ€™

(Shastri 1987, 183). Consequently it does not seem plausible that PrasannamÂ¯

atra or his successor would have tolerated an independent ruler in the close vicinity of his own capital. It may even cautiously be suggested that the â€˜right honourable royal officers of the kingâ€™, 21 in whose presence VyÂ¯

aghrarÂ¯

ajaâ€™s grant

was declared, and the year 41 of the â€˜reign in which victory ever increasesâ€™ 22

should be understood as referring to the ruling king of Åšarabhapur.

Whatever the exact relationship of the AmarÂ¯

aryakula with the rulers of

Åšarabhapur might have been, the marriage of the king of MekalÂ¯

a, Bharatabala,

with a princess of the former family seems to have furnished the hill people of the Maikala Range with a foothold in the fertile plains of Kosala, of which they were proud enough to have it explicitly mentioned in their charters. 23

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala 243

However, it did not yet bring them sovereignty over Kosala, which for the greater part remained in the hands of the rulers of Åšarabhapur for at least one more generation. 24

The rulers of Åšarabhapur

The kings who issued their charters from Åšarabhapur, generally designated as ÅšarabhapurÂ¯Ä±yas in want of any other dynastic nomination, may be divided into two groups, which are linked by similarity in the style of their seals and inscriptions as well as by their capital. 25 Kings of both groups call themselves paramabhÂ¯

agavatas, i.e. worshippers of Vis.n.u. To the earlier group belongs mahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja Narendra, son of Åšarabha, of whom we possess three epigraphical testimonies, written in 5th-century square-headed characters which we think very similar to the ones used in the charters of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kings.26 Also to

be included in this group is a king called Mahendra or MahendrÂ¯

aditya, who is

known from repoussÃ© gold coins of the Khairtal Hoard, 27 and, possibly, from a Peerless, the chief queen of King Bharatabala, whose fame resembles the illustrious rays of the moonâ€”she, being as it were the river Ga Ë™

ngÂ¯

a herself descended to earth

from the world of the gods, who purifies the people, carrying the waters of her good character, bright and spotless like cristal, her pure stream contained within the two banks formed by self-control and good conduct, and her waves being a mass of virtues and tranquilityâ€”she, being born in KosalÂ¯

a and holding high the fame of the family

descending from Amara, and being very much the â€˜Lustre of the Worldâ€™ (LokaprakÂ¯

aÅ›Â¯

a),

by whom darkness has been counteracted by means of eternal dharma, artha and kÂ¯

ama,

she has attained preeminence (owing to) her grandsons and great-grandsons, princes like lions, devoted to good policy and conduct.

Cf. EI XXVII, 141; JESI III, 190 f.

Hans Bakker

sealing found in the excavation in Malhar. 28

In his Kurud Plates Narendra reconfirms an earlier grant of the paramabhat.t.Â¯araka and the ensuing merit is also assigned to the latter. Sircar (EI XXXI, 267) argues convincingly that the respectful manner in which the paramabhat.t.Â¯araka is mentioned shows that Narendra â€˜still considered himself, howsoever nominally, a subordinate of the Imperial Guptasâ€™. Another argument in favour of an allegiance of Åšarabha and Narendra to the Imperial Guptas pursued by A. M. Shastri, who follows Sircar in this respect, has been contested by Mirashi in his later work. According to Sircar, Shastri and others, Narendraâ€™s father Åšarabha is â€˜identical with the maternal grandfather of GoparÂ¯

aja who died in

fighting on behalf of the Gupta monarch BhÂ¯

anugupta at Eran [. . . ] in the Gupta

year 191 (= ad 510)â€™.29 In his Indological Research Papers I (1982, 187 f.) Mirashi gives up his earlier view and argues against this identification, though, in our view, he missed the most plausible argument, which was formulated by J.

Williams as follows: â€˜Åšarabha cannot be the maternal grandfather of GoparÂ¯

aja

of Eran, called Â´

sarabharÂ¯

aja-dauhittrah

. . That term is used only when a male

heir is lacking, and Åšarabha of Kosala had a sonâ€™ (scil. Narendra). 30

When the â€˜GoparÂ¯

aja argumentâ€™ has thus proven to be invalid, there seems to be no longer any reason not to date King Åšarabha around the middle of the 5th century, as one is inclined to do on the basis of the palaeography of the inscriptions of his son. The paramabhat.t.Â¯araka to whom Narendra refers might therefore have been KumÂ¯

aragupta I himself, whose biruda and coinage

the kings of Kosala, in particular Mahendra/MahendrÂ¯

aditya, may have sought

to imitate. 31 During the second half of the 5th century, when Mahendra and Narendra ruledâ€”Narendra at least for 24 yearsâ€”Gupta power was certainly on the wane, a fact of which the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kings Haris.en.a and Narendrasena may

have temporarily taken advantage, to judge by their claims of suzerainty over Kosala/KosalÂ¯

a and MekalÂ¯

a. 32 However, a disruption of the rule of Åšarabhapur

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala 245

did not come from the side of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas, as it would seem, but may

have been brought about by their enemies, the Nala kings of Pus.karÂ¯Ä± from the Andhra country to the southeast of Kosala, when they overran the kingdom of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas in the last decade of the 5th century.33

In fact the end of the 5th century marked the end of an era; when PrasannamÂ¯

atra succeeded in reorganizing Åšarabhapurâ€™s power and started issuing gold coins in his own name, he might have done so temporarily from another residence, viz. Prasannapur, which may have afterwards been turned over to the AmarÂ¯

arya family. The beginnings of the 6th century may have also offered enough freedom to the kings of MekalÂ¯

a to call themselves mahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja, beginning

with NÂ¯

agabala. The new Ã©lan of the ÅšarabhapurÂ¯Ä±ya rulers clearly speaks from the first Malhar Plates of PrasannamÂ¯

atraâ€™s son JayarÂ¯

aja, which dates from his

5th regnal year. Grafted on earlier formal phrases, the epigraphs contain from this time onwards high flown eulogies, not yet heard in Kosala and MekalÂ¯

a,

such as,

The illustrious great JayarÂ¯

aja, giver of riches, land and cattle, who made the women of his enemies tear out their parted hair, whose feet are washed by the sprinkling water that is the brilliance of the crest-jewels of his feudatories who have been brought into submission by his prowess, great devotee of the Lord, favoured by his venerable father and mother. 34

The same Ã©lan gave rise to the construction of stone temples, the oldest of which may date back to the first half of the 6th century. In the remains of some of them VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka influences are still distinct, as in, for instance, the door-frame and some pillars preserved in the (later) RÂ¯

amacandra Temple in

Rajim or almost identical pillars found in Turturiya. 35

33 Bakker & Isaacson 1993, 68 (above, n. 67 on p. 142); Bakker 1997, 53â€“57. This would explain from where the Nalas got the idea of issuing their own gold coins, which were devised after those of MahendrÂ¯

aditya (Mirashi in JNSI XI, 109 f.).

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala 247

the east (e.g. Kosala) of the old culture area. However, there seems to have been enough self-confidence to allow for revolutionary new experiments of an astonishing richness and beauty, such as are witnessed in the temples in TÂ¯

alÂ¯

a

(see below). They lay the foundation of the emerging Daks.in.a Kosala style of sculpture and architecture of the second half of the 6th and 7th centuries.

JayarÂ¯

aja was, in all likelihood, succeeded by his nephew SudevarÂ¯

aja, who

soon inaugurated a second centre from where the kingdom was governed, a place named after the goddess who adorned the seals of the dynasty, ÅšrÂ¯Ä± (Laks.mÂ¯Ä±), viz. ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura (modern Sirpur) on the right bank of the Great River (MahÂ¯

anadÂ¯Ä±).

The residence of the king remained in Åšarabhapur, as is evident from the fact that the charters issued from there were direct orders of the king himself ( svamukhÂ¯

ajËœ

nayÂ¯

a), 37 whereas the charters from ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura were issued by his proxy ( dÂ¯

u-

taka), the illustrious great feudatory ( Â´

srÂ¯Ä±mahÂ¯

asÂ¯

amanta) IndrabalarÂ¯

aja, whose

office is described as that of chief minister ( sarvÂ¯

adhikÂ¯

arÂ¯

adhikr.ta).38

There can be little doubt that Indrabala is the same as the king of the PÂ¯

an.d.ava lineage from whom the later King TÂ¯Ä±varadeva traced his descent (see below). 39 The ending of the name â—¦ bala as well as the fact that he belonged to a PÂ¯

an.d.ava lineage are strong indications that Indrabala was somehow related to the Somavam

. Å›a dynasty of MekalÂ¯

a, whose last ruling king, ÅšÂ¯

urabala, was

born from a princess of KosalÂ¯

a and who probably ruled as a feudatory of the

ÅšarabhapurÂ¯Ä±yas over parts of southern MekalÂ¯

a and/or northern Kosala at the

times of JayarÂ¯

aja and/or SudevarÂ¯

aja. 40

SudevarÂ¯

ajaâ€™s successor, PravararÂ¯

ajaâ€”probably his younger brotherâ€”may

have had a rather short reign. Both of his charters date from his 3rd regnal year. 41 They were issued from ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura, this time, however, without media-tion of Indrabala or another sÂ¯

amanta. It appears not implausible that the

death of SudevarÂ¯

aja was followed by a power struggle between the old family of Åšarabhapur and the feudatories of the newly founded ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura. Within the family of the PÂ¯

an.d.uvam

. Å›ins of MekalÂ¯

a this may also have led to a conflict of

interests, in particular between ÅšÂ¯

urabala, reigning in MekalÂ¯

a, and NannarÂ¯

aja,

son of Indrabala, reigning in Kosala; according to Bosmaâ€™s hypothesis they were brothers (above, n. 14 on p. 240; see Figure 3). The outcome of this struggle we know: the Indrabalaâ€“NannarÂ¯

ajaâ€“TÂ¯Ä±varadeva/Candragupta lineage of the

PÂ¯

an.d.avas of Kosala emerged as the new monarchs of ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura and under their rule this place evolved into an imposing temple town.

It is conceivable, nevertheless, that the territory over which King Indra(bala) and the PÂ¯

As we have pointed out, in respect of general appearance, formal features, drafting, the list of addresses of the royal order concerning the grant, the privileges bestowed on the grantee, the mode of recording the date as well as other matters, the MalgÂ¯

a Plates and the extant records of the PÂ¯

an.d.avas of MekalÂ¯a resemble each

IÅ›vara, H.T.B.].

Two dating criteria are thought to be relevant: 1) his capital (obviously ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura, but possibly also called â€˜Trivaranagaraâ€™) might have been alluded to in an inscription of MÂ¯

adhavavarman, the Vis.n.ukun.d.in king; 2) he might have been a contemporary of the (Maukhari) prince SÂ¯

asat.Â¯a

With regard to the first criterium A. M. Shastri has convincingly argued, on the strength of the IndrapÂ¯

alanagara (Tummalagudem) charter of the Vis.n.u-

kun.d.in king Vikramendravarman II, which is dated in the expired Åšaka year 488

(= ad 566), that the latterâ€™s great-grandfather, MÂ¯adhavavarman II JanÂ¯aÅ›raya, must have ruled between the termini post and ad quem of ad 470 and 528

(Shastri 1987, 122â€“131). This MÂ¯

adhavavarman II, son of Govindavarman and

married to a VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka princess, is said in his Ipur Plates to have â€˜rejoiced the hearts of the young ladies in the palaces of the town of Trivaraâ€™. 55 In view of the highly improbable, very early date that has to be assumed for TÂ¯Ä±varadeva in by MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta (EI XXVII, 324) to a temple of Â¯

aneÅ›varabhat.t.Â¯araka in the township

aneÅ›vara Temple seems

order to make his residence the scene of MÂ¯

adhavavarmanâ€™s conquests, Shastri

concludes that, whatever might have been meant by the expression, it had nothing to do with the PÂ¯

an.d.ava king TÂ¯Ä±varadeva and his capital ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura.56

Regarding the second criterium, A. M. Shastri, following Sankaranarayanan 1977, argued that the father of TÂ¯Ä±varadevaâ€™s nephewâ€™s wife VÂ¯

asat.Â¯a, Prince

( nr.pa) SÂ¯uryavarman, who is said to belong to a family of Varmans that had attained sovereignty over MagadhÂ¯

a, 57 has nothing to do with the homonymous

Maukhari prince, son of Â¯IÅ›Â¯

anavarman, who is known from the Haraha Inscrip-

tion (EI XIV, 110â€“120).

Shastriâ€™s arguments (1987, 215â€“217) fail to carry

conviction. They had already all been cogently discussed by B. P. Sinha (1977, 116â€“119) and shown to be invalid. Shastriâ€™s assertion to the effect that â€˜history knows of several other dynasties like the Pallavas, all the members of which had names ending with varman; but that was never employed as a dynastic nameâ€™ 58 and that, consequently, no dynasty, including the Maukharis, was ever designated as â€˜Varmanâ€™, is ipso facto refuted by the Sirpur inscription, unless we accept that only completely unknown â€˜Varmanâ€™ families could be denoted varman

. Â¯

am

. kulam. Secondly, Shastriâ€™s assessment that the Maukharis at the time of Â¯IÅ›Â¯

anavarman were not in actual control of MagadhÂ¯

a is beside the point.

They were certainly claiming to be sovereigns of this province and were about to realize it; epigraphical praÂ´

sastis serve to promulgate this sort of claims, not to report truthfully about the often less rosy historical reality. Moreover, when VÂ¯

asat.Â¯a/MahÂ¯aÅ›ivagupta made this claim, about half a century had passed since

Â¯IÅ›Â¯anavarman.

Sinhaâ€™s conclusion that â€˜ â€œthe Varman dynasty famous for its supremacy over Magadhaâ€ on strong circumstantial evidence can be no other than the imperial Maukhari dynasty which ruled over Magadha for many generationsâ€™ should be accepted as the most plausible interpretation of the evidence furnished by the Sirpur stone inscription (Sinha 1977, 118). Because the Haraha inscription of SÂ¯

uryavarman has been shown to date from ad 554,59 we may safely conclude that his contemporary, TÂ¯Ä±varadeva, ruled in the middle of the 6th century, a conclusion that is fully consistent with the archaeological dating of the monuments in Sirpur that were built by VÂ¯

asat.Â¯a and her son MahÂ¯aÅ›ivagupta

BÂ¯

alÂ¯

arjuna two generations later (ad 600â€“650).60

56 Shastri 1975-76; Shastri 1987, 117â€“220. Cf. Sankaranarayanan 1977, 224â€“230: Therefore it is certain that Trivaranagara was the capital of the Vis.n.ukun.d.ins. We have also seen earlier how both MÂ¯

adhavavarmans of the Ipur (I) and Polamuru (I)

plates brought prosperity to this capital Trivaranagara.

We have identified this

Trivaranagara with the modern Tiruvuru (17â—¦ 10Åƒorth and 30â—¦ 35Ã‰ast), the headquarters of the taluk of that name in the Krishna District, Andhra Pradesh.

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala 253

TÂ¯Ä±varadeva

To judge by his inscriptions, TÂ¯Ä±varadeva was a great warrior. In his military campaigns he may have been supported by the alliance which had evidently been forged between the Maukharis and the rulers of Daks.in.a Kosala.

There was enough geographical proximity for the Maukharis and Somavam

. Å›Â¯Ä±s to

come into contact. Åšarvavarman [reigning brother of SÂ¯

uryavarman, H.T.B.] was

overlord of Kalanjar region and probably held the Vindhyan fort Asigarh; 61 and the Somavam

. Å›Â¯Ä± kings of MahÂ¯

akosala were associated with Mekala region. It is

likely that [the Maukhari king] Â¯

IÅ›Â¯

anavarman was helped by the Somavam

. Å›Â¯Ä± king in

his campaign against the Vis.n.ukun.d.ins of Â¯

Andhra. 62 TÂ¯Ä±varadeva who was master

of the entire MahÂ¯

akosala region must have facilitated Â¯

IÅ›Â¯

anavarmanâ€™s march into

the interior of Orissa and Â¯

Andhra. 63 (Sinha 1977, 118 f.)

TÂ¯Ä±varadeva may have actively participated in the exploits of his northern ally, since his successor, NannarÂ¯

aja II, credits him with sovereignty over Orissa

(Utkala) etc. 64

Irrespective of how much these campaigns (or raids) may have contributed to the wealth of Kosala, they did not result in a lasting expansion of the kingdom. NannarÂ¯

aja II, who in his own charter calls himself â€˜sonâ€™, 65 but who might actually have been the son-in-law of TÂ¯Ä±varadeva, 66 only claims the sovereignty of the KosalÂ¯

aman.d.ala (EI XXXI, 221 ll. 8â€“9). This â€˜modestyâ€™ of NannarÂ¯aja II, also apparent from the comparison of his â€˜fatherâ€™ with Vis.n.u (Kait.abhÂ¯ari), himself with Pradyumna (EI XXXI, 221 l. 7), and the fact that the charter does not feature a regnal year, may all point to the comparative insignificance of his reign. Whether brought about by force or not, after him the line of succession switched again to the collateral branch. It must also remain uncertain whether Candragupta, brother of TÂ¯Ä±varadeva, 67 and his son Hars.agupta, who was married to VÂ¯

asat.Â¯a, ever really ruled, as long as we do not possess their inscriptions. Anyway, the exceptionally long reign (c. ad 590â€“650) of Hars.aguptaâ€™s son MahÂ¯aÅ›ivagupta (at least 57 years) indicates that he ascended the throne as a boy or young man. 68

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala 255

MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta, who, unlike his ancestors who were paramavais.n.avas, was a paramamÂ¯

aheÂ´

svara (EI XXVII, 323 l. 5), evidently pursued a policy of active patronage of various religious currents of his day, as is apparent from his grant to a Buddhist monastery in Tarad.am

. Å›aka (at the request of his maternal uncle

BhÂ¯

askaravarman), 72 and, indirectly, from the Buddhist monasteries a little south of ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura. The inscription found in one of them records the donation by a monk called Â¯

Anandaprabha of a â€˜free-feeding establishment for the yatis or monksâ€™ under the reign of MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta. 73

Among the major constructions of this period, however, is the GandheÅ›vara Temple on the bank of the MahÂ¯

anadÂ¯Ä±. According to Hiralal this temple was,

Repaired by the Bhonsalas who took all kinds of old material from the ruins of other temples and used it in making the mahÂ¯

aman

. d

. apa. We therefore find here a

number of inscriptions, some of which do not really belong to this temple. [. . . ]

Altogether there are six inscriptions, of which perhaps 2 or 3 only may be said to belong to GandheÅ›vara Temple. The one which specifically mentions the name GandharveÅ›vara is built into the plinth (on the right side as you enter). It records the arrangement made for the offerings of flowers for the pÂ¯

ujÂ¯

a of Gandh[arv]eÅ›vara

by one Jejuraka, a subject of prince Åšiva Gupta in whose kingdom pious people lived. 74

The prospering capital of Kosala under the reign of MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta was visited

by the Chinese pilgrim Xuanzang, who gave the following description, The capital is about 40 li round; the soil is rich and fertile, and yields abundant crops. [. . . ] The population is very dense. The men are tall and black complexioned. The disposition of the people is hard and violent; they are brave and impetuous. There are both heretics and believers here. They are earnest in study and of a high intelligence. The king is of the Kshattriya race; he greatly honours the law of Buddha, and his virtue and love are far renowned. There are about one hundred sa Ë™

nghË†

arË†

amas, and somewhat less than 10,000 priests: they all alike study the teaching of the Great Vehicle. There are about seventy Deva temples, frequented by heretics of different persuasions. Not far to the south of the city is an old sa Ë™

nghË†

arË†

ama, by the side of which is a stÂ¯

upa that was built by AÅ›Ã´karÃ¢ja.

(Beal 1884 II, 209 f.)

MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivaguptaâ€™s reign marks the acme of the early history of South Kosala.

No inscriptions of his successors have come to light and we may conveniently end our survey at this point. It is meant to provide some sort of dynastic and chronological framework, in which the cultural history of South Kosala has 72 EI XXIII, 120 f. ll. 11â€“13.

73 EI XXXI, 197 n. 2.

to fit. 75 To conclude we may select just one of its highlights for a tentative examination, the temples of TÂ¯

alÂ¯

a.

TÂ¯

alÂ¯

a

TÂ¯

alÂ¯

a is a tiny village in the Bilaspur District, situated a little north of the confluence of the ManiÂ¯

arÂ¯Ä± and the SevnÂ¯

ath rivers; the junction of the latter with

the MahÂ¯

anadÂ¯Ä± is c. 50 km downstream. The hamlet lies at a distance of 25 km to the west of Malhar as the crow flies. Near the village, on the left bank of the ManiÂ¯

arÂ¯Ä± are two stone temples known under the names Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± and DevarÂ¯anÂ¯Ä±.

Bajpai suggested that one of these temples was the JayeÅ›varabhat.t.Â¯araka Temple, which was endowed with the village at the confluence by one Narasi Ë™ngha and King ÅšÂ¯

urabala UdÂ¯Ä±rn.avaira (see above, p. 239).76

At the time of the grant this â€˜confluence-hamletâ€™ ( sam

. gamagrÂ¯

amaka) be-

longed to the southern province ( daks.in.arÂ¯as.t.ra) of the kingdom of the PÂ¯an.d.avas of MekalÂ¯

a. As we have argued above, this dynasty may have extended its territory to the north of Kosala since the times of ÅšÂ¯

urabalaâ€™s father, who had

married a princess of KosalÂ¯

a. This princess, as has been shown, probably came

from the AmarÂ¯

arya family, who were petty chiefs in Kosala. Their progenitor was Jayabhat.t.Â¯araka. In view of the common practice to name temples after their builders, we would venture the hypothesis, that this JayeÅ›varabhat.t.Â¯araka Temple was founded by Jayabhat.t.Â¯araka of the AmarÂ¯aryakula. From this it would follow that ÅšÂ¯

urabala made a grant to the temple built by either his maternal grandfather or, less likely, his maternal uncle (depending on whether the princess â€˜LokaprakÂ¯

aÅ›Â¯

aâ€™ was a daughter or (younger) sister of Jayabhat.t.Â¯araka).

And this would place this temple around 500 ad, according to the dynastic history of Kosala that has been reconstructed above on the basis of epigraphical testimony. Pending new epigraphical discoveries that throw fresh light on this issue, we shall now have a look at the archaeological evidence of the two temples themselves.

75 In addition to A.M. Shastri, Thomas E. Donaldson may be mentioned as an art-historian who has argued in favour of a much later historical framework for the Kosala temples (Hindu Temple Art of Orissa I (1985), 188 ff.). One of his main arguments is the dynastic gap or dark period of the region that follows the reign of MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta BÂ¯

alÂ¯

arjuna.

Apart from the fact that shifting the whole dynastic and art history with 200 years to fill this gap only results in another gap, beginning at the time that VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka and

Gupta hegenomy ended (c. 500 ad), it may be assumed that, after the PÂ¯

an

. d

. uvam

. Å›a, a

re-emerged Nala dynasty ruled over parts of Kosala including Rajim, where VilÂ¯

asatu Ë™

nga

reconstructed the RÂ¯

ajÂ¯Ä±valocana Temple (EI XXVI, 49â€“58; cf. Krishna Deva in EITA II.1, 224 f.).

Hans Bakker

With regard to the relative chronology of the two temples, it would seem that the better preserved DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± is somewhat later than the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± Temple, by

virtue of the formerâ€™s more refined carving and more conventional structure (Plate 19). The enormous slabs of stone of the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± ruin give the impression that this temple was a not wholly successful experimental construction that finally collapsed under its own load (Plate 20). 77 The brick buttresses that are found at the base along the west, north and east sides and the square brick prop in the centre of the southern stairs could have been meant to prevent the temple from falling down (Plate 21). 78 In the building of the DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Temple

these constructional errors were evidently remedied.

Plate 21

Brick buttresses at the western side of the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± Temple at TÂ¯alÂ¯a 77 Cf. Williams 1982, 125: â€˜The temple known locally as the Jet.hÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± is in ruins, per-

haps because it had an unstable stone superstructure, indicated by fragments of large

Â¯

amalakas.â€™

78 This has first been suggested to me by the two excavators G. L. Raykwar and R. K.

Singh. These brick supports may, possibly, date from the beginning of the 7th century when, as e.g. the Laks.man.a Temple of Sirpur shows, brick had become the building material in Kosala.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala 259

So far it is mainly the DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Temple that has been discussed in the Indo-

logical literature. Donald Stadtner was the first to propose a date for it, viz.

ad 525â€“550 (Stadtner 1980, 47). Two years later Joanna Williams observed:

â€˜To establish a precise date for temples of Tala is impossible, for nothing in the area is preserved to which they can be significantly related. [. . . ] The position of about 480 to 530 is a reasoned guessâ€™ ( op. cit. 128). Krishna Deva, finally, dates the DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Temple to c. ad 550â€“575 (EITA II.1, 229 f.).

The dynastic chronology that we have tried to establish seems to support the early dating of Joanna Williams. Viewed from the dynastic perspective and considering the relative chronology of the two temples we are inclined to assign the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± Temple to the last decade of the 5th century. Keeping in view a margin of uncertainty in the dating of at least 25 years, however, it is virtually impossible to determine with certainty whether JayeÅ›varabhat.t.Â¯araka of the Malhar Plates of ÅšÂ¯

urabala refers to the deity of the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± or to that of the DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Temple, if indeed Jayabhat.t.Â¯araka lent his name to one of these temples.

Williams (1982, 127) observes that the motifs found on both temples are on the whole â€˜basically orthodox Guptaâ€™. This observation should now, in view of the sculptures that have been discovered in Vidarbha since 1982 (Mandhal, Ramtek, Nagardhan, Mansar) be qualified to the effect that the artefacts of TÂ¯

alÂ¯

a, especially the gan

. a type images, bear just as much or more relation to the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka as to the Gupta idiom.79 However, it has been noted that the basal wall-mouldings and niched walls of the DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Temple in particular

have a definite South Indian flavour. 80 Krishna Deva (EITA II.1, 229) speaks of â€˜some features reminiscent of Calukya and Pallava templesâ€™. This theme had earlier been elaborated by Stadtner (1980, 39â€“41) who observes about the DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Temple that,

Vertical exterior niches alternating recessed and projecting and with or without images, are a characteristic of early temples of the Deccan and of South Indian architecture in general. [. . . ] Certain elements of the base ( adhis.t.hÂ¯ana) moldings of the Devarani also indicate a relationship between the temple and South Indian forms. [. . . ] The presence of these distinctly southern features in Kosala should probably be interpreted as a borrowing of architectural forms that probably existed in the sixth century in the Deccan and in South India but that appeared on temples constructed of perishable materials and therefore have not survived. It is highly unlikely that these forms originated in Kosala during the sixth century in light of Kosalaâ€™s rather provincial and isolated position.

79 Cf. K.K. Chakravarty in the Abstract of his dissertation (see below, n. 84 on p. 261):

â€˜As such, I have attributed the continuing volume of Tala art to the influence of the vigorous style of neighbouring Vidarbha and detected seeds of the medieval rarefication and complexity in Tala style.â€™

80 Stadtner 1980, 38: â€˜The magnificent sculptures surviving at Tala bear strong affinities with Gupta art of the north; at the same time architectural and iconographic features of the temple reveal important connections with so-called Dravidian, or south Indian forms.â€™

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

260

Hans Bakker

Joanna Williams (1982, 26), though agreeing with Stadtner that the architecture of TÂ¯

alÂ¯

a may go back to wooden archetypes and that â€˜these forms are in a general way akin to slightly later buildings to the south, both Calukya and Pallavaâ€™, disagrees with Stadtnerâ€™s emphasis of the southern origin of these forms.

Stadtner describes these (scil. base moldings) as forming a typically Dravidian base of the type known as pratibandha, citing the authority of M. A. Dhaky. [. . . ]

The makara toran

. as of the exterior, another seemingly south Indian element, are also found at Ajan.t.Â¯a (Cave 6, lower). I would prefer to think of such forms as indigenous to Kosala in wood, rather than as resulting from influence from the South, where such forms are not known at this point. ( op. cit. 125, n. 81) We are not in the position to make a final assessment on this issue, which should be settled by historians of Indian architecture. However, the hypothesis advanced above, making a ruler of the AmarÂ¯

arya dynasty primarily responsible

for the origin of these monuments, could provide an historical explanation of some South Indian influence in the architecture of TÂ¯

alÂ¯

a in virtue of the possible

South Indian descent of this family.

The Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± Temple

Bajpai & Pandey 1977 are again the first to report on this temple.

They

noticed â€˜the colossal nature of the stone-sculptures lying around the ruined Jethani Temple. [. . . ] Some of the sculptures have a height of 4 m to 5 m. The images of Narsimha, Buddha and a few other deities have been identified. The temple may have been a DaÅ›Â¯

avatÂ¯

ara shrine. In point of time this temple is

earlier than the Devrani Temple. It can be assigned to the 4th century A.D.â€™ 81

The archaeological exploration of the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± Temple mound was initiated in 1986 according to the Indian Archaeological Review of that year (IAR 1985â€“86, 48 (published in 1990)). Here it is said that â€˜the unearthed temple has a large, simple but typical plan. Amongst antiquities mention may be made of silver coin of PrasannamÂ¯

atra Sarabhpuriya king of Dakshina Kosala [. . . ].â€™ 82 This seems to confirm a dating of the site to the end of the 5th, beginning of the 6th 81 Op. cit. 37. Cf. Stadtner 1980, 46 f.:

The style of the sculptures surrounding the Jithani conforms to that of the Devarani, and it can be concluded that both temples were constructed at the same time. However, the fragments of architectural members reveal that the Jithani probably differed in construction from the Devarani. The most important of these are at least three large stone amalakas which, if they were used in the superstructure, may indicate that the temple adopted a form more consistent with north Indian standards.

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala 261

century. The final clearance of the mound was conducted during three seasons from 1985â€“86 under the supervision of G.L. Raykwar and Rahul Kumar Singh (Nigam 2000, 46). R. K. Singh published a short note on the uncovered temple in PurÂ¯

atan vol. 6 (1989), 169 in which he observes that, though the image of the deity enshrined in the garbhagr.ha seems lacking, the whole collection of images definitely prove the temple to be of Åšaiva stamp. Among the free-standing images found at the site mention is made of that of KÂ¯

arttikeya, a Åšiva

head, a torso of ArdhanÂ¯

arÂ¯Ä±Å›vara, a head of an emaciated devotee, a head of

NandikeÅ›vara and a stele of GaurÂ¯Ä±. 83 As part of the architecture Singh lists images of Gan.eÅ›a, Nandin and Åšivagan.as.

K. K. Chakravarty devoted his PhD thesis to the subject: The temples at Tala and the art of Daks.in.a KoÅ›ala.84 Unfortunately this thesis was not available to me. I had the privilege of visiting the site in November 1992 in the company of the two excavators R. K. Singh and G.L. Raykwar along with Dr L. S. Nigam of Raipur University. To all three of them I owe many valuable observations.

First of all I fully agree with R. K. Singhâ€™s observation that the temple is decidedly Åšaiva although the overall scheme of the monument has yet to be established. Bajpai and Pandeyâ€™s conjecture to the effect that the temple was a DaÅ›Â¯

avatÂ¯

ara shrine is based on very shallow evidence, made obsolete by the clearance of the mound. The large slabs of stone lying to the west of the temple are too much damaged (they look as if their front sites are sliced off by a razor, probably caused by fractures in the stone) to allow identification as Narasim

. ha

and the Buddha, though one of them (measuring 110 x 265 cm) does seem to have an us.n.Â¯Ä±s.a (Plate 22). A smaller image of a seated Narasim

. ha is found in

low relief on a stone architrave lying to the southwest of the mound (Plate 23).

One of the remarkable aspects of this temple is its lay-out. There appear to have been three entrances reached by steps. The major entrance is a flight of steps, more than 7 m in width, at the bottom of which four huge pillars (measuring between 70 to 80 cm on each side, one still standing) must have supported a roof like projection (Plate 20). The space between these pillars is 114, 206 and 108 cm. This propylaeum faces south. The two pillars in the middle of the frontside rest on plinths that are bolstered by atlantid gan

. as

( bhÂ¯

araraks.akas) (Plate 24). The plinths of the two outward pillars are formed by lions (Plate 25). The bases of the two central pillars are formed by kumbhas on four sides, out of each of which two horses jump (Plate 26). The broadness 83 Some of these images are now in the Bilaspur Museum (State Archaeology in Bilaspur).

For photos see Bosma 2018, Plates 3.17, 3.26, 3.25, 3.29.

84 Harvard 1992. For an abstract of this thesis see Dissertation Abstracts International.

A: The Humanities and Social Sciences Vol. 53 No. 5, November 1992, 1297-A. Here Chakravarty states: â€˜The coexistence of classical and medieval features, volumetric and linear styles in Tala art stamps it as one of the most important missing links in the transition from classical to medieval art.â€™ Publication of this thesis (Chakravarty 2018) came too late to be of use for the present volume.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

262

Hans Bakker

of the steps and their direction to the south suggest that this temple faced the nearby waters of the confluence, which at those days may have been closer to the temple than it is to date.

The other two entrances are at the rear of the temple, facing east and west respectively (Plate 21). Near the steps of the western entrance lies a pillar that is deliciously carved with oblique bands of floral and foliage patterns (Plate 27). On these bands a mouse or rat is sculptured as if running down the pillar (Plate 28). A similar motif recurs in the DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Temple. Along the north

and east sides of the moulded base of that temple a snake emerges repeatedly out of the stone in chase of a mouse. The distance between snake and mouse gradually decreases until the mouse is caught.

Several â€˜sliced offâ€™ slabs of stone flank the eastern steps (Plate 29). A standing pillar, which seems to have split along its vertical axis, has different bands of ornamentation. The upper portion consists of a â€˜convex-lobed Â¯

amalakaâ€™ that

rests upon a vase decorated with festoons hanging from lions (cf. Williams 1982, 127 Plate 197). At the rear side of this pillar a figure with bird-like legs and ram-like head is carved standing against the vase (Plate 30). The sculpture work evokes a strong flavour of wood carving. At the bottom of the steps stands a torso clad in a tiger skin covering a pronounced scrotum and erect penis (Plate 31). A claw and the face of the tiger is sculptured on the right thigh next to what seems to be a trident. Along the left thigh the tail of the animal runs downwards starting next to the phallus. Two huge elephant heads buttress the temple platform on the northern side (Plate 32). To compare, an image of Gan.eÅ›a with trunk to the left and holding a danta in his right hand is found at the northern base (i.e. right side) of the steps leading up to the DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Temple (Plate 33).

The mound of the ruined temple is strewn with very lively carved images of makaras and gan

. as, which once supported pillars and other figures (Plates 34â€“39).

These jolly, delicately sculptured, pot-bellied figures, all markedly different, are in a way reminiscent of VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka and Gupta examples, yet they

definitely breathe an atmosphere of their own. Luxuriant patterns of flowers and foliage decorate the faces of the stone remains as far as these are not damaged and â€˜sliced offâ€™.

Two fragmentary images merit particular attention. One is a complex, broken image, about 1.50 m as it stands now, fixed in concrete and resting against the brick prop at the middle of the southern staircase (Plate 40). It shows a group of three figures; the main one is a male deity broken just below the waist, against whose breast two makaras rise up (the right one has lost the upper portion of his trunk-like jaw). 85 The left arm of the main deity is broken off, but part of what seems to be his underarm in an upwards position is 85 Under the left makara a fan-shaped fold protrudes, which in a way resembles the sole of a left foot. If indeed it is that it must, in view of its position, have been attached to the image by those who are responsible for fixing the sculpture in concrete. Or it may belong to the makara itself which, anyway, is not complete as we see it now.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

12 / History and Culture of Daks.in.a Kosala 263

preserved under his shoulder. The right arm is broken off at the elbow. The fracture above the bent elbow indicates that originally the right underarm also was directed upwards. This right underarm is preserved on a slab of stone that is placed to the left of the image (Plate 41). The right hand holds braided curls of hair, also seen at other images found in TÂ¯

alÂ¯

a, which may have belonged to

the female figure that rises above the hood-like halo of the main image. This hood consists of layers of petals, on the outer rim of which (lotus) buds are placed in a row. Altogether I count eleven buds, two preserved on the slab that contains the right underarm. The head of the female figure is missing. To her right, placed a little below her, stands a male figure, apparently making an aËœ

njali.

The head of the main deity is slightly slanted to the left. His round face, with eyes half closed as he looks downwards, with rather flat nose and thick lips, seem to express forbearance. He wears a broad necklace ( graiveyaka) adorned with pendants. The female figure rising above his head wears a simple necklace and bangles on her right wrist.

The group of figures as it stands now is flanked by two round pillars, profusely decorated with scroll-work. The preserved upper portion of the right pillar consists of abacus, Â¯

amalaka, a vase and (damaged) capital, a sequence that recurs in other fragmentary pillars preserved at the site.

The interpretation of this sculpture poses many problems. There are few, if any, clues that connect it with other known iconographic material. In discussions with the excavators the suggestion arose that the image could be that of Varun.a, i.e. the ocean, out of which ÅšrÂ¯Ä± arises. The apparently invariable attribute of Varun.a, the noose ( pÂ¯aÅ›a), is absent. It can not be excluded that it was held in the left hand which is missing. The makaras (the traditional vÂ¯

ahana

of Varun.a), and possibly, the scroll-work on the pillars (waterplants / waves) may point to the ocean. 86 His expression of forbearance would be appropriate if we assume that the goddess ÅšrÂ¯Ä± arises out of him while he is being churned.

The halo of lotuses encircling his head serves the goddess above as pÂ¯Ä±t.ha, the traditional one of ÅšrÂ¯Ä±/Laks.mÂ¯Ä±.

The other sculpture is also incomplete and apparently composed of at least three figures. It is hewn out of a large slab of stone that lies on top of the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± Temple mound (Plate 42). The main figure is a large decapitated male deity wearing a belt, keyÂ¯

ura adorned with lionâ€™s head on his left arm, a ka Ë™nkana, and a graiveyaka. His left arm seems to hold at the waist another, smaller male figure, who is positioned on the main imageâ€™s right side and of whom only the upper part of the head and left arm are preserved. The head is deliciously sculpted showing a youthful face, almond eyes, snail-like curls, and a cranial bumb (Plate 43). At both sides of the cranial bumb the feet are preserved of a third figure that must have stood on top of his head. The left 86 For the iconography of Varun

. a see Sahai 1975, 45â€“52.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Hans Bakker

arm, wearing bangles at the wrist, holds this third figure at his/her left ankle. 87

The identification of this group is hampered by the fact that, in the state it is in now, it lacks all significant attributes.

To conclude I would venture a tentative interpretation of this image group by directing attention to a passage from the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata that describes the

god Skanda and his offspring.

Deserted by the gods Åšakra then hurled (his) thunderbolt ( vajra) at Skanda. That (thunderbolt), being hurled, directly hit the right side of Skanda and split open the side of that noble one, O great king. Through the stroke of the thunderbolt another person ( purus.a) was born from Skanda, youthful, with golden armour, wielding a spear and wearing divine earrings; he became ViÅ›Â¯

akha, because he was

born from the entering ( viÂ´

sanÂ¯

at) of the thunderbolt. Then, when he saw (still) another one emerging, whose splendour resembled doomsday-fire, Indra folded his hands and took refuge with Skanda out of fear. Skanda put him and his army at ease, O foremost of men, and thereupon the Thirty (Gods) rejoiced and sounded their instruments. (MBh 3.216.12â€“15)

I would conjecture that the main figure is Skanda/KumÂ¯

ara, the smaller deity at

his right side ViÅ›Â¯

akha. 88 MBh 3.217 continues by describing the other deities that were born â€˜from the thunderboltâ€™s impact on Skandaâ€™, maidens ( kanyÂ¯

as)

and KumÂ¯

arakas, whose father is ViÅ›Â¯

akha.

MBh 1.60.23 lists three sons of

KumÂ¯

ara: â€˜ÅšÂ¯

akha, ViÅ›Â¯

akha, and NaigameÅ›a, born from his backâ€™. 89 Whether

Naigames.a (NaigameÅ›a or Naigameya), the ram-headed deity, also formed part of this group is impossible to determine. That his existence was well-known to the sculptors, however, is proved by the image of Naigames.a that is found at the left side of the steps leading up to the DevarÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Temple (Plate 44). 90 An

early parallel for this sculpture is found among the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka images discovered

in Mandhal (Plate 45). 91

Another origin myth relating to the various forms of Skanda/KumÂ¯

ara, pos-

sibly relevant to the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± Temple, is told in MBh 9.43â€“46. In the course of his pilgrimage Baladeva (BalarÂ¯

ama) arrived at SthÂ¯

an.utÂ¯Ä±rtha at the Saras-

vatÂ¯Ä± (MBh 9.41.4). It is told how once the consecration of KumÂ¯

ara as general

( senÂ¯

apati) took place here ( kumÂ¯

abhis.ekam, MBh 9.43.1). The curious

birth of KumÂ¯

ara is briefly related. Then it is said that KumÂ¯

ara, in order to

venerate his four parents (Rudra, DevÂ¯Ä±, Agni and Ga Ë™ngÂ¯

All gods come together for KumÂ¯

araâ€™s consecration, bringing with them all nec-

. bhÂ¯

ara). The text continues by saying that earlier at this site the consecration of Varun.a as â€˜Lord of the Watersâ€™ ( jaleÅ›vara, MBh 9.44.20) had taken place, as is indeed described in MBh 9.46.5â€“11. KumÂ¯

ara is conse-

crated and he is equipped with an army:

And the gods gave him the army, which thronged together in the southwest (?), to destroy the enemies of the gods, invincible, containing all sorts of beings. Then all the gods and descendants of Vasu, Gandharvas, Yaks.as, Raks.as, sages and ancestors exclaimed the word â€˜Jaya!â€™ (â€˜Victory!â€™). 93

They each present him with two servants and then the text embarks on a lengthy description of the soldiers making up Skandaâ€™s army (MBh 9.44.51â€“

108), among whom we encounter all sorts of gan

. as (a summary is given by

atr.gan.a), which sur-

rounds KumÂ¯

ara (MBh 9.45.1â€“40), is described, the major gods present him with special gifts, a ceremony concluded by Varun.a and BrahmÂ¯a.

And King Varun.a gave the noose provided with strength and courage, and Lord BrahmÂ¯

a gave Brahman.ya (i.e. KumÂ¯ara) the skin of a black antelope, and the Creator of the World also gave victory ( jaya) in battle. 94

Thus equipped KumÂ¯

ara/Skanda gained victory over the enemy of the gods.

We have rendered this passage from the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata in some detail be-

cause it seems to fit with the materials we find in and around the ruins of the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± Temple. Two divine figures play a major part in the MÂ¯ahÂ¯atmya of SthÂ¯

an.utÂ¯Ä±rtha, Skanda/KumÂ¯ara and Varun.a, and the two major images found at the Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± mound could, tentatively, it is true, be identified with these two gods. 95 And to this could be added the recurrent motif of makaras and the abundance of gan

. a images at the site, the latter concurring with the prominence of these figures in the epic story. Further research is needed to support the correspondence found. For the present purpose, the introduction of TÂ¯

alÂ¯

a

in its cultural-historical setting, may it suffice to end with a speculation, viz.

that the name â€˜JayeÅ›varaâ€™, referring simultaneously to Lord Åšiva as well as to the great victory obtained by KumÂ¯

ara in his stead, could have been thought

to be an appropriate name for the â€˜Jit.hÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± Templeâ€™ at TÂ¯alÂ¯a.

SomaÅ›arman, Somavam

. Å›a and SomasiddhÂ¯

anta

A PÂ¯

aÅ›upata tradition in seventh-century

Daks.in.a Kosalaâˆ—

Studies in the SkandapurÂ¯

an.a III

HarÂ¯

aya Namah

.

The first fruit of Minoru Haraâ€™s life-task-project to clarify the early history of the Åšaiva religion appeared in the Indo-Iranian Journal of 1958 under the title NakulÂ¯Ä±Å›aâ€“PÂ¯

aÅ›upataâ€“DarÅ›anam. This was followed by the submission of his dissertation, Materials for the study of PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Åšaivism, to the Department of

Sanskrit and Indian Studies of Harvard University in 1966 (Hara 1967). Ever since, Hara has contributed to the research into the history of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata

religion by a continuous series of meticulous studies. 1 Thanks to these studies our knowledge of this enigmatic but fascinating branch of early Hinduism has significantly increased. Paucity of sources, however, has inevitably hampered our understanding of the process of origin and spread of this religious movement. Hara, like other scholars before him, duly recognized that the puranic text corpus contains numerous references to the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata religion. Yet, due to

inconsistencies of all sorts and uncertainty as to their exact dates, he considered, rightly, the use of these texts for historic purposes a hazardous affair and consequently assigned them to the periphery of historical research. That is to say, for the time being, since,

Some day in the future, when all PurÂ¯

an.ic texts are critically edited and the inter-

relationships among them established, they may help us in tracing the history of PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Åšaivism. (Hara 1967, 12 f.)

This day is, after thirty-four years, still far off. Critical editions of some PurÂ¯

an.a

texts have indeed been prepared since, by the All-India Kashiraj Trust in Ramnagar, the Oriental Institute in Vadodara (Vis.n.upurÂ¯an.a), and the Institute of

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Wezler, Albrecht & Ryutaro Tsuchida (eds.), HarÂ¯

anandalaharÂ¯Ä±. Volume in Honour of Professor Minoru Hara on his Seventieth Birthday. Inge Wezler Verlag, Reinbek 2000. pp. 1â€“19.

1 A collection of his contributions appeared in 2002 (Hara 2002).

283

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

284

Hans Bakker

Learning and Research in Ahmedabad (BhÂ¯

agavatapurÂ¯

an

. a), but they have not

really brought the progress in PurÂ¯

an.a studies that one should wish. Partly this

is due to the unwieldiness of the puranic text corpus, partly to the fact that no old manuscript material has been used for these editions. How valuable ancient manuscripts are for gaining insight in the puranic text tradition itself and for the assessment of these texts as historical sources may be shown by the original SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a (SP), the edition of which is a long-term project of the Institute of Indian Studies in Groningen. Because the oldest manuscript of this text is dated ad 810, we can be certain that the information it contains dates from the eighth century or earlier. But even in this particular case the use of the PurÂ¯

an.a text as a source of historical information remains a venturesome undertaking. Its historical value is greatly enhanced, however, when it proves possible to relate its data to other historical sources such as inscriptions. It is a matter of good fortune that this turns out to be the case in chapter 167 of the original SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, a chapterâ€”transmitted in two old Nepalese manu-

scripts, among which the one dated in ad 810â€”which deals with the traditional history and holy places of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata and which is, as we will show, partly

in agreement with epigraphical evidence of the seventh century. In this tribute to Hara I intend to make a modest contribution to the objective envisaged by the great Japanese scholar, viz. â€˜tracing the history of PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Åšaivismâ€™.

Åšaiva cosmology

The cosmology developed in mainstream early tantric Saivism distinguishes between the Pure ( Â´

suddhÂ¯

adhvan) and the Impure Universe ( aÂ´

suddhÂ¯

adhvan).

Both universes are hierarchically structured; the different levels of reality or domains are called tattva. A standard hierarchy counts thirty-one domains in the Impure Universe and five domains in the Pure one. 2 The domain that forms the trait-dâ€™union between both universes is the MÂ¯

ayÂ¯

atattva. According to the

Svacchandatantra, this reality can be divided into two layers ( put.a), which are separated by a knot or barrier ( granthi). 3 Each layer comprises six â€˜worldsâ€™

( bhuvana) that are reigned over by altogether twelve Rudras. The barrier or granthi seems actually to be the border between both universes and may be considered a layer or madhyaput.a by itself (SvT 10.1122â€“1131).

2 See e.g. Davis 1991, 45. The canonical list of 36 tattvas is, as has been demonstrated by Goodall 1998, liâ€“lv, in fact a consensus only reached â€˜in the post-scriptural Åšaiva SiddhÂ¯

anta of the commentatorsâ€™ ( ibid. lii).

3 The Svacchanda is a Bhairava (MantrapÂ¯

Ä±t.ha) Tantra and does not belong to the tradition

of the Åšaiva SiddhÂ¯

anta, though it seems to be quite close to this tradition (Sanderson 1988, 669 f.). The granthi is not a universally shared feature of the Åšaiva cosmos (no mention of it is made in the Mr.gendratantra, for instance).

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

13 / SomaÅ›arman, Somavam

. Å›a and SomasiddhÂ¯

anta

285

The first Rudra on our side of the barrier is Gopati and the Rudra reigning the lowest â€˜worldâ€™ of the sub-barrier layer of the MÂ¯

ayÂ¯

atattva is Gahana. 4

Directly underneath him spreads the â€˜net of bondsâ€™ ( pÂ¯

aÂ´

sajÂ¯

ala), 5 the created

ayÂ¯

a Reality, assuming material form through

incarnated in the eight PramÂ¯

. a, as this text is quoted by Ks.emarÂ¯

Here we meet the very same Rudras again: â€˜Those Rudras who have been mentioned, beginning with Gopati and ending with Gahana, they, however, are designated â€˜terribleâ€™ ( ghora); they live in various worlds.â€™ 11

With regard to the fourth of these PramÂ¯

an.a texts, the Hr.daya, Ks.emarÂ¯aja

makes an interesting remark. From this text six other PramÂ¯

an.a texts have

been extracted that deal with ritual acts ( kriyÂ¯

a) and in this respect differ

from the other eight PramÂ¯

an.as, which deal with knowledge ( jËœnÂ¯ana).12 These ritual PramÂ¯

an.as are said to have been revealed by a pupil of Laku(leÅ›a), Musulendra. 13

This brings Ks.emarÂ¯aja to the difference between two divisions within the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata movement (referred to as â€˜Tantraâ€™), namely between the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata

proper, founded by LakuleÅ›a, and hence designated â€˜LÂ¯

akulaâ€™, and the Mausula,

founded by the eponymous pupil of LakuleÅ›a, Musula or Musulendra. These Mausulas, though PÂ¯

aÅ›upatas in the wider senseâ€”after all they too stem from LakuleÅ›aâ€”are put on a lower scale by the Svacchanda and its commentator.

Whereas the observance of the Mausulas leads them finally to the MÂ¯

ayÂ¯

a Reality

(SvT 11.71cd), the PÂ¯

an.as and

belong to the LÂ¯

akula division reach the Â¯IÅ›vara Reality in the Pure Universe (SvT 10.1169cdâ€“70ab, 11.71ab).

The question now arises: who is this disciple of LakuleÅ›a, Musulendra or Musula, who initiated a sect designated â€˜Mausulaâ€™? Evidently we are here concerned with a group within the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata movement that was chiefly en-

gaged in ritual (worship) activity, forsaking the more rigorous portion of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata praxis. As such it might be a group that stood between the lay MÂ¯

aheÅ›varas ( laukikas) and the tough ascetics with their transgressive practices. Unfortunately, none of the PramÂ¯

an.a texts ascribed by Ks.emarÂ¯aja to this

school has survived and little more information about the sect is known from the later Åšaiva SiddhÂ¯

anta, which, in view of its ritualistic orientation, in a way may be conceived of as its successor (see below, p. 296). However, the alleged dependence of the Mausula text corpus on the LÂ¯

akula PramÂ¯

an.as seems to allow

the inference that this sect also ackowledged the hierarchy of Rudra worlds and as such deviated from the PaËœ

ncÂ¯

artha school.

13 / SomaÅ›arman, Somavam

. Å›a and SomasiddhÂ¯

The epigraphical evidence from Malhar

The antiquity of a tradition that traced its origin back to a certain Mugalisa who was initiated by LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a is secured by an inscription of which the text has recently become available. I refer to the Malhar Plates of MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta, Year

57 (c. ad 650), actually found in JunvÂ¯anÂ¯Ä± (near Malhar) and hence also known as The JunvÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± Copperplate Inscription of MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta, Year 57, 21 which

was published by G.L. Raykwar and Rahul Kumar Singh in PurÂ¯

atan (Vol. 9

(1994), 146 f.). 22

I take â€˜Mugalisaâ€™ to be a variant or prakritism of MudgalÂ¯Ä±Å›a or MusalÂ¯Ä±Å›a, both names meaning â€˜Club-bearing Lordâ€™. MusalÂ¯Ä±Å›a again may be a variant of MusaleÅ›a/MusuleÅ›a and, having the same meaning, it might not seem too far-fetched to identify the â€˜Musulendraâ€™ of Ks.emarÂ¯aja with the â€˜Mugalisaâ€™ of the inscription. 23

I present here my edition of 2000, which gave a Sanskrit text that was slightly emended according to its intended reading. Since then, however, I have reconsidered this edition and proposed some alterations in Bakker 2014, 143 f. These are presented in the notes.

Before discussing this inscription any further, I give the text of that portion of it that is relevant for the present study. This portion starts with the last word on the first plate (second side), line 8, and ends in line 23 on the second plate, second side.

21 For the early chronology of Daks.in.a Kosala, the PÂ¯

an

. d

. uvam

. Å›a dynasty of ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura and

the reign of MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta (c. ad 590â€“650) see Bakker 1994b; above, pp. 235 ff.

22 My edition of this inscription in Bakker 2000 was based, in addition to Raykwar and Singhâ€™s edition of 1994, on a draft of a new edition by Ajay Mitra Shastri (Nagpur), which was published in 2001 (cf. Shastri 1995 II, 380 f.). Since then the original edition of Raykwar & Singh has been republished in Raykwar & Singh 2005, 188â€“192. The inscription was again edited by Susmita Majumdar in 2007. This set of three plates of copper is presently in the collection of Shri Raghunandan Prasad Pandeya (Raykwar & Singh 2005, 188; Majumdar 2007, 285). Shastri, unlike Raykwar and Singh, worked from photographs. Majumdar saw the plates herself and made use of photographs provided by Rahul Kumar Singh (Majumdar 2007, 293 n. 1). The text starts on the verso side of the first plate and comprises altogether 40 lines.

23 I consider musula/ mausula to be a variant of musala/ mausala. Cf. RÂ¯

amakan

. t.haâ€™s intro-

duction to Mata Ë™

nga 1.1.1 (p. 2) reading: lÂ¯

akulamausalÂ¯

adibhyah

. . That we are concerned

with an ancient historic tradition seems to be confirmed by grafitti found in the caves at Padan

. a Hill (Bombay), reading: sadhamusala ( siddhamusala), and twice musaladatta.

See Indraji 1881â€“82; Bakker 1991, 23; Bisschop 2006, 47. The site has been destroyed by building developments.

asamund tahsil of the Raipur

District), and T(Â¯

u)lapadraka may have been a suburb of this locality.â€™ Their names seem to indicate villages where cotton ( tÂ¯

ula) was cultivated and stored.

âˆ—âˆ— Singh, Shastri and Majumdar read mÂ¯apuâ—¦.

âˆ—âˆ—âˆ— Singh, Shastri and Majumdar read: mahÂ¯avratena. The emendation mahÂ¯avrate tena (haplography) in Bakker 2000 was proposed by H. Isaacson. In Bakker 2014, 144 this emendation has been again rejected.

âˆ—âˆ—âˆ—âˆ— Majumdar reads mugalisas; Singh and Shastri: â€˜ mugalisas (?)â€™. Mugalisa may be a variant/prakritism of MudgalÂ¯Ä±Å›a or MusalÂ¯Ä±Å›a.

âˆ—âˆ—âˆ—âˆ—âˆ— In Bakker 2014, 144 I have followed Majumdarâ€™s emendation: sthÂ¯anaguruâ—¦.

Translation

Let it be known to you thatâ€”after we have earlier asked permission of the VÂ¯

ajasaneya branch (of the White Yajurveda) and have given the village 24 Critical edition based on Raykwar and Singh 1994 (Bakker 2000).

Cf. Shastri 2001;

Majumdar 2007, 292; Bakker 2014, 143 f.

13 / SomaÅ›arman, Somavam

. Å›a and SomasiddhÂ¯

anta

291

BhÂ¯

an.d.Â¯agÂ¯ara-Tulapadraka in the district of On.Â¯Ä± in returnâ€”this village (scil.

PÂ¯

aÅ›ipadraka) together with Kurapadraka, along with the rights to hidden treasures and deposits, the right to collect all taxes, immunity from all impositions, the right to impose fines for the ten offences, and the exemption from being entered by officials and constables, starting immediately, has been bestowed by us here and now, on the day of full moon of MÂ¯

agha (?) with

the offering of a libation and by (this) copperplate charter, upon the feet of the illustrious BhÂ¯Ä±masoma, for the increase of merit of father, mother and ourselves and to be enjoyed as long as moon, stars and sun will last: There are eight embodiments of Åšiva, the VigraheÅ›varas; the embodiments of GahaneÅ›a are the sixty-six Rudras who bestow grace (initiation) and who roam about in successive yugas. Now the Kali Age has come and LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›anÂ¯

atha has

descended. He was born in the family of a brahmin named SomaÅ›arman; after having been initiated by him (i.e. SomaÅ›arman) in the Great Vow he became a moon on earth. 25

And he again (i.e. LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›anÂ¯

atha) initiated Mugalisa.

Then, in due succession of the lineage that started with Soma (â€˜the Moonâ€™), the afore-mentioned BhÂ¯Ä±masomaâ€”the pupil of the illustrious Tejasoma and grand-pupil of the illustrious guru Rudrasoma 26 â€”has been (justly) raised to the position responsible for the protection of the tapovana attached to the BÂ¯

aleÅ›vara-bhat.t.Â¯araka (Temple), which has been erected by ourselves. The donation is made to meet the expenses of ceremonies, initiations, teaching and housing of pupils and grand-pupils and to restore the shrines that have fallen into decay and are in need of repair.

Interpretation

The inscription is of paramount importance for more than one reason. One of them is that, in addition to the lineage of preceptors, it gives doctrinal arguments to legitimize the claims of the recipient BhÂ¯Ä±masoma. These doctrinal arguments should be compared with what we know of PÂ¯

aÅ›upata theology. In

order to follow the param

. parÂ¯

a of teachers back to Åšiva himself, the text refers first to the latterâ€™s eight forms that are designated â€˜VigraheÅ›varasâ€™. As we have seen above, VigraheÅ›vara is, according to one tradition, 27 the name of the deity who stands at the apex of our cosmos, in the granthi, where it borders on the Pure Universe. There he is surrounded by eight Rudras, four of whom bear names that mark the As.t.amÂ¯urti according to Kaus.Â¯Ä±taki BrÂ¯ahman.a 6.2â€“3. Just 25 Having reconsidered the issue, I have accepted the reading of the epigraph in my 2014

publication, against the emendation accepted in Bakker 2000 (reproduced here). This has led to a new interpretation in Bakker 2014, 144:

Consecrated by the Great Vow (MahÂ¯

avrata), He (i.e. LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›anÂ¯

atha) became a â€˜Moon

on Earthâ€™ (Jagadindu). By Him again Mugalisa [was initiated].

26 If we follow Majumdarâ€™s emendation we should translate: â€˜the illustrious SthÂ¯

anaguru

Rudrasomaâ€™.

27 This seems to be the tradition of the Åšaiva SiddhÂ¯

anta as represented by the NiÅ›vÂ¯

asa-

mukha and the Mata Ë™

nga (see above p. 285).

like Rudra, the (grand)son of PrajÂ¯

apati, through his eight forms, is the actual

manifestation of God in the created cosmos, sometimes represented as the divine child, 28 so, it seems, is Åšiva in his eightfold form of VigraheÅ›vara (â€˜the Lord of Formâ€™) considered the fountain-head of our universe in the theology underlying the inscription at issue. Then the inscription mentions GahaneÅ›a (â€˜the Lord of the Abyssâ€™), the Rudra who rules the lowest world of the MÂ¯

ayÂ¯

a

Reality in the sub-barrier layer, directly above the â€˜abyssâ€™ or â€˜net of bondsâ€™, the material world. He is said to roam about in sixty-six embodiments in successive yugas and LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a is just the last of these incarnations in the present Kaliyuga.

In a letter already mentioned (see above, n. 7 on p. 285) Professor Alexis Sanderson brought an unpublished text to my notice, the JayadrathayÂ¯

amala

(JRY), which belongs to the (later) Bhairava scriptures of Agamic Saivism.

Sanderson kindly placed at my disposal a portion of the edition he made of this text (4.449â€“460), based on a ms in the National Archives in Kathmandu.29

He drew my attention to the fact that this text describes the sixty-six embodiments as â€˜the Bhavas who reside in the sixty-six MÂ¯

ana (i.e. PramÂ¯

an.a)

[worlds]â€™. 30 These embodiments or manifestations are divided into two lines of gurus ( gurupa Ë™nktis), a set of twenty-eight Åšivas and one of thirty-eight Rudras, which are associated with different levels of Åšaiva teaching. The first set, which begins with Åšveta and of which the last two gurus are SomeÅ›a and LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a, is said to bestow both exegesis of the scriptures and, occasionally, initiation, following the division of the PramÂ¯

an.ajËœnÂ¯ana.31 The second line of thirty-eight

Rudras, which begins with VareÅ›vara and ends with Vas.at.kÂ¯ara, is said to be authorized to granting initiation and is described as propounding the teachings of Bhairava. 32 It may be that the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata ascetic UdbhavarÂ¯

13 / SomaÅ›arman, Somavam

. Å›a and SomasiddhÂ¯

anta

293

from an inscription from the GandharveÅ›a Temple in Sirpur (ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura) (c. ad 600), claimed to belong to this lineage, since he is explicitly called a Rudra (see below, p. 532).

There can be little doubt that the inscription at issue in mentioning the sixty-six Rudra manifestations descending from GahaneÅ›a, â€˜who roam about in successive yugas to bestow grace (initiation)â€™, refers to the doctrine mentioned in the JayadrathayÂ¯

amala. This is again reinforced by the fact that the last two of the twenty-eight Åšiva manifestations, SomeÅ›a and LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a also figure prominently in the inscription. 33 To SomeÅ›a or SomaÅ›arman, as he is called in the inscription, we will return below.

LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›anÂ¯

atha, unlike SomaÅ›arman, is explicitly said in the inscription to be an avatÂ¯

ara and through him the lineage of the donee BhÂ¯Ä±masoma is directly connected with the divine (Rudra) param

. parÂ¯

a: GahaneÅ›a, VigraheÅ›vara, Åšiva.

BhÂ¯Ä±masomaâ€™s lineage, namely, is said to stem from LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a through the latterâ€™s pupil Mugalisa, who was initiated by the â€˜Moon on Earthâ€™, LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a, and whom we have identified with Musula or Musulendra, the founder of the Mausula sect.

If this identification is right, the conclusion would be natural that the lineage of BhÂ¯Ä±masoma belonged to the sect of the Mausulas, who, as we have seen, probably acknowledged the theology of an hierarchy of Rudra worlds, which plays such an important role in the inscription.

SomaÅ›arman and the SomasiddhÂ¯

anta

Here, however, we encounter a difficulty. Though BhÂ¯Ä±masoma and his predecessors no doubt belonged to the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata fold, the designation â€˜Mausulaâ€™ does

not occur in the inscription. With the Mausulas these Â¯

acÂ¯

aryas may have in

common, it would seem, that they were engaged with ceremonies ( kriyÂ¯

a) and

worship rather than with ascetic practices, though they were in charge of the tapovana attached to the BÂ¯

aleÅ›vara-bhat.t.Â¯araka Temple in ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura. But how

do we explain that their names end in soma? On account of these names I have argued (Bakker 2000a, 1159) that these Â¯

acÂ¯

aryas probably belonged to the

PÂ¯

aÅ›upata sect known as SomasiddhÂ¯

anta, a sect that hardly, if at all, features in

Agamic literature where it is concerned with the AtimÂ¯

arga, but which in later

sources is often equated with the KÂ¯

apÂ¯

alikas. 34 PÂ¯

aÅ›upata ascetics whose names

â€˜Åšivasâ€™.

end in soma are known from several inscriptions in which they are said to be engaged in the MahÂ¯

PurÂ¯

an.as describe him as the 27th incarnation of Åšiva, born in PrabhÂ¯asatÂ¯Ä±rtha, a holy place in Saurashtra near the Arabian Sea, famous for its SomanÂ¯

atha

Temple, an assignment that makes the impression of being secondary. 36 The legend told in the Malhar Plates, however, is apparently somewhat different.

It says that LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›anÂ¯

atha was born in the brahmin family of SomaÅ›arman,

who therefore may have been a senior contemporary of his. Moreover, LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a is said to have been initiated by this SomaÅ›arman in the MahÂ¯

avrata and so

became the â€˜Moon on Earthâ€™. 37

SomaÅ›arman and his family ( kula) thus appear, in the religious imagination of the believer, to have been the House ( Â´

sarman) from which the Moon ( soma)

rose over the world ( jagadindu). The play of words may allude to â€˜Somaâ€™ as a name of Åšiva and the transfiguration undergone by LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a in the initiation ritual, which, when he underwent the anointment with ashes, made him shine like the moon.

SomaÅ›arman in the Kali Age and he and his family are said to have been the first ones blessed with LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›aâ€™s grace; the text apparently implies that the latter was born in SomaÅ›armanâ€™s, i.e., Atriâ€™s House.

The spot

where the incarnation took place is called KÂ¯

arohan.a.38 The relevant passage

reads:

And God, the Lord of the gods, who is possessed of supreme sovereignty, after having assumed a white-bodied form (i.e. a body like that of the moon), went to the auspicious House of Atri, (that is to say, he went to the house of a man) named SomaÅ›arman, who was born in the lineage of Atri. . kara,

blessed/initiated that brahman-knowing brahmin belonging to Atriâ€™s lineage together with his (whole) family by bestowing upon him perfection in yoga. Thereupon, after he had initiated this excellent brahmin and his family, O VyÂ¯

asa, God

went to UjjayanÂ¯Ä± (Ujjain) and entered the cremation ground.

There the bull-

bannered God took a bath in ashes, took a torch in his left hand and sat down (in meditation). 39

argya, Mitra and a fourth person who is only

agud.i, taught them his own doctrine ( svasiddhÂ¯anta), known as â€˜PaËœncÂ¯arthaâ€™, which, as the SkandapurÂ¯
