SomaÅ›arman, Somavam

. Å›a and SomasiddhÂ¯

anta

When we return to the JunvÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± inscription and combine its evidence with that

of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, we may say that there evidently was a tradition within the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata fold that recognized a, what we may call â€˜PÂ¯

aÅ›upata milieuâ€™ be-

fore the appearance of LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a.

SomaÅ›arman belonged to this milieu.

In

the PÂ¯

aËœ

ncÂ¯

arthika-PÂ¯

aÅ›upata context he was mostly either ignored, or relegated to a previous yuga by being promoted to an avatÂ¯

ara of Åšiva himself. Both

our sources, however, the inscription and the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, emphasize that,

though they recognize SomaÅ›arman as a patriarch, SomaÅ›arman is not an incarnation, and he or his tradition derived legitimacy only from the belief that LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a was born in or resorted to his House. According to the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a,

SomaÅ›arman himself was favoured with initiation by LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a, according to the inscription it was the other way round, 42 but, the inscription adds, the lineage of BhÂ¯Ä±masoma, received its â€˜certificate of divinityâ€™ through Mugalisa, who was initiated by the incarnated Åšiva himself.

The combined evidence of both sources thus seems to suggest that there existed an early Åšaiva tradition that, on the one hand, recognized the uniqueness of LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›aâ€™s incarnation, but that, on the other hand, distanced itself from the PÂ¯

aËœ

ncÂ¯

arthika and LÂ¯

akula divisions. In its initial stage this tradition, or one strand of it, may have been named after its putative preceptor: â€˜Mausulaâ€™. In the course of time other groups may have been assimilated, and gradually a distinct theology and praxis may have been developed, which became known as the SomasiddhÂ¯

anta, thus preserving a reference to a distant saint who was hallowed as its founder, SomaÅ›arman. Part of this tradition, again, may eventually have merged with groups that produced the Bhairava texts such as the JayadrathayÂ¯

amala, that is to say, became indistinguishable from the KÂ¯

apÂ¯

alikas. 43

Others may have joined the Åšaiva SiddhÂ¯

anta, of which a mat.hikÂ¯a was attached

to the very same temple complex of BÂ¯

aleÅ›vara-bhat.t.Â¯araka in ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura.44

42 This clause is no longer valid according my 2014 interpretation; above, p. 290.

43 Sanderson 1988, 668.

44 A hoard of nine copperplate grants of MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta BÂ¯

alÂ¯

arjuna was found in Sirpur

(Shastri 1995 II, 376â€“379; see also Shastri 1992a and Shastri 2001). These nine charters have been edited and published by Rahul Kumar Singh in Raykwar & Singh 2005, 196â€“217. It appears that in this Sirpur hoard there are altogether seven charters that record grants made to Åšaiva Â¯

acÂ¯

aryas said to issue from Nandapura, but who were living in this mat.hikÂ¯a in ÅšrÂ¯Ä±pura. The lineage of these Â¯

acÂ¯

aryas should therefore been seen

as a subbranch of the Nandapur one; it can be reconstructed from these grants: 1)

Â´

saivÂ¯

acÂ¯

apaÅ›iva, and 4)

sthÂ¯

anaguru AstraÅ›iva. All the donations were made to meet the expenses on repairs, daily worship and musical performances.

From these inscriptions and the names of

the Åšaiva Â¯

acÂ¯

aryas ending in Â´

siva it becomes clear that the Åšaiva SiddhÂ¯

anta was firmly

established in Daks.in.a Kosala, at least from the second half of the 6th century onwards.

The original headquarters may have been in Nandapura, a place not properly identified, but probably an administrative division within the PÂ¯

an

. d

. ava Kingdom. The charters of

the Sirpur hoard and their significance for our understanding of the BÂ¯

aleÅ›vara-bhat.t.Â¯araka

Temple complex in Sirpur have been evaluated in Bosma 2018, 75â€“87.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

13 / SomaÅ›arman, Somavam

. Å›a and SomasiddhÂ¯

anta

297

The SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a goes a step further in its mystification of the origins by affiliating SomaÅ›arman to the lineage of Atri, the father of the Moon, that is to the Lunar Race, the Somavam

. Å›a. 45 There are indications that this powerful

symbolism was not lost on the rulers of Daks.in.a Kosala. It can hardly be coincidence that the JunvÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä± inscription is a charter issued by a king who

proclaims to belong to the Somavam

. Å›a. 46 After the theological and legendary

superstructure, the actual param

. parÂ¯

a of BhÂ¯Ä±masoma is said to begin with Soma,

thus creating, possibly intentionally, a profound ambiguity: Soma who? Soma that is Åšiva, Soma that is the son of Atri, the Moon, Soma that is SomaÅ›arman, Soma that is Jagadindu (i.e. LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›anÂ¯

atha), or just a preceptor named Soma

who lived long after the times of LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a and Mugalisa, but who happened to start a tradition of ascetic teachers within the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata fold?

The intimate relationship of the royal Soma dynasty with this particular branch of PÂ¯

aÅ›upatas may thus have been endorsed by an ideology according to which both claimed descent from Somaâ€”the dynastic one from Soma, the son of Atri, the sectarian one from the â€˜Moon on Earthâ€™ that appeared in the family of SomaÅ›arman, that is in the House of the Moon. This House may therefore have been conceived by the mythmakers of the time as the joint cradle of two lineages: a worldly one culminating in MahÂ¯

aÅ›ivagupta, the Somavam

. Å›in king

of Kosala, and a religious one headed by BhÂ¯Ä±masoma, an Â¯

acÂ¯

arya living in the

temple complex founded and patronized by his royal counterpart.

45 That this tradition was not completely obliterated in later centuries, but locally survived well into the second millennium is shown by the KÂ¯

aravan

. amÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya. This late text sings

the greatness of the KÂ¯

arohan

A Theatre of Broken Dreamsâˆ—

VidiÅ›Â¯

a in the Days of Gupta Hegemony

Prologue

In his monumental Geschichte Indiens Hermann Kulke depicts the relationship between the Gupta and VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka dynasties as basically an unproblematic

one, an alliance that was dominated by the Guptas and secured a peaceful coexistence till their fall.

Vermutlich in der Phase der Vorbereitung seines Krieges gegen die Kshatrapa gab dann aber Candragupta seine Tochter dem KÃ¶nig Rudrasena II. zur Ehe, um den RÃ¼cken fÃ¼r seinen Kampf im Westen frei zu haben. Rudrasena starb jedoch schon nach fÃ¼nfjÃ¤hriger Regierung etwa im Jahre 390 n. Chr. Auf Candraguptas Rat hin Ã¼bernahm daraufhin seine Tochter Prabhavatigupta die Regentschaft fÃ¼r ihre SÃ¶hne. WÃ¤hrend ihrer etwa zwanzigjÃ¤hrigen Regentschaft geriet das Vakataka-Reich zunehmend unter direkten einfluÃŸ der Gupta und gehÃ¶rte de facto bald zu deren Reichsverband. Zwar wurde die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit der Vakatakas unter Pravarasena II. (ca. 410 bis 440 n. Chr.), von dem eine groÃŸe Zahl Inschriften bekannt ist, wiederhergestellt. Doch hatte das Reich der Vakatakas aufgehÃ¶rt, eine potentielle Bedrohung fÃ¼r die Guptas zu sein. Bis zum Untergang der Guptas bestanden statt dessen Ã¼beraus enge Beziehungen zwischen beiden Reichen, so daÃŸ man in der Geschichtsschreibung bisweilen sogar vom Vakataka-Gupta-Zeitalter spricht. Diese engen Beziehungen trugen wesentlich zur Ausbreitung der Gupta-Kultur nach Zentralindien bei. (Kulke 1998, 114)

This representation (including the chronology) reaches back to a powerful, historical theory set forth by A.S. Altekar in a book which he edited together with R.C. Majumdar and which was first published in 1960 under the title The VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akaâ€“Gupta Age. The evidence that has come to light in the last forty years justifies a reassessment of it. In Religion and Politics in the Eastern VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka Kingdom (Bakker 2002) I investigated the actual lines along which Gupta culture reached the Deccan and how Gupta examples of religious and artistic expression informed those of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas. This study has confirmed

the last quoted statement of Hermann Kulke to the effect that the close relations between both kingdoms significantly contributed to a process of acculturation.

âˆ— The first version of this article was published as Chapter 9 of: Brandtner, Martin

& Shishir Kumar Panda (eds.), Interrogating History.

Essays for Hermann Kulke.

Manohar, Delhi 2006. pp. 165â€“87.

301

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

302

Hans Bakker

The historical question that should next be investigated is for how long, and in which way, these close relations prevailed between both kingdoms. Did they really last till the fall of the Guptas? We shall try to answer this question in the following pages as a tribute to the great historian. We shall focus in particular on Eastern Malwa and its capital VidiÅ›Â¯

a, since this appears to have been the

theatre in which aspirations to the Gupta throne were fostered and shattered and in which VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka presence made itself most expressly felt.

Act 1

RÂ¯

amagupta

In our reappraisal of the historic image sketched above, we may start on the war of Candragupta II with the Ks.atrapas or Åšakas. Candraguptaâ€™s father, Samudragupta, had extended his home territoryâ€”to be located along the Ganges, around KauÅ›Â¯

ambÂ¯Ä±-PrayÂ¯

aga, with SÂ¯

aketa (present AyodhyÂ¯

a) in the north and

PÂ¯

at.aliputra (present Patna) in the eastâ€”towards the west by subduing i.a.

the NÂ¯

aga kingdom and its capital PadmÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± (modern Pawaya), a kingdom or

confederacy which seems to have comprised local NÂ¯

aga families ruling from the

cities of KÂ¯

antipurÂ¯Ä± (modern Kutwar) and VidiÅ›Â¯

a (modern Besnagar). 1 The

confederacy, if that it was, may have been led by the king of PadmÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±,

Gan.apatinÂ¯aga, who, according to the famous Allahabad Pillar Inscription, was forcefully dethroned ( prasabhoddharan

. a). 2 The three NÂ¯

aga cities, KÂ¯

antipurÂ¯Ä±

to the North and VidiÅ›Â¯

a to the South of PadmÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±, mark roughly the broad

stroke of land to the West of Bundelkhand, south of the Chambal River and north of the NarmadÂ¯

a. The southern part of this country includes the northeastern Malwa Plateau, the fertile land around VidiÅ›Â¯

a known as DaÅ›Â¯

arn.a; its

western frontier borders on the central Malwa Plateau with its capital UjjayinÂ¯Ä± (Ujjain). This plateau, which came to be called (Western) Malwa, was apparently not annexed by Samudragupta to his kingdom. Behind the tribes of the MÂ¯

alavas, Â¯

ArjunÂ¯

ayanas, and Yaudheyas, listed in the Allahabad Inscription and said to be ruled by tributary â€˜frontier-kingsâ€™ ( pratyantanr.pati), loomed a more formidable enemy, the Åšaka king, probably mahÂ¯

aks.atrapa Rudrasena III, who

in the same inscription is said to have acknowledged Samudragupta by paying his respect (â—¦ sevÂ¯

akr.taâ—¦). The city of VidiÅ›Â¯a thus appears to have been some sort of a frontier town by the end of Samudraguptaâ€™s reign and this may partly explain the great importance attached to control over it and the surrounding country throughout the rest of Gupta history.

1 Trivedi 1957, xxxiiiâ€“xxxviii.

2 CII III (1888), 7. Many coins of Gan

. apati (Gan

. apatÂ¯Ä±ndra, Gan

. endra) have been found

in Pawaya (Trivedi 1957, 5â€™, xxii-xxiii, 49â€“54). The Hars.acarita (ed. Kane p. 50 ll. 18 f.) mentions as the ruler of PadmÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± that was killed NÂ¯

agasena (who also figures in the

Allahabad Inscription), but so far no coins of him have been found. Cf. Bakker 1997, 10 f.

14 / A Theatre of Broken Dreams

303

It is very much probable that the MahÂ¯

aks.atrapa was little pleased with his

subordinate status and his disaffection may have led to a military campaign when he judged the situation to be most favourable, that is, directly before or after Samudraguptaâ€™s death in c. ad 376. That such a campaign and the ensuing Guptaâ€“Åšaka war(s) took place we only know from circumstantial evidence. More than 250 years later a general of Hars.aâ€™s army narrates in BÂ¯an.aâ€™s Hars.acarita the treachery and intrigue that befell earlier kings, among which the renowned act of Candragupta who â€˜cut down the lord of the Åšakas, who desired another manâ€™s wife, by disguising himself in her dressâ€™. 3 Rather than remembering an historical event, BÂ¯

an.a may have discussed what was known to

him from a play, written only a few decades before by a dramatist at the court of one of Hars.aâ€™s predecesors (the Maukhari king Avantivarman), namely the DevÂ¯Ä±candragupta of ViÅ›Â¯

akhadatta. 4

The story of the DevÂ¯Ä±candragupta

The reconstruction of events directly after Samudraguptaâ€™s death almost fully depends on an historical assessment of this play, which itself, unfortunately, is lost, but which has been reconstructed from quoted fragments and brief references to it in other sources (among which the Hars.acarita). This reconstruction, admirably carried out by V. Raghavan (1963, 858â€“80), and discussed by many scholars (e.g. Warder 1989â€“92 III, 260â€“64), may be briefly summerized as follows.

A Gupta rÂ¯

aja, named RÂ¯

ama, is threatened in his military camp by a ruler

( pati) of the Åšakas. He is forced to surrender his wife DhruvadevÂ¯Ä± to the Åšaka ruler. His younger brother ( kumÂ¯

ara), called Candra, is unable to

accept the disgrace and resorts to a ruse to kill the Åšaka chief. In the disguise of the queen he enters the camp of the enemy and kills the Åšaka.

This act of boldness ( sÂ¯

ahasa) earns him the title SÂ¯

ahasÂ¯

a Ë™nka. For reasons

unknown Candra, after his heroic deed, seems to be in danger again, which this time is coming from within the Gupta camp. He resorts to feigning madness. The end of the play is not known.

The main characters of this play are known as historical persons: RÂ¯

amagupta,

his (younger) brother Candragupta, the latterâ€™s wife DhruvadevÂ¯Ä±, and the Åšakapati, not mentioned by name, but who may have been thought to be Rudrasena III. The play thus seems to have an unusually high historic profile.

3 Hars.acarita UcchvÂ¯

asa 6 p. 51 ll. 10 f.: aripure ca parakalatrakÂ¯

saguptaÂ´

aks.asa) in some MSS of another of

ViÅ›Â¯

arÂ¯

aâ€™ instead (discussion by Dhruva in

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

304

Hans Bakker

The historical assessment is complicated by two allusions made in RÂ¯

as.t.rakÂ¯ut.a inscriptions dating from ad 871 and 933. The praÅ›astis of the kings Amoghavars.a I and Govinda IV seek to elevate their protagonists by comparing their deeds with the miserable behaviour of the foremost of the Gupta dynasty. The two verses run as follows.

After killing his brother, he took (his) kingdom and (his) wife; even so the wretch had recorded surely, a thousand billion times, in the Kali Age: â€˜A member of the Gupta family, he is the donor.â€™ The man (on the other hand), who gave his kingdom away more than once, a trifling thing (for him)â€”not to mention (other) external objectsâ€”he blushed, when merely the report went that their donor was the exalted ornament of the RÂ¯

as.t.rakÂ¯ut.a dynasty (i.e. Amoghavars.a).5

Though it was within his power, neither did he contrive outrageous cruelty against his elder brother, nor did he (ever) bring shame (upon himself) by despicable acts such as sleeping with the wife of his next of kin, nor did he betake himself out of fear to demoniac behaviour, irrespective of the holy and unholy alikeâ€”by liberality and unequalled acts of boldness that (king Govinda) became on earth a (true)

â€˜man-marked-by-boldnessâ€™ (SÂ¯

ahasÂ¯

a Ë™nka). 6

To go by these verses, Candragupta not only killed the Åšakapati and then feigned madness, but he killed his brother RÂ¯

amagupta as well, took his wife,

and usurped the throne. There is nothing in ViÅ›Â¯

akhadattaâ€™s play that suggests

that its hero Candra in the last, lost act turned into such a villain all at once; or as Warder remarks:

As for ViÅ›Â¯

akhadatta, it would seem to have been very difficult to have concluded his play with such an action by his hero. He surely arranged the plot in such a way as to free Candra from guilt. 7

Though the praÂ´

sastis are of course specimina of blatant propaganda couched in poetry, it is equally difficult to imagine that the two Deccan kings actually invented such disgraceful acts altogether. In view of what was at stake at this crucial junction, viz. the preservation of the paternal heritage established at great costs, and in the light of similar events later in the Gupta history that we are going to discuss, it seems not wholy unlikely that the RÂ¯

as.t.rakÂ¯ut.a kings

14 / A Theatre of Broken Dreams

305

did actually divulge an historic stain on the otherwise so glorious reputation of the Gupta dynasty. That RÂ¯

amagupta ruled for a short period is undeniable.

Candraguptaâ€™s chief wife was called DhruvadevÂ¯Ä±, and her husband became master over the Gupta Empire, including not only VidiÅ›Â¯

a, but, eventually, also the

realm of the Åšaka kings.

There is therefore every appearance that Samudraguptaâ€™s old age or death initiated a struggle for power in which at first the elder son, RÂ¯

amagupta, who

as a viceroy might have been in charge of his fatherâ€™s troups at the western frontier, was on top. To mark his position and to finance it he had begun issuing his own coinage, for which he used the local mints that earlier struck the copper coins of the NÂ¯

aga kings. 8 RÂ¯

amagupta did not succeed, however, in

extending his control over the whole of the Gupta kingdom. As Ellen Raven (1994a, 163 n. 4.66) remarks: â€˜Perhaps the copper coins of King RÂ¯

amagupta

also belong to the imperial currency, but the lay-out of their devices does not support such an attribution.â€™ The imperial mints still beyond his reach, at home, in his own power base VidiÅ›Â¯

a, RÂ¯

amagupta could adorn himself with

the grand titles to which he claimed the right. MahÂ¯

arÂ¯

ajÂ¯

adhirÂ¯

ajaÂ´

srÂ¯Ä±rÂ¯

amagupta

was engraved on the pedestals of three Jaina images found in the village of Durjanpura in Vidisha District, 2 miles from Besnagar, proclaiming that these three images were ordered ( kÂ¯

arita) by the â€˜emperorâ€™ himself. 9

Candraguptaâ€™s matrimonial policy and the triangle of power The failure on the part of RÂ¯

amagupta to consolidate his power may have been

caused by adverse developments in his war against the Åšakas. As the drama DevÂ¯Ä±candragupta and references to it suggest, Candraguptaâ€™s coup dâ€™Ã©tat followed after he had rescued the course of the Guptas. Subsequently, in addition to silver and copper coins minted locally in Malwa, Candragupta, as has been suggested, 10 began issuing his so-called Lion-slayer Type of imperial gold coins 8 Bajpai 1992, 84: â€˜The excavations at Vidisha, conducted by the ASI have also brought to light copper coins of RÂ¯

amagupta, similar in size and fabric to the Eran

. coins of that ruler.

. . . After the conquest of the NÂ¯

aga territories and after the death of Samudragupta, coins of RÂ¯

amagupta were struck in mints of the region previously occupied by the NÂ¯

agas.â€™

9 Gai 1969. Mirashi 1982b. The three inscriptions on the pedestals read basically the same:

bhagavato hâ€™i rhatah

. pus.padantasya [image A & C: candraprabhasya] pratimeyam

It seems that image B (or C) served as an exemplar for the image A, because the irregular sam

. dhi between rÂ¯

amaguptena upadeÂ´

sÂ¯

at is explained by B, where these words are separated by an image of a cakra; similar the irregular sam

. dhi between praÂ´

sis.ya-Â¯acÂ¯arya in A can be

explained by the assumption (but the text has been erased here) that in B the word Â¯

acÂ¯

was written on a new line. The reading in A candraks.amÂ¯acÂ¯arya seems haplography of reading in B: candraks.aman.Â¯acÂ¯arya. For a translation and discussion of these lines see below, p. 321.

10 Majumdar 1954, 22. Cf. Raven 1994a I, 48 f., n. 2.125.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

306

Hans Bakker

to commemorate this victory, though this remains highly conjectural.

If

Candragupta thus appeared successful where RÂ¯

amagupta failed, this may have

had to do with the greater political skills of the former. Candragupta was in a better position to hold on to the enemies defeated by his father, because he was married to one of their princesses, KuberanÂ¯

agÂ¯

a, on whom he confered the

title of mahÂ¯

adevÂ¯Ä±. 11 These NÂ¯

agas remained a local force to be reckoned with,

despite their subjugation, and their help against their former arch-enemies, the Åšakas, may have been a decisive factor. The same political skill, namely to turn old enmities into effective alliances through matrimony, was again displayed by Candragupta when he, after he had consolidated his power, married off his own daughter by his NÂ¯

aga wife to the house of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas,

another old enemy of his father.

The marriage between Candraguptaâ€™s

daughter PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a and Rudrasena II took place around ad 388.12 It

seems plausible that especially Candraguptaâ€™s relation with the NÂ¯

agas through

his wife secured him victory over the Åšakas at long last, whereas his alliance with the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas may have provided the necessary backing, as has been argued by Kulke. 13 This alliance may be viewed as a display of strength rather than of weakness. It not only established family ties between the Guptas and the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas, but also tied together the VÂ¯akÂ¯at.akas and the NÂ¯agas. In all her inscriptions PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± took great pride in her Gupta and NÂ¯

aga ancestry. 14

In this way came into being the geopolitical triangle that would determine the ramifications of power in the Gupta Empire during the greater part of the fifth century: 1) the Gupta homeland along the Ganges (centring on KauÅ›Â¯

ambÂ¯Ä±â€“PrayÂ¯

aga), 2) the strategic southern part of the homeland of the NÂ¯

aga dynasty (the area around VidiÅ›Â¯

a), 3) Vidarbha to the south of the Nar-

madÂ¯

a, across the Satpura Range (centring on Nandivardhana, residence of the Eastern VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas).

11 Bakker 1997, 11 f. Below, n. 14 on p. 306.

12 Bakker 1997, 16.

13 Jain 1972, 236:

The great success achieved by the Gupta emperor is indirectly attested to by his coins. The long series of coins testifying to the almost unbroken rule of the Western Kshatrapas, for more than three hundred years, comes to an end between 388 and 397 ad, and is replaced by the coin of a similar design, issued by Candragupta II. The earliest silver coins of Candragupta are of the year 409 ad, issued to replace the coins of the Western Kshatrapas in Malwa.

It would thus appear that Candragupta did not deal the final blow to the Åšakas before the middle of the first decade of the 5th century. This is indirectly confirmed by the late date by which Candragupta established his authority over Mandasor (see below, n. 17

on p. 308).

14 / A Theatre of Broken Dreams

307

Act 2

Govindagupta

Candragupta, thus in charge of the greater part of northern India, appointed another viceroy ( mahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja) in VidiÅ›Â¯

a to succeed RÂ¯

amagupta. There may have

been several viceroys during his reign about whom we do not possess any information at all, but it seems likely that MahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja Govindagupta, son by his chief

queen DhruvadevÂ¯Ä±, was prominent among them. Govindagupta is known from a clay seal of DhruvasvÂ¯

aminÂ¯Ä± found from VaiÅ›Â¯

alÂ¯Ä± which reads: â€˜The illustrious

MahÂ¯

adevÂ¯Ä± DhruvasvÂ¯

aminÂ¯Ä±, wife of the illustrious emperor Candragupta and mother of the illustrious MahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja Govindagupta.â€™ 15 The title mahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja may

designate the status of governor or viceroy, whereas the fact that the queen-mother mentions him explicitly on her seal seems to suggest that he might even have been heir-apparent.

The testimony of PrabhÂ¯

akara

And there is more evidence. An inscription of a feudatory chieftain ( bhÂ¯

umipati)

of Skandagupta, PrabhÂ¯

akara, found in DaÅ›apura (modern Mandasor) in west-

ern Malwa (dating from ad 467/68), makes it probable that Govinda was governor of the western division of Candraguptaâ€™s empire, i.e. Malwa. The Mandasor Inscription of MÂ¯

alava Sam

. vat 524 reports:

There was a king that resembled the moon ( candra) in the firmament of the Gupta lineage by the renowned name of ÅšrÂ¯Ä± Candragupta; he captured the eyes of the people like the rising moon. After he had snatched away from (many local) princes ( pati) their kingship over the earth by brilliant and powerful means, he ensnared the earth with the help of members of his own dynasty; until today it has not yet liberated itself (from these bonds). That Lord of the Earth (i.e. Candragupta), the majesty of whose virtues resembled that of Govinda (i.e. Kr.s.n.a), begat a son who well-deserved the name of Govindagupta and who equaled the sons of Diti and Aditi (i.e. the Asuras and Devas). When kings bowed their heads to his (i.e.

Govindaguptaâ€™s) lotusfeetâ€”their splendours sinking downâ€”even the Lord of the Gods (i.e. Indra), beset by doubts, ascended the swing of (fearful) deliberation. 16

The commander of Govindaâ€™s army that held these feudatory kings in check, the inscription tells us, was VÂ¯

ayuraks.ita. The chieftain PrabhÂ¯akara came to employ

308

Hans Bakker

his son Dattabhat.a as his general. There is something strange about this inscription. Its author explicitly pledges allegiance to the Gupta emperor, who, at PrabhÂ¯

akaraâ€™s time, was Skandagupta, and sings the praises of Candragupta and Govindagupta, but is silent on KumÂ¯

aragupta, Govindaguptaâ€™s brother. The in-

scription strongly suggests that the military services of VÂ¯

ayuraks.ita and his son

Dattabhat.a were not needed during the reign of KumÂ¯aragupta. Evidently the family fell into disgrace when KumÂ¯

aragupta established suzerainty. This is

corroborated by the fact that during KumÂ¯

araguptaâ€™s reign another feudatory

family was in charge of DaÅ›apura, viz. the Varmans or Early Aulikaras. 17 All this indicates that Candraguptaâ€™s succession had not been without a struggle.

The contender for the imperial throne had again been an elder brother, the viceroy of VidiÅ›Â¯

a, viz. Govindagupta. His general, VÂ¯

ayuraks.ita, thus turned

out to have been on the losing side.

The Mandasor Inscription, though prima facie loyal to Gupta rule, shows some ambiguities that might hint at PrabhÂ¯

akaraâ€™s uneasiness. First, in this

charter this prince speaks of the snares ( pÂ¯

aÂ´

sa) laid over the earth ( avapÂ¯

aÂ´

sita)

by the Guptas, from which it has not yet been able to free itself ( moks.am

.

samupaiti); on the lips of a feudatory, this has a dubious ring. Second, he tells us that Indra trembled at the sight of all the feudatories who bowed before Govindagupta. As has been suggested by Thaplyal (1972, 66), the allusion to Indraâ€™s (VibudhÂ¯

adhipa) fear, although a hyperbole not uncommon to this genre, may hint at KumÂ¯

aragupta, whose biruda is â€˜Mahendraâ€™. 18 The assumed war of succession may have taken place in ad 415-416,19 too short a period, it seems, for Govindagupta to issue his own coins. KumÂ¯

aragupta, on the other hand,

may have issued a special coin to commemorate his victory and to herald his

â€˜legitimateâ€™ ascension to the imperial throne: it showed him (anachronistically) as an invincible ( apratigha) youth blessed by his parents. 20

17 ViÅ›vavarman (MÂ¯

alava Era 480 (ad 424): CII III (1888), 72â€“78) and Bandhuvarman (MÂ¯

alava Era 493 (ad 437): CII III (1888), 79â€“88). This family reigned already in DaÅ›apura before it was annexed by Candragupta to his kingdom, as the earliest inscription of Naravarman seems to show: Mandasor Inscription of the Kr.ta Year 461 (ad 404-05). In this inscription no reference to Gupta rule is found and I doubt whether the epithet sim

n. 1).

14 / A Theatre of Broken Dreams

309

Plate 46

KumÂ¯

aragupta I: Apratigha Type gold coin

In view of the postulated geopolitical triangle, it might be asked what role Vidarbha played in this power struggle. KumÂ¯

araguptaâ€™s sister, PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±, ruled

as a regentess for her minor sons in Nandivardhana at the time. Unfortunately our sources do not allow us to say anything with certainty in this matter.

However, considering her close and peaceful relations with KumÂ¯

ara throughout

her life, one may speculate that PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± stood on his side and it is not

impossible that this may have contributed to his success. Her choice may have ensured that the local NÂ¯

agas in eastern Malwa too supported KumÂ¯

araguptaâ€™s

claim to the throne. That PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± and KumÂ¯

ara were two hands in one glove

may also be inferred from the following.

Act 3

Ghat

. otkacagupta

After he had ousted his brother Govinda, KumÂ¯

aragupta needed another viceroy

in VidiÅ›Â¯

a. Again it must be noted that there might have been viceroys during his reign of whom we do not possess any information at all, yet it is nearly certain that his younger brother, Ghat.otkacagupta, was a prominent one among specimens of the Archer Type. Considering the fact that there was a gradual increase in weight of the Gupta gold coins till the time of Skandagupta, the Apratigha Type of coins have to be the earliest issues of KumÂ¯

aragupta I.â€™ For another elaborate discussion

in favour and against this interpretation see also Raven 1994a I, 41â€“44. Though the Apratigha coins were issued after the death of Candragupta, his image on the coins served the imperial propaganda by proclaiming that the young prince was elected by his father (and mother) himself. When studying this type of coin in the collection of the British Museum (Allan 1914, No. 257), I noticed that the male figure to KumÂ¯

araâ€™s right,

presumably his father King Candragupta, with a gesture of his right hand shows him the Garud

. a standard; the female figure to the left, his mother, in a similar hand gesture shows a small, indistinct object between thumb and index-finger, which I think could be a signet-ring (Plate 46). Cf. Raven 2004â€“05. 83; below, n. 36 on p. 316.

them. This prince is known from the Tumain Inscription of KumÂ¯

aragupta and

Ghat.otkacagupta, G.E. 116, which reads as follows.

The son of the illustrious Candragupta, KumÂ¯

aragupta, well-nigh the great Indra

(Mahendra), protected the whole earth by holding her in his arms of power, as if she were his virtuous, lawful ( dharma) wife. [. . . ] white [. . . ], that moon ( candra) had risen by the name of Ghat.otkacagupta, encircled by a halo that is the array of his virtues, [. . . ] (illuminating?) the sky and the earth. This inscription, which records the foundation of a temple in Tumbavana (modern Tumain) by a group of five brothers headed by ÅšrÂ¯Ä±deva in the Gupta year 116 (ad 435-36), indicates that Ghat.otkacaâ€™s station was eastern Malwa, although, just as of Govindagupta, a seal bearing his name was recovered from VaiÅ›Â¯

alÂ¯Ä±. 22 The simile in which he is compared with another rising moon ( candra) suggests that Ghat.otkaca too was a son of Candragupta. This is confirmed by the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple Inscription from RÂ¯

amagiri:

At all times the conduct of this King ( deva) Candragupta, Lord of the three oceans, was perfect: the sovereign (gave) his daughter [i.e. Mun.d.Â¯a/PrabhÂ¯avatÂ¯Ä±] to the illustrious Rudrasena, (a mine of) virtues (9). 23

[ one verse lost (10)]

About this Ghat.otkaca the inscription says that,

14 / A Theatre of Broken Dreams

311

Ghat.otkaca must have been considerably younger than PrabhÂ¯avatÂ¯Ä±, since the inscription suggests he was born after his sisterâ€™s marriage to the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka

king. He therefore was a contemporary of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s children. When his

elder brother KumÂ¯

ara appointed him viceroy in VidiÅ›Â¯

a in ad 416 or slightly

later, he may have been about 25 years old. After the death of Rudrasena and Candragupta and Govindaâ€™s elimination, KumÂ¯

aragupta and his sister, the

dowager queen of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas, seized the opportunity to consolidate the

geopolitical triangle, on which their power was based. They agreed to marry PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s daughter, whose name may have been AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±, to their younger

brother Ghat.otkaca, viceroy of VidiÅ›Â¯a. This extraordinary fact is unambiguously reported in the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple Inscription.

Then, after he (i.e. Ghat.otkaca) had seen that niece ( bhÂ¯agineyÂ¯Ä±) (of his) [. . . ], who was a palace Laks.mÂ¯Ä±, [. . . ] (this) king paid his respects (to her) and married her (13). 26

The stability thus created ushered in three decades of unparallelled cultural bloom. It seems that it is this period in particular (c. ad 415â€“445) that gave rise to the image of a long-lasting, close and peaceful relationship between the Guptas and VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas, first drawn up by Altekar and taken over by many other scholars, among whom Hermann Kulke, quoted above.

KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asaâ€™s MÂ¯

alavikÂ¯

agnimitra

Among the cultural achievements of the time were the plays of KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asa. One

of them stages momentous events of a remote past, the days in which the Åšu Ë™nga general Pus.yamitra usurped the Maurya Empire (c. 187â€“151 bc). However, as we will show, the contemporary spectators may have seen through this historic guise the political situation of their own days. In order to facilitate our analysis of this play, its contents may be briefly summarized, with the restriction that we leave the intrigue at the VidiÅ›Â¯

a court, which is the playâ€™s main plot, for

what it is.

A rÂ¯

aja rules in VidiÅ›Â¯

a as viceroy, appointed as such by his father who, as

commander-in-chief, senÂ¯

apati, is about to consolidate his kingship by a horse sacrifice. To secure the horse the father extends his power to the extreme west, where his army successfully fights the Yavanas. The chief queen of the rÂ¯

aja of VidiÅ›Â¯

a is apparently of indigenous NÂ¯

aga stockâ€”she

is called DhÂ¯

arin.Â¯Ä±, and her signet-ring bears the seal of a serpent ( nÂ¯aga).

The viceroy of VidiÅ›Â¯

a, heir-to-the-throne of the empire founded by his

312

Hans Bakker

father, with whom relations are good, is at loggerheads with his southern neighbour, the kingdom of Vidarbha. It appears that this kingdom is the domain of two rival branches of a family divided over the question how to deal with the new mighty northern neighbour. One branch had pledged allegiance ( pratiÂ´

srutasam

. bandha) and had wished to enter into

a matrimonial alliance, but this was initially prevented by the ruler of the other branch, who was temporarily in power and, through his in-laws, allied to the party that was overthrown by the senÂ¯

apati when he

established his rule over northern India.

The rÂ¯

aja of VidiÅ›Â¯

a sends his brother-in-law, a bastard brother of DhÂ¯

arin.Â¯Ä±

( varn

. Â¯

avara), to command a frontier post ( antapÂ¯

aladurga) on the River

NarmadÂ¯

a, evidently the border between the kingdoms of VidiÅ›Â¯

a and Vi-

darbha.

After an exchange of unsuccessful diplomatic missions, war breaks out between them. The inimical ruler ( pati) of Vidarbha is conquered. The kingdom of Vidarbha is divided into two, and both rulers are installed as joint vassals of the rÂ¯

aja of VidiÅ›Â¯

a, one ruling to the

south, the other to the north of the VaradÂ¯

a River (the Warda). Peace

is sealed by matrimony, when the rÂ¯

aja of VidiÅ›Â¯

a marries the co-uterine

sister ( sodaryÂ¯

a) of the friendly ruler of Vidarbha, who thus lives up to her name, MÂ¯

alavikÂ¯

a, and becomes a princess of the country of MÂ¯

alava.

No doubt the reader has recognized the play as the MÂ¯

alavikÂ¯

agnimitra, about

which Warder remarks that its â€˜modernityâ€™, as claimed by KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asa in the

Prologue, perhaps consists in â€˜this critical presentation of a prince, or perhaps in the presentation in the theatre of the new Gupta-VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka politics of marriage

alliances and vassal kingdoms, though in the guise of ancient historyâ€™ (Warder 1989â€“92 III, 129).

The MÂ¯

alavikÂ¯

agnimitra was written for a Gupta audience rather than for a VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka one. This is inferred from the fact that supremacy of the northern rulers, though challenged, is gloriously confirmed and the relationship between the sovereign and the viceroy in VidiÅ›Â¯

a, despite the latterâ€™s moral flaws, is

represented as unproblematic, unlike the representation thereof in the post-Gupta play DevÂ¯Ä±candragupta (see above).

An analysis of the background, against which the play is set, reveals the following elements that reflect the political arena of the first half of the fifth century that we have tried to sketch above.

1

The major powers of the time are the northern empire and the kingdom of Vidarbha.

The border between both kingdoms is formed by the River NarmadÂ¯

a.

2

The political centre of the western part of the northern empire is VidiÅ›Â¯

a,

where the heir-to-the-throne rules as viceroy.

3

This viceroy has tied the indigenous rulers of Malwa to his throne by taking one of their princesses as his chief wife. In KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asaâ€™s play this wife is called

DhÂ¯

arin.Â¯Ä±, a name that echos the gotra name, DhÂ¯aran.a, of PrabhÂ¯avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯a.

The signet-ring of DhÂ¯

arin.Â¯Ä±, which features a nÂ¯aga, and plays an important role in the plot, reinforces this NÂ¯

aga descent. The historicity of this detail may be

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

14 / A Theatre of Broken Dreams

313

illustrated by the signet-ring of MahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja MaheÅ›varanÂ¯

aga, son of NÂ¯

agabhat.t.a

(Plate 47). 27

4

The attitude of the Vidarbha rulers (whose coronation names end in Sena) against their northern neighbours is ambivalent. One faction is inclined to come to terms with northern overlordship, the other has not forgotten its allegiance to the ancien rÃ©gime, to the rulers who had been overthrown by the new sovereign.

5

After hostilities between both kingdomsâ€”the NarmadÂ¯

a is crossedâ€”

northern suzerainty is established by dividing the Vidarbha kingdom into two vassal states, one ruling to the north of the VaradÂ¯

a River, the other to the

south of it.

6

The establishment of the balance of power is sealed by the marriage of a Vidarbha princess with the viceroy of VidiÅ›Â¯

a.

Plate 47 A & B

Signet-ring of MahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja MaheÂ´

svaranÂ¯

aga, son of NÂ¯

agabhat.t.a (B mirrored)

Attempts to read more in KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asaâ€™s drama and to connect its protagonists and

actions with historical individuals and events is doomed to fail. The play is not an historic drama, and, if one wants to see it as such, it explicitly professes to be one concerned with a more distant past. The audiences of the fifth century may have recognized the general political reality of their times, though. It gave the play an exciting dimension and in that, as Warder remarked, its avowed innovation vis-Ã -vis the works of the poetâ€™s predecessors may have consisted.

27 This copper seal in the form of a signet-ring was purchased by Cunningham from a local dealer in Lahore and to date forms part of the Cunningham Collection of the British Museum. It was published in CII III (1888), 282 f. and Plate XLIII A. It reads: [1]

mahÂ¯

arÂ¯

ajanÂ¯

agabhat.t.a [2] putramaheÅ›varanÂ¯agah. . The crescent to the left and bull in front of a li Ë™

nga in the upper half of the seal confirm that the NÂ¯

aga kings were Åšaivas. The

name of the king is not known from other sources. It is conjectured that the indistinct tiny objects held in the right hands of the mothers of KumÂ¯

such signet-rings (see n. 20 on p. 309 and n. 36 on p. 316).

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

314

Hans Bakker

There is one element in the play that we have not yet encountered. This concerns the internal division within the kingdom of Vidarbha and its partition.

Returning from literature to history, we may observe that from the fourth century onwards one branch of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka family ruled in Nandivardhana

(near modern Ramtek), the other in Vatsagulma (modern Wasim). The border between both kingdoms was the River VaradÂ¯

a (modern Warda). We do not

have enough evidence to know whether the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas were unanimous in their

friendship towards their northern neighbours. A priori, this seems unlikely, particularly because the dynasty had lost much of its original land to Samudragupta (Bakker 1997, 9â€“15). We do not know how much resistence there was against PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s regency over her sons and whether there was resentment from the side of these sons against their mother, who seemingly indefinitely postponed (from c. ad 405 to 419) their ascension to the throne (Bakker 1997, 15 f.). Is it pure accident that in the aftermath of the power struggle between Govinda and KumÂ¯

aragupta the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka crown-prince ( yuvarÂ¯aja) and eldest

son of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±, DivÂ¯

akarasena, vanished from the scene, never to be heard

of again? 28 And, finally, we do not know at what costs PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± enforced

the marriage of her daughter with her maternal uncle, Ghat.otkaca. What we do know, however, is that after the death of this formidable lady (c. ad 443) Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka relations quickly deteriorated.

The VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akaâ€“Gupta conflict

About ad 445 PrabhÂ¯avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s youngest son Pravarasena crossed the NarmadÂ¯a and pitched his army camp ( vÂ¯

asaka) in TripurÂ¯Ä± (modern Tewar) on the northern bank of this river, i.e. in Gupta territory. 29 To all appearances the tripartite alliance between Guptas, NÂ¯

agas, and VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas, was beginning to erode. This

might also have had to do with a new player that had entered the arena, Skandagupta, a bastard son of KumÂ¯

aragupta. The Gupta emperor was growing

old and the jockeying for the best position to succeed him had begun. As far as we know, there were at least three contenders for the throne. 1) KumÂ¯

araâ€™s legal

son by his chief wife AnantadevÂ¯Ä±, PÂ¯

urugupta, who at the time might still have

been too young to play a significant part. 2) The emperorâ€™s younger brother 28 In the 13th year of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s regency (c. ad 417) DivÂ¯

akarasena was still recognized

as yuvarÂ¯

aja. CII V, 7 ll. 9â€“10: yuvarÂ¯

aja[ Â´

akarasenajananÂ¯Ä±. The seal of these Poona

avatÂ¯Ä± runs (CII V, 8): â€˜[By] the enemy chastising order of the Mother of the crown-prince, who is the ornament of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas and has attained royal fortune

by inheritance.â€™ ( vÂ¯

akÂ¯

Ghat.otkaca, ruling in VidiÅ›Â¯a, and, 3) the outsider, a boy from the harem, Skandagupta.

To stake his claims, Ghat.otkaca may have begun to issue his own gold coins; one such coin can, with some amount of confidence, be ascribed to a Ghat.o(tkaca), on which he wields the imperial Garud.a standard and takes the biruda â€˜KramÂ¯

adityaâ€™. 30 For the third time the Gupta Empire threatened to fall apart. I have analysed this episode elsewhere (Bakker 1997, 25â€“29). Here it may suffice to refer to the BhitarÂ¯Ä± Stone Pillar Inscription of Skandagupta in which, following Mirashi, we may find references to three wars conducted by Skandagupta. The first one records how Skandagupta, while his father KumÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas and Pravarasenaâ€™s campaign on the northern banks of the NarmadÂ¯

KumÂ¯

for a decade and may have intensified after the death of KumÂ¯

When at a certain time [. . . ] he of desirable appearance (i.e. Ghat.otkaca) [. . . ]

Finale

Confronted with defeat, the political triangle, on which the stability and power of his kingdom was based, in ruins, the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka king Pravarasena made the

most of a hopeless situation, marched on Malwa, brought his widowed sister back to Vidarbha in a military campaign, and died soon thereafter. In ad 455 Skandagupta officially succeeded his deceased father and proudly declared himself emperor. Frustration concerning his birth may have bred this great pride. In verse 6 of the BhitarÂ¯Ä± Pillar Inscription, Skandagupta, after his victory (over his uncle Ghat.otkaca), is said to have run towards his mother, â€˜which made her weep like DevakÂ¯Ä± after Kr.s.n.a had killed his enemyâ€™, namely his uncle (Kam

. sa). 35 This scene, as has been rightly suggested by Goyal, is depicted on Skandaguptaâ€™s so-called â€˜King-and-Laks.mÂ¯Ä± Typeâ€™ of gold coins, on which the lady to the left of the victorious warrior king, smaller than him and without a nimbus, may represent not the goddess ÅšrÂ¯Ä± or Laks.mÂ¯Ä±, but his anonymous mother. 36

14 / A Theatre of Broken Dreams

317

Epilogue

Our reappraisal of Gupta history in the light of the recurrent events in VidiÅ›Â¯

a

and the role of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas in them has come to an end. The idyllic picture to the effect that the Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka relations were close till the fall of the

imperial Gupta dynasty, i.e. till the end of the 5th century, stands in need of revision. It has emerged that these relations were only intimate and peaceful during the lifetime of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a. Before and after the long period of

more than half a century that this formidable lady dominated the stage (ad 388â€“443), these relations were marred by conflicting interests, which led to war at least twice, first under the reign of Samudragupta, when the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas lost

much of their original territory in the Vindhyas, then again under his great-grandson Skandagupta, when they were forced to give up their influence at the court of the viceroy of VidiÅ›Â¯

a. Loss of the Malwa connection, and therewith of

Gupta support altogether, resulted in disaster for the Eastern VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas, who

soon became subordinate to their relatives in Vatsagulma.

Thus was VidiÅ›Â¯

a, as we hope to have demonstrated, for at least eighty years (ad 375â€“455) a theatre of broken dreams, a stage on which three Gupta viceroys paid with their lives for their imperial aspirations, and from which, in a grand finale, a widowed VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka princess was hurried away and brought to safety across the NarmadÂ¯

a River by the faltering troups of her brother.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

Hans Bakker

Figure 5

Genealogy of the Gupta and VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka dynasties

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

Royal Patronage and Religious Toleranceâˆ—

The Formative Period of Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka Culture

Udayagiri

When, at the beginning of the 5th century, the royal elephant carrying his majesty climbed the slopes of the Udayagiri for a visit to the sacred complex, Emperor Candragupta made sure not to give offence to any of the parties involved in his grand project. His aim was clearly defined in the inscription that records his visit, namely the winning of the entire earth: He (VÂ¯Ä±rasena) has come here in the company of the king himself, who was on his way of winning the entire earth, and he has commissioned this cave out of devotion for Lord Åšambhu. 1

Though himself a devotee of Vis.n.u and so a BhÂ¯agavata, the king paid his respect to his learned chief minister VÂ¯Ä±rasena, who came from PÂ¯

at.aliputra, by

visiting the cave dedicated to Lord Åšambhu, i.e. Åšiva, which had recently be completed under the patronage of the chief minister. The chief minister was content and proudly recorded the honour that had been bestowed upon him in an inscription at the back of the cave. However, this rather insignificant Cave 8, which probably enshrined a li Ë™nga, can hardly have been the main purpose of Candraguptaâ€™s visit. 2 For, next door, around the corner, a truly grandiose scheme had just been, or was about to being accomplished, a work of art that was designed to broadcast the kingâ€™s larger ambition: â€˜the winning of the entire earthâ€™, expressed allegorically in the great VarÂ¯

aha panel of Cave 5.

As Michael Willis (2004, 2009) has shown, the VarÂ¯

aha panel was intrinsically

connected through a system of hydrological engineering with a natural cleft in the central ridge of the mountain. Water once cascaded down through this narrow passage, flowing underneath a large image of Vis.n.uâ€“NÂ¯arÂ¯ayan.a. This panel shows the god in his cosmic sleep while resting on the primordial snake (AnantaÅ›ayana), floating on the cosmic ocean. At the bottom of the cascade, the water was collected in a resevoir at the feet of the VarÂ¯

aha sculpture of Cave

5, making the cosmic boar rise out of the waters.

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in the Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society, third series, Volume 20.4, October 2010, pp. 461â€“75.

1 CII III (1888), Udayagiri Cave Inscription of Candragupta II, p. 35: kr

. tsnapr

. thvÂ¯Ä±jayÂ¯

a-

rthena rÂ¯

ajËœ

naiveha sahÂ¯

agatah

. | bhaktyÂ¯

a bhagavataÂ´

s Â´

sambhor guhÂ¯

am etÂ¯

am akÂ¯

arayat k

2 This cave is referred to as Cave 8 in the archaeological literature (Willis 2009, 39).

Williams 1982 refers to it as Cave 7.

319

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

320

Hans Bakker

It will not be our aim here to analyze the iconography and the allegorical double-entendre of these two panels, the VarÂ¯

aha and the NÂ¯

arÂ¯

ayan.a, which

most recently has been done by Willis in a penetrating study referred to above. 3

What concerns us here is the ecumenicity of the situation: a Vais.n.ava king,

â€˜whose prowess is [Vis.n.uâ€™s] Cakraâ€™,4 selects a prominent spot at the centre of the holy mountain of Udayagiri for celebrating his faith and political mission, and allows at the same time two leading figures of his kingdom, a minister (VÂ¯Ä±rasena) and a vassal king (the SanakÂ¯

anika mahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja Sod.hala (?)), to con-

struct next door cave-sanctuaries (Caves 6 and 8) dedicated to Åšiva, the other high god of Hinduism. Inscriptions in both shrines duly recognize the sovereignty of Candragupta. 5 Admittedly, we cannot be certain as to the original dedication of the sanctuary of Cave 6â€”the cave no longer contains its original sculptureâ€”but the two Vis.n.u images at the outer wall, flanking the two DvÂ¯

arapÂ¯

alas, as well as the image of Gan.eÅ›a overviewing the entrance at the left and a shrine of the seven mothers at the right of the sanctum, strongly suggest that Cave 6 was also a Åšiva sanctuary, 6 in which the two Vis.n.u images, in the words of Joanna Williams, were merely â€˜attendant upon the greater glory of Åšivaâ€™. 7

And, to complete the picture, adjacent to the VarÂ¯

aha cave on the other,

southern side, was one more Åšaiva cave (4), enshrining an ekamukhali Ë™nga. 8

Thus it cannot have escaped the attention of the contemporaneous visitor that, with the establishment of Gupta power over the area, the BhÂ¯

agavata religion

had taken pole position, not by ousting its Åšaiva rivals, but rather by including them in a subordinate position. By doing so the three caves together mirrored the situation in Cave 6 on a larger scale: Åšiva (Caves 4 & 6) â€˜attendant on the greater glory ofâ€™ the Bhagavat (Cave 5). Although the majority of the temple structures on the Udayagiri can be assigned to Hindu gods, this by no means excluded other persuasions to establish their own sanctuary on the hill. At the top of the north side of the hill is a cave of the heterodox Jains, which an inscription dates to the reign of Candraguptaâ€™s son KumÂ¯

aragupta (ge 106 =

ad 436). â€˜The inscription records the dedication of an image of PÂ¯

arÅ›vanÂ¯

atha.â€™ 9

3 Willis 2004, 41 ff.; Willis 2009, 30â€“46.

4 Willis 2004, 55 n. 52.

. halaâ€™, is a conjecture of D.C. Sircar

(SI I, 279 n. 5.). No king of that name is known otherwise. It is uncertain whether

15 / Royal Patronage and Religious Tolerance 321

Jainism had been favoured in this region by Candraguptaâ€™s ill-fated elder brother, RÂ¯

amagupta, who commissioned the three images that were reportedly found inside old Besnagar (Durjanpura), 1.5 km from Udayagiri. 10 Three inscriptions on the pedestals record basically the same dedication: This image of the Lord, the venerable Pus.padanta/Candraprabha, was commissioned by the MahÂ¯

arÂ¯

ajÂ¯

adhirÂ¯

aja ÅšrÂ¯Ä± RÂ¯

amagupta, at the instigation of CelÂ¯

uks.aman.a,

son of GolakyÂ¯

antÂ¯Ä±, who is the pupil of the preceptor Sarpasenaks.aman.a and the grand-pupil of the pÂ¯

an

. ipÂ¯

atrika 11 Candraks.aman.a, preceptor ( Â¯acÂ¯arya) and forbear-ing monk ( ks.aman.aÅ›raman.a). 12

No direct evidence of Buddhist presence in Udayagiri has come to light, the reason for which is not difficult to see: the great, ancient centre of Sanchi, 5 km to the south, naturally attracted all Buddhist devotion. This was, for instance, the case when another favourite of Candragupta, Â¯

AmrakÂ¯

ardava, donated in ge

93 (= ad 413),

An allotment of land, called â€˜Â¯

IÅ›varavÂ¯

asakaâ€™, and a sum of money to the Â¯

Arya-

sa Ë™ngha, or community of the faithful, at the great vihÂ¯

ara or Buddhist convent of

KÂ¯

akanÂ¯

adabot.a, for the purpose of feeding mendicants and maintaining lamps. 13

Candraguptaâ€™s favours are explicitly said to have contributed to Â¯

AmrakÂ¯

ardavaâ€™s

way and means of life. 14

Thus we possess within a circle of five kilometers from the Udayagiri Caves and within a time frame of a few decades around ad 400, plenty of epigraphical and sculptural evidence that proves that the reign of Samudraguptaâ€™s successors ushered in a period of royal patronage that was not limited to one religious denomination only, but was beneficial to all the four major religions of the times: BhÂ¯

agavata (Visnuism), MÂ¯

aheÅ›vara (Saivism), Jaina (Jainism) and Bauddha

(Buddhism). This is not to say, of course, that the Guptas invented religious patronage, but their rule marked the emergence of kings and courtiers as a major class of patrons, whereas earlier â€˜groups of lay peopleâ€™ were the prominent sponsors. 15 And in contrast to most of the earlier patrons, their patronage 10 The images are presently stored in the State Museum, Bhopal. See Gai 1969; Williams 1982, 25f, 28 f. Bakker 2006, 169, n. 9.

11 In an email dated 17 September 2009, Paul Dundas explained this term to me as follows: pÂ¯

an

. ipÂ¯

atrika I would not take as a title but rather as a eulogistic epithet signifying an ascetic who uses his cupped hands as an alms bowl and thus follows the jinakalpa, the rigorous mode of life of the Jinas. The term usually designates, or came to designate, a Digambara monk.

12 CII III (1981), 231â€“34.

aËœ

nchi Stone Inscription of Candragupta II,

Year 93.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

322

Hans Bakker

extended to religions other than their personal persuasions, thus spreading an atmosphere of religious tolerance throughout the realm. 16

Royal patronage

As we will see, this patronage could take the form of financing prestigious building projects as well as lending financial support to religious groups and individuals through gifts of money or land. We do not possess much direct evidence of courtly patronage of individual sculptors, decorators, architects or other artisans who worked in the visual arts, although this must have been substantial. They were paid, of course, and some artists more than others, no doubt. Since the king himself was the centre of the patronage system, it is remarkable that we do not possess epigraphical testimonies of Candraguptaâ€™s own building projects. It looks as if he was satisfied with being credited by his subjects for his goodness, whereas the ones that appear to have been his own monumental plans, such as the VarÂ¯

aha and NÂ¯

arÂ¯

ayan.a panels, were apparently so

obvious that they needed no special commemoration in the form of dedicatory inscriptions.

This large-scale and broad-minded religious patronage practised by the court, which involved the king, his courtiers and officials ( amÂ¯

atya), favourites

and so-called feudatories ( sÂ¯

amanta), 17 enhanced the development of the

classical forms of the Indian religions, as well as their sacred architecture and art. It formed part of a wider system of patronage, which operated as a powerful political strategy, through which the king could advance and visualize a religiously sanctified social order ( dharma), from which his authority as a ruler by Godâ€™s grace was deduced. 18 Partly due to this policy, North India became covered with religious monuments of various sorts, a small number of which survived the ages. The Gupta court and its satellites promoted a lifestyle and devotional ethos that obviously was appealing to a broad section 16 Cf. A.K. Narain (1983) in Religious Policy and Toleration in Ancient India:

â€˜Tolerationâ€™ in this context means a stateâ€™s recognition and protection of the right of private judgement in matters of faith and worship, and a lack of persecution or obstruction of the beliefs and practices of sects and religions other than the kingâ€™s own. Often the king of ancient India does not get credit for his act of toleration by modern historians beause it is wrongly assumed that toleration is an essential part of his religious practice or of rÂ¯

ajadharma. (Narain 1983, 50)

17 Ali 2004, 8: â€˜It was the activities of the kingâ€™s court, composed of dependents and re-tainers, and attented by underlords and vassals, which constituted â€œgovernmentâ€ rather than a putative â€œadministrationâ€.â€™

18 See Bakker 1992d (above, p. 153). This should not be taken as support of a legitimation theory which, in the words of Daud Ali, â€˜suggests the rather unlikely and even anachronistic scenario of the court acting collectively on the basis of certain principles, and then representing them back to itself in order to legitimate themâ€™. On the contary, we subscribe to Aliâ€™s insight that â€˜the ideas enshrined in art and literature are in fact identical to the key concepts found in the texts which urge the king and his men to constitute their political actions, which is to say that the supposedly non-ideational realm of power and politics is in fact already ideationalâ€™. (Ali 2004, 14) Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

15 / Royal Patronage and Religious Tolerance 323

of the population; it proved not only to be politically effective, but it lent stability and grandeur to Gupta reign, thanks to which some still speak of â€˜the golden ageâ€™, or â€˜the classical ageâ€™. 19

Mandhal

This successful model set an attractive example for other dynasties to follow.

Influence emanating from the Gupta realm becomes best visible in a dynasty to the south of the Vindhyas with which close relations were established, the Eastern VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas of Vidarbha.

Candragupta had married a princess of the NÂ¯

aga dynasty (an old enemy of

his father Samudra) named KuberanÂ¯

agÂ¯

a, by whom he had a daughter. This

princess, who came to be known from her own inscriptions by her dynastic name PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a, was married to the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka prince Rudrasena II in about

ad 388. 20 The NÂ¯

agas had been a major force in Eastern Malwa and the region around Udayagiriâ€“VidiÅ›Â¯

a till the Gupta conquest, and the marriage of a Gupta-NÂ¯

aga princess with the crown-prince of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas established a triangular

political relationship between the centre of Gupta power in the Ga Ë™ngÂ¯

a-YamunÂ¯

a

doab in the north, VidiÅ›Â¯

a in the west, and the Eastern VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kingdom in

the south. 21

Rudrasena, once king, inspired it would seem by the example of his in-laws, reinforced a tradition of large-scale religious patronage within the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka

kingdom. 22 Two inscriptions of Rudrasena himself bear testimony to this: the Deot.ek Stone Inscription of Rudrasena and the Mandhal Plates, Year 5. The Deotek palimpsest stone inscription (Rudrasena overwriting an inscription that 19 Although Daud Ali admits that he has â€˜bracketed out the question of religionâ€™, he makes an important observation that is relevant to our subject: In fact, religious and political notions of lordship differed more in degree than kind.

They formed part of a continuous and homologously structured â€˜chain of beingâ€™ which linked the entire cosmos. This, on the one hand, meant that the kingâ€™s authority and mystique resembled and participated in that of the temple god, giving a theological dimension to relationships at court. On the other hand, however, it meant that the life of gods, housed in their sumptuous palaces, shared striking resemblances to those of princes. (Ali 2004, 104)

I have earlier argued in a similar line, pointing out, however, that this notion of â€˜lordshipâ€™

was itself part of a historical process, or, that the â€˜degreeâ€™ of homology between gods and kings can be demonstrated to have evolved from an analogy in The Gupta/VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka

age to a full homology in the centuries before the establishment of the Delhi Sultanate (Bakker 1992d, 99; above, p. 165).

apparently pertains to the reign of AÅ›oka) records the erection of a DharmasthÂ¯

Forty kilometers to the north of it is the findspot of the second Rudrasena inscription, which was found while ploughing a field near the village of Mandhal. 23

The locations of both inscriptions indicate that the earliest political heart of the VÂ¯

at.aka kingdom was along the Wainganga, to the south of Nagpur. This may have been the Padmapura District that is known from two inscriptions, one of which is Rudrasenaâ€™s Mandhal Plates, the other the MÂ¯

On account of the above considerations it is our best guess to ascribe the unfinished MohallÂ¯

a Plate to the same Rudrasena II who issued the Mandhal Plates, Year 5. However, instead of mentioning Padmapura as the place of issue, as one might have expected on the basis of this hypothesis, these Mandhal Plates specify the god â€˜MondasvÂ¯

aminâ€™ as the issuing agency.

Yet, there is

archaeological and historical evidence that makes it plausible that this authority relates to a Vis.n.u temple in the Mandhal area, that is, arguably, in the vicinity of Padmapura, as we will see below.

Mun

. d

. asvÂ¯

amin

In his Mandhal Plates Rudrasena II styled himself as someone â€˜whose rule is based on the cakra, the emblem of the Bhagavatâ€™, 35 i.e. Vis.n.u; in other words, just like his father-in-law Candragupta, Rudrasena professed to be a bhÂ¯

agavata.

The VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kings before and after him, with the exception of Pr.thivÂ¯Ä±s.en.a II, were all devotees of MaheÅ›vara (Åšiva), i.e. they were MÂ¯

aheÅ›varas, so it

seems that his conversion to Bhagavatism had been part of an antenuptial contract. And there is more in this inscription, which may be dated to c. ad 400, that links up with Candragupta, who, at about this time, was engaged in his grand Udayagiri project. The opening of the Mandhal inscription runs as follows:

Success! Approved. By order of Lord Mun.d.asvÂ¯amin, God of gods, who holds the conch, discus and sword; after He had made the NÂ¯

aga king stretch out on

the waters of the ocean, He has entered a state of yogic sleep, while lying on the serpent coils of that (king) Ananta (the Infinite One)â€”a bundle of expanded hoods bending (over Him by way of canopy). 36

times in the sense of a temple or place of worshipâ€™; it refers to a â€˜court of justiceâ€™, whereas vaijayika (victorious) is to be taken as â€˜an honorificâ€™. The location of Padmapura, like that of the Victorious DharmasthÂ¯

ana, is unknown (cf. above, n. 65 on p. 141). A plausible conjecture, however, identifies the town with the ancient SÂ¯

atavÂ¯

ahana site of PaunÂ¯Ä± in the

The reading of the first lines of the first plate are difficult due to severe damage.

The editors Shastri & Gupta read in the middle of line 2: mondasvÂ¯

aminasâ—¦; in

the published photograph of Plate 1, I can read â—¦ svÂ¯

aminasâ—¦, but the reading

â€˜ mondaâ€™ is impossible to confirm.

The word monda gives apparently little

sense. Dental and cerebral nd are identical but for their top part, in which the square head-mark is replaced by two short curved strokes. Assuming that the reading mon

. d

. a is correct, we could think of Prakrit influence by which Ë‡

o

replaced u before a double consonant without much change of pronuncation. 37

If mon

. d

. a is not the correct readingâ€”the upper and lower part of the aks.ara are illegibleâ€”one could think of reading mau instead of mo, the difference between mo and mau being only that the right top stroke is making an upward curve rather than being a horizontal curve. Or, more likely perhaps mu, in which the straight stroke down forming the short syllable u has become erased. I tentatively conjecture the reading mun

. d

. asvÂ¯

aminasâ—¦, but mo( au) n

. d

. asvÂ¯

aminasâ—¦

cannot be excluded either.

arÂ¯

ayan.a relief in Udayagiri. But

. d

. a

refers to an eponymous person who envisaged and installed this manifestation of the Bhagavat.

15 / Royal Patronage and Religious Tolerance 329

stance, from MahÂ¯

arata 12.332.13â€“18 and the TusÂ¯

The SÂ¯

atvatas worshipped VÂ¯

asudeva and the four other members of the Vr.s.n.i

clan; they originated from western India. 44 The invocation of the god of his wife strongly suggests that Rudrasena was acting on her behalf: the queen hid-ing herself behind the god Mu(o/au)n.d.asvÂ¯amin at whose command the grant was made. The heuristic principle cherchez la femme has again proven its value.

The Mandhal inscription thus seems to prove that the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka queen (nÃ©e

Gupta) followed in her fatherâ€™s footsteps by favouring religious organisations and building temples. She may have been the major source of inspiration of her husband and have brought the SÂ¯

atvata ritual experts from Vatsagulma to

the Padmapura District in order to serve in her new temple.

Archaeological excavations in Mandhal have brought to light three temples, the most prominent of which stood on top of a hillock named Bom

. gÂ¯Ä± Hud.kÂ¯Ä±

(BHK II); this temple was built on a massive platform (11.70 Ã— 14.70 m), with a garbhagr.ha and man.d.apa. The platform was partly built into the surface of the rock, which was levelled by 32 layers of brick at the southern side. 45 At the foot of this hillock excavations revealed another building (BHK I); underneath its brick floor a dozen of Hindu sculptures were found, among which two or three images of the SÂ¯

atvata deities: VÂ¯

asudeva, Sam

. kars.an.a, and (pos-

sibly) SÂ¯

amba ( Â¯

Aditya). 46 Whether or not this VÂ¯

asudeva image represented the

Mun.d.asvÂ¯amin is impossible to say. The fact that, next to these three Vais.n.ava images, five stylistically very similar images of markedly Åšaiva nature were discovered, 47 testifies to the apparently harmonious way by which the BhÂ¯

agavatas

and MÂ¯

aheÅ›varas existed side by side, tapping the same royal source of subsistence.

RÂ¯

amagiri

Rudrasena died young. His sudden death may account for the fact that the MohallÂ¯

a Plate remained unfinished. His Gupta queen assumed power, officially as regentess of her minor sons. Her Poona Plates, dated in the 13th year of the yuvarÂ¯

aja DivÂ¯

akarasena, i.e. around ad 418, show that momentous decisions had been taken since the Mandhal foundations. 48 The dowager queen had her residence moved northwards, to Nandivardhana at the foot of the RÂ¯

amagiri,

which hill she was developing into a state sanctuary that could match her fatherâ€™s Udayagiri. Again a hilltop was chosen; two minor caves were excavated 43 CII III (1888), 269â€“271; Willis 2009, 223 ff.

This festival of cosmogonic re-awakening had an important political dimension, as has been shown by Michael Willis in the case of Candragupta and Udayagiri, 49 a case that must have been very well known to the queen. Styling herself as entirely devoted to the Bhagavat ( atyantabhagavadbhaktÂ¯

lel with Udayagiri can even be extended further, since the oldest image that survives on the hill is that of the Boar, VarÂ¯

Mansar

For several years BhÂ¯

agavatas and MÂ¯

aheÅ›varas were living together in the Nandi-

vardhana residence, but somewhere between the eleventh and sixteenth years in the reign of Pravarasena, the latter had decided that he should construct his own residence, Pravarapura, and his own state sanctuary, PravareÅ›vara, both named after the king himself. 56 For these two building projects wonderful sites were found, which mirrored, as it were, the old residence and the RÂ¯

amagiri:

The PravareÅ›vara complex was erected five kilometers to the west, on a hill again (Hid.imbÂ¯a T.ekd.Â¯Ä±), facing the RÂ¯amagiri, whereas at its foot the residence Pravarapura arose. Excavations at these two sites near the village of Mansar (MNS 3 and 2) during the last ten years have brought to light a wealth of material, which has been the subject of a symposium in the British Museum in 2008. 57

The personal sealsâ€”both, of Pravarasena and PrabhÂ¯

(Plates 49 & 50), 58 suggest that the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka king stayed close to his mother

and that she, at an advanced age, remained a powerful figure behind the scenes, also in the new palace of her youngest son, which was her third and last residence since she had left the Gupta court of her youthâ€”Padmapura, Nandivardhana, Pravarapura. 59 When the Gupta-NÂ¯

aga princess, the queen mother

of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas, eventually died in her early seventies in c. ad 444, a funeral monument ( ed

. Â¯

uka) was erected, as I have argued elsewhere, at a location in between the RÂ¯

amagiri and Pravarapura, a monument that was appropriately guarded by a NÂ¯

aga. 60

In the present context it may suffice to evaluate the recent discoveries at Mansar in as far as they throw light on the theme of this essay, royal patronage, religious tolerance, and the formation of Gupta-VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka culture.

The magnificent state sanctuary ( devakulasthÂ¯

ana) PravareÅ›vara, erected on

the Hid.imbÂ¯a T.ekd.Â¯Ä± near the village of Mansar (MNS 3), served as the place where the ceremony of issuing royal charters was performed, as attested by the PÂ¯

an

. d

. urn

. Â¯

a Plates of Pravarasena II, Year 29 (ad 441).61 A generous land-donation was granted to a group of VÂ¯

ajasaneya brahmins, and the same in-

scription records that one of the donees (SomÂ¯

arya) received some more land

later, after a ceremonial offering of sesamum ( tilavÂ¯

acanaka), i.e. a Â´

addha rit-

ual, had been performed in that same DharmasthÂ¯

ana. 62 The kingâ€™s largesse

towards his subjects was immortalized in the benign smile of the main Åšiva image of this temple (Plate 113), the god who bestowed life on his devotees by extending a right hand filled with flowers to them, in a gesture of benevolence ( varadamudrÂ¯
