15 / Royal Patronage and Religious Tolerance 333

Conclusion

In the four decades following Candraguptaâ€™s inauguration of his Udayagiri monument at the turn of the 5th century, (1) his daughter (Mun.d.Â¯a/PrabhÂ¯avatÂ¯Ä±) founded a sanctuary, dedicated to Mun.d.asvÂ¯amin, in Mandhal, probably on the Bom

. gÂ¯Ä± Hud.kÂ¯Ä±, whereafter the dowager queen began the building of a series of sanctuaries on the RÂ¯

amagiri among which the state sanctuary of RÂ¯

amagiri-

svÂ¯

amin, and (2) his grandson Pravarasena II erected his own state sanctuary PravareÅ›vara, on a hilltop near the village of Mansar. Yet, as is the case in the Gupta kingdom, we have hardly any charters of foundation regarding these royal sanctuaries by these monarchs themselves. 64

Nevertheless it is fair to say that the policy of religious patronage initiated by Candragupta and his court was vigorously followed by the rulers in the Eastern VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kingdom. The following facts bear witness to it: 1) sanctuaries bore the names of their royal founders, Mun.d.asvÂ¯amin and PravareÅ›vara; 2) they were alternatively dedicated to either the Bhagavat or MaheÅ›vara; 3) they served as hallowed places for making large donations to various religious group-ings (SÂ¯

atvatas and VÂ¯

ajasaneyins), mostly in the form of land grants. 65 And later, a similar policy was practised by the DharmamahÂ¯

arÂ¯

ajas of the West-

ern VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka branch in Vatsagulma, in whose kingdom we find the famous Buddhist cave monuments of Ajanta. However, here too we witness the same curious phenomenon: a lack of charters of foundation issued by the reigning king Haris.en.a himself.

Although the kings showed clearly their religious orientation, we have no evidence whatsoever that could point to great enmity between the religious organisations, despite the fact that rivalry for patronage as well as clients no doubt played a role. The first four decades of the fifth century, dominated by the rule of Candra- and KumÂ¯

aragupta in the north and PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a and

Pravarasena in the south, may be counted among the most stable and peaceful periods in ancient Indian history. It is this stability established by good policy and tolerance that created the conditions for an unprecedented development of the imagination, reflected in the literary and visual arts, achieving a perfection that still impresses today.

The iconographic programme developed on the Udayagiri mountain was only partly taken over in the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kingdom: images of Vis.n.u, VarÂ¯aha,

Narasim

. ha, Gan.eÅ›a, and Mahis.Â¯asuramardinÂ¯Ä± are found at both locations, all nearly in the classical form that would remain normative for the centuries to 64 We possess a deed of foundation of Skandagupta, viz. his BhitarÂ¯

Ä± Stone Pillar Inscrip-

tion, in which the Gupta king records his installation of the deity KumÂ¯

arasvÂ¯

amin (see

Bakker 2005, 249; below, p. 375; cf. Willis 2009, 144 ff.). And we possess a document of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s daughter AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± (name uncertain), viz. the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Tem-

ple Inscription, which records the installation of PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin (Isaacson & Bakker

1993, 54; Bakker 1997, 30â€“33; above, p. 124; below, p. 354).

65 For a survey of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka land donations see Shrimali 1987.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

334

Hans Bakker

come. However, in Vidarbha this sophisticated artistic tradition blended with a local form of craftsmanship which lent to it its peculiar, somewhat rustic flavour and which gave rise to creative experiments that were not all equally successful. The sculptures found in Mandhal are a good example of this. But in the course of a few years since the Mandhal inception, the classical images on the RÂ¯

amagiri of VarÂ¯

aha, Trivikrama, and Narasim

. ha were created in the ma-

ture VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka idiom, which matched their Udayagiri counterparts in artistic quality and refinement.

The workshop set up by PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± for the production of high quality,

red-sandstone sculptures continued to work under her son and reached an unequalled level of sophistication and originality in the sculptures that once adorned the PravareÅ›vara Temple. Although the research of these sculptures is still in its infancy and their iconography is still little understood, it may be observed that their appeal lies in their tranquility, which expresses mood and emotional state ( bhÂ¯

ava) rather than action ( vikrama), sentiment and emotion ( rasa) rather than force ( bala), and as such they are characteristic of the best that Indian art has produced.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hillâˆ—

Transgression and Atonement on a Hill in the South

and the Inadequacy of Substitutes

Preamble

Coming from a part of the world where there are neither holy places nor mountains, it may seem strange that my professional career has been marked by the research of these two phenomena. Curiosity to discover unknown fields, no doubt, lies at the base of every scholarly endeavour, but in my case there may have been a more compelling factor, namely the fascination for the cultural and religious world of India. Studying the religious heritage of the Subcontinent means that one cannot miss the holy places: they are simply ubiquitous, and many of them are mountains. 1

The symbolism of holy mountains in the Hindu tradition has been well covered by Laura Giuliano in her contribution to the proceedings of the conference on Religioni e Sacri Monti. As she points out, the idea of the holy mountain is interchangeable with concepts such as, for instance, â€˜the world pillarâ€™ (il pi-lastro del mondo or axis mundi) and â€˜the world treeâ€™ (lâ€™albero cosmico). 2 This symbolism is not limited to mountains as such, as Giuliano demonstrates, but underlies the very idea of the Hindu temple and its architecture.

Rather than repeating what has been competently put forward, I would like to concentrate here on a single holy mountain, the RÂ¯

amagiri or RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hill,

right in the heart of India, in the region known as Vidarbha (47 km north of Nagpur in eastern Maharashtra). As we will see, the nexus of ideas pointed out by Giuliano will gain relevance, when we fix our attention on the significance that this hill had, and still has for the pilgrim who visits it today. This pilgrim will, no doubt, think of the classical Sanskrit epic, which has contributed so much to the Indian culture through the ages, the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a and its main hero,

RÂ¯

ama, son of DaÅ›aratha, king of AyodhyÂ¯

a.

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Italian under the title: La collina di RÂ¯

ama. Transgressione ed espiazione su una collina nel sud e lâ€™inadeguatezza delle sostituzioni in: Pellizzari, Paolo (ed.), La bisaccia del pellegrino: fra evocazione e memoria, a cura di Amilcare Barbero e Stefano Piano. Atlas, Centro di Documentazione dei Sacri Monti, Monferrato 2010. pp. 73â€“82. The present English essay, published here for the first time, is a revised version of the text that underlay the Italian translation.

1 Cf. Bakker 2010b, where I deal with the mountain: RohitÂ¯

agiri.

2 Giuliano 2006, 177.

335

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

336

Hans Bakker

The Åšaivala Mountain of the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a

In the seventh and last book of the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a, after RÂ¯

ama had been crowned

king in AyodhyÂ¯

a and a period of golden rule, referred to as the RÂ¯

amarÂ¯

ajya, had

been ushered in, a nasty incident occurred, which could have been meant to remind the reader of the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a of the fact that the golden age was nearing

its end. Bad behaviour, which would become endemic in our own Kali Age, was already occasionally practised in the DvÂ¯

aparayuga and forbodings thereof

appeared in the TretÂ¯

ayuga, thus posing a threat to the universal happiness that characterized RÂ¯

amaâ€™s rule.

A brahmin arrived at the palace gate in AyodhyÂ¯

a and loudly bewailed the

fate of his only son, who had died before having come of age. As the brahmin himself was absolutely blameless, this stroke of misfortune must have been caused by some other mean creature who had abused the dharma (RÂ¯

am. 7.64).

The possible cause of this tragic event was revealed to RÂ¯

ama by his counsellor,

the seer NÂ¯

arada.

Could it be that somewhere in his realm a Â´

sÂ¯

udra might

have had the nerve to practise asceticism, thereby setting a trend that was only permissible in the Kaliyuga (RÂ¯

am. 7.65)? The righteous king ordered the

preservation of the boyâ€™s body by having it laid in oil, a method that worked so well in the case of his own father, and called for his celestial chariot, the Pus.paka. The following reconnaissance flight affirmed that the dharma reigned supreme in the west, north and east of his kingdom, but in the south, the region associated with death, on the slope of the Åšaivala mountain, which the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a situated to the south of the Vindhyas, 3 at the border of a lake, 4

something questionable seemed to be going on. 5

An ascetic was hanging upside down, a form of severe tapas that was evidently not customary in the golden age of the TretÂ¯

ayuga, since those entitled

to practise austerities did not need such extreme mortifications to attain their aims. The Pus.paka landed and RÂ¯ama questioned the hanging man, asking whether he was by any chance a Â´

sÂ¯

udra. The honest ascetic frankly admitted

his humble descent, saying that he had been taken to this severe asceticism by the wish to reach the status of a god. While he was still speaking with his head hanging downâ€”â€˜know that I am a Â´

sÂ¯

udra, O RÂ¯

ama, named ÅšambÂ¯

ukaâ€™ 6â€”

the righteous king drew his sword and chopped off his head (RÂ¯

am. 7.67.3â€“4).

RÂ¯

ama was praised by the gods for having prevented a Â´

sÂ¯

udra from reaching

heaven and a rain of celestial flowers fell down at the spot. 7 Pleased that the 3 See below, n. 8 on p. 337.

4 Åšaivala is the name of a water plant. Meulenbeld 1974, 604 mentions 12 identifications of this plant, the major ones are Vallisneria spiralis Linn. and Blyxa octandra Planch.

5 RÂ¯

am. 7.66.12â€“13.

The commentaries ad 7.66.12 identify the Åšaivala as a giri in the vicinity of the VindhyÂ¯

a.

6 RÂ¯

am. 7.67.3cd: Â´

sÂ¯

udram

. mÂ¯

am

. viddhi kÂ¯

akutstha Â´

sambÂ¯

ukam

. nÂ¯

ama nÂ¯

amatah

. .

7 RÂ¯

am. 7 App. I, No. 11.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

16 / RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hill

337

danger of having to accept a Â´

sÂ¯

udra in their midst had been warded off, the gods granted that the dead brahmin boy was restored to life on RÂ¯

amaâ€™s request.

Thereupon RÂ¯

ama accepted the invitation of the gods to visit the hermitage of Agastya, which, as the text suggests, was thought to be somewhere in the neighbourhood, south of the Vindhya mountains. 8 It was his second visit to the Â¯

aÂ´

srama; previously, during the period of exile, RÂ¯

ama had been there in the

company of his wife SÂ¯Ä±tÂ¯

a and younger brother; Agastya had then pointed out

their way to PaËœ

ncavat.Â¯Ä± (RÂ¯am. 3.12.13).

In earlier publications I have repeatedly tried to demonstrate the futility of the attempts by the Archaeological Survey of India to plot the epic geography of the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a on the historical map of South Asia. 9 The problem is comparable to tracing the itinerary of Ulysses in the Mediterranian basin.

Though much has been written since to prove that I was wrong, especially with regard to the location of AyodhyÂ¯

a and RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Birthplace (RÂ¯

amajanmabhÂ¯

umi)

in connection with the dispute over the Babri Masjid (Plate 4), 10 I have not come across valid arguments that have made me give up my view.

In my opinion, therefore, the question is not where exactly the hill was on which ÅšambÂ¯

uka was beheaded, or where this hermitage of Agastya was, but the scholar should ask where and when traditions emerged that identified specific topographic sites with localities of the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a. Or to put it differently,

when and where did sacred places emerge that derived their fame and holiness from their believed connection with places mentioned in the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

The epigraphical evidence

Two 5th-century VÂ¯

That this epigraphical â€˜RÂ¯

is now generally accepted by all historians dealing with the history of the VÂ¯

at.akas.18 In one of these 5th-century inscriptions the VÂ¯akÂ¯at.aka queen PrabhÂ¯

a gives some additional information regarding the nature of the sanctuary on top of the hill, when she declares that her charters were issued from the â€˜soles of the feet ( pÂ¯

adamÂ¯

These epigraphs agree with a tradition that seems to underly the famous verses in KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asaâ€™s MeghadÂ¯

uta, the â€˜Cloud Messengerâ€™, written in the first

alaya mountains.

A Yaks.a, who had neglected his duties, had lost his powers by his masterâ€™s curseâ€”

heavy to bear, since he had to live separated from his beloved for one year; he took up his abode in the hermitages on the RÂ¯

amagiri, where the trees (spread) a gentle

shade and where the waters were hallowed by the bathing of Janakaâ€™s daughter.

[. . . ]

After having embraced that lofty hill, you, (O cloud), should take leave of your dear friend, who, on his slopes, is marked by Raghupatiâ€™s footprints, venerated by mankind; every time when you and he meet, the shedding of warm (tear)drops born of long separation betrays his affection. 21

16 / RÂ¯

341

After an examination of the itinerary of the cloud as described by KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asa,

the great Maharashtrian scholar, V.V. Mirashi, identified the RÂ¯

amagiri of the

MeghadÂ¯

uta with Ramtek Hill. He argued that the route that was followed by the cloud corresponds closely with the geography of Middle India and this left, in his view, only one possibility open. 22 The coherence of Mirashiâ€™s arguments and the apparent consistency of the evidence give his conclusions a great plausibility.

From the combined evidence of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka inscriptions on the one hand,

and KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asaâ€™s poetic description on the other, we may deduce the following hypotheses regarding the situation on this hill in the first half of the 5th century:

1

The Lord of RÂ¯

amagiri was Bhagavat, i.e. Vis.n.u, known as RÂ¯amagirisvÂ¯amin.

2

The hill was associated with the perigrinations of Raghupati, i.e. RÂ¯

ama,

the hero of the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a and for that reason was called â€˜RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hillâ€™.

3

The hill may have contained a tank or pond named SÂ¯Ä±tÂ¯

akun.d.a or

JÂ¯

anakÂ¯Ä±tÂ¯Ä±rtha. 23

4

The hill may have contained a sanctuary where Vis.n.uâ€“RÂ¯amaâ€™s footprints ( pada) were worshipped.

Vis.n.upada

Since the time Mirashi advanced his theory, many new VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka artefacts have

come to light.

Plate 54

Footprint tablet, Nagardhan (c. 12Ã— 12Ã— 4 cm) 22 Mirashi 1964a, 138.

23 This tank may have been referred to in the YÂ¯

adava inscription under the name of

RÂ¯

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

342

Hans Bakker

I have selected two of them for discussion here. 24

A tablet containing a pair of footprints was reportedly found in the Nagardhan area, i.e. at the foot of RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hill (Plate 54). 25 On account of the style

compared to other findings of the same site, the tablet is probably to be dated to the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka period (5th century). The iconography of the tablet merits a closer examination.

In addition to the pair of footprints, it contains the Vais.n.ava symbols of the conch ( Â´

sa Ë™nkha) and club ( gadÂ¯

a). From this we conclude with certainty that we are concerned with an icon representing the footprints of Vis.n.u (Vis.n.upada).

An investigation into the early evidence of Vis.n.upada shrines has established that such shrines were preferably situated on hill- or mountaintops. And this makes sense, since it may have its origin in the idea that the three cosmic strides of Vis.n.u Trivikrama were taken along the axis mundi, represented either by the primordial hill of Vedic cosmogony or by the sacrificial post or yÂ¯

upa in Vedic

ritual. To this effect the Dutch scholar F.B.J Kuiper has observed: From a purely mythological point of

view Vis.n.u, who by his position in

the center must also in Vedic be-

lief have been immediately associ-

ated with the cosmic pillar ( skambhÂ´

a),

must have ascended along the pillar

at the beginning of the year and de-

scended in the second half of it. [. . . ]

There is clear evidence of Vis.n.uâ€™s con-

nection with the mountains:

he is

â€˜dwellingâ€™ or â€˜standingâ€™ on the moun-

tain(s) and â€˜regent of the mountainsâ€™.

[. . . ]

he stands on the summit of

the mountain (R

. gveda 1.155.1). [. . . ]

Later art represents him standing on

Mount Mandara, and arising from it

as the cosmic pillar.

In the middle

of the seventh century A.D. an artist

at MÂ¯

amalapuram portrayed the god,

while taking his three strides, as being

the supporting pillar of the universe.

(Kuiper 1983, 49)

Plate 55

Vis

The idea of Vis

. n

. u Trivikrama, RÂ¯

amagiri

.n.u Trivikrama leaving a

footprint behind on earth was eventu-

ally extended to Vis.n.u in general and to his human incarnations in particular.

24 I have earlier dealt with these findings separately in more detail in Bakker 1991, 1993b, 1997.

25 Cf. Bakker 1991, Plate facing p. 19. Bakker 1997, 136 f., Plate XXXI B.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

16 / RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hill

343

RÂ¯

amagiri appears to be an example as may be inferred from the evidence presented here. The VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akasâ€™ familiarity with this cosmogonical nature of Vis.n.u is proven by a 5th-century Trivikrama image of this god which still stands on top of the hill (Plate 55).

Returning to the iconography of the tablet, we observe that in between the two footprints an enigmatic symbol is engraved. It consists of a vertical axis to which horizontal strokes, slightly turning upwards, are attached on both sides, rounded off in the apex. In earlier publications I have suggested that this may represent a (cosmic) tree. Although the tree would fit perfectly in the symbolism described above, this view should now be given up in favour of an interpretation that sees in the object a cakra in upright position, thus completing the Vais.n.ava iconography of conch, club and wheel. Vis.n.uâ€™s footprint, referring to his three strides to separate heaven and earth along the cosmic pillar ( skambha) fits his â€˜connection with the mountainsâ€™, as observed by Kuiper.

The symbolism of the footprint tablet would thus be complete, if we could assume that the tablet found at the foot of the hill reflects, in miniature format, a shrine that once crowned the hill.

This hypothesis helps us to understand the significance of the squares within which the footprints are enclosed: they may mirror the ground plan of the open-air shrine that once crowned RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hill, the rÂ¯

amagirisvÂ¯

aminah

. pÂ¯

adamÂ¯

ulam

sanctuary, in which PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a worshipped and from where she issued

her charters: a square enclosure giving access to a square platform on which an altar containing the footprints of the Lord was installed, squared in by a low railing or wall. 26 The tradition that connected the hill with a visit of RÂ¯

ama

naturally saw in it the footprints of Raghupati.

The above reasoning rests on the assumption that smaller replicas were made of the images which were enshrined in the temples on top of RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hill in

the 5th century. Replicas that may have served personal devotional purposes.

They may have been for sale in the local bazars, as they generally still are today, and they may have been purchased by the pilgrim to put in his satchel for carrying home as a sacred memento. For this assumption we possess further evidence.

Narasim

. ha

Among the most prominent remains of the fifth century are the two Narasim

. ha

temples on top of the hill. In one of these temples a VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka inscription

has been discovered which says that the image of PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin had

been installed by the daughter in memory of and for the transfer of merit to her deceased mother, the dowager queen PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a. It is uncertain

whether the Narasim

. ha image in the temple where the inscription was found actually corresponds with the named PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin, since the inscription

may have originally belonged to another temple on the hill, for instance the 26 For the evidence of footprint shrines in the Gupta/VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka period see Bakker 1991.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

344

Hans Bakker

one of Trivikrama. The discussion of this possibility will be postponed; it will be investigated in Bakker 2010c, 2012, 2013b (see below, pp. 351 ff., pp. 357 ff., pp. 365 ff.).

For the sake of our present argument we concentrate on the Narasim

. ha image.

This image (Plate 57) is very similar to a slightly earlier specimen which we find in the adjacent temple (Plate 58) and of which we have conjectured that it was installed by PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± herself for her deceased husband Rudrasena II. 27

The temple is still known as Rudraâ€“Narasim

. ha. Both these temples and their

impressive images thus testify to the grandeur of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka royal family

and its god: Bhagavat Vis.n.u. In front of them, the fifth-century pilgrim must have stood in awe, as we still do today. What is more natural than the wish to carry it home in portable format?

At the foot of the hill, in the same area where the Vis.n.upada icon has been found, about nine small Narasim

. ha images have come to light and of these

we can be certain that they are miniatures of the two large Narasim

. ha images

preserved in the temples on top of the hill (Plate 56). The devout practice of making and distributing replicas of the main images on the RÂ¯

amagiri in the

5th century thus seems to be proven beyond reasonable doubt.

Hans Bakker

The pilgrimâ€™s satchel

Coming to the end of our study, we are now in the position to address that aspect of the phenomenon of pilgrimage that has been chosen by the organizers, A. Barbero & S. Piano, as theme of the conference.

Once they return to their home countries, pilgrims make great efforts to reproduce, either wholly or in part, the buildings and environment that they have seen. [. . . ]

Can this phenomenon of imitation, we may ask, be demonstrated by means of samples taken from the classical Indian heritage, that is, for instance, from the material that we have surveyed? The footprint tablet is less suited to this aim, on account of its rather general nature. The Narasim

. ha icon, on the other

hand, may be a better index. The iconography of this type of Man-lion icon is unique enough to serve as a marker, and the RÂ¯

amagiri one is apparently the

first specimen of this type. Soon, that is from the sixth century onwards, a new iconography of this avatÂ¯

ara of Vis.n.u became fashionable all over India, one in which the demon Hiran.yakaÅ›ipu is lying across the knees of the Man-lion, his belly ripped open by the lionâ€™s claws (Plates 18 and 59).

Plate 59

Narasim

. ha slaying the demon Hiran

. yakaÂ´

sipu

RÂ¯

ajÂ¯Ä±valocana Temple, Rajim (7thâ€“8th cent.)

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

16 / RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hill

347

Moreover, the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka culture and its religious and artistic achievements rapidly sunk into oblivion after the fall of this dynasty by the end of the 5th century, and we hardly have any evidence that RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Hill retained more than

local significance, until it re-emerged as a regional centre of pilgrimage in the 12th and 13th centuries, in the wake of the rise of the cult of RÂ¯

ama as the

supreme form of God (above, pp. 161 ff.) It is in that period, we presume, that the old 5th-century footprint shrine was replaced by the large temples of RÂ¯

ama and Laks.mana, which still stand today on the promontory of the hill. For imitations of the Narasim

. ha icon we therefore have to look for 5th or

6th century specimens in the area covered by the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kingdom and its

neighbours (Figure 6).

Figure 6

Map of Vidarbha and surrounding countries

I know of three specimens belonging to the early 6th-century that are clear imitations of the RÂ¯

amagiri icon. They are found in regions that have been in close contact with the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kingdom. The first one (Plate 60) is carved in

the rock at Sindursi near Bahuriband (Madhya Pradesh), c. 20 km west from Sleemanabad on highway No. 7, which connected and still connects Vidarbha with the Gangetic plain.

The other two have been found in Garh-Dhanora (c. 140 km south of Raipur) in the Bastar District of neighbouring Chhattisgarh, 28 an archaeological site identified with the ancient capital Pus.karÂ¯Ä± of the Nalas, whose expanding kingdom contributed to the collapse of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kingdom at the end of the

28 Nigam 2004, 151 f.

. ha icon lived

amagiri in Vidarbha.

Conclusion

We briefly return to KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

the poet, when he introduced the anonymous Yaks.a living in exile on the RÂ¯

amagiri, was thinking of a local deity on Ramtek Hill, a predecessor of the one Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

350

Hans Bakker

whom the 13th-century YÂ¯

adava inscription called â€˜Smoke Eyeâ€™, DhÂ¯

umrÂ¯

aks.a,

and who, in that inscription, was identified with the Â´

sÂ¯

udra ÅšambÂ¯

uka of the

RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a. A feature that these two have in common, KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asaâ€™s yaks.a and

the deity DhÂ¯

umrÂ¯

aks.a/ÅšambÂ¯uka, is that both were punished for a transgression of the law ( dharma). However, what the poet knew very well, and what seems to have a special relevance in our age of virtual reality, was that â€˜substitutesâ€™

can never replace the real thing. This he expressed beautifully in a verse that the Yaks.a gave to the Cloud to convey to his beloved: Whenever I draw your picture on a rock in natural colours and wish to throw myself at your feet, you who are wounded by love, time and again my eyes become misted with a flood of tears: cruel fate prevents our meeting even there. 30

A New Interpretation of RÂ¯

amagiri Evidence

âˆ—

1

Trivikrama: Word and Statue

Preamble

A long series of seminars at the Institute of Indian Studies of the University of Groningen came to its preliminary conclusion in 1993. In these seminars, in which Rob Adriaensen, Harunaga Isaacson and Hans Bakker took part, the newly discovered stone inscription in the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple (KNT) on

top of the RÂ¯

amagiri (Ramtek Hill) had been studied; this study resulted in the publication of the inscription with a translation and commentary (Bakker & Isaacson 1993; above, pp. 113 ff.).

The greater part of the inscription was illegible due to severe damage, but we were and are pretty confident that what was readable was read correctly.

The main problem, namely that of the interpretation of the inscription, could only partly be solved. The large gaps in the legible text left ample scope for conjecture. A modest beginning was made by presenting conjectured syllables between angular brackets, and some conjectures, of which we were less certain, were given in the footnotes and annotation. Nevertheless it remained unre-solved whether the inscription originally had contained the 34 verses edited or whether another 15 or 16 verses were missing due, to the fact that a right portion of the slab of unknown size had broken off and had been lost. Also the overall dedication of the inscription, which largely depends on the interpretation of its first verse, remained problematic.

When I was working on the history of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas, I decided to reedit the

inscription, that is to say, to carry on with conjectural interpretation. Some conjectures earlier carefully regulated to the footnotes were included in the text and some new conjectural readings were proposed. This second revised edition appeared as Appendix I: The Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple Inscription (second

revised edition), in Bakker 1997, pp. 163â€“167. Another round of discussions followed. Isaacson, for one, pointed out that some of my new conjectures were

âˆ— The first version of this article was published as the first in a series of three under the title Trivikrama: Word and Statue. A new interpretation of RÂ¯

amagiri evidence (1). in:

Acta Orientalia Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae. Volume 63.3 (2010), 241â€“247.

I am much obliged to Harunaga Isaacson, who has been willing to discuss the evidence with me again and again, and whose valuable suggestions have helped to shape my thoughts as presented below.

351

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

352

Hans Bakker

less plausible, 1 and of others I became myself gradually more doubtful. 2 In sum, the final edition and interpretation of the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple In-

scription is still beyond our reach. In the present contribution I would like to address the central hermeneutic question: the overall dedication and assignment of the inscription.

Ma Ë™ngalavÂ¯

ada: Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple (KNT) Inscription verse 1

The first verse of the inscription is of the nature of a ma Ë™ngala or benediction and refers to the main deity to whom the pious works listed are dedicated. It was published in 1993 as follows:

at.aka conference held in Groningen in June 2002 Isaacson pointed out that my conjectural reading of verse 5b: pitur gr

. h hes.v a i (pra)ti(s.)i(ddha) h Â´

a i jar(s.)isa h mudraguptah. i, which would imply that the verses 2 and 3 are concerned with the father of Candragupta, who, however, does not play a role further on in the inscription. The inscription does not contain the official dynastic genealogy, as do the copperplate charters of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±

GuptÂ¯

a and her son Pravarasena. I now think it more likely that the verses 2 and 3 sing the praise of Candragupta who, as the late grandfather and father-in-law of the donor (the princess AtibhÂ¯

17.1 / Trivikrama: Word and Statue

353

The second edition built on the hypothesis advanced in the first edition, viz.

that the deity of this verse is the Bhagavat, Vis.n.u, whose dark-blue colour resembles the rain cloud, but, more clearly than in the first edition, it makes explicit that at least one of the deeds referred to concerns the VÂ¯

amana avatÂ¯

ara,

in which King Bali is outwitted by Trivikrama. Whether this caused the fear of the wife/wives of the demon in pÂ¯

ada d, or another one of Vis.n.uâ€™s deeds,

could not well be decided, as long as the meaning of pÂ¯

ada b remained opaque.

Afterall, the inscription is found in a Narasim

. ha temple and the wife of the

ditija Hiran.yakaÅ›ipu could also possibly have been intended.3

I would now propose a reading of the remaining lacuna that would give this verse a significant coherence (changes to the 1997 edition in bold face): 1

hsa jai(ya)ti sajalÂ¯

ambudodarÂ¯

ahbhai(s),

[2010]

(su)hrasaimitihpirasarÂ¯

ajyahpÂ¯

ainahlaujÂ¯

ah

**. **i |

hbai(l)hii(ma)khasamayaidhitÂ¯

a Ë™nga(Å›o)hbhoi,

hditijavadhÂ¯

uibhayalohlaidr.s.t.i(dr.)hs.t.aih. k 1 k

The one whose colour resembles the depths of a water-laden rain-cloud and whose vigour is (like) a sacrifical fire drinking the clarified butter (poured) in streams within the divine assembly; the splendour of whose body is enlarged at the time of Baliâ€™s sacrifice, and who is looked at by the wives of Ditiâ€™s son with gazes that tremble with fright, that one is victorious. (1)

The conjectured reading divides the verse clearly into two halves: the first hemistich regards Bhagavat Vis.n.u under some of his general aspects, his dark-blue colour symbolizing his bounty, just as the blue rain cloud is a boon of nature; 4 his vigour and splendour is like a flash, just as fire blazes up when ghee is poured into it. The hemistich evokes the beautiful and powerful image of flashes/lightning against the background of dark monsoon clouds and connects Vis.n.uâ€™s bounty with the (Vedic) sacrifice. The second half specifies one particular aspect of his, viz. his rescue of the world from the hands of the demon king, the son of Diti, Bali, by a powerful display of his cosmogonic dimension, the three strides, Trivikrama. From this hypothesis I infer that the piety listed in the inscription is integrally dedicated to Vis.n.u Trivikrama. The verse is consistent and cogently voices orthodox Bhagavatism.

The conjectured reading Â¯

ajyapa, â€˜drinking clarified butterâ€™, is well attested and may be illustrated by a passage in the ÅšatapathabrÂ¯

ahman

. a (translation

Eggeling):

He then says 3), â€˜SvÃ¢hÃ¢ Agnim!â€™ with reference to Agniâ€™s butter-portion;â€”â€˜SvÃ¢hÃ¢ Agnim PavamÃ¢nam!â€™ if they determine upon (offering to) Agni, the blowing 4) ; 3 Cf. Bakker & Isaacson 1993, 57; Bakker 1997, 30 n. 94.

4 Cf. VDhP III, Vol. 1, 3.44.10.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

354

Hans Bakker

or â€˜SvÃ¢hÃ¢ Agnim Indumantam!â€™ if they determine upon Agni, the drop-abounding 5) ;â€”â€˜SvÃ¢hÃ¢ Agnim!â€™â€”â€˜SvÃ¢hÃ¢, the butter-drinking Agnis! May Agni graciously accept of the butter!â€™â€”this is the offering-prayer he (the Hotri) pronounces. 5

In post-Vedic Sanskrit Â¯

ajyapa is mostly used as a proper noun, but the slightly archaic attributive usage of the word in the 5th century inscription may have been intended as a show of orthodoxy. After all, the sacrificial myth at issue, Vis.n.uâ€™s three strides (Trivikrama), is a R.gveda one, and the VÂ¯amana myth is told in the same text (ÅšBr 1.2.5; 1.9.3.8 ff.) that calls Agni Â¯

ajyapa. The

reading ojas (if the conjecture is correct) also may recall the R

. gveda myth:

yadÂ¯

a te [scil. Indra] vis.n.ur ojasÂ¯a trÂ¯Ä±n.i padÂ¯a vicakrame | (R.V 8.12.27). The kavi who composed the praÂ´

sasti (referred to in vv. 33, 34) knew his Â´

sruti.

The above observations prompt us to speculate about the group of priests (to which also the kavi may have belonged), which performed the various rituals that accompanied the described activity and which may have (indirectly) benefited from it. These pious acts were for the greater part performed for the exclusive benefit (merit) of the (deceased) mother, whom, as we have argued, is queen PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±. 6 It would be natural that for this purpose the daughter employed priests (not mentioned in the readable part of the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha

Temple Inscription), who had been closely connected to her mother; some of those we know from PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s last charter dated in the 20th regnal year

of her son Pravarasena II (c. ad 442), that is shortly before she died, when the dowager queen was about seventy years old: they were brahmins belonging to â€˜the KaÅ›yapa gotra and the MÂ¯

adhyandina Â´

sÂ¯

akhÂ¯

a of the VÂ¯

ajasaneyÂ¯Ä± sam

. hitÂ¯

a

of the Yajurvedaâ€™, in other words, brahmins to whose sacred text corpus the ÅšatapathabrÂ¯

ahman

. a belonged. 7 It can therefore hardly be surprising if idiom of this corpus would show up in the inscription, as our conjecture suggests.

The KNT Inscription verse 21

We now turn to a portion of the inscription that describes the deeds performed for the sake of merit, which was the main object of the activity of the princess (v. 19: manujendraputrÂ¯Ä±), verses 20 ff. Being not part of the praÂ´

sasti, it is in

the simpler metre of the Åšloka. In the second edition of 1997 verse 21 runs as follows (changes to the edition of 1993 in bold face):

The conjectures accepted in the revised text make the references to the temple ( Â¯

. a

(a cretic:

Ë˜

) is avoided in the positions 2 to 4 of the even pÂ¯

it would give us the following text (changes to the 1997 edition (above, p. 124) in bold face):

11

prabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

aminam

. ca, lokanÂ¯

a(la)hyei |

[2010]

pun.yam aks.ayam uddiÅ›ya, (mÂ¯a)htuh. **Å›ubham **aikhÂ¯airayahti k 21 k Then (the princess) commissioned the splendid â€˜Master of PrabhÂ¯

a-

vatÂ¯Ä±â€™, (the image of the) Lord of the World, within the temple, for the sake of undecaying merit of (her) mother. (21)

The principal deed recorded in the inscription, the foundation of the temple ( Â¯

alaya) itself, may have been duly mentioned as the first item in the list of pious acts; it may have been expressed in the illegible verse 20. The installed deity, represented by the image within this temple, is Vis.n.u LokanÂ¯atha, designated as PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin.

Because the inscription was found in a Narasim

. ha sanctuary, we have hy-

pothesized that the splendid Narasim

. ha image in this temple (Plate 57) repre-

sents PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin. 8 However, in both editions already some doubt had been expressed regarding this identification, 9 and now, as we have reached a complete understanding of the first ma Ë™ngala verse, which unambiguously seems to refer to Trivikrama, not to Narasim

. ha, this doubt has turned into a firm

belief: originally the inscription did not belong to the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Tem-

ple.

The discovery of the KNT Inscription

Let us re-examine the present condition of the stone inscription. The inscription was found â€˜in the course of cleaning the walls of the Narsimha Temple at Ramtek . . . on the southern wall of the mandapaâ€™ by the Central Museum, Nagpur, as reported in Indian Archaeologyâ€”A Review 1982â€“83, 137.

The

removing of the layers of plaster caused great damage to the inscription. The latter was engraved in two stone slaps, the lower one (containing lines 13 to 15) was broken in the middle. Altogether these three parts were walled up again during the restoration work by means of cement. 10 The total height of the stone is about 50 cm, the breadth about 100 cm. The ragged right sides of 8 Bakker & Isaacson 1993, 69; Bakker 1997, 30, 141 f.

9 Bakker & Isaacson 1993, 57 (above, p. 128); Bakker 1997, 30 n. 94, 145.

10 Jamkhedkar 1992, p. 164 n. 18 notes: â€˜The removal of the whitewash and the location of the inscription on the original blocks of stone showed that the wall was intact.â€™

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

356

Hans Bakker

both the upper and the lower slab indicate that some portion of the stone had earlier been broken off, a portion that was obviously not recovered during the restauration work and is to be considered as irretrievably lost.

In other words, when the inscription originally was inserted into the southern wall of the man

. d

. apa of the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple it was already incom-

plete. 11 In an unknown state of the templeâ€™s history, possibly the Bhonsle period (18th century), when the temple was being repaired or rebuilt, the remaining slabs of the stone inscription must have been brought to the Kevalaâ€“

Narasim

. ha Temple. 12 The inscribed slabs of black stone thus came from elsewhere, possibly along with other building blocks of red sandstone, and their source may have been a similar, though ruined temple in the neighbourhood that was used as a quarry. Such a ruin does still exist on the RÂ¯

amagiri, viz.

a 5th-century temple of which, apart from two man

. d

. apa walls, little remains

today. Only its image has miraculously survived the ages in situ, and, although it is heavily damaged, this statue conclusively proves that this ruin once was a Trivikrama Temple. 13

From the evidence presented we infer that this Trivikrama image (Plate 55) is the one that is named â€˜PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

aminâ€™. The Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple

Inscription may thus originally have belonged to this, now ruined, Trivikrama Temple on the RÂ¯

amagiri. Other arguments that substantiate this inference are presented below, pp. 365 ff. (Bakker 2013b).

11 See Bakker & Isaacson 1993, 62; above, p. 135.

12 According to Jamkhedkar 1992, 159:

Raghuji (Bhonsle), after establishing himself in the Nagpur region, created an agrahÂ¯

ara

and religious endowments for the maintenance of the monuments and worship there.

At least at that time some repairs must have been executed.

In n. 15 ( ibid. ) this author writes:

When Raghuji set out on his expedition of Deogarh, he had camped at RÂ¯

am

. t.ek. On

seeing that the main temples are devoid of images, he made a vow that he would restore the images in their places if he was blessed with victory.

In fact, he had

got new images made at Jaipur, but ultimately consecrated old images (1753 A.D.) retrieved from the waters of the river Sur.

If this statement were true, it is not even certain that the Narasim

. ha image origi-

nally belonged to the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple. One wonders which and how reliable

the sources are of Jamkhedkarâ€™s above statement. The description of the temple after restoration and the first edition of the inscription were given in Jamkhedkar 1987b. In this publication (pp. 219, 222 f. nn. 17â€“19) Jamkhedkar describes the earlier â€˜conservative repairsâ€™ that were removed in the latest restoration. All this conveys the impression that the KNT temple has frequently been tampered with over the centuries.

13 See A.P. Jamkhedkar 1988, 85 f., Plates 103â€“09; Bakker 1997, 142â€“45, Plate XXXIV; above, Plate 55; below, Plates 64, 65.

A New Interpretation of RÂ¯

amagiri Evidence

âˆ—

2

The Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at

. aka Relationship

Preamble

The 5th-century stone inscription preserved in the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple

(KNT) on top of the RÂ¯

amagiri (Ramtek) has been edited thrice: by A.P Jam-

khedkar in 1987b, by Bakker & Isaacson in 1993, and by Bakker 1997. 14 Its interpretation is hindered by the fact that only one third of the text is legible.

Recently the present author has studied the inscription again and has proposed some new conjectural readings, which seem to clarify the overall dedication of the pious activity recorded in the inscription (Bakker 2010c; above, pp. 351 ff.).

According to this latest reconstruction, the pious activity recorded in the inscription seems to have been dedicated to Vis.n.u Trivikrama. Consequently, it has been argued that the inscription does not originally belong to the Kevalaâ€“

Narasim

. ha Temple in which it is presently found, but to the adjacent ruin of the Trivikrama Temple. The surviving Trivikrama image of this ruin may represent the PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin, the commission of which by a princess ( manu-

jendraputrÂ¯Ä±) is recorded in the KNT inscription (v. 19, above, pp. 354 f.).

The PraÂ´

sasti. KNT Inscription verses 2â€“19

In the present contribution I would like to reconsider the narratative structure of the praÂ´

sasti part of the inscription, i.e. its verses 2 to 19, in order to obtain a better understanding of the royal pedigree that it proclaims. Because the right-hand portion of the slab of stone on which the inscription has been engraved is missing, it could not be determined with certainty what the original number of verses may have been. A conservative estimate assumes that the inscription comprised 34 verses, of which the praÂ´

sasti part counted 19 (including

the Ma Ë™ngala verse). This estimate is based on the assumption that there were two UpajÂ¯

ati verses (88 syllables) to a line, each line beginning a new verse. The present slab measures c. 50 cm in height and 100 cm in width. The conservative estimate implies that the original stone must have covered a breadth of about 170 cm.

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in 2012 as the second in a series of three under the title The Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka Relationship. A new interpretation of RÂ¯amagiri evidence (2). in: Religions of South Asia 5.1â€“2 (2011), 293â€“302.

14 Jamkhedkar 1987b; Bakker & Isaacson 1993; Bakker 1997, Appendix I, The Kevalaâ€“

Narasim

. ha Temple Inscription (second revised edition), pp. 163â€“167.

357

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

358

Hans Bakker

However, in our first edition we did not exclude the possibility that the inscription originally had 3 UpajÂ¯

ati verses to a line, which would make the

breadth come to approximately 250 cmâ€”very broad indeed (above, p. 116).

The reason for this speculation was the contents of the inscription, since apparently much vital information, which we thought must have been in the original, was not found in the legible portion. 15

Rethinking the contents and structure of the praÂ´

sasti, I now think that

the conservative estimate leaves enough room for providing all information that is needed to make the story told in the inscription an intelligible and meaningful unity. The praÂ´

sasti does not contain the standard genealogy as do the copperplate charters of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas; instead it gives an unusually

detailed historical account of the extraordinary life of its patroness, the princess ( manujendraputrÂ¯Ä±) mentioned in v. 19, the last verse of the praÂ´

sasti, after which

the record of her pious deeds begins (vv. 20â€“34).

We take as our point of departure that the praÂ´

sasti originally counted only

one Pus.pitÂ¯agrÂ¯a verse (1) and 18 UpajÂ¯atiâ€™s (2â€“19). For the Sanskrit text and translation see above, p. 122 ff. We may present its hard core, that is the legible information contained in the inscription, as follows (verses are grouped in pairs when the subject is surmised to be divided over two verses and we have too little information to distinguish between the individual verses).

Verse

Number

Subject

1

1

Vis.n.u Trivikrama

2

rÂ¯

ajars.i, mighty king

4

1

5

1

girl who grows up like a flame in fatherâ€™s house

6

1

7

1

birth of sons and youngest sister named Mun.d.Â¯a

8

1

9

1

a . . . to Â´

srÂ¯Ä± Rudrasena

10

1

1

king . . . gets son Ghat.otkaca

12

1

1

wedding of rÂ¯

ajarÂ¯

aja . . . with bhÂ¯

agineyÂ¯Ä±

praise of . . .

1

bhrÂ¯

atr. brings . . . home with force ( balÂ¯at) 18, 19

Our first conjecture is that Candragupta mentioned in v. 9 is introduced in 15 Bakker & Isaacson 1993, 48; above, p. 116.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

17.2 / The Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka Relationship

359

the verses 2 and 3. Either he, or possibly his father Samudragupta, 16 is the one who is called rÂ¯

ajars.i in v. 2. This king Candragupta II gives his daughter named Mun.d.Â¯a to Rudrasena. Our second conjecture is that the king who in v. 11 is said to get the son Ghat.otkaca is also Candragupta and that this son Ghat.otkaca is the subject of v. 12 and is the same as the rÂ¯ajarÂ¯aja who is said to marry his sisterâ€™s daughter, that is his niece ( bhÂ¯

agineyÂ¯Ä±) in v. 13.

These set of conjectures is based on a postulate, that is, a premise that we cannot deduce from the inscription itself, but that we need, in order to give coherent meaning to its diverse pieces of information. The postulate is that the inscription is concerned with the genealogical relationship of the Gupta and VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka dynasties, neither of which is mentioned as such in the legible part of the inscription, and that this relationship underlies the contents of the illegible verses 4, 6, and 8. This relationship is known from other sources to be as follows.

Figure 7

Gupta VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka relationship as known before the KNT Inscription Candragupta IIâ€™s daughter PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a is married to the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka king

Rudrasena II. Ghat.otkaca is known as the viceroy of VidiÅ›Â¯a during the reign of his senior half-brother KumÂ¯

aragupta. 17 We assume that this relationship

underlies the illegible verses 8 and 10, that is to say that in v. 8 Rudrasena of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka dynasty is introduced and that in v. 10 the birth of a son (or sons) and one daughter in the marriage of Candraguptaâ€™s sutÂ¯

a and Rudrasena

(v. 9) is described. If this assumption is correct, it implies that the princess Mun.d.Â¯a given to Rudrasena is no one else than PrabhÂ¯avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯a, of whom Mun.d.Â¯a may be the personal name (see below, p. 362).

On account of these premises we conclude that the niece ( bhÂ¯

agineyÂ¯Ä±) of verse

13 is a daughter of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a and Rudrasena, who married her maternal

at.aka relationship as deduced from the KNT Inscription For the above reasoning to be correct, it is necessary to assume that the illegible verse 6 describes the wedding of Candragupta and the NÂ¯

aga princess

akÂ¯

at.aka king Pravarasena II, who may have been introduced either in verse 10 or verse 16. This inference is based not only on the above premises but also on the assumption that the illegible verse 16 refers, in guarded terms maybe, to a conflict leading to the death of Ghat.otkaca in verse 17, as the mentioning of Indra/Purandara suggests; this event turned the â€˜nieceâ€™ into a widow. The fact that he brings his widowed sister home â€˜with forceâ€™ ( balÂ¯

at, v. 17d) could

be explained by assuming that Pravarasena II sided with Ghat.otkaca against a common enemy. The manujendraputrÂ¯Ä± of v. 19 refers to this widow, daughter of Rudrasena and PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±, who had returned to her paternal home; from

verse 24d we conjecture that her name was AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±. 18

It goes without saying that the above schematic interpretation of the inscription is a hypothesis. If, to conclude, this hypothesis is correct, there is no need to suppose that a third UpajÂ¯

ati verse is missing at the end of the lines. The

The Daughter named Mun

. d

. Â¯

a

A key assumption in the theory advanced above is the identity of the daughter named Mun.d.Â¯a and the dowager queen known from her own inscriptions as PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

Success! Approved. By order of Lord Mun.d.asvÂ¯amin, God of gods, who holds the conch, discus and sword; after He had made the NÂ¯

aga king stretch out on

the waters of the ocean, He has entered a state of yogic sleep, while lying on the serpent coils of that (king) Ananta (the Infinite One)â€”a bundle of expanded hoods bending (over Him by way of canopy). 19

To make sense of this opening statement, we take it that the presiding god Devadeva (Vis.n.u), on whose cakra Rudrasenaâ€™s rule is said to be based (above, 19 Based on Shastri & Gupta 1997, 155 ll. 1â€“2. For Sanskrit text and discussion see Bakker 2010d; above,n. 36 on p. 326.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

362

Hans Bakker

p. 153, p. 326), is here designated â€˜Mun.d.asvÂ¯aminâ€™; and, in accordance with the practice of the age to prefix the names of the temple deities with the names of their founders, it follows that this deity had been installed by Mun.d.Â¯a (cf.

above, n. 41 on p. 328).

Although this is obviously the primary meaning of the opening statement, some double-entendre seems to be implied, since Mun.d.asvÂ¯amin may be taken to mean â€˜the husband of Mun.d.Â¯aâ€™, that is king Rudrasena, who is the actual author of the inscription. And the NÂ¯

agarÂ¯

aja who supports him could be taken

to mean a ruler of the NÂ¯

aga House, the house in which his mother-in-law,

KuberanÂ¯

agÂ¯

a, â€˜grew up like a flameâ€™. From the MÂ¯

an.d.hal. Plates it thus seems to

emerge that Rudrasenaâ€™s wife used her personal name Mun.d.Â¯a as long as her husband was alive. The dynastic name â€˜PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

aâ€™ was adopted when

she, as a dowager queen, assumed the regency over her sons. 20

The Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka relationship

The matrimonial relations of the Gupta and VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka dynasties can thus finally

be presented as follows.

Figure 9

The Gupta VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka relationship

After we have thus established the contents of the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple

Inscription to the best of our ability, it is time to be astonished at the story it tells.

The narration of the KNT Inscription

First of all it needs to be noted that, despite the fact that the inscription is found in VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka territory and celebrates foundations within the complex 20 Bakker & Isaacson 1993, 53; Bakker 1997, 16. The KNT inscription may hint at the dynastic name, when it compares in verse 7 the girl Mun

. d

. Â¯

a with the light ( prabhÂ¯

a) of

the moon ( candra): PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± is â€˜the one who possesses the lustreâ€™, scil. of Candra, her father. For a discussion of this name (meaning â€˜the bald oneâ€™) see above, n. 40 on p. 327.

Is it coincidence that Mun

. d

. Â¯

aâ€™s younger brother is named the one who is â€˜Bald-like-a-potâ€™

(Ghat.otkaca)?

17.2 / The Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka Relationship

363

of VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka state sanctuaries on the RÂ¯amagiri, the document may be called

â€˜Guptaâ€™ rather than â€˜VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akaâ€™. The praÅ›asti devotes ten verses (2â€“3,6â€“7,11â€“

16) to the Gupta lineage against only three (8â€“9, 17) to the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka family

members. Clearly the Gupta princess, nÃ©e VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka, remained loyal to her in-

laws, also after she had returned to the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kingdom. This emerges from

the fact that, if our theory is correct, four or five verses deal with her deceased husband Ghat.otkaca. And like her mother PrabhÂ¯avatÂ¯Ä± in her inscriptions, the princess AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± does not waste words on the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kings, mentioning

her father Rudrasena only in passing and apparently omitting his ancestors. By contrast, however, she elaborates on her maternal lineage, the NÂ¯

agas in vv. 4

and 5, the birth of her mother in vv. 6 and 7, and her own birth and wedding in vv. 10 and 13.

Like her mother Queen PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±, the princess took great pride in being a

descendant of Candragupta II, her maternal Gupta grandfather, who also happened to become her father-in-law. That the princess followed in the footsteps of her celebrated mother PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± is also evident from another important

fact revealed by the inscription: women, queens and princesses, had obviously a direct say in state affairs and had access to the financial recourses of the state, which they could apply to their own works of charity. It is unthinkable that temples, images, and a water reservoir could have been financed out of the traditional strÂ¯Ä±dhana. To have permitted such a degree of freedom to the women of their family is entirely to the credit of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kings Rudrasena

II and Pravarasena II. To this freedom we owe the magnificent monuments on the RÂ¯

amagiri.

Another astonishing fact revealed by the inscription is that marriages between uncle and niece ( bhÂ¯

agineyÂ¯Ä±) were, occasionally probably, permitted in the aristocracy, even under a brahmin king who boasted to have brought back to earth the Kr.tayuga, the golden age, in which the dharma was supposedly uncorrupted. 21 Here we are not concerned with cross-cousin marriage that is known from the Dravidian South. This once-removed filiation served to consolidate political power and territory. In this respect the Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka matrimonial

policy was not different from that practised within European royal courts. 22

The genealogy constructed by matrimony thus served a Machiavellian scheming for power in 5th-century India. I have described this scheming elaborately in my Theatre of Broken Dreams (Bakker 2006; above, pp. 301 ff.).

At the end, the inscription reports an act of violence, the forceful removal of a widow from the house of her in-laws. This implies war between the Guptas and VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas. Obviously the political objective of this non-dharmic union had grown stale when the Guptaâ€“VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka relationship deteriorated. The

21 See e.g. Pravarasenaâ€™s JÂ¯

amb Plates, in CII V, p. 12 lines 15â€“16.

22 Two European examples that spring to mind are found in the House of Habsburg: Charles II of Austriaâ€™s marriage to his niece Maria Anna of Bavaria (daughter of his sister Anna of Habsburg), and Phillip II of Spainâ€™s (fourth) marriage to his niece Anna of Austria (daughter of his sister Maria of Spain).

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

364

Hans Bakker

death of Ghat.otkaca probably happened in a conflict over the royal succession after KumÂ¯

aragupta. Ghat.otkaca, viceroy in VidiÅ›Â¯a under KumÂ¯aragupta, was prevented from succeeding his brother to the throne by the latterâ€™s bastard son, Skandagupta. Evidently the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka king Pravarasena II took the side of his

brother-in-law Ghat.otkaca, and when this party lost the war of succession, he abducted his sister from the palaces of his enemy. 23 The war may have started with Pravarasenaâ€™s crossing of the NarmadÂ¯

a in c. ad 445,24 and ended with the

return of the widow to his capital Pravarapura/Nandivardhana. Skandagupta acceded to the Gupta throne in c. ad 455.

It cannot be excluded that yet another motive incited Pravarasena to this unprecedented act. His sister was given in marriage to her maternal uncle by Pravarasenaâ€™s mother PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± during the latterâ€™s regency. It could well

be that the young prince Pravarasena had never been too happy about this breach of the dharma and the subordination to the Gupta dynasty that it entailed. By bringing her back to her place of birth, King Pravarasena may have strengthened his image of a righteous king. This image was boosted further by allowing his sister to spend great sums on meritorious activity, the most significant of which may have been the building of the Trivikrama Temple and the installation of the image of PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin in memory of their mother,

PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a.

23 For more details see Bakker 2006.

24 In the Indore Plates dating from Pravarasenaâ€™s twenty-third regnal year, i.e. soon after PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s death, it is reported that Pravarasena II pitched his army camp ( vÂ¯

asaka)

in TripurÂ¯Ä± (modern Tewar) on the northern bank of the NarmadÂ¯

a River, i.e. in Gupta

territory (Mirashi 1982a, 69, 72 l. 1; Bakker 1997, 25; above, p. 314).

A New Interpretation of RÂ¯

amagiri Evidence

âˆ—

3

The Trivikrama Temple

Preamble

This essay is the last of a series of three. 25 In the first two sections it has been argued that the pious activity recorded in the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Tem-

ple Inscription was actually dedicated to Vis.n.u Trivikrama, not to Narasim

. ha,

the deity installed in the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple on top of the RÂ¯

amagiri

(Ramtek) where the inscription has been found.

From this and other cir-

cumstantial evidence it has been inferred that the KNT inscription does not originally belong to the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple, but to the adjacent ruin of

the Trivikrama Temple and that PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin, the deity named in the in-

scription, actually refers to the Trivikrama image preserved in this ruin (above, p. 356). The KNT Inscription may have been placed in the Narasim

. ha Tem-

ple together with other building blocks when this temple was reconstructed in the Bhonsle period (18th century). The ruins of the Trivikrama Temple in its vicinity may have served as a quarry. In the present study I will substantiate this inference by comparing the evidence of the inscription with the material remains of the Trivikrama Temple which are still in situ.

The Trivikrama Temple

As shown by the Google Earth satellite picture in Plate 63, both temples, the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha and the Trivikrama, are situated somewhat outside the main temple complex on the spur of the hill, which may be an indication of the relative late date of these two temples. This applies in particular to the Trivikrama Temple at the edge of the hill, c. 200 m northeast of the VarÂ¯

aha

Temple (Plate 11), which marks the entrance to the spur of the hill.

Of the Trivikrama Temple only parts of the vestibule ( man

. d

. apa) are still

standing (Plate 64). The main temple idol has been miraculously preserved (Plate 65), although it is heavily damaged and seems to occupy still its original position, facing west like the VarÂ¯

aha and Narasim

. ha images.

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in 2013 as the third in a series of three under the title The Trivikrama Temple. A new interpretation of RÂ¯

amagiri evidence (3).

in: South Asian Studies 29.2 (2013), 169â€“76.

25 For the first two see above, pp. 351 ff., and pp. 357 ff. (Bakker 2010c and 2012).

17.3 / The Trivikrama Temple

367

Plate 65

Main image of the Trivikrama Temple

The style and ornamentation of the walls and pillars of the vestibule have been described and illustrated by Jamkhedkar 1988. A stylistic comparison with the other 5th-century remains on the hill also indicates a relatively late date of this temple. In this respect it seems relevant to refer to Joanna Williamsâ€™ VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka

Art and the Gupta Mainstream, in which she observed the following: The pillars [of the Trivikrama Temple] are similar and might be compared to examples from Nachna and Deogarh in the late fifth and early sixth centuries ad, although the resemblances are not very specific. The only pecularity is a flat, anchor-shaped element below the lower vase, perhaps a simplified version of the palmette which often appears in this position. (Williams 1983, 225 f.) This anchor-shaped element and its counterpart in Deogarh are illustrated in Plates 66 and 67.

The iconography of the Trivikrama image

The Trivikrama image is made of red sandstone and measures 178Ã—119 cm.

Mirashi was the first to give a description of this idol.

The god has a crown on his head, with a halo round his face. He wears the ku-n

. d

. alas on his ears and a pearl-necklace with a large pendant round his neck. His vaijayantÂ¯Ä± garland is shown falling on both his legs. He wears an udarabandha. His lower garment, which is fastened at the waist with a girdle, hangs down in folds in front. His arms are now broken on both the sides, but their jewelled a Ë™

ngadas

(armlets) can still be seen. His left foot is planted on the ground, while the right foot, which was raised to measure the sky, is now broken at the knee. (Mirashi 1963, lx)

The deity had eight arms, all sadly broken off, which makes it impossible to say anything directly about the attributes he must have carried. He wears the double muktÂ¯

ayajËœ

nopavÂ¯Ä±ta, of which the six strings of pearls have been almost completely erased at the front side of the image, but are still clearly visible at the back. A significant feature of the Trivikrama image of the RÂ¯

amagiri is

the â€˜pleatedâ€™ Â´

siraÂ´

scakra that encircles his head, the origin of which James Harle (1987) has traced to the fan-shaped tufts at the end of the band holding the crown.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

17.3 / The Trivikrama Temple

369

Plates 68 and 69

Relief at the bottom of the Trivikrama sculpture

In the present context, the most significant part of the imageâ€”iconographically speakingâ€”is the relief at the bottom of the striding Trivikrama. This relief is rather worn off, but enough remains to identify the depiction (Plates 68 and 69). Clear and relatively well-preserved is the figure of King Bali standing underneath the stretched right leg of Trivikrama (Plate 71). To the right of the Daitya king we see the outline of a smaller figure, which, I presume, represents his wife (Plate 70).

Hans Bakker

The iconographic programme be-

comes clear if we compare it with

the well-known lintel from Pawaya

(Plate 73), which depicts Baliâ€™s sac-

rifice and Vis.n.u Trivikrama.

If

we ignore the representation of the

depicts from left to right:

17.3 / The Trivikrama Temple

371

The pious works of AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±

Although the relief is admittedly too worn to see the frightened eyes of the Daityaâ€™s wife, the RÂ¯

amagiri Trivikrama sculpture conforms to the depiction of the myth in the dedicatory verse of the KNT Inscription when it says of Vis.n.u:

The splendour of whose body is enlarged at the time of Baliâ€™s sacrifice, and who is looked at by the wives of Ditiâ€™s son (i.e. Bali) with gazes that tremble with fright, that one is victorious. (above, p. 353)

This inscription, as we have discussed in Bakker 1997, 2006 and 2012 (above, pp. 301 ff., pp. 357 ff.), relates the life and pious deeds of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

aâ€™s

daughter AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± after the Eastern VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka king Pravarasena II had

brought home his widowed sister from VidiÅ›Â¯

a. AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± erected the Trivi-

krama Temple in commemoration of her deceased mother, naming the deity after her mother PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin in order to transfer merit to her, as v. 21

of the inscription records:

Then (the princess) commissioned the splendid â€˜Master of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™, (the image

of the) Lord of the World, within the temple, for the sake of undecaying merit of (her) mother. 26

And after the building of this main temple and the installation of its main image, the princess commissioned other works. The most evident among them was the building of a flood-control dam, which yielded the water reservoir SudarÅ›ana (v. 24):

She of extreme lustre ( atibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±) had a water reservoir SudarÅ›ana made, along with the beautiful god (SudarÅ›ana) in the village of KadalÂ¯Ä±vÂ¯

at.aka. 27

KadalÂ¯Ä±vÂ¯

at.aka may be the modern hamlet KelÂ¯apur, 2 km north of RÂ¯amaâ€™s Hill and the artificial lake is, after the dam had been rebuilt in recent times, again (or still) there, known under the name of Khindsi Lake. The Trivikrama Temple towers high above this beautiful sight, SudarÅ›ana (Plate 74).

Conclusion

Summarizing, it may be observed that the identification of PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin

with Vis.n.u Trivikrama and, consequently, the assignment of the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple Inscription to the Trivikrama Temple are corroborated by: 1 The perfect match of the Ma Ë™ngala verse and the iconography of the Trivikrama image.

2 The location of the Trivikrama Temple, somewhat outside the main temple area, which links this temple closely to the other work of AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±, the

artificial SudarÅ›ana Lake.

3 The relatively late date of the Trivikrama Temple and sculpture, which are stylistically the latest of all VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka remains at RÂ¯amagiri.

26 For the Sanskrit text see above, p. 124 and p. 354.

27 For the Sanskrit text see above, p. 124.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

372

Hans Bakker

Plate 74

View of the reservoir SudarÂ´

sana (Khindsi Lake) from the

Trivikrama Temple on the top of the RÂ¯

amagiri (view to the north)

As has been argued, the activity of AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± must have taken place between

the death of her husband Ghat.otkaca Gupta (c. ad 453â€“54) and that of her brother Pravarasena II (c. ad 456â€“57). AtibhÂ¯avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s example was copied, when power shifted from the Eastern to the Western VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka kings following the

death of Pravarasena II. An inscription found in Hisse-Borala near Wasim of Devasena, VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka king in Vatsagulma, dated in the year 380 of the Åšaka Era, i.e. ad 457â€“58, records â€˜the construction of a water storage ( saras) called SudarÅ›ana by a noble named SvÂ¯

amilladeva, for the welfare of all living beingsâ€™

(Bakker 1997, 32).

The building of the Trivikrama Temple and the installation of its deity PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin took place before this and may thus be dated between ad 453 and 457. The Trivikrama sculpture (Plates 55 and 65) was made in those years, probably in the same workshop in which the images of the PravareÅ›vara Temple in Mansar (5 km to the west) were sculptured. The latter temple was the grand project of the princessâ€™ brother, King Pravarasena II, and by this time the sculptors had exchanged the dark basalt stone, used in the earlier images of VarÂ¯

aha and Narasim

. ha, for the red sandstone that gave the hill its

other name, SindÂ¯

uragiri. 28

28 For the SindÂ¯

uragirimÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya see above, p. 338. For the PravareÅ›vara Temple in Mansar and its images see Bakker 2008, http://irs.ub.rug.nl/dbi/4ccec5f085aa0.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

A Note on Skandaguptaâ€™s BhitarÂ¯Ä± Stone Pillar Inscription, verses 8â€“12âˆ—

Commemorating the Dead

Ajay Mitra Shastri

One of the dear memories I have of Prof Dr Ajay Mitra Shastri is the moment that the doors of the arrival hall of Amsterdam Airport opened and I saw my learned friend leaving the â€˜nothing to declareâ€™ behind him. He came as a an invited speaker of the biennial conference of the European Association of South Asian ArchÃ¦ologists, held in Leiden in the summer of 1999. The journey had been a safe one and evidently Ajay was much relieved when he saw a familiar person at the place of landing. A happy smile passed over his face. And I was glad that, finally, I had an opportunity to return some of the kind hospitality that had been bestowed on me every time I had come to Nagpur. Taking its start from a common interest, our relationship had developed from mutual respect to friendship.

Ajayâ€™s contribution to the conference, SÂ¯

atavÂ¯

ahana-Ks.atrapa Chronology and

Art-history, was a brilliant one, displaying a learning in history, numismatics and epigraphy that only few people can match. To invite my friend had proven to be an excellent idea. For myself he had a surprise in store. When I spoke of the role the archaeological site of Mansar could have played in VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka

history and had made the conjecture that the temple that the ASI had only just unearthed (MNS 3) could have been PravareÅ›vara, known from inscriptions, Ajay rose and informed the audience that this conjecture had been confirmed by recently found sealings, which had been brought to him from the site by the excavators for deciphering: they read that very templeâ€™s name. 1

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Sharma, R.K & Devendra Handa (eds.), Revealing Indiaâ€™s Past (Recent Trends in Art and Archaeology). Prof. Ajay Mitra Shastri Commemoration Volume. Aryan Books, New Delhi 2005. 2 vols. The editors made the decision to publish this article in two parts. Its first part they gave the title: Commemorating Prof. Ajay Mitra Shastri; it appeared in Volume I, p. lxii. Its second part, A Note on Skandaguptaâ€™s BhitarÂ¯Ä± Inscription vv. 8â€“12 was published in Volume II, 248â€“51.

These two parts were originally drafted as a whole and for that reason are reassembled here.

1 See Kropman 2008.

373

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

374

Hans Bakker

Plate 75

Sealing (seal impression) found in MNS 3 reading: pravareÅ›vara After the conference I had the honour and pleasure to be Ajayâ€™s host for some more days. The weather was beautiful, we did some sight-seeing and drunk tea in our garden. It was there that we discussed for the first time the idea to organize a joint conference on the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akas. Plans were worked out in the

years that followed. The conference was scheduled to take place in Groningen in June 2002. On Saturday 12 January 2002 the news reached me that Ayaj Mitra Shastri had passed away a day earlier. 2 The shock was great. Shastriâ€™s death meant that Vidarbha had lost one of its great historians, a scholar whose work crowned the famous, learned tradition of V.V. Mirashi and V.B. Kolte.

And I had lost a friend.

As a tribute to the eminent savant I present a note on an inscription that is of great importance for our understanding of the Gupta-VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka period of

Indian history, the BhitarÂ¯Ä± Stone Pillar Inscription of Skandagupta.

Skandaguptaâ€™s BhitarÂ¯

Ä± Inscription vv. 8â€“12

This inscription has been published several times: 3 by Fleet in CII III (1888), 52â€“56, by Sircar in SI I, 321â€“324, by Bhandarkar in CII III (1981), 312â€“317, 2 The conference went ahead, sadly without A.M. Shastri, in Groningen from 6 to 8 June 2002. The proceedings were published in 2004 (Bakker 2004d).

3 See CII III (1981), 312 f.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

18 / A Note on Skandaguptaâ€™s BhitarÂ¯Ä± Stone Pillar Inscription 375

and most recently by DÃ¡niel Balogh forthcoming. In addition, the inscription has been discussed by several scholars, among whom Chhabra 1963, Mirashi 1982a, Agrawal 1986, 54â€“66, and Willis 2009, 144â€“49.

In his New Light on a Period in Gupta History Mirashi focused his attention on the verses 4 to 8 and argued that these verses â€˜refer to three different struggles in which Skandagupta was involvedâ€™. 4 Broadly speaking, I have followed Mirashiâ€™s argument, 5 and I would now like to discuss the concluding part of the inscription, verses 8 to 12, in which the immediate reason of the epigraph is given.

In verse 8, in which Skandaguptaâ€™s victory over the HÂ¯

un.as is reported, the

twanging sound of a bow is referred to in a simile that is part of Skandaguptaâ€™s swagger. 6 It appears natural that the mentioning of the bow ( Â´

sÂ¯

ar Ë™nga) implies

Skandagupta, which would mean that his bow is meant.

Verse 9 is nearly completely illegible, but a connection is made in it between Skandaguptaâ€™s deeds and his father ( svapituh

. ) KumÂ¯

aragupta. It should be

observed that kÂ¯Ä±rtti, apparently the first word of a compound, could refer to fame or anything that brings fame, e.g. a temple.

The first three syllables of pÂ¯

ada a of the next verse (10) are lost. Fleet

and Sircar conjectured kartavyÂ¯

a (Bhandarkar prakÂ¯

aryÂ¯

a), but an ingenious con-

jecture was made by Chhabra 1963, 546: na yasya (quoted with approval by Agrawal 1986, 63). It gives significance to the double occurrence of the word pratimÂ¯

a in the first hemistichâ€”more meaningful, in my view, than the pedestrian â€˜an image should be madeâ€™ of Fleet, Sircar, and Bhandarkarâ€”to the effect that, although God Vis.n.u is admittedly transcendent, that is without form ( na yasya pratimÂ¯

a kÂ¯

acit), a material image of Him in his manifestation of ÅšÂ¯

ar Ë™ngin can be made. I therefore take the genitive, â€˜of that wielder of the bowâ€™ ( tasya Â´

sÂ¯

ar Ë™ngin

. ah

. ) in 10b as depending on ( pratimÂ¯

am

. ) and referring to

the deity; the form chosen, that of the archer, implements a comparison with KumÂ¯

aragupta or Skandagupta (cf. 8b, 8d)â€”both certainly mighty bowmen to judge by their coinage. 7 The pratimÂ¯

am

. . . . imÂ¯

am (10bc) of Vis.n.u-ÅšÂ¯ar Ë™ngin is

the deity installed, whose name, as proposed by Bhandarkar, may have been KumÂ¯

arasvÂ¯

amin. 8

In the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata VÂ¯

asudevaâ€™s and/or Kr.s.n.aâ€™s bow is called ÅšÂ¯ar Ë™nga. It is the divine vais.n.ava bow.9 Curiously enough, the term or name ÅšÂ¯ar Ë™ngin does 4 Mirashi 1982a, 70 related the first of this struggles to the Indore Plates of Pravarasena II, Year 23 and argued that the â€˜un-named enemies of the Guptas included the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.akasâ€™

(cf. above, p. 146 and n. 29 on p. 325).

. , read by Fleet as gË†

7 See KumÂ¯

araguptaâ€™s and Skandaguptaâ€™s Archer Type and Skandaguptaâ€™s so-called â€˜King-and-Laks.mÂ¯Ä± Typeâ€™ of gold coins (above, p. 316 and Plate 48).

376

Hans Bakker

not occur in the critical text of either the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata or the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a. It

does occur, however in the *-passages in the critical apparatus and appendices of the MBh edition as a name of VÂ¯

asudeva-Kr.s.n.a.10 From this it follows that

the word ÅšÂ¯

ar Ë™ngin as a name of VÂ¯

asudeva is comparatively late, attested only in

the later phase of the composition of the epic, that is the 3rd to 5th centuries ad.

This agrees well with the evidence of the inscription. It is therefore reasonable to assume that the ÅšÂ¯

ar Ë™ngin mentioned in verse 10 is considered to be a form of VÂ¯

asudeva, the Bhagavat (v. 12). 11

It is clear that in verse 10 Skandagupta is credited with the making of an image of a deity that is known to be a mighty archer and as such reflects the qualities of himself and his father. In view of the fact that the merit of this act is assigned to the deceased father, KumÂ¯

aragupta, the name suggested for the

installed image, KumÂ¯

arasvÂ¯

amin, is a plausible conjecture. It has a contempo-

rary parallel in the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple Inscription, in which the merit

of the installation of the deity PrabhÂ¯

avatisvÂ¯

amin is assigned to KumÂ¯

araguptaâ€™s

sister, the deceased VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka queen, PrabhÂ¯avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯a.12

The puzzle in v. 11 is to whom/which (the masculine) enam, as read by Fleet, Sircar and Bhandarkar, in pÂ¯

ada a refers. It would normally be something that

is already mentioned ( anvÂ¯

adeÂ´

sa), something that is now being installed at the site ( iha). It can hardly be anything else but the deity ( devam), supposedly mentioned in 10d, i.e. KumÂ¯

arasvÂ¯

amin. A good suggestion made by DÃ¡niel

Balogh is to read (feminine) enÂ¯

am

. , which naturally refers to the pratimÂ¯

a of

the preceding verse. PÂ¯

adas 11cd add that a village or community ( grÂ¯

ama) is

assigned ( vidhÂ¯

a-) to the deity (i.e. to the temple and its priests) and that the merit of this deed accrues to KumÂ¯

aragupta. 13

This appears to be one of two ( ubhayam) acts that are performed for the benefit of the father (12cd). Which is the other one? I think we can exclude the erection of the column itself, as proposed by Bhandarkar, 14 since the inscription does not say anything explicit about it. This would leave the following possibilities: 1) the making ( cakÂ¯

ara) of the image, or, 2) the installation ( pratis.t.hÂ¯apya) of the image, or, 3) a combination of 1) and 2). The last possibility seems the most plausible one, that is, if we analyse verse 12 correctly.

Verse 11 is a syntactically independent clause: â€˜having done so and so, he assigned the village/community. . . â€™. This suggests that v. 12 is also a syntactically complete clause, consisting of a relative clause (12ab), in which two things 10 MBh 1 App. I No. 114 l. 339, 7.59 *440, 12 App. I No. 6 l. 29, 17.1 *3, 18.5 *30. Cf.

KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asaâ€™s MeghadÂ¯

uta 1.46 and AmarakoÅ›a 1.1.19.

11 VÂ¯

asudeva is used synonymously with Kr.s.n.a (sometimes equated with Vis.n.u). It is extremely unlikely that it refers to RÂ¯

ama.

12 Bakker 1997, 166 v. 21; above, p. 124.

13 The grÂ¯

ama is not specified in the legible part of the inscription, but, in view of the use again of the pronoun enam in 11c, it has probably been mentioned earlier as well, maybe in v. 9; the place of residence may have been the site where the inscribed column is found, i.e. the present BhitarÂ¯Ä±.

14 CII III (1981), 317 n. 4.
