18 / A Note on Skandaguptaâ€™s BhitarÂ¯Ä± Stone Pillar Inscription 377

are mentioned, and a main clause (12cd). The crux of the verse is pÂ¯

ada b. Fleet

and Sircar read â€˜ iyam

. yaÂ´

s cÂ¯

atra sam

. sthitah

. â€™ (with question marks), Bhandarkar

(Chhabra and Gai) proposes: â€˜ iyam

. yaÂ´

s cÂ¯

atra [ sa Ë™

mskri(r.)tah. ]â€™ ( op. cit. 316).

One would assume that the act of sam

. skr.- (consecration) is normally comprised

in the ritual of pratis.t.hÂ¯a- (installation) and plays no role here. iyam

. is signif-

icant: it may correspond to mÂ¯

urtir in pÂ¯

ada a, but it stands after the caesura

in the next pÂ¯

ada. This means that pÂ¯

ada 12b actually recapitulates the two

things that are referred to by ubhayam in 12c: 1) this one here (namely, the image), and ( ca) 2) â€˜who/that which is here sam

. . . . â€™. This interpretation takes

pÂ¯

ada 12a in apposition to iyam

. . Fleetâ€™s and Sircarâ€™s reading sam

. sthitah

. could

be understood as a periphrase of grÂ¯

amah

. : â€˜the one who is living here, (i.e. the

community)â€™, although it remains slightly unsatisfactory. Willis 2009, 148 f.

has reexamined the case in detail and reads sam

. Â´

sritah

. , which gives the better

sense: that which has been â€˜attachedâ€™ or â€˜consignedâ€™, viz. to the installed deity.

My comprehensive understanding of the proclamation made in vv. 8â€“12 is presented in a critical edition and translation of the text in the Appendix.

Concluding remarks on the inscription and the site of BhitarÂ¯Ä± To sum up, the purport of the inscription is to proclaim, in additon to Skandaguptaâ€™s victories on the battle field, that Skandagupta installed an image of VÂ¯

asudevaâ€“ÅšÂ¯

ar Ë™ngin, possibly named KumÂ¯

arasvÂ¯

amin, a deity who is a great

archer and as such reflects the qualities of the emperor and his father. For the maintenance of the image/temple Skandagupta assigns a village or community to the deity, that is to say, he exempts this community from taxes, so that its surplus production from now on may be used for worship of the deity and maintenance of the temple. Both beneficial acts are performed to increase the merit of his deceased father, KumÂ¯

aragupta.

Finally I would like to draw attention to an important remark made in the Introduction of the 1981-edition of CII III. On page 83 it is observed: â€˜In fact, BhitarÂ¯Ä± is studded with so many mounds that it is not impossible that it was the mausoleum or pratimÂ¯

a-gr.iha of the Gupta family.â€™15 This hypothesis has only partly been corroborated by the excavations carried out by the Department of Ancient Indian History, Culture and Archaeology, Banaras Hindu University, between the years 1968 and 1973, and 1995. 16 A proper assessment of these excavations reported by Vidula Jayaswal (2001), would go beyond the scope of this article. One photograph, taken from the excavatorâ€™s website, 17 may give an impression of the situation (Plate 76).

15 For the concept of the pratimÂ¯

agr

. ha and memorial temples see below, p. 415 (Bakker 2007a, 19â€“23).

16 Jayaswal 2001, vii.

17 https://www.cse.iitk.ac.in/users/amit/books/jayaswal-2001-royal-temples-of.

html.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

378

Hans Bakker

Above we adduced the parallel example of the foundation of the PrabhÂ¯

avati-

svÂ¯

amin temple on the RÂ¯

amagiri. In discussing this and neighbouring temples

on this hill, I have argued that these sanctuaries were erected to transfer merit to the deceased members of the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka family.18

Plate 76

BhitarÂ¯Ä±. Pillar with Skandaguptaâ€™s inscription and adjacent excavation of site 2

I would be hesitant to call these temples â€˜mausoleumsâ€™, since they were certainly no tombs or cenotaphs, nor is it at all likely that portraits (otherwise than through metaphor) of the deceased were set up, and maybe even the designation

â€˜memorialâ€™ is misleading, but these temples seem to have served some funerary or commemorative function, namely to ensure the salvation of the deceased by means of a transfer of merit. 19 An evaluation of the results of the excavations by Vidula Jayaswal and his team and further research must establish whether or not the site of BhitarÂ¯Ä± served such aims in Gupta times. I for one conclude with a paraphrase of Skandaguptaâ€™s words:

18 Bakker 1992b and 1997, 30 f., and above, p. 371.

19 For the phenomenon of merit-transfer see Wezler 1997.

translation

When he (Skandagupta) joined in close conflict with the HÂ¯

un.as, the earth was made

to tremble due to (the power of) his arms, since he caused a terrible whirlpool among the enemy by . . . of arrows; the brilliant . . . is proclaimed . . . , (which) sounds like the twanging of (his) bow ( Â´

sÂ¯

ar Ë™

nga) in (their) ears. (8)

Of his father . . . fame/temple . . . (9)

He (i.e. Skandagupta), as he is a celebrated (archer), has made an image of that

â€˜Wielder of the Bowâ€™, ÅšÂ¯

ar Ë™ngin (i.e. Vis.n.u), the One who is (actually) beyond form ( pratimÂ¯

a)â€”this (image) here, hwhich carries the name KumÂ¯

arasvÂ¯

amini. (10)

And after this image had been installed by him at this site, he (i.e. Skandagupta), as his orders are well-obeyed, has assigned this village (to the installed deity) for the sake of the increase of his fatherâ€™s merit. (11)

Hence the manifestation of the Lord,

this (image/manifestation) here (i.e.

KumÂ¯

arasvÂ¯

amin) and that which here has been consigned (to it) (i.e. the grÂ¯

ama),

he (i.e. Skandagupta) has destined both for the merit of (his) father, since he is determined upon merit. (12)

âˆ— This Appendix has been added and is not contained in the original publication of 2005.

The So-called

â€˜Jaunpur Stone Inscription of Â¯IÅ›varavarmanâ€™âˆ—

Preamble

Few scholars can claim mastery of such a wide range of different fields within the discipline of Indology as Prof Dr Oskar von HinÃ¼ber. One of the branches of learning that owes a great deal to his studies is Indian epigraphy. My contribution here is meant as a humble tribute to Oskar and his work.

Introduction

We possess two inscriptions that undisputably belong to that branch of the Maukhari family which eventually turned the ancient KÂ¯

anyakubja (Kanauj)

into their new capital, viz. the well-known Haraha Stone Inscription of

Â¯

IÅ›Â¯

anavarman of Vikrama Samvat 611 (ad 554), in which Â¯IÅ›Â¯anavarmanâ€™s son SÂ¯

uryavarman records his renovation of a dilapidated Åšiva temple, and an inscription found in Jaunpur. 1 The Jaunpur Inscription is merely â€˜a fragment of a very much larger inscriptionâ€™. 2 It deserves a detailed examination.

It is estimated that only about one-third of the width of the inscribed stone has been preserved (Plate 77), and it is unknown how many lines would have been below the last line extant. Fleet remarks that â€˜the probability is [. . . ]

that the larger number (seventy-two) has been lost at the beginning of this (i.e.

first) line, and in proportion all the way downâ€™. 3 The other option considered by Fleet is that only thirty-eight syllables are missing at the beginning of each line. This option is invalidated by the ÅšÂ¯

ardÂ¯

ulavikrÂ¯Ä±d.ita verse in line 3, of which

the end coincides with the right side of the stone. From this and the preceding incomplete MÂ¯

alinÂ¯Ä± verse of line 2 it can be deduced that altogether 69 syllables have been lost in line 3. This would bring the total number of aks.aras in line 3

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Indo-Iranian Journal 52.2â€“3 (2009), 207â€“16. The article in this double issue of IIJ was dedicated to Oskar von HinÃ¼ber.

1 For the Haraha Inscription of the Reign of Â¯

IÅ›Â¯

anavarman, Year [VS] 611 see: ÅšÂ¯

astri 1917â€“

18; Sircar SI I, 385â€“389; Thaplyal 1985, 141â€“146. For the Jaunpur Stone Inscription of

Â¯

IÅ›varavarman see: J.F. Fleet in CII III (1888), 228â€“230; Thaplyal 1985, 139â€“40.

2 CII III (1888), 228.

3 CII III (1888), 229 n. 2.

381

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

382

Hans Bakker

to 91. 4 Since the whole inscription consists of verses, it should be possible to estimate how many aks.aras have been lost in each line, notwithstanding Fleetâ€™s admittance that he has â€˜tried several ways of arranging the verses, [. . . ], but without being able to satisfy myselfâ€™. 5 It appears that the number of aks.aras per line varied between 91 and 99.

The inscription was published again in Thaplyal 1985, but he too refrained from a restoration of the distribution of verses. Earlier Sircar had reconstructed three verses along the lines we propose to follow here for the inscription as a whole. 6

Figure 10

The Maukharis of Kanauj

ardÂ¯

ulavikrÂ¯Ä±d

. ita

verse (CII III (1888), 229 n. 7).

5 CII III (1888), 229 n. 2.

via free access

19 / The So-called â€˜Jaunpur Stone Inscription of Â¯

IÅ›varavarmanâ€™

383

The inscription had been ascribed to Â¯IÅ›varavarman, on account of the fact that he is the only king mentioned by name in the fragment. When we collate our reconstruction with the Haraha Inscription, it appears that a similar pattern underlies both praÂ´

sastis and that it is highly unlikely that Â¯IÅ›varavarman was the last king mentioned, a conclusion also reached by Sircar 1964, though on other grounds. 7 Both praÂ´

sastis, however, are independent compositions and it is impossible to say which one of them is the older, although the Haraha Inscription seems to be slightly more ornate, having e.g. two ma Ë™ngala verses (the second one apparently drawing inspiration from the Ks.emeÅ›vara Temple, the object of the inscription) against one in the Jaunpur Inscription. In the underlying pattern two verses are reserved for Harivarman and Â¯

Adityavarman

in both inscriptions; Â¯IÅ›varavarman has three verses in the Haraha Inscription and three or two in the Jaunpur one, depending on whether one assigns verse 8 to him or to his son Â¯IÅ›Â¯

anavarman. The latter possibility is the most likely,

in view of the explicit mention of the â€˜lion throneâ€™, which we also encounter in the Haraha Inscription verse 13. In the Haraha Inscription Â¯IÅ›Â¯

anavarman has

five verses dedicated solely to him, whereas in the sixth his son SÂ¯

uryavarman

is introduced. The pattern we conjecture in the Jaunpur Inscription gives to

Â¯IÅ›Â¯anavarman at least five verses, while it remains unclear whether a son is introduced in verses 12 or 13. The Jaunpur inscription may therefore have belonged to either Â¯IÅ›Â¯

anavarman or to one of his successors.

An edition of the thus reconstructed text of the inscription is presented below, which is followed by my translation. In the footnotes to this translation the parallel verses of the Haraha Inscription are given together with my translation thereof.

The Jaunpur Stone Inscription

The reconstruction follows basically the text of Fleet with some minor adaptations, using, for instance, standard orthography. The bold figures between square brackets are the line numbers. Angular brackets (in edition and translation) are used to indicate that the reading is conjectured. Commas indicate the end of uneven pÂ¯

adas. The verse numbering is mine.

7 Sircar 1964, 129 draws this conclusion from verse 11, in which the kingâ€™s victory over the Andhras is celebrated. This victory was obtained by Â¯

IÅ›Â¯

anavarman, as Haraha Inscription

verse 13 tells us (see below, n. 26 on p. 388).

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

. k 2 k

He who is the cause of the acting deities that effect the manifestation, destruction and preservation of the world; the one on whom yogis, for whom the mass of darkness (i.e.

tamas) has been destroyed and who have overcome their passions ( rajas), meditate; the one in whose heart passion has no place, although a woman occupies half (his body); he, the soul of (all) living beings, the destroyer of the Triple City, the fountainhead of bliss on earth, is victorious. (1)

May that figure of Andhakaâ€™s Foe, on whose body snakes glimmer, offer you a stable abodeâ€”a figure who wears a lion skin that is slightly crimsoned by the light of the jewel in the hood of the serpent that is his sacred thread, and who reddens the white line of skulls that is the chaplet by the radiance from his third eye, and who bears on his crest the slender, darkness dispelling digit of the moon. (2) The verse describing the mythic descent of the Maukharis is found in the Haraha Inscription verse 3:

Among them (there arose) at the beginning, for the well-being of the world, a ruler of the earth, the (powerful) being (called) Harivarman, (a powerful being) measured by his fame, by which all quarters of space were besieged, and his brilliance, which destroyed the happiness of his foes; for whom the enemies bowed in fear, when they saw his face at the battlefield, as this was aglow with the lustre of (sacrificial) fire, and who for that reason obtained the name JvÂ¯

Conclusion

From the collation of the Jaunpur fragment and the Haraha Inscription it becomes clear that both Maukhari inscriptions follow a similar tradition. This tradition assigned to Harivarman great military prowess, to Â¯

Adityavarman piety,

[Â¯

anavarman] is victorious, he who has ascended the lion throne, his feet bowed to by the rulers of the earth, after having vanquished the sovereign of Andhra of whom the elephants, counted by the thousands, were passing triple fluid (scil., temple-must secretion, urine and faeces, due to excitement), after having routed in battle the SÂ¯

. as, driven from their territory by (his) might, take refuge at the ocean. (13) 27 Sircar 1964, 130 is right when he notes that, â€˜The word dhÂ¯

arÂ¯

arÂ¯

28 Sircar 1964, 128 conjectures that it was an unknown enemy, other than the Lord of Andhra, who fled to the Raivataka hill. The hill has not satisfactorily been identified.

To go by its name it may have been a hill along the RevÂ¯

a (= NarmadÂ¯

a) River. A hill

of this name is mentioned in the JunÂ¯

agad

. h Rock Inscription of Skandagupta. Fleet

identifies this Raivataka with the hill â€˜opposite to Ã›rjayat or GirnÃ¢râ€™ in Kathiawar, Gujarat ( CII III (1888), 64 n. 1).

19 / The So-called â€˜Jaunpur Stone Inscription of Â¯

IÅ›varavarmanâ€™

389

to Â¯IÅ›varavarman virtuousness, and to Â¯IÅ›Â¯

anavarman emperorship. The latter

was credited with the title MahÂ¯

arÂ¯

ajÂ¯

adhirÂ¯

aja in the seals of his successors and in

the inscriptions he is said to be seated on the lion throne. His son SÂ¯

uryavarman

was a young man in Vikrama Sam

. vat 611 (=ad 554), the date of the Haraha

Inscription. Â¯IÅ›Â¯

anavarmanâ€™s exploits may therefore have taken place in the second quarter of the 6th century. Whether or not the heroic deeds of one of

Â¯IÅ›Â¯anavarmanâ€™s descendants were described in the missing part of the inscription will forever remain unknown.

By placing the two Maukhari inscriptions side by side, we have won a more secure basis from which the individual achievements of each of the Maukhari kings and the Maukhari history as such can be studies. The results of this study are found in Bakker 2014, The World of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a. The sixth

century is generally considered as a â€˜dark ageâ€™ and for that reason every piece of evidence should be treasured. It is hoped that the present preliminary study of the source material will contribute to the historiography of the Maukharis in general and may be of use to scholars who, like the present author, are fascinated by an age that started with the fall of a great empire and culminated in the magnificent rule of Hars.avardhana.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

The Temple of Man.d.aleÅ›varasvÂ¯aminâˆ—

The Mun.d.eÅ›varÂ¯Ä± Inscription of the Time of Udayasena Reconsidered

Introduction

The hill near the village Ramgarh, on whose top (height 184 m) the so-called

â€˜Mun.d.eÅ›varÂ¯Ä± Templeâ€™ is found,1 belongs to the northern spurs of the Kaimur Range, the eastern embranchment of the Vindhyas. It is situated in the Kaimur District of southwest Bihar, 70 km SE of VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±, 170 km SW of Patna, 60 km

NW of Rohtasgarh on the River Son, and 8 km SW of Bhabua, as the crow flies.

The present octogonal temple has attracted the attention of scholars since the early days of Francis Buchanan, whose description had been used by Montgomery Martin in his Eastern India, which appeared in 1838. Buchanan reports that his description is based on the drawings of a painter whom he had sent up to the place, which might have taken place in January 1813. 2 A print based on this was included in Martinâ€™s Eastern India (Plate 78). Earlier a drawing of the temple had been made by Thomas Daniell (Plate 79), who probably visited the site in February 1790, 3 and whose engraving, published in 1808, might have been known to Buchanan. 4 As can be derived from both pictures, the temple was largely covered by a mound of rubble overgrown with plants and trees. The site was excavated by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) after a visit of Theodor Bloch in 1902. 5 Bloch was also the first to report on the inscription that is the subject of this paper. He notes the following ( op. cit.

43):

[. . . ] Among the dÂ´

ebris the second half of an inscribed stone has been found, the first half of which had been sent to the Indian Museum Calcutta in 1891.

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Indo-Iranian Journal 56.3â€“4 (2013), 263â€“77. This double issue of IIJ contained the articles based on papers given at the symposium Epigraphical Evidence for the Formation and Rise of Early Åšaivism, which was held at the University of Groningen, 4â€“5 June 2012.

1 The temple and hill are named after the goddess who today is the central focus of worship (see Jayasal 2017, 117 Fig. 340).

2 Nuess 2003, 533 (based on Oldham 1926). Martin 1838 I, 456: â€˜I could not conveniently visit the place, but sent a painter, who drew the most remarkable part. The temple, now very ruinous, has been an octagon supported by four columns (E).â€™

3 Nuess 2003, 533 (based on Archer 1969).

4 The drawing was engraved by Thomas and his brother William and published in Antiquities of India, December 1808.

This stone is dated year 30, the 22nd of KÂ¯

arttika, which must be referred to the

Hars.a Era, thus corresponding with 635 A.D.

Plate 78

Plate 79

Buchanan: sketch ad 1813 6

Daniell: drawing ad 1790 7

The two halves of the stone have been combined and were first edited and published by R.D. Banerji in Epigraphia Indica IX (1907â€“08).

This Mun

. d

. eÅ›varÂ¯Ä± Inscription of the Time of Udayasena, Year 30 has gone through altogether five editions (R.D. Banerji 1907â€“08, N.G. Majumdar 1920, P.K. Agrawala 1987, P.R. Srinivasan 1991, J. Neuss 2003), but in spite of the work done by these excellent epigraphists, I think there is still room for improvement. 8

The temple on Mun

. d

. eÂ´

svarÂ¯Ä± Hill

Before discussing the inscription in more detail, however, a few words should be said about the temple. Joanna Williams gives the following assessment.

Fragments at the site extend from the sixth century until the eighth or later. On stylistic grounds the surviving octagonal shrine should belong to the first half of the seventh century. [. . . ] 9

6 Martin 1838, Vol. I, opposite p. 474 (Pl. V No. 1, â€˜Temple of Mundeswariâ€™).

7 â€˜The Temple of Mandeswara near Chaynpore, Baharâ€™. C f. Archer 1980, Plate 76.

8 A recent new edition was made by Arvind Kumar Singh, which is included in Jayaswal et al. 2017. I will refer to this as Singh (2017).

9 Williams 1982, 166 f. Cf. Deva 1988 in EITA II.1, 119: â€˜If the foundation inscription Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

20 / The Temple of Man

. d

. aleÅ›varasvÂ¯

amin

393

The interior of the temple consists of a central pavillion supported by four rucaka pillars and encircled by a pradaks.in.apatha, which enshrines a tall, c.

13th-century caturmukhali Ë™nga. 10

Plate 80

Plate 81

Daniell: drawing ad 1790 11

The li Ë™

nga in ad 2008

The hill, temple, surrounding dÃ©bris, and the inscription have been thoroughly examined by JÃ¼rgen Neuss (2003). 12 Neuss subscribes to the almost universally accepted theory that dates the oldest elements of the architecture of the present refers to the Hars.a Era, yielding a date of A.D. 636, the temple stylistically can be assigned to the same period.â€™

10 Deva 1988 in EITA II.1, 119.

11 â€˜Interior of the temple of Mandeswara near Chaynpore, Bahar.â€™ Cf. Archer 1980, Plate 77.

12 More recently another inventory of the remains on the hill was made by Fiona Buckee (2008).

She generously shared her photo documentation with me.

In 2018 Buckee

presented a paper The Curious Case of the Octagonal Temple: A Revised History of the Temples of Mundeshvari Hill in the 24th Conference of the EASAA in Naples, 2â€“6

July 2018. I refer to this as Buckee forthcoming. Again another extensive survey of the archaeological remains of the hill, in situ and in museums, was made by Meera Sharma 2017. It is included in Jayaswal et al. 2017. This latest inventory is not incorporated in the present essay. Finally an extensive treatment of the historic evidence regarding Mun

. d

. eÅ›varÂ¯Ä± Hill is found in Bakker 2014, 221â€“39.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

394

Hans Bakker

temple to the first half of the seventh century. 13 However, Neuss rejects one piece of evidence used to endorse this theory, viz. the alleged contemporaneity of the temple and the inscription. 14

The date of the Mun

. d

. eÂ´

svarÂ¯Ä± Inscription

Neussâ€™s main arguments run as follows. Firstly, there is no reason to assume that â€˜the year 30â€™ refers to the Hars.a Era, as has been done by all scholars following Bloch (see above), apart from Majumdar, who takes it to refer to the Gupta Era. Nuess refers to Asher, who had argued â€˜that in the ancient written documents of eastern India, time was almost invariably marked according to the regnal year of a current monarchâ€™, 15 and, Neuss continues, â€˜that there is thus no basis to connect the date of our inscription with any known eraâ€™. 16

Secondly, a detailed palÃ¦ographic investigation leads him to the final observation that,

As the Mun.d.eÅ›varÂ¯Ä± record still uses the older tripartite ya, I would suggest that the Mun.d.eÅ›varÂ¯Ä± inscription must have been engraved between A.D. 570 and A.D.

590, and that the script shows influences from writing habits developed in Western India. 17

I subscribe tentatively to Neussâ€™s analysis and would therefore propose to date the inscription to the second half of the sixth or early seventh century. It follows that the otherwise completely unknown MahÂ¯

asÂ¯

amanta Udayasena was a feuda-

tory, not of Hars.avardhana, but of the Maukharis of Kanauj, and most likely ruled under Avantivarman, the last of the great Maukhari kings of Kanauj, whose reign spanned the final decades of the sixth and beginning of the seventh century. The inscription is not the foundation charter of the main temple itself, but it testifies to a historical process in the second half of the 6th century, in which the building of a new religious complex on the hill was in full swing.

Neuss presents a new edition of the inscription and his interpretation thereof has important consequences for his understanding of the type and development of the sacred complex on the hill. The reading and interpretation of the inscription that I present here differ significantly from the one given by Neuss.

Our disagreement is mainly the result of a different interpretation of the signs that are found at the end of line 6 and 11 and in the middle of line 16:

.

Neuss, following Majumdar, takes these as dan

. d

. as that conclude a sentence.

13 Neuss 2003, 543. The temple has a long history of reconstructions. Its architectural history has been investigated by Adam Hardy and Fiona Buckee. Buckee ( forthcoming) concludes that the present octagonal shape of the temple may go back to a reconstruction, influenced by nearby Suri tombs, made in the 16th or 17th century. The present appearance of the temple is due to a â€˜creative restaurationâ€™ made between 1913â€“1916.

14 Neuss 2003, 535.

15 Asher 1985, 133.

16 Neuss 2003, 534 f.

17 Neuss 2003, 538.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

20 / The Temple of Man

. d

. aleÅ›varasvÂ¯

amin

395

In my view this interpretation is untenable, because it would break up the sentence construction. In line 6 the Sanskrit syntax requires that we do not read a pause after â—¦ devakulasya, since this is the adject of upanibandhah

. kÂ¯

aritah

.

in line 9. If we would take this sign as a dan

. d

. a in line 11, it would separate

the subject from the predicate: . . . â—¦ upakaran

. Â¯

ani . . . dattÂ¯

ani (l. 12). For these

reasons I follow the suggestion first made by Banerji to the effect that, â€˜The sign at the end of this line has been added in order to fill up the vacant space.â€™ 18

Similar scroll-work is, for instance, found at the end of line 3 (after the double dan

. d

. a that concludes v. 4) of the so-called â€˜Jaunpur Stone Inscription of

Â¯IÅ›Â¯anavarmanâ€™.19 In line 16 of our inscription the double scroll sign is used to fill up the line and, concomitantly, to mark a new paragraph, uktam

. ca, so that

the concluding, exhortative verse could begin on a new line.

My edition is presented in two ways: first, a literal transliteration of what is readable; second, an edited version with conjectural emendations and standardized orthography. My study is based on the estampage supplied by Sten Konow and published by Banerji in Epigraphia Indica IX (Plate 82).

Translation

Success!

In the thirtieth year, at the twenty-second day of KÂ¯

arttika; here, at the

above year, month and dayâ€”within the reign of the illustrious MahÂ¯

asÂ¯

amanta,

MahÂ¯

apratÂ¯Ä±hÂ¯

ara, MahÂ¯

arÂ¯

aja Udayasenaâ€”after having requested the permission

of the head of the community ( kulapati), BhÂ¯

anÂ¯

udayin (?), and the Temple

Council, General Gomibhat.a has commissioned the building of this accomodation as part of the VinÂ¯Ä±teÅ›varamat.ha, in order to increase the merit of his father, mother, and himself.

He has made an assignment to the temple of the illustrious NÂ¯

arÂ¯

ayan.a of a pala

of lampoil and two prasthas of rice for the daily food-offering (to the deity), permanently, for as long as sun and moon exist, to be taken from the storeroom that belongs to the temple of the illustrious Man.d.aleÅ›varasvÂ¯amin.

(And) to the Temple Council he has given the means, such as cows, offerings, garlands, and food, at the value of fifty dÂ¯Ä±nÂ¯

aras, meant collectively for the

29 This is a real crux interpretum. Banerji (followed by Singh) proposed to read: vicchitti-viÂ´

srÂ¯

antaâ—¦. Majumdar read vicchitti

to interpret this passageâ€™. Srinivasan reads: vici (chehitti) . . . . Agrawala: vicchitti-nimittaâ—¦; Neuss: vicchittimÂ¯

antaâ—¦. I tentatively read: vicitrakarmÂ¯

antatantraâ—¦.

any etad evam, which was taken over

20 / The Temple of Man

. d

. aleÅ›varasvÂ¯

amin

399

regular set of various observances for the sake of the illustrious feet of Man.d.aleÅ›varasvÂ¯

amin.

Having learned so, there should not be a disruption of what has thus been assigned, neither by future incumbents nor by the ascetics.

The one who, having thus been informed, acts otherwise, will live in hell with great sins.

Thus [. . . ]

And it has been declared,

O Yudhis.t.hira, zealously protect the land, whether it has been given by yourself or by others. O foremost of the landlords, protection is superior to giving.

Interpretation

General Gomibhat.a made altogether three donations, for which he had to make two formal requests, namely one to the head ( kulapati) of the VinÂ¯Ä±teÅ›vara(mat.ha), and the other to the Temple Council ( devanikÂ¯aya), of which he himself may have been a member. 37 The task of the DevanikÂ¯

aya may have

been to supervise and administer the temple properties on the hill and that of the Man.d.aleÅ›varasvÂ¯amin temple complex ( devakula) in particular. The membership of general Gomibhat.a of such a council would not be surprising, if we consider the people who are reported to sit on such a council. To this effect the TaleÅ›vara Copperplate Grant of Dyutivarman provides information. 38 The latter grant was made at the request of the MahÂ¯

asattrapati TrÂ¯

ata and the Deva-

nikÂ¯

aya, â€˜which was headed by the minister Bhadravis.n.u, the governor of the fort, the officer in charge of the kingâ€™s betel-box, the custodian of the sacrificial fire, and the head of the royal guardâ€™. 39

Gomibhat.a needed the permission of kulapati BhÂ¯anÂ¯udayin for his first donation, viz. accomodation or housing ( mat.ha) for the ascetics, since that was to be built on the premises of the VinÂ¯Ä±teÅ›varamat.ha. The word kulapati poses a problem. Literally it signifies â€˜head of a communityâ€™. Because the community here is defined as that of a mat.ha, a likely interpretation is that the kulapati is 37 If we read with Neuss svadevanikÂ¯

aya in l. 4, this membership would be explicit.

38 EI XIII No. 7, 109â€“21: Two Talesvara Copperplates by Y.R. Gupte (1915â€“16). These two copperplates have been found in TaleÅ›vara in the Almore District, United Provinces (modern Uttarakhand). Though they appear to be forgeries, they are nevertheless documents pertaining to the period â€˜between the middle of the 6th and second quarter of the 7th centuryâ€™ (Gupte op. cit. 113), i.e. to the same period as to which the Mun

. d

. eÅ›varÂ¯Ä±

Inscription belongs.

39 EI XIII, 115 ll. 6â€“8: rÂ¯

ajadauvÂ¯

the Mahant or abbot of the community of ascetics ( tÂ¯

He needed the approval of the Temple Council for his second donation, viz.

a daily offering of lampoil and rice meant for the NÂ¯

arÂ¯

ayan.a Temple ( devakula),

since this was to be taken from the storeroom ( kos.t.hikÂ¯a) connected to the Man.d.aleÅ›varasvÂ¯amin Temple. How this was paid for remains unclear, unless we assume that the third donation to the Temple Council was considered to be sufficient to cover the costs of this as well.

His third donation to the Temple Council, for which he also needed approval, was meant for the worship of Man.d.aleÅ›varasvÂ¯amin himself and is said to have had a value of 50 dÂ¯Ä±nÂ¯

aras. For this amount he provided the means needed for worshipping the deity, such as milk (a cow), food and garlands, epitomized in the words vicitrakarmÂ¯

antatantraâ—¦ (regular set of various observances), if our conjecture (l. 10) is correct.

The inscription attests to the existence, in the second half of the 6th century, of a main Åšaiva temple complex, called Man.d.aleÅ›vara. Connected to this temple was a storeroom, which could also supply the daily offerings for a minor Vais.n.ava sanctuary dedicated to NÂ¯arÂ¯ayan.a. In addition, and possibly closely connected to the Man.d.aleÅ›vara complex, was a monastery of Åšaiva ascetics, named VinÂ¯Ä±teÅ›varamat.ha. Whether there was a temple or shrine of VinÂ¯Ä±teÅ›vara cannot be deduced from this inscription with certainty, but the existence at the time of such a temple is very likely indeed. The monastery or/and its temple was headed by BhÂ¯

anÂ¯

udayin.

Man

. d

. aleÅ›vara and the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a

This is as far as epigraphy (and archaeology) can bring us. It does not tell us why ascetics and pilgrims flocked to this hill in great numbers. Why the site was considered holy. In order to answer these questions we need texts, and such a text has become available. I refer to the original SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a.

TilottamÂ¯

a makes her pradaks.in.Â¯a around him (and

the gods), four faces emerge on the four sides of the li Ë™nga, which gives her the power of sexual desire, the tejas, namely, that had been stored within Åšiva ever since he had burnt Madana. Thus the caturmukhali Ë™nga comes into being (SP

62.8â€“26). Then Åšiva says that,

Because she [TilottamÂ¯

a], as well as the gods, has circumambulated Him in a circle ( man

. d

. ala), this place on Mt. Vindhya, which is sacred to Him, will be called Ma-n.d.aleÅ›vara, and He will always be present here. 43

The story continues, again in the words of Yokochi.

After sending TilottamÂ¯

a to the demons, all the gods huddle together. They see ParameÅ›vara in their midst. Because He appeared in the midst of the gods while they were huddling together ( pin

. d

. yamÂ¯

A holy place called Pin.d.Â¯araka is known to the MahÂ¯abhÂ¯arata (MBh 13.26.54), and other places with this name are known to several PurÂ¯

an.as.

The

Pin.d.Â¯areÅ›vara at issue, however, must be located in the vicinity of Man.d.aleÅ›vara.

The word pin

. d

ara means mendicant and the aetiological myth told in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a probably refers to a local li Ë™nga that was worshipped by Åšaiva ascetics.

The place where our text locates these two li Ë™ngas is in the northern part of the Vindhyas, since TilottamÂ¯

a is said to go to the south to find the two demons

in the foothills of the Vindhya ( vindhyapÂ¯

ades.u). Our investigation thus seems to

Once the hill had established its reputation, it began to attract patronage of the elite. Gomibhat.a exemplifies this development and we have suggested elsewhere that the VinÂ¯Ä±teÅ›vara temple may have been founded by someone named VinÂ¯Ä±ta, who may have ruled from the stronghold of near-by RohitÂ¯

agiri, Rohtasgarh. 48

The inscription and earliest archaeological material on the hill belong to the period in which we date the beginning of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a composition, that

is after ad 550, when North India became united again, for the first time since the fall of the Gupta Empire, under the Maukhari rulers, whose homeland was in the near-by valley of the River Son.

It is the period in which the

Åšaiva movement was beginning to organize itself through sectarian settlements 46 This li Ë™

nga is found in the temple compound, near the entrance. Neuss 2003, 546 n. 37:

â€˜This caturmukhali Ë™

nga seems to be the model for the one which is at present in the temple and which most likely is a substitute for the former.â€™ Photo by the author (2011).

47 This li Ë™

nga is presently stored within the temple. For its history see Neuss 2003, 546 f.

It came from â€˜site Aâ€™. Photo courtesy of F. Buckee (2008).

48 In inscriptions of the Tu Ë™

nga dynasty, ruling in the tenth century as feudatories of the Bauma-Kara kings of Orissa in the Yamagarta-man

. d

. ala in the Dhenkanal District of

Central Orissa, this dynasty of petty kings claims that its ancestor, named VinÂ¯Ä±ta, came originally from the RohitÂ¯

agiri. See Bakker 2010b.

Monuments to the Dead in Ancient North Indiaâˆ—

Preamble

The scope of this study is limited to funerary practices within the brahminical (Hindu) fold of the ancient period, i.e. North India from the Vedic Age to the reign of King Hars.avardhana (7th century). Funerary practices in South India, Dravida country, and Southeast Asia seem to have differed significantly from those in North India. 1 They deserve a study of their own. In late medieval North India new forms of commemoration ( samÂ¯

adhis, chatarÂ¯Ä±s) emerged,

possibly under Islamic influence. 2

The funerary monument in Sanskrit literature

We possess a moving literary description of what the death of a kingâ€”great in the eyes of his contemporariesâ€”brought about, how it was experienced by the court, and which ritual and ceremonies were performed to cope with the calamity. BÂ¯

an.a in Hars.acarita 5 tells us that, even before the actual demise of Hars.aâ€™s father, PrabhÂ¯akaravardhana, the latterâ€™s first wife, Queen YaÅ›ovatÂ¯Ä±, was so overwhelmed by grief and the prospect of widowhood that she, against the express wish of her son, committed herself to the flames (i.e. became a satÂ¯Ä±), while her husband was still alive.

After the death of his mother Hars.a goes to his dying father and clasps his feet in dispair. The latter comforts him, recommends him to his royal duties, and utters his last words: â€˜enemies should be exterminatedâ€™. 3 The body is brought to the bank of the SarasvatÂ¯Ä± on a bier, a funeral pyre is built and the cremation ritual is performed at dusk. It is suggested that the remaining ladies of the kingâ€™s harem also commit satÂ¯Ä±. Hars.a keeps a vigil and next morning goes to the SarasvatÂ¯Ä± to bathe, offers an oblation of water to his father, and goes home in distress (p. 293). A brahmin eats the first pin

. d

. as offered to the

ghost ( preta) and the period of impurity passes.

The deceased kingâ€™s paraphernalia are given to the brahmins; the collected bones are brought to holy places. Then it is said that a â€˜stab of painâ€™ is set up

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Indo-Iranian Journal 50.1 (2007), 11â€“47.

1 See below, n. 23 on p. 410, n. 27 on p. 411, and n. 84 on p. 431.

2 Cf. below, n. 84 on p. 431.

3 Hars.acarita (HC* 5 p. 288): niravaÅ›es.atÂ¯

am

. Â´

satravo neyÂ¯

ah

. .

in the form of a monument at (the place of) the funeral pyre made of a mass of bricks. 4 Finally the royal elephant is set loose and gradually the lamentations subside. The metaphor used by BÂ¯

an.a, â€˜a stab of painâ€™ ( Å›okaÅ›alya)â€”the primary meaning of Â´

salya being â€˜dartâ€™â€”suggests that the monument had the form of a needle. 5 Such a monument seems to be known from the Sanskrit literature, viz. the Vis.n.udharmottarapurÂ¯an.aâ€™s chapter on the so-called aid.Â¯uka.

The aid

. Â¯

uka of the Vis.n.udharmottarapurÂ¯an.a

Vis.n.udharmottara 3.84.1â€“15 describes the aid.Â¯ukarÂ¯upa as follows.6

A structure is built of three (receding) square platforms ( bhadrapÂ¯Ä±t.ha), with steps on four sides. On the third platform a li Ë™ngarÂ¯

upa is erected, but one not

decorated with lines ( rekhÂ¯

a, i.e. without the brahmasÂ¯

utra and the pÂ¯

arÂ´

svasÂ¯

utra).

In the middle of this li Ë™ngarÂ¯

upa an immovable square column ( yas.t.i) is fixed.

On that thirteen bhÂ¯

umikÂ¯

as are made. 7

On top of this is an Â¯

amalasÂ¯

araka

(= Â¯

amalaka?) and on that again a round column, yas.t.i, is fixed. This column is decorated with a medallion ( candraka). 8 In between the bhÂ¯

umikÂ¯

as and

the li Ë™nga (i.e. on the square column?) the four LokapÂ¯

alas are situated, VirÂ¯

ud.ha,

Dhr.tarÂ¯as.t.ra, VirÂ¯upÂ¯aks.a, and Kubera, with lances ( Å›Â¯ula) in their hands, wearing armour and ornaments. 9 It is said that in this construction VirÂ¯

ud.ha is

Åšakra, Dhr.tarÂ¯as.t.ra is Yama, VirÂ¯upÂ¯aks.a is Varun.a, and Kubera is RÂ¯ajarÂ¯aja.

This aid

. Â¯

uka is named â€˜PrajÂ¯

ahitaâ€™; men who worship it obtain happiness and

heaven after death.

Shah in her commentary emphasizes that this Aid.Â¯uka structure is not a particular deity but is designed to embody the whole universe. As to the names of the LokapÂ¯

alas she remarks: â€˜These are known to Buddhist mythology as the four Buddhist Yaks.as who do the work of the LokapÂ¯alas.â€™10 Shah assumes that 4 Hars.acarita (HC* 6 p. 300): kalpitaÅ›okaÅ›alye sudhÂ¯

the aid

. Â¯

uka of the VDhP is without ashes or bones and is therefore acceptable to be worshipped, whereas originally such monuments would have contained bones or relics. This plausible assumption as well as the naming of the four Buddhist LokapÂ¯

alas strongly suggest that Buddhist examples lie at the root of the PurÂ¯

an.aâ€™s description of the aid.Â¯uka.11 We may add that the use of the word aid

. Â¯

uka, instead of ed

. Â¯

uka, could also point to this, meaning â€˜derived from/related to/of the nature of the ed

. Â¯

ukaâ€™, not the original (Buddhist) â€˜ossuaryâ€™.

The

view that sees in the aid

. Â¯

uka an appropriation by the author of the VDhP of a Buddhist architectural tradition finds support in the outcome of Gustav Rothâ€™s investigation into the Symbolism of the Buddhist StÂ¯

upa. 12

The ed

. Â¯

uka

We have some more literary evidence regarding the ed

. Â¯

uka. The MahÂ¯

avastu

refers to an anticipated funerary monument of Princess SudarÅ›anÂ¯

a, who tells

her mother:

Mother, when the seven Ks.atriyas, after fighting one another, shall have caused my death, then, after having performed the cremation rite and collected the bones, you should next erect for me a monument ( elÂ¯

ukÂ¯

a). And at the entrance of that

monument you should plant a karn.ikÂ¯ara tree. Thereupon, when the first month of the rainy season has come after the hot season, that karn.ikÂ¯ara tree will be wrapped in a golden colour as it is covered abundantly by blossoms. Then you shall remember me, thinking to yourself: â€˜I had a daughter whose complexion was beautiful ( sudarÂ´

sanÂ¯

a) like thisâ€™. 13

Lore, p. 212, is of the opinion that the names of the four world-guardians do not occur in the older PÂ¯

ali texts, but they are given in the MahÂ¯

asamayasutta (D II, 257â€“258)

and in the Â¯

At.Â¯anÂ¯at.iyasutta (D III, 197 ff.) in accordance with their fixed distribution in the four directions.

In the Aid

. Â¯

uka construction it seems that VirÂ¯

ud

. ha represents the East (= Åšakra) and

Dhr.tarÂ¯as.t.ra the South (= Yama). This would make a pradaks.in.Â¯a: VirÂ¯

ud

. ha East,

Dhr.tarÂ¯as.t.ra South, VirÂ¯

upÂ¯

aks.a West, Kubera North. This is a deviation from the standard Buddhist doctrine; cf. Banerjea 1956, 521 f.:

In Buddhist mythology too we find a group of four divine beings associated with the four principal quarters, and the Sanskrit Buddhist texts give us a stereotyped list of four; they are Dhr.tarÂ¯as.t.ra, the Gandharva king (east), VirÂ¯

ud

. haka, the king

of the KumbhÂ¯

an

. d

. as (south), VirÂ¯

upÂ¯

aks.a, the NÂ¯aga monarch (west) and VaiÅ›ravan.a,

the Yaks.a king (north). They are the Catur-mahÂ¯arÂ¯ajas of some Buddhist texts, and PÂ¯

an

. ini seems to have had them in his mind when he referred to their bhaktas in one of his sÂ¯

utras (P 4.3.99): mahÂ¯

arÂ¯

ajÂ¯

at.t.haËœ

n.

Evidently the word used here for the monument, elÂ¯

ukÂ¯

a, refers to a funerary

monument of laymen. Emeneau, discussing the word in a review of Mayrhoferâ€™s kewa, 14 and referring to Edgertonâ€™s bhsd s.v. eluka, remarks: The word in Buddhist texts seems clearly to be eluka or elÂ¯

uka and to mean â€˜mon-

ument containing the ashes or bones of a dead personâ€™. [. . . ] Considering the clear meaning in the Buddhist texts (bones are specifically mentioned in one passage) and the l of the word there, one must at least consider again Kittelâ€™s old suggestion. . . of connection with the Dr[avidian] words for â€˜boneâ€™. . . .

Shah quotes Helmer Smith who derives it from the Canarese root el.- â€˜to stand up, to riseâ€™. 15 This meaning of the word ed

. Â¯

uka is confirmed by the AmarakoÅ›a,

in which it occurs in connection with â€˜wallâ€™: â€˜An ed

. Â¯

uka is (a wall) wherein bones

are placed, i.e. an ossuary.â€™ 16

From the evidence surveyed above it seems to appear that the erection of funerary monuments was not strictly limited to the heterodox traditions. However, being from its inception connected with the remains of the dead, the ed

. Â¯

21 / Monuments to the Dead in Ancient North India 409

was, for obvious reasons, not much in vogue in orthodox circles, as the following passage demonstrates. MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata 3.188 pretends to describe the period

of total disruption at the end of the Kali Age, but, as is often the case with such passages, its hidden agenda seems to be to attack contemporaneous practices. 17

And this perverted world shall be upside down: at the dissolution of the yuga (people) will venerate charnel-houses ( ed

. Â¯

ukas) and abandon the gods, (whereas)

Å›Â¯

udras will not serve the brahmins. When the yuga expires, the earth shall no longer be decorated by temples, but marked by charnel-houses ( ed

. Â¯

ukas): in the

hermitages of the great seers, in the settlements of brahmins, in the dwellings of the gods, in hallowed places ( caitya), and in the abodes of the NÂ¯

agas. That is the

sign that the yuga has come to an end. When men, fierce and devoid of dharma, will be constantly eating meat and drinking liquor, then the yuga will collapse. 18

Although not popular with the orthodox, the custom of erecting a monument for the dead goes back to megalithic times and was partly sanctioned by Vedic literature. 19 Kane, dealing with funerary rites, observes (IV, 255): â€˜It will be seen that the disposal of the dead in ancient India was divided into four stages, viz. cremation, collecting the charred bones and depositing them underground in an urn, expiatory rites (called ÅšÂ¯

antikarma) and erection of a monument

over the bones. The last was not necessarily done in every case.â€™ Caland in his Die altindischen Todten- und BestattungsgebrÃ¤uche describes this optional procedure. On the ground where the cremation had taken place ( Â´

smaÂ´

sÂ¯

ana) a

plot of land of the size of a man is demarcated, square or, according to others, round. The land is ritually ploughed.

Mitten in die gepflÃ¼gte Stelle wird der Aschenkrug hingestellt . . . ( op. cit. Â§93) Darauf wird die ÅšmaÅ›Â¯

ana-stÃ¤tte besprengt und besÃ¤t ( op. cit. Â§95).. . . Ganz wie bei der gewÃ¶hnlichen â€˜Feuerschichtungâ€™ wird das ÅšmaÅ›Â¯

anafeld jetzt mit kleinen Steinen

umschlossen ( op. cit. Â§96).. . . Jetzt, da das Terrain fÃ¼r die â€˜Schichtungâ€™ gehÃ¶rig zu-bereitet ist, wird die Stelle des Â´

smaÂ´

sÂ¯

ana, wo die Gebeine niedergelegt werden sollen, zur Aufname derselben zurechtgemacht ( op. cit. Â§98). . . . Jetzt endlich das in allen Kalpas beschriebene Ausstreuen der Knochen. . . . Der MÂ¯

adhyandina verwendet

Hans Bakker

folgenden: â€˜Gott Savitar soll dein Gebein in den SchoÃŸ der Mutter ausstreuen, O

Erde, sei du gÃ¼nstig ihmâ€™ ( op. cit. Â§102). . . . Die Knochen sollen jetzt so auseinan-der gelegt werden, dass eine menschliche Gestalt hergestelllt wird ( op. cit. Â§103).. . .

Der Aschenkrug wird darauf vernichtet ( op. cit. Â§105). . . . . Die eigentliche Schichtung kann jetzt einen Anfang nehmen ( op. cit. Â§107).. . . Jetzt ist die citi mittelst der â€˜raumfÃ¼llendenâ€™ Ziegel zur erforderlichen HÃ¶he aufzuschichten. Ihre Anzahl ist abhÃ¤ngig von der GrÃ¶ÃŸe, die man der citi geben will; meistens ist die Gesammtzahl der Ziegel tausend ( op. cit. Â§112). 20

Despite the attention paid to these barrows ( citi) in the KalpaÅ›Â¯

astra, we, pace

Giuseppe de Marco, find little hard evidence that this Vedic tradition was continued in historic times in classical North India. Disposal of the remains in holy water ( tÂ¯Ä±rtha)â€”be it the ashes/bones, or the body as a whole (as in the case of ascetics)â€”seems to have replaced the older practices of inhumation and exposure. 21 This tallies with the virtual absence in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata of

any reference to the erection of monuments to the dead, apart from the quoted passage regarding the alleged worship of ed

. Â¯

ukas. 22

The Sanskrit literature knows, however, yet another type of monument to commemorate the deceased; it is said to appertain in particular to the ks.atriya class. 23 The PratimÂ¯

anÂ¯

at.aka, traditionally ascribed to BhÂ¯asa, describes how Bharata on his return to AyodhyÂ¯

a pauses at a building, outside the city, tucked

away amidst the trees, on the walls of which sandal imprints of hands are found, of which the doors are decorated with floral wreaths, and where he finds offerings ( bali), evident from flowers and parched rice grains that are well-arranged, and a floor strewn with sand. 24 Little wonder that, when he also fails to see a dhvaja or other emblem of a god ( cihna), Bharata is puzzled: could this be a â€˜house of the godsâ€™ ( devakula)? Inside there are images, well made and true to life, which makes one believe that they are human beings. And this they 20 Caland 1896; cf. Falk 2000, 75 ff. Saindon 2000.

21 Cf. de Marco 1987, 219 ff.

22 In an interesting study, Disposal of the Dead in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata, Tiwari 1979, 23 f.

observes the following:

It has already been remarked that the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata seems to contain no clear refer-

ence to the rite of asthi-saËœ

ncayana, which formed an essential element of antyes.t.i as described in several ritual texts. This rite involved the collection of charred bones and ashes some days after the cremation and disposal of them in various waysâ€”hanging in a bundle on the branch of a tree, or recremating in some special cases, or depositing at the foot of a tree, or, more generally, burying them in a hole dug in the ground and sometimes also building some kind of memorial mound ( Â´

smaÂ´

sÂ¯

ana) over them.

Apparently this practice gradually went out of vogue, and, already towards the close of the epic, the custom of depositing the bones in holy river had probably become more common.

21 / Monuments to the Dead in Ancient North India 411

prove to be. Bharata has come upon a statue gallery, pratimÂ¯

agr.ha, in which

images of the deceased kings of the Iks.vÂ¯aku race are set up; his uncertainty seems to indicate that it is an uncommon phenomenon. 25 The keeper tells him that a brahmin should not salute or worship them as they do not represent gods ( daivata), but kings ( ks.atriya) who have passed away. When Bharata discovers an image of DaÅ›aratha among them, he understands that his father has died. 26

The problem with this testimony, however, is its date and place of origin.

The issue has been discussed by many scholars, and Tieken 1993, summarizing much of this discussion, argues that the so-called â€˜Trivandrum Playsâ€™, to which the PratimÂ¯

anÂ¯

at.aka belongs, may be late and of South-Indian origin.27

The archaeology of the funerary monument

If we turn to archaeology, it becomes immediately clear that, despite the literary evidence, material testifying to the actual practice of erecting funerary monuments in the Brahminical tradition in ancient India is rare. 28 A. Ghosh 25 PratimÂ¯

anÂ¯

at.aka 3.6.

26 PratimÂ¯

anÂ¯

at.aka 3.7â€“9.

27 On account of a formal statistical analysis, van der Geer 1998 dates this particular play to the 4th or 5th century ad ( op. cit. 177) and also thinks a South Indian author most likely ( op. cit.

187).

The PratimÂ¯

anÂ¯

at.aka may reflect a South-Indian custom. That

South-Indian funerary practices differed from the â€˜Aryanâ€™ North may also be deduced from the description of a cemetery in the early Tamil epic Man

. imekalai (DaniÃ©lou 1989,

24 ff.). The practice to install commemorative images of Åšivabhaktas is prescribed in the relatively late South-Indian redaction of the AjitÂ¯

agama, not known to (12th-century)

AghoraÅ›iva (Goodall 2004, cx), which text tells us that this sort of images may be installed at holy places or in a Åšiva temple where they should be worshipped. According to DÂ¯Ä±ptÂ¯

agama 52.59 images of bhaktas should follow the rules of the images of the king (above, n. 23 on p. 410). The AjitÂ¯

agama gives the following description 63.39â€“42:

The editor of the AjitÂ¯

agama, N.R. Bhatt, quotes the Acintya- and refers to the UttarakÂ¯

agama ad loc. The underlying idea seems to be that these bhaktas have reached sÂ¯

arÂ¯

upya with Åšiva and can therefore be depicted with four arms, though they keep the distinct (iconographic) characteristics of the devotee: two hands forming an aËœ

njali, as a

true devotee should, two others holding li Ë™

nga and chowry.

Along with this South Indian custom one may consider funerary practices in Indianized Southeast Asia. Thus there is substantial evidence that in Cambodia as well as on Java and Bali temples and statues were erected for deceased kings and their families; see i.a.

412

Hans Bakker

observes the following: â€˜As by the time cremation had virtually replaced inhumation there is hardly any archaeological evidence of the practices concerning the disposal of the dead. [The Buddhist (and Jaina) stÂ¯

upas form an entirely

different category.]â€™ 29 From the following it will emerge that this sweeping statement should be qualified on two points: the Buddhist and Jain customs are not so categorically different from the Hindu ones (see p. 425), and there is more archaeological evidence of Hindu funerary practice than supposed by Ghosh (see below, p. 430).

In discussions regarding this apparent absence reference is often made to excavations at Lauriyaâ€“Nandangarh (W. Champaran District, Bihar), 30 which, since T. Blochâ€™s excavations in 1905, 31 are supposed to show â€˜Vedic burial moundsâ€™. Ghosh assesses the evidence unearthed by Bloch, refers to the reexamination by N.G. Majumdar, 32 whose excavation he himself continued after the demise of Majumdar, and concludes:

He (i.e. Majumdar) found that all of them were earthen burial memorials with burnt-brick revetment, two being faced with a brick lining in a double tier, so that there was no justification for regarding them as more earthen barrows. He also pointed out that the gold leaves found by Bloch [containing a female figure in frontal pose] had their exact replica in the stÂ¯

upa at Piprawa, which is definitely a

Buddhist stÂ¯

upa of 300 bc or earlier. The respective Lauriya stÂ¯

upas might be of a

comparable date and there is nothing to connect them with Vedic burial rites. 33

Nevertheless, the question is justified whether cremation completely replaced inhumation. It certainly did not for certain categories of persons such as children, yogins or ascetics ( yati), and pregnant women. 34 The evidence of eighteen GandhÂ¯

ara reliefs containing depictions of cemeteries and burial monuments discussed by de Marco 1987 seems to indicate that burial was still customary long after the Vedic period at least in certain parts of India and for certain categories of persons. We shall come back to this below (p. 424 ff.).

In order to improve our understanding of the phenomenon of memorials to the dead it might be useful to distinguish between categories of monuments.

1

Temples dedicated to a particular god, erected in order to transfer the merit thereof to the deceased, often recorded in epigraphs. Many temples may actually fall into this category, for which there is, to the best of my knowledge, no 29 Encyclopaedia of Indian Archaeology I, p. 267.

30 E.g. Kane IV, 254; Das 1968, 59â€“63; Singh 1970, 133.

31 ASI Annual Report 1906â€“07, 119â€“126. See below, p. 427.

32 ASI Annual Report 1935â€“36, 55â€“66; 1936â€“37, 47â€“50.

33 Ghosh in Encyclopaedia of Indian Archaeology II, 254 f., s.v. Lauriya-Nandangarh. In 1912 Caland had already raised serious doubts about Blochâ€™s identification.

34 De Marco 1987, 221â€“226 discusses various categories of people liable to be buried and evidence of the burialgrounds. As to the burial of pregnant women he concludes ( op. cit.

222, n. 59): â€˜Therefore it is reasonable to conclude that the practice of burial for deceased pregnant women, even if not explicitly traceable in the texts, has always been considered, from an unspecifiable epoch, as both necessary and legitimate.â€™ Cf. Kane IV, 227â€“233.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

21 / Monuments to the Dead in Ancient North India 413

specific Sanskrit word, but which in the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple Inscription

is referred to with the generic term prÂ¯

asÂ¯

ada. 35 A special relation between the

god and the deceased indicates that this type of buildings has a commemorative function, at least for contemporaries, and I therefore propose to refer to this type of monuments as â€˜memorialsâ€™.

2

Sanctuaries/buildings that contain an image/images of the deceased. They are known in Sanskrit as pratimÂ¯

agr.ha, or â€˜statue galleriesâ€™.

3

Hero-stones, including satÂ¯Ä±-stones, which are found in particular in the Deccan in great number, and which commemorate the place where a heroic death took place. They could be classified as â€˜memorial stonesâ€™.

4

Structures that have some formal correspondences with the funerary monuments of the following category (5), but which do not contain the actual mortuary remains; these seem to have been described in the Vis.n.udharmottarapurÂ¯

an

. a under the name of aid

. Â¯

uka.

5

Burial mounds or sepulchral monuments that actually contain the ashes and/or bones, or the bodies of the deceased, in Sanskrit literature referred to as ed

. Â¯

uka.

Memorials

This category may be illustrated by two examples, the first one being the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka temples on the top of the RÂ¯amagiri, the other a temple built by Skandagupta for his father KumÂ¯

aragupta in BhitarÂ¯Ä±. 36

As I have argued elsewhere (Bakker 1992b and 1997, 30 f.), the 5th-century VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka temples on the RÂ¯amagiri were erected to transfer merit to the dead.

The choice of the temple-deity was not arbitrary; it was made on the basis of an envisaged similarity or affinity of the god and the deceased queen and kings (Bakker 1992b). This theory builds on the evidence of the inscription found in the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple on the RÂ¯

amagiri, in which PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s daugh-

ter, Princess AtibhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±, widow of Ghat.otkacagupta, records the good works she has done. The text is very fragmentary and problematic. A translation of the relevant passage may run as follows.

Then (the princess) commissioned the splendid â€˜Master of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™, (the image

of the) Lord of the World, within the temple, for the sake of undecaying merit of 35 Above, p. 125; Bakker 1997, 167. Granoff 1992, 187 refers to a temple built after the cremation of the Jain minister VastupÂ¯

ala on Mt ÅšatruËœ

njaya called â€˜SvargÂ¯

arohanaprÂ¯

asÂ¯

adaâ€™.

Granoff 1992 ( passim) proves that the building of memorial temples was just as popular in Jainism as it was in Hinduism.

This type of memorial temple seems to be

referred to under the CÂ¯

ol.as as pal.l.i-pat.ai in Tamil: â€˜temple erected in memory of kingsâ€™.

Huntington 1985, 310 conjectures that the famous DharmarÂ¯

aja shrine in MÂ¯

amallapuram

may have been such a pal.l.i-pat.ai, since it contains a portrait image of the Pallava king Nr.sim

. havarman I himself on its southern face.

36 The wide-spread practice to install li Ë™

ngas in commemoration of the deceased, which could be comprised in the category of â€˜memorialâ€™, is left out of account here. An example hereof is e.g. attested by the MathurÂ¯

a Pilaster Inscription of Candragupta II, Year 61, above, p. 287, below, p. 494. For this practice in Nepal, centering around PaÅ›upatinÂ¯

atha, see

Mirnig 2016.

On account of this evidence we assume that either the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Tem-

ple, in which the inscription is found to date, or the adjacent Trivikrama Temple, to which the inscription originally may have belonged, 38 had been erected around the middle of the 5th century to transfer merit to the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka queen

PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä± GuptÂ¯

a, who may have died a little earlier. This queen took great pride in her descent from two famous families, her father being the Gupta emperor Candragupta II, her mother KuberanÂ¯

agÂ¯

a born in the NÂ¯

aga House and

belonging to the DhÂ¯

aran.a gotra (Bakker 1997, 12). It may therefore not be coincidence that in front of the Kevalaâ€“Narasim

. ha Temple entrance an image

of a serpent, NÂ¯

aga, is found. We will come back to this below, (p. 434).

A reference to another specimen of a memorial temple erected to transfer merit to a deceased king can be found in the BhitarÂ¯Ä± Stone Pillar Inscription of Skandagupta. 39 The inscription of PrabhÂ¯

avatÂ¯Ä±â€™s nephew, Skandagupta, is not

without difficulties. The temple to which it may refer has been excavated, 40

but the image installed has not been found. Though somewhat elliptical, verse 12 may be read as follows.

Hence the manifestation of the Lord (Bhagavat), this (image/manifestation) here (i.e. KumÂ¯

arasvÂ¯

amin) and that which here has been consigned (to it) (i.e. the grÂ¯

ama), he (i.e. Skandagupta) has destined both for the merit of (his) father, since he is determined upon merit. 41

The inscription tells us that Skandagupta installed an image, probably of VÂ¯

asudeva and possibly named KumÂ¯

arasvÂ¯

amin, 42 a deity who is said in verse 10

to be a great archer, ÅšÂ¯

ar Ë™ngin, and as such reflects the qualities of the emperor 37 Kevalaâ€“Narasim

21 / Monuments to the Dead in Ancient North India 415

and his father. In verse 8, in which his victory over the HÂ¯

un.as is reported, the

twanging sound of a bow ( Â´

sÂ¯

ar Ë™ngadhvanih

. ) is referred to in a simile that seems

to express Skandaguptaâ€™s prowess. For the maintenance of the image/temple Skandagupta assigned a community/village ( grÂ¯

ama) to the deity, that is to say,

he exempted this community from taxes, so that its surplus production could be used for worship and maintenance. Both beneficial acts were performed to increase the merit of the deceased father, KumÂ¯

aragupta.

PratimÂ¯

agr.has

When searching for galleries where effigies of kings were installed, the pratimÂ¯

agr.ha, our second category, two sites spring to mind: MÂ¯at. near MathurÂ¯a, and a cave at NÂ¯

an.eghÂ¯at., a pass leading from the Konkan to Junnar (Pune Dist.). The latter site has been discussed by Ajay Mitra Shastri. In this cave two sets of inscriptions are found: 43

One of them, a large but fragmentary one is inscribed partly on the left and partly on the right walls. On its [i.e., the caveâ€™s] back wall were put up statues of eight personages which have all disappeared almost completely and over their heads there were inscribed what may be called labels of which also only six are now extant enabling us to identify the figures originally carved below them. Going by the preserved labels there were installed statues of Simuka SÂ¯

atavÂ¯

ahana, the

founder of the dynasty, queen NÂ¯

aganikÂ¯

a and her spouse king SÂ¯

atakani (SÂ¯

atakarn.i),

KumÂ¯

ara (prince) BhÂ¯

aya, MahÂ¯

arat.hi Tranakayira, KumÂ¯ara Hakusiri and kumÂ¯ara SÂ¯

atavÂ¯

ahana. 44

According to Shastri the gallery was initiated by King Kr.s.n.a, who set up the image of his elder brother Simuka, and continued by VediÅ›rÂ¯Ä±, who set up the images of his father and mother SÂ¯

atakarn.i and NÂ¯aganikÂ¯a. Shastri argues, on

the basis of the PratimÂ¯

anÂ¯

at.aka, that all images were erected after the death

of the person involved. If his identification of these early SÂ¯

atavÂ¯

ahana kings

is correct, it would mean that this pratimÂ¯

agr.ha predates the one at MÂ¯at. and

therefore cannot have been inspired by the Kus.Â¯an.a example. The epigraphs found in NÂ¯

an.eghÂ¯at. do not give any reason to believe that these images were worshipped. The long inscription enumerates many Vedic sacrifices and their daks.in.Â¯as, but is silent as to the images.

The situation seems different at MÂ¯

at.. The archaeological remains of a build-

ing and the inscribed images of the Kus.Â¯an.a kings Vima/Vema (Kadphises), Kanis.ka, Huvis.ka (?) and others, belong to the most well-known India has produced. The epigraphs have been competently dealt with by LÃ¼ders (posthumously published by Janert 1961). The building that housed these images is referred to as devakula in the inscriptions themselves. About this LÃ¼ders remarks:

43 For these inscriptions see also Sircar SI I, 190â€“197.

44 Shastri 1998, 102. Cf. Verardi 1983, 244â€“50.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

416

Hans Bakker

There can be little doubt that the devakula at the MÂ¯

at. site, similarly to â€˜BhÂ¯asaâ€™sâ€™

devakula, served chiefly as a hall for the statues of members of the royal Kus.Â¯an.

family, although, as proved by the life-size image found together with the Kanis.ka statue, images of gods were mixed up with them. 45

The latter concessive clause may mark a significant difference with the situation in NÂ¯

an.eghÂ¯at. and the depiction in the PratimÂ¯anÂ¯at.aka. It may account for the term devakula used in the MÂ¯

at. inscriptions. â€˜BhÂ¯asaâ€™ speaks also about a

devakula, but that word is used when Bharata does not yet know whether he has to do with a â€˜house of the godsâ€™ or not. When he discovers the true nature of the monument the text uses the word pratimÂ¯

agr.ha.46 Another important

difference may be related to this. LÃ¼ders remarks,

In one respect, however, the collection of the Kus.Â¯an. statues seems to have differed from the gallery described in the PratimÂ¯

anÂ¯

at.aka. BhÂ¯asa tells us that only deceased

kings were honoured by setting up their images. This restriction does not seem to have prevailed in the case of the Kus.Â¯an. devakula. The present inscription was engraved on the pedestal of a statue, and we may reasonably assume that, in addition to the repair of the devakula, the gift of the statue was recorded in the inscription. The statue cannot have represented the grandfather of Huvis.ka, nor is it likely that it was the second image of Kanis.ka. As the donation was made for the increase of the life and strength of Huvis.ka, it becomes very probable that it represented that king, but that benedictory phrase shows at the same time that the statue was set up during the lifetime of Huvis.ka. 47

From this combined evidence it may appear that the images of the Kus.Â¯an.a kings were worshipped like those of gods, even when still alive. The true nature of the devakula was the subject of an interesting essay by GÃ©rard Fussman, who compared the MÂ¯

at. sanctuary with a similar one in Surkh-Kotal, also containing images of Kus.Â¯an.a kings.48 He argues that we should conceive of these temples as â€˜shrines where the king, his family and high officials worshipped the deity who protects the king and his family, not the temple of the godlike kingâ€™. 49

A devakula is, according to the French scholar, â€˜a royal family shrineâ€™. 50 This 45 LÃ¼ders 1961, 144.

46 PratimÂ¯

anÂ¯

at.aka 3. 5, 6. Cf. ibid. 3.1 pad.imÂ¯ageha, 3.13 idam

. gr

. ham

. tat pratimÂ¯

anr

. pasya.

It has to be admitted, though, that the keeper is called devakulika.

47 LÃ¼ders 1961, 144 f.

48 Fussman 1989; cf. Rosenfield 1993, 154â€“172. Shastri 1998, 109 refers to similar â€˜small sanctuaries in the SwÂ¯

at region of Afghanistanâ€™.

49 Fussman 1989, 199.

50 Fussman 1989, 198. Cf. Frantz Grenet 2015, 209 f. discussing the Rabatak Temple and its inscription:

The temple is said to contain images of KaniË˜

skaâ€™s three direct ancestors and prede-

cessors (Kujula Kadphises, Vima Taktu, Vima Kadphises), and of himself: as in the Surkh Kotal temple, and also at MÂ¯

at. in Mathura, another royal foundation, the royal

statues are commemorative and not in themselves an object of worship (despite the enduring theory of the Kushan dynastic cult). In the Rabatak inscription gods, clearly distinguished from deceased kings, are mentioned in two contexts.

21 / Monuments to the Dead in Ancient North India 417

connotation accords well with the use of the term in the VÂ¯

akÂ¯

at.aka inscriptions,

in which the state sanctuaries are referred to as â€˜placesâ€™ ( sthÂ¯

ana) of the devakula

(above, p. 332). However, the idea of installing in these sanctuaries life-size images of the royal family itself is clearly imported into North India. Fussmanâ€™s contention that these royal images were not meant for worship in their own right remains open to doubt; the word devakula may have been used precisely because the Kus.Â¯an.a kings thought of themselves, or wanted their subjects to believe that they were members of the divine family ( kula). 51

Their title,

devaputra, also seems to endorse this. 52 Apparently the Brahmanical tradition represented by â€˜BhÂ¯

asaâ€™ found this too much to swallow, in view of the shift from devakula to pratimÂ¯

agr.ha, and, to judge by our archaeological evidence, the idea of a statue gallery as a whole became obsolete, at least in North India during the period under review. 53

Memorial stones

The third category, â€˜hero-stonesâ€™, has been the subject of a seminar at Dharwad, the papers of which have been edited by S. Settar & GÃ¼nther D. Sontheimer (1982).

In this volume D.R. Patil studies The Origin of Memorial Stones. Patil ( op. cit. 48) observes that â€˜. . . a memorial stone, in its basic conception, is commemorative in character, raised in memory or honour of the dead, and did not form part of the actual practice of the disposal of the deadâ€™.

Nevertheless Patil traces its origin back to this very practice by referring to early Buddhist monuments containing mortuary deposits, because in some of them a wooden post was found (Lauriya-Nandangarh), whereas an inscription in another Buddhist monument (Sui Vihar) seems to refer to such a post as a yas.t.i raised in honour of the deceased (see below, p. 426). Typical of this type of stones seems to be that they contain a visual representation or symbol referring to the fate of those commemorated, in addition to, occasionally, a brief text.

Early specimens of â€˜memorial stonesâ€™ as defined above seem to have been the so-called chÂ¯

ayÂ¯

astambha or chÂ¯

ayÂ¯

askambha (â€˜shade-pillarâ€™) from NÂ¯

agÂ¯

arjunakon.d.a

51 Von HinÃ¼ber 2004, 172 n. 234. Rosenfield 1993, 202 thinks that Iran is the most likely source of the tendency to deify the Kus.Â¯an.a kings. The term devakula literary means the

â€˜family seat of the god(s)â€™. When one installs a life-size image of oneself in this â€˜seatâ€™, does that not suggest that one wants to be regarded as part of that family?

52 Cf. Rosenfield 1993, 202 ff. Differently Grenet 2015, 209 n. 27: The Kushan royal title â€˜son of the god(s)/son of the lord(s)â€™, Bactr. bagopouro, Indian devaputra, are no more real proof of a claim to divine filiation as theopatÂ¯

or on some

Arsacid coins, probably corresponding to a genuine Parthian word *bagpuhr. It can just as well allude to the legitimate royal filiation, eventually to the divine election.

A critical examination of this difficult issue is found in Verardi 1983.

53 Cf. above, n. 27 on p. 411. Granoff 1992, 190 reports that â€˜. . . images of tÂ¯

Ä±rtha Ë™

nkaras

were often made for the welfare of the dead. Bharataâ€™s funerary monument to his father also bears striking resemblances to actual funerary monuments for Jain monks in having a portrait image of the deceased. . . â€™ See also below, n. 72 on p. 425. discussed by H. Sarkar in the same volume. 54 These pillars were raised during the rule of the Iks.vÂ¯akus in the third century ad. They commemorate the death of members of the ruling class, religious personages and soldiers. One may serve as an example. King Rudrapurus.adatta erected in the 11th year of his reign a memorial stone ( chÂ¯

. bha) for his mother, MahÂ¯

(Vam

aks.atrapa, probably a Åšaka king from Ujjain.55

The pillar on which the inscription is found is decorated by one panel depicting the queen. The queen â€˜is seated on a stool [and] holding a mirror in her hand.

She is dressed like a foreign lady, accompanied by two female attendantsâ€™. 56

Sircar ( op. cit. 20) argues that the word chÂ¯

ayÂ¯

a in this context means â€˜imageâ€™,

and thus refers to the portrait of the deceased queen above the inscription. 57

Most chÂ¯

ayÂ¯

astambhas belong to a Buddhist milieu, but this pillar seems to be the only one that â€˜was found in the precincts of a Buddhist monasteryâ€™ (Sarkar op. cit. 202). 58

atavÂ¯

ahana site in the

. bha) mentions a prince ( kumÂ¯

. ma actually ruled over Vidarbha,

as does Mirashi, but surmises that â€˜he might have come over there as a pilgrim as PaunÂ¯Ä± was an important religious centre, especially for the Buddhists. . . â€™. In view of this evidence, Sarkar (1982, 205) tentatively suggests that the memorial in this form, i.e. our third category, may have originated in and spread from the area under Åšaka rule in the first centuries of the Christian era.

21 / Monuments to the Dead in Ancient North India 419

It is indeed in the Åšaka territories that we find corroborative evidence for this hypothesis. It has the form of six â€˜long narrow slabs of stoneâ€™ that were discovered â€˜standing as monuments on a hillockâ€™ at the village Andhau on the Rann of Cutch (Gujarat). 60 These stones had been erected in the (Åšaka) year 52, i.e. ad 130, under the rule of RÂ¯aja RudradÂ¯aman, who is none other than the MahÂ¯

aks.atrapa RudradÂ¯aman I.61 Four stones still carry inscriptions, one of which records that the inscribed slab of stone, referred to as las.t.i (=

yas.t.i) in the inscription itself, had been erected ( uthÂ¯apita), by Madana for his sister Jes.t.havÂ¯Ä±rÂ¯a belonging to the OpaÅ›ati (AupaÅ›atika) gotra. This Madana erected in the same year similar monuments for his brother R

. s.abhadeva and

his wife YaÅ›odattÂ¯

a, who is called a novice nun ( Â´

srÂ¯

aman

. erÂ¯Ä±). Patil and Sarkar

( op. cit. 54 f., 204 ff.) discuss a number of similar pillars, all of them from areas â€˜where the Åšakas were rulingâ€™, and Patil concludes that they are â€˜funerary monuments. . . presumably intended to commemorate the deadâ€™. 62 We have no indications that the memorial stones ( yas.t.is), such as found in Andhau, marked the spot where mortuary remains were deposited, although this may be deceptive, since the sites have not been subject to archaeological scrutiny. 63 If this is correct, however, and there are no deposits, we are here concerned with funerary monuments that may be thought of as forerunners of the â€˜hero-stonesâ€™

(category 3), not yet carrying a picture; strictly speaking, they should be classified in our fourth category: funerary monuments without mortuary deposits.

On the other hand, although the term yas.t.i is used to refer to these steles, these monuments differ widely from the constructions composed of square and circular yas.t.is as described under the heading aid.Â¯uka in the VDhP.

Aid

. Â¯

ukas

Ahicchatra

There exists a brick monument that has been thought to conform to and has been identified as an aid

. Â¯

uka in the sense of the VDhP. This is the â€˜Åšiva templeâ€™

at Ahicchatra (AC I), which is, in the words of Agrawala (Plate 85): A massive brick structure unique of its kind in North India. On plan it is similar to the quadrangular Buddhist stÂ¯

upas raised in several tiers, diminishing upwards like a gigantic staircase. The structure answers closely to what the Vis.n.udharmottarapurÂ¯

an

. a describes as an ed

. Â¯

uka (sic) built in three terraces ( bhadra-pÂ¯Ä±t.has), one above the other, with four stepped approaches and surmounted on the top by 60 EI XVI (1921-22), 19 ff.

other hand, is explicitly not a temple and not dedicated to one god in particular. Moreover, there seem to be more terraces than the three bhadrapÂ¯Ä±t.has of the VDhP, whereas there is apparently not a trace of the four LokapÂ¯

The â€˜colossal Åšiva-li Ë™ngaâ€™ originally may have been enshrined, as foundation walls found atop the uppermost terrace seem to indicate. In view of these incongruities and uncertainties the structure crowning mound AC I and a similar one at mound AC II may therefore have been more adequately characterized by A. Ghosh who describes them as:

Terraced temples of brick, each terrace made on foundation cells round a square frame, filled with earth. Both of them underwent many restorations and exten-sions resulting in the increase of their dimension. The larger of them [i.e. AC I]

was founded on a layer with typical Stratum IV (Kushan) pottery and could not therefore have been founded before the early Gupta age. 66

On the other hand, the mass of bricks ordered in a pyramidal, i.e. tapering framework, ending in a column or li Ë™nga has an outward similarity with the structure described in the VDhP. It could be that BÂ¯

an.a (above, n. 4 on p. 406),

describing the â€˜funerary monumentâ€™ ( citÂ¯

acaitya) of King PrabhÂ¯

akaravardhana

in Thanesar as a â€˜mass of bricksâ€™ ( sudhÂ¯

anicaya) resembling the form of a dart

or needle ( Â´

salya), was thinking of a monument similar to the one uncovered in Ahicchatra, 300 km to the southeast of Thanesar, 150 km north of Kanauj.

According to BÂ¯

an.a the ashes and bones ( kÂ¯Ä±kasa) had been sent off for dispersal in holy places ( tÂ¯Ä±rthasthÂ¯

ana), and this too would conform to the description of the aid

. Â¯

uka in the Vis.n.udharmottarapurÂ¯an.a, which does not mention nor refers to mortuary deposits. As far as one can tellâ€”the description of this monument in the excavation report being very brief indeedâ€”this would agree with the archaeological state of affairs in AC I, where no mortuary deposits have been reported. 67

Mansar

â€˜Uniqueâ€™ as the structure may have appeared to the excavators at the time, I would like to draw attention to a recent excavation that has surprisingly much 66 Ghosh in EIA II, 7. Cf. Shrimali 1983 I, 149: â€˜Even if it was an ed

67 Ahicchatra has most recently been investigated by Laxshmi Greaves (2015). She concludes (p. 219):

Hans Bakker

in common with the Ahicchatra one. These are the excavations at Mansar: MNS 3 (Plate 86). The brick structure uncovered at a mound there, the so-called Hid.imbÂ¯a T.ekd.Â¯Ä±, has been interpreted by the excavators, who failed to refer to Ahicchatra, as a mixture of Hindu temples and Buddhist stÂ¯

upas.

Elsewhere I have shown the untenability of this conflation (Bakker 2004a).

As in Ahicchatra, the Mansar mound shows a series of terraces built of brick, constructed over and against a natural hillock, which makes the whole thing look like a pyramid of brick.

As in Ahicchatra, the various platforms are

constructed over brick boxes filled with rubble, earth and stones, a construction device also know from stÂ¯

upa domes. The mistake the Mansar excavators have made is that they have confounded similarity with identity. Mansar, like Ahicchatra, is definitively a Åšaiva sanctuary, identities corroborated at both sites by beautiful 5th-century Åšaiva sculptures, of terracotta in Ahicchatra, of red sandstone in Mansar. Are we to classify the Mansar structure as an aid

. Â¯

uka?

Plate 86

Mansar (MNS 3)

The same reasons that speak against such an identification in Ahicchatra also apply to Mansar, but the Mansar site is characterized by some intriguing features of its own.

One of these is â€˜the figure of a Purus.a made of limeâ€™ (Plate 87).68 This figure is truly out of the ordinary and various interpretations are possible. In Bakker 2007b and 2009a (below, p. 458) I have made a case for seeing this Man 68 Joshi & Sharma 1999-2000, 128. Cf. Bakker 2004a, 81.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access
