stones in mud masonry, the intervening space being filled in with pebbles. The maximum length from head to toe is 23.05 m and the head portion, which is in the northwest, is 6.35 m long and 4.85 m wide. The legs, which are in the southeast direction, are 10.88 m long and their maximum width at the thigh is 2.20 m. [. . . ]

The left-half of the head is destroyed. Around the head was a pavement of stone rubble in mud masonry which is 0.88 m wide. Near the legs was noticed a circular pit, which is now full of fallen stones. (IAR 1983â€“84, 58 f.) Plate 106

Human figure underneath temple in Kandhar

This remarkable structure may be half a millennium later than the Manasarapurus.aâ€”dating from the RÂ¯as.t.rakÂ¯ut.a periodâ€”and lacks the latterâ€™s sophistication, but it more clearly reflects the literary idea of the VÂ¯

astupurus.a. A conspicous agreement between both figures is the direction of head and legs: northwest/southeast.

Curdi

Finally I would like to discuss briefly a figure found in Curdi (Goa). I am obliged to my friend Frans Janssen for sharing this information with me. The more than life-size image is made of laterite stone and is situated between a temple and a tank. In between the left arm and the trunk is the effaced image of a child still visible.

The featuring of the child proves that we are here concerned with another type of image that may rather be classified as a fertility icon. In that respect Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

462

Hans Bakker

the brief description of Dr Shirodkar in the Purabhilekh-Puratatva 50 may be correct, when he calls the image a LajjÂ¯

a GaurÂ¯Ä±, although we usually understand

a completely different type of icon by that term.

Plate 107

Plate 108

Curdi: Human figure with child

Curdi: child underneath left arm

Final remark

Apart from a few rare exceptions, the idea of the VÂ¯

astupurus.aman.d.ala is first

and foremost a mythological and theoretical, ritualistic concept, which has hardly, if at all, had demonstrable effects on the actual architecture of the temple, or its archaeology for that matter.

As such it is one more ingenuous product of brahmanical ritualistic speculation, and it carries its hallmark: abstraction. Taking its origin from the construction sacrifice, such as represented by the Manasarapurus.a, and ultimately from the Purus.amedha in the context of the make-shift fire-altar, the sacrifice of Man or sacrifial man is thus preserved in the concept of the VÂ¯

astupurus.a. It

testifies to the civilizing force of brahmanical culture, which first banned human and then animal sacrifice, and which teaches us that even the most gruesome of religious practices can be viewed under the perspective of the sublime. Pace Xenophanes.

50 Journal of the Directorate of Archives, Archaeology and Museum, Panaji, Goa. This journal is unavailable to me. Information kindly provided by Frans Janssen.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

RÂ¯

ama Devotion in a Åšaiva Holy Placeâˆ—

The Case of VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±

I do homage to SarasvatÂ¯Ä± and Ga Ë™

ngÂ¯

a,

both holy and enchanting streams;

the latter washes away the sin of him

who bathes therein and drinks of its waters;

the former destroys the ignorance

of him who speaks or hears of it.

(RCM 1 C15.1, tr. Hill)

Introduction

In the eulogizing stanzas that precede the Acts of RÂ¯

ama, TulsÂ¯Ä±dÂ¯

as makes a

curious remark:

[I do homage] to Hara, too, and GirijÂ¯a, who for the good of the world and with regard to the evil of this age composed a number of spells in a barbarous tongue, incongruous syllables, meaningless mutterings, whose influence is manifest by the power of MaheÅ›a. (RCM 1 C15.3, tr. Hill)

When Åšiva can empower even meaningless mutterings, how great then would be the effect if he empowered meaningful truths?

If the grace of Hara and GaurÂ¯Ä± be at all truly with me, then all the influence I claim for my verses, composed in common speech, will be a reality.

(RCM 1 D15, tr. Hill)

These words have a special significance, since they touch upon a general development in the religions of northern India, an evolution from an increasingly abstruse, technical tantric religion taught in the Åšaiva Â¯

Agamas in a lan-

guage that ever fewer people could understandâ€”sometimes even resorting to sam

. dhyÂ¯

abhÂ¯

as.a or obstruse languageâ€”to a more simple religion of the heart, a devotion expressed in plain words of the vernaculars that have an immediate appeal to human emotions.

âˆ— The first version of this article was published as Chapter 5 in: Pauwels, H.R.M. (ed.), Patronage and Popularisation, Pilgrimage and Procession. Channels of Transcultural Translation and Transmission in Early Modern South Asia. Papers in Honour of Monika Horstmann. Harrassowitz Verlag, Wiesbaden 2009. pp. 67â€“80.

463

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

464

Hans Bakker

Åšiva as lord of the mantra preserved his position of eminence, but how much more effective would he be, if he employed meaningful language, TulsÂ¯Ä±dÂ¯

as seems

to say. The RÂ¯

amacaritamÂ¯

anasa (RCM) is itself a specimen of this development,

which we can trace several centuries back; seen in that perspective we may consider the MÂ¯

anasa as an end-point rather than a beginning.

Yet another, older conflict is hidden behind this evolution, viz. the rivalry between the Åšaiva and Vais.n.ava religions. Although some schools of Vaisnavism had borrowed the technical ritualistic formalism from Â¯

Agamic Saivism, 1

Vaisnavism, by its nature, could more easily accommodate to less elitist, more emotional forms of worship that were on the rise in northern India from the 11th century onwards. This advantage had its effect especially in Hindu holy places, where great interests were at stake, and which were frequented by a growing stream of devotees expressing popular forms of religion. Unlike newly emerging holy places like AyodhyÂ¯

a and Braj, which were predominantly within

the Vais.n.ava domain from the beginning, an old, overall Åšaiva holy place like VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± must have been the theatre par excellence, in which this competition came to the fore.

TulsÂ¯

Ä±dÂ¯

as, Åšiva, and the Name

In all his writings TulsÂ¯Ä±dÂ¯

as gives Åšiva his due, and more than that, he beseeches Åšambhu to grant him attachment to RÂ¯

amaâ€™s feet. Åšivaâ€™s divine grace operating

in VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± is fully acknowledged, for instance, in the opening verses of TulsÂ¯Ä±â€™s VinayapatrikÂ¯

a:

That state which saints, scriptures and all the PurÂ¯

anas tell as hard won, even by

great sages,

That salvation eternal Shiva gives to all alike whose hour of death is in his city.

(VP v. 3, tr. Allchin)

Indeed, it is an ancient tradition that bestows on VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± the power to release

those who die within its precincts, a power derived from Åšivaâ€™s grace. We shall examine the history of this doctrine, but for doing this we take our cue from the RÂ¯

amacaritamÂ¯

anasa.

In the prologue of the BÂ¯

alakhan

. d

. a TulsÂ¯Ä± sings the praise of the holy Name

consisting of two aks.aras: rÂ¯

a-ma. To highlight its effectiveness he attributes

all sorts of miraculous powers to it, including Åšivaâ€™s grace. Then, coming to VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±, TulsÂ¯Ä± says:

I do homage to rÂ¯

ama, the Name of Raghubar, signifying fire and sun and moon; essence of BrahmÂ¯

a, Hari and Hara; vital breath of the Veda; impersonal, unique, treasure-house of all perfections; the Great Spell (MahÂ¯

amantra) uttered by MaheÅ›a,

who teaches it as effecting final release at KÂ¯

aÅ›Â¯Ä±. Gan.eÅ›a knows its power, for by

the might of the Name he is first to be worshipped. (RCM 1 C19.1â€“2, tr. Hill) 1 Sanderson 2001, 35â€“41.

23 / RÂ¯

ama Devotion in a Åšaiva Holy Place

465

A little further on TulsÂ¯Ä± is even more precise and specifies that it is this MahÂ¯

a-

mantra, equated with the Name, that grants release to the dying, when it is compassionately bestowed upon them by Åšiva himself:

The immortal Åša Ë™

mbhu, Åšiva, the Blessed Lord, sum of all knowledge and perfection, continually repeats it, and the four kinds of creatures that are in the world win to the highest realm if they die at KÂ¯

aÅ›Â¯Ä±; (2)

and that too, O prince of sages, is due to the greatness of RÂ¯

ama, for Åšiva of his

compassion instructs them in the power of the Name. I ask you, lord, which RÂ¯

ama

is this? Tell me and explain, O treasure-house of grace! (3) (RCM 1 C46.2â€“3, tr. Hill)

More pedestrian as we are, our answer differs from that of the prince of sages, YÂ¯

ajËœ

navalkya; we will look for the origin of this doctrine to the beginnings of the RÂ¯

ama bhakti in northern India in the 11th and 12th centuries ad. This new form of devotion that envisaged the hero of the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a as the highest form and

manifestation of Vis.n.u was from the start, it would seem, intrinsically linked to the cult of the divine Name. TulsÂ¯Ä± reports the outcome of the development in which Name and God became equated: the Name of RÂ¯

ama is the supreme

mantra, which alone can deliver the supreme goal, final release.

The claims of Åšaiva texts and pandits in VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± to the effect that it is

Åšiva who mercifully whispers the MahÂ¯

amantra into the ear of the dying, as

a sort of last sacrament, is not false by itself, so the reasoning goes, but this MahÂ¯

amantra cannot be another than the supreme mantra, the Name of God.

So all the Åšaiva followers who had always believed that this release-granting formula would be a Åšaiva mantra had been mistaken and they must have been in for a big surprise in their hours of death.

The syllables of this mantra were not given in the early Åšaiva texts, as far as I am aware, being a mystery to be revealed by Åšiva himself at the moment of dying. From this mystery the Vais.n.avas cleverly made use when they claimed the mantra.

The Agastyasam

. hitÂ¯

a

The earliest text that bears testimony to this reframing of an ancient doctrine is the Agastyasam

. hitÂ¯

a. I have dealt with this text extensively in Bakker 1986, and a critical edition of it was prepared by Roelf Barkhuis as his PhD thesis (1995). For the first twenty-three chapters I am using his edition. We have dated the text before the Islamic revolution and its place of origin, it has been conjectured, may well have been Benares.

In chapter 7 we read that many devotees ( upÂ¯

asakÂ¯

ah

. ) resort to VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±,

wishing to obtain release ( mumuks.avah. ). Continuously they repeat â€˜Å›iva Å›ivaâ€™, and Åšiva, hearing this, thinks to himself: â€˜how could I bestow mukti to them?â€™

Åšiva asks BrahmÂ¯

a, who tells him that a means ( upÂ¯

aya) does exists. BrahmÂ¯

a

initiates Åšiva in the S.ad.aks.ara, the MantrarÂ¯aja, on the bank of the Ga Ë™ngÂ¯a in VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± at LolÂ¯arka on a SÂ¯uryaparvan day (AgS 7.14â€“15). After japa and other devout practices for a long period, RÂ¯

ama appears to Åšiva and is ready to fulfil

via free access

Hans Bakker

his wishes:

RÂ¯

ama said:

They, indeed, who have died in your holy field, O Lord of the gods, no matter where, even worms, insects and the like, they shall immediately attain release and this will not be otherwise. (26)

Those who obtain, either from you or BrahmÂ¯

a, the Six-syllable Mantra,

they shall be mantrasiddhas during their lifetimes and, when they die, shall reach me. (27)

And, O Åšam

. kara, when one worships devoutly in this holy field with this mantra, there I shall be present, in stones, images etc. (28) Or, when you yourself specifies my mantra in the right ear of one who longs for release, no matter who he is, he shall be released, O Åšiva. (29) When the God of gods had thus spoken, Åšam

. kara answered: My preten-

tion is great here, in this unique holy place, (30)

May final release be the fruit for everyone, O God of gods; and I shall give the supreme boon to all those who are about to die: the mantra.

(31) 2

In reading the Agastyasam

a again, it struck me that the text actually seems

. ),

( manmantra), in which mad refers to RÂ¯

ama and which Åšiva whispers into the

ear of the dying. Until now I had assumed that these two mantras were one and the same, but the tradition of the name as expressed by TulsÂ¯Ä± and the AgS

itself, 3 and the fact that the AgS refers to the powerless Åšaiva equivalent as Å›iva, now suggest to me that the text may have actualy meant rÂ¯

ama. 4

This was really a dashing feat of the VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± Ramaite pandits: to tell their

clientele that in the hour of death Åšiva will come to their rescue by whispering rÂ¯

ama into their right ears. This is no longer a specimen of â€˜Inklusivismusâ€™, for which the Indian religions are renowned, this is downright appropriation.

LolÂ¯

arka

The choice for LolÂ¯

arka as the place of Åšivaâ€™s own initiation into the Six-syllable mantra may not have been arbitrary. Dedicated to SÂ¯

urya, it was one of the

main, non-Åšaiva temples in VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± in the 12th century. The inscriptions of

the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯ala kings, who were staunch Vais.n.avas, mention only two VÂ¯arÂ¯anas.Â¯Ä± temples by name in which the royal family performed pÂ¯

ujÂ¯

a, Â¯

AdikeÅ›ava and

LolÂ¯

arka, on the two extreme ends, north and south, of the Avimuktaks.etra.

A queen of Govindacandra, GosaladevÂ¯Ä±, issued a charter, after a bath in the Ganges, in front of the deity LolÂ¯

arka in ad 1150.5 The same deity was the

recipient of a grant given by Jayacandra in ad 1177 (EI IV, 128 f.). The important LolÂ¯

arka is located near the confluence of the Ganges with the so-called Asi River at the southern tip of the holy ks.etra.

Somehow this area of Benares remained connected with the worship of RÂ¯

ama.

TulsÂ¯Ä±dÂ¯

as is said to have settled at what is now called TulsÂ¯Ä± GhÂ¯

at., adjacent to

the LolÂ¯

arka compound and tradition has it that he died at the neighbouring AsighÂ¯

at. in 1623 at the age of 80 ( assÂ¯Ä±).

For the origin of the doctrine of salvation, which has contributed so much to the greatness of VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± as a centre of pilgrimage, we have to examine the Åšaiva sources concerned with this holy place.

. a is a text that is to be dated after the regime change of ad 1193. It reflects the recovery of the town and the resilience of the Hindu religious spirit in the 13th and 14th centuries, reconstructing the holy place on an unprecedented scale. The composer of the KÂ¯

The SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a

Let me briefly recall a few important facts about this text. We call it â€˜the original SkandapurÂ¯

an

. aâ€™, because the text appears to be about a half millennium older than the oldest khan

. d

. as of the printed SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, with which it has

hardly anything in common apart from its name. 10 We think it is the first textual composition that carries the name â€˜SkandapurÂ¯

an

. aâ€™, which is what the

adjective â€˜originalâ€™ is meant to indicate, nothing more and nothing less.

From the 12th century onwards, this original SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a was gradually

replaced by a series of texts that style themselves as khan

. d

. as of the Skanda-

purÂ¯

an

. a. Our text, in the colophons of the three oldest manuscripts, does not refer to itself as a khan

. d

. a, but simply as â€˜the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. aâ€™. In the 14th century

this replacement had advanced so far that our text was nearly obliterated.

We can be so certain about the early date of our text because the National Archives in Kathmandu possesses three nine-century manuscripts of this PurÂ¯

an.a, one of which is dated in Am

. Å›uvarman Sam

. vat 234, i.e. ad 810. The

authenticity of this text is warranted by Laks.mÂ¯Ä±dhara, the minister and pandit at the court of the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯ala king Govindacandra in the 12th century, who in his description of Benares quotes extensively from a â€˜SkandapurÂ¯

an

. aâ€™. All his

quotes turn out to be from our text, none from the KÂ¯

aÅ›Â¯Ä±khan

. d

. a or any other

khan

. d

. a for that matter.

When the text had reached the point of near-oblivion due to its replacement by later texts styled khan

. d

. as, copyists in northeastern India preserved it, be it in the very margins of the PurÂ¯

an.a text corpus, by renaming it the AmbikÂ¯a-, or

in one case, by mistake probably, RevÂ¯

akhan

. d

. a of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a. Collation

of these later manuscripts so named with the three manuscripts from Kathmandu has established that the text had evolved into a new recension that substantially differs from the â€˜Nepaleseâ€™ text. We refer to this new recension as the RA recension to distinguish it from the S recension, which refers to the text as found in the Nepalese manuscripts. When we collate the quotations in Laks.mÂ¯Ä±dharaâ€™s TÂ¯Ä±rthavivecanakÂ¯an.d.a with the VÂ¯arÂ¯an.asÂ¯Ä±mÂ¯ahÂ¯atmya of the original SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, it becomes clear that an early form of this RA recension already existed in the 12th century and was used by the Nibandha author (Bisschop 2002). Further research into the history of this text has made it plausible that the new recension was created in one major redaction that took place somewhere in North India, most likely in the ninth century. 11

The original text, we estimate, was composed either under the Maukhari kings or Hars.avardhana of Kanauj, in the second half of the sixth or first half of the seventh century. 12

10 Cf. above, pp. 185 ff.; for borrowings from the SP by the Â¯

Avantyakhan

. d

. a, Yokochi 2004.

11 Bakker 2014, 138.

12 In Bakker 2014, 137 I argued that the most likely time span is ad 570 to 620.

Hans Bakker

Textual criticism

Different from what some believe, this philological work is not a blind hunt for

â€˜the originalâ€™ in which all readings of later recensions, Are damned to the rubbish heap of the â€˜critical apparatusâ€™, which appears in published form as a mystifying jumble of characters and symbols creeping along the bottom of the pages. 13

Our method aims at precisely the opposite, namely to distinguish between various layers in the text transmission, in order to be in a position to value each stage through which the text evolved on its own merits as a reflection of its time. And in this assessment the later recensions are equally valuable to us as â€˜the originalâ€™ or what comes closest to it. Far from being a â€˜rubbish heapâ€™, the critical apparatus thus appears to be a precious store house of historical information.

At the risk of being decried an inveterate â€˜orientalistâ€™, I would like to illustrate this method, finally, by tracing the doctrine of the saving mantra in the text tradition of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a.

The saving mantra in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a

In adhyÂ¯

aya 30 of the SP, that is in the middle of the VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an

. asÂ¯Ä±mÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya,

we read in verse 50 that â€˜the devotee who dedicates all his activity to Åšiva attains final release here in the Avimuktaks.etra, more easily than anywhere elseâ€™. This verse is found in all MSS. Immediately following this verse, however, the RA recension has two interesting verses, which are given in the critical apparatus.

Men who are dedicated to japa and meditation as well as those who are slow-witted and deluded in matters of knowledgeâ€”their minds orientated towards external thingsâ€”they (all) reach their goal in VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±:

Here, in the hour of death, MaheÅ›vara himself gives (them) the saving mantra ( tÂ¯

arakam

. brahma), thanks to which one becomes consubstantiated with Him. 14

The second of these verses we have already encountered in a slightly modified form in the MÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya of Avimukta in the KÂ¯

aÅ›Â¯Ä±khan

. d

. a (KKh 1.25.73). This

verse corresponds also closely with a prose passage in the JÂ¯

abÂ¯

ala Upanis.ad

(JÂ¯

abU 1). This prose passage contains two metrically correct uneven Åšloka pÂ¯

adas (beginning with prÂ¯

an

. eo. . .

and yenÂ¯

asÂ¯

av. . . , below n. 15 on p. 470 f.),

which may be an indication that the Upanis.ad text derived from a metrical exemplar, which might have been close to the verse found in the RA recension. 15

13 Smith 2006, 25.

an

. a RA Recension 30.50 (1â€“2):

23 / RÂ¯

ama Devotion in a Åšaiva Holy Place

471

It probably was a Åšloka that people knew by heart and had a more or less independent, floating existence, and so found its way into the Upanis.ad on the one hand, and into the KÂ¯

aÅ›Â¯Ä±khan

. d

. a on the other. The RA recension of the

SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a might be its first attestation.

As already observed, the doctrine of the saving mantra is also known to the VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an

. asÂ¯Ä±mÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya of the MatsyapurÂ¯

an

. a where it is called the karn

. ajÂ¯

apa. A

collation of the MÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmyas in the MatsyapurÂ¯

an

. a and the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a has

proven beyond reasonable doubt that the Matsya borrowed from the Skanda, but it used the older Nepalese recension. 16 This, combined with the fact that both the Matsya and the revised Skanda record this doctrine of the saving mantra independently, has led us to the hypothesis that the RA redaction and the composition of the VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an

. asÂ¯Ä±mÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya of the MatsyapurÂ¯

an

. a belong

approximately to the same period: the 8th to 9th centuries ad.17

It is during this period that this doctrine became widely accepted and met with the approval of orthodox brahmins and PaurÂ¯

an.ikas. Its origin might have

been earlier. This new doctrine, namely, is connected with the inclusion of the cremation ground ( Â´

smaÂ´

sÂ¯

ana) within the sacred fabric of VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±. It may be

conceived as a landmark in the history of the holy town: a change of paradigm by which the cremation ground, from being tabooed, became hallowed and was accommodated to the holy ks.etra. This last remark requires some explanation, and for that we turn to the oldest, â€˜Nepaleseâ€™ or S recension of our text.

Avimukta

VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±â€™s connection with death, the catering for the needs of the moribund, goes back at least to Gupta times and is a dominant feature until today. It is strongly represented in the oldest form of the VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an

. asÂ¯Ä±mÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya of the

SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a. This MÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya, which dates back to the 6th or 7th century,

describes first the primordial situation, when the holy field was covered by a divine garden called udyÂ¯

ana or devodyÂ¯

ana. Åšiva, who has taken residence there

forever (a nirukti of avimukta), shows PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± the garden and the li Ë™ngas in

it, which are either svayam

. bhu or have been installed by various gods, twelve altogether. AvimukteÅ›vara is not included within this dozen, as it is conceived of as Åšivaâ€™s own residence in VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±.

The twelve primordial li Ë™ngas on the other hand are enumerated in such a way that they may be seen as forming a pattern, some sort of circuit around the Avimuktaks.etra, i.e. around the AvimukteÅ›vara sanctuary (Figure 12).18

The town is, on the one hand, described as a meeting place of yogis, in particular of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata variety, on the other hand as a place where one should wish to die, as this promises immediate release. It is therefore all the more conspicuous that the cremation ground itself, the ÅšmaÅ›Â¯

ana, is not mentioned with one word.

That is to say, it is not mentioned in the recension that is preserved in the Nepalese manuscripts (S). The later RA recension has, in addition to the two verses that we have quoted (above, n. 14 on p. 470), made some other highly Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

significant changes. Outside the MÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya proper, in SP 167, which gives

a survey of the major Åšaiva Â¯

ayatanas including VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±, and of which the

texts in S and RA diverge widely, the eulogy of Avimukta of the S recension is replaced in RA by a passage mentioning the Â´

smaÂ´

sÂ¯

ana, known under the name

of â€˜Avimuktakaâ€™. This brings the RA recension of the SP again alongside the VÂ¯

. asÂ¯Ä±mÂ¯

. a, which is for the greater part a eulogy

of Avimukta as cremation ground.

Conclusion

Although Benares from its inception as a holy place has been connected with death and the belief that dying in the vicinity of the AvimukteÅ›vara Temple would bring immediate release, attested already in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata, 19 the

strongly felt polluting nature of the dead themselves and the disposal of their bodies made that originally the Â´

smaÂ´

sÂ¯

ana was considered beyond the pale of

sanctified ground.

This cremation ground was there, as it was in every Indian city, and in one of the earliest PurÂ¯

an.as, the MÂ¯arkan.d.eyapurÂ¯an.a, it is depicted as the unholiest place on earth, the place where king HariÅ›candra passed his doleful days as a can

. d

. Â¯

ala. 20 If we assume that its location has not altered over the centuries, a location that is known in later sources as Man.ikarn.ikÂ¯a, it lay in the early days at the southern fringe of the then holy field, as it should do. 21 With the growth of the town, however, and the omnipresence of the dying along with the industry that surrounded them, this is beginning to change in the seventh and eighth centuries. An important factor in this process has been the spread of the belief that salvation would be available to all, if only the dying days were spent in the holy town. The doctrine of the saving mantra, administered there, and only there, allâ€™ultimo momento, made VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± stand out against

all other competing holy places that promised moks.a; this doctrine has thus greatly contributed to the reputation of the city as the most holy place on earth.

No wonder therefore that, when a wind of change was blowing through northern India in the 11th and 12th centuries, new religious communities jumbed on the bandwagon. The pandits of the emerging Ramaite faith and the cult of the Name in particular were most successful. The ingenuity and flexibility of the Indian religious mind created fresh forms of devotion, in which the old was preserved and the new could flourish. Awareness of this historical process makes that we can now fully appreciate the opening couplets of TulsÂ¯Ä±dÂ¯

asâ€™ Vinayapa-

trikÂ¯

a, which may have been composed in VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±, when the poet felt that â€˜his

20 See the description in MkP 8.109â€“130.

21 See Figure 12; SP II A, 48 f.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

The Hindu Religion and Warâˆ—

Preamble

Although, since Mahatma Gandhi, India is known by many as the country where the principle of ahim

. sÂ¯

a, â€˜not killingâ€™, has being invented and implemented, this ancient principle had originally little or nothing to do with how warfare was conducted and conceived in Hindu society. War was endemic in South Asia and seen as the right and duty of the Hindu king. This warfare, however, was regulated by some rules, which were humane in some respects.

Battle was sometimes conceived of as a form of ritual, in which the soldiers were the sacrificial victims, but this does not entail that Hindu kings went to war for the sake of religion.

By the 11th century the tradional Hindu view of war was seriously challenged by Islamic invaders. This essay investigates the impact of this confrontation.

The conflict between both communities, Hindu and Muslim, has flared up again in recent years. It is argued that the communal unrest in India since its independence tends to alter the Hindu self-perception and its values.

AÅ›oka and ancient warfare in India

What warfare could mean in India in the 3rd century bc we learn from AÅ›okaâ€™s Thirteenth Rock-Edict.

When king DevÂ¯

anÂ¯

a Ë™

mpriya PriyadarÅ›in (i.e. AÅ›oka) had been anointed eight years, (the country of) the Kali Ë™ngas was conquered by (him). One hundred and fifty thousand in number were the men who were deported thence, one hundred thousand in number were those who were slain there, and many times as many were those who died. (CII I, 68)

The same Edict, however, shows that ethical principles were considered to have a relevance with respect to wartime conditions, when AÅ›oka continues, After that, now that (the country of) the Kali Ë™ngas has been taken, DevÂ¯

anÂ¯

a Ë™

mpriya

(is devoted) to a zealous study of morality ( dhramaÂ´

silana = dharmaÂ´

sÂ¯Ä±lana), to

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in: Anna King (ed.), Indian Religions.

Renaissance and Renewal. Equinox, London 2007. pp. 28â€“40. A second, revised version was published in: Dijk, Jacobus van (ed.), Onder OrchideeÃ«n. Nieuwe Oogst uit de Tuin de Geesteswetenschappen te Groningen. Barkhuis Publishing, Groningen. pp. 7â€“17.

475

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

476

Hans Bakker

the love of morality, and to the instruction (of people) in morality. [. . . ] For, this is considered very painful and deplorable by DevÂ¯

anÂ¯

a Ë™

mpriya, that, while one

is conquering an unconquered (country), slaughter ( vadha), death ( maran

. a) and

deportation of people (are taken place) there. [. . . ] For DevÂ¯

anÂ¯

a Ë™

mpriya desires

towards all beings abstention from hurting ( aks.ati), self-control, (and) impartiality in (case of) violence. (CII I, 68 f.)

The ArthaÂ´

sÂ¯

astra

The campaigns of AÅ›oka and his military objectives appear, generally speaking, not out of tune with what is recommended to the â€˜ruler who wishes to conquerâ€™, the vijigÂ¯Ä±s.u, in the ancient â€˜Treatise on Polityâ€™, the ArthaÅ›Â¯astra, which has the following to say on warfare.

Fighting ( yuddha) is said to be of three kindsâ€” prakÂ¯

aÂ´

sa-yuddha â€˜open fightâ€™ in the

place and at the time indicated, kÂ¯

ut.a-yuddha â€˜concealed fightingâ€™, involving the use of tactics on the battlefield, and tÂ¯

us.n.Â¯Ä± Ë™

m-yuddha â€˜silent fightâ€™, implying the use of

secret agents for enticing enemy officers or killing them (AÅš 7.6.40â€“41).

It is stated that when the vijigÂ¯Ä±s.u is superior in strength and the season and terrain are favourable to him, he should resort to open warfare (AÅš 10.3.1). In fact, a fight, about the place and time of which notice has been given, is considered righteous, dharmis.t.ha (AÅš 10.3.26).

If the vijigÂ¯Ä±s.u is not superior to the enemy and the terrain and the season are unfavourable to him, he may resort to kÂ¯

ut.a-yuddha [. . . ]. 1

The same ArthaÅ›Â¯

astra that defines the ruler as the â€˜one desirous of conqueringâ€™

and defines the specific duty ( svadharma) of the ks.atriya as â€˜living by the profession of arms ( Â´

sastrÂ¯

ajÂ¯Ä±va) and protecting the beingsâ€™ (AÅš 1.3.6) enumerates among the duties common to all classes of society, including the ks.atriyas, the

â€˜abstaining from injuryâ€™, ahim

. sÂ¯

a (AÅš 1.3.13). From this it follows that the

duty of ahim

. sÂ¯

a is a duty that concerns the individual, but does not relate to the state, nor to the ruler of the state, the vijigÂ¯Ä±s.u, nor to those, the warriors and soldiers, who are engaged by the state to realize its aims, defence and conquest.

Although AÅ›okaâ€™s morality seems to break with this conception in that it apparently advocates bringing ethical principles to bear on the apparatus of government, he formulates this new policy of â€˜conquest by moralityâ€™ ( dharmavijaya) and the purpose of his proclamationsâ€”viz. â€˜in order that the sons (and) great-grandsons (who) may be (born) to me, should not think that a fresh conquest ought to be madeâ€™ (CII I, 70)â€”only after he himself had conquered all there was to conquer. And he is not slow to add that those subjugated by him â€˜should be told of the power (to punish them) which DevÂ¯

anÂ¯

a Ë™

mpriya

(possesses) in spite of (his) repentance, in order that they may be ashamed (of their crimes) and may not be killedâ€™ (CII I, 69).

In other words, the policies envisaged in Kaut.ilÂ¯Ä±ya ArthaÅ›Â¯astra and AÅ›okaâ€™s Edicts are not as different as they may appear at first sight: both aspire to 1 Kangle 1963â€“65 III, 258.

477

bring violence ( him

. sÂ¯

a) firmly under government control, reserving the right to kill to the state.

The principle of ahim

. sÂ¯

a and the rules of war

Ahim

. sÂ¯

a

All this is not to say that AÅ›okaâ€™s conception of â€˜abstention from killing animals and from hurting living beingsâ€™ ( avihisÂ¯

a) and Kaut.ilyaâ€™s maxim of ahim

. sÂ¯

a cover

exactly the same ground. It is clear that the former is inspired by a Buddhist ethos, 2 while the second relates to a discourse of Brahmanical jurists. Hanns-Peter Schmidtâ€™s article on The Origin of Ahim

. sÂ¯

a, Heestermanâ€™s Non-Violence

and Sacrifice, and Bodewitzâ€™s Hindu Ahi Ë™

msÂ¯

a and its Roots, to mention some

of the main discussants, have shown that the development of this concept is an intricate one, 3 one which we shall leave aside here however, since from these studies it emerges that, whatever the origin of the concept and whatever a DharmaÅ›Â¯

astra author may have understood by ahim

. sÂ¯

a, it had no bearing

on the policies of the state and the right, nay the duty of the king to wage war. 4 This right, and hence the right to stage organized killing in the interest of the state, has, to the best of my knowledge, never been questioned in the brahmanical tradition, before Mahatma Gandhiâ€”and foreign influences play a role hereâ€”gave a new meaning to this old concept. 5 Before him, and sadly also after him, war was rather considered to be part and parcel of organized society, sanctified by those who had probably most to win and least to lose by it, the brahmanical elite.

The BhagavadgÂ¯Ä±tÂ¯

a

One example, a very early one that has however retained its unquestioned authority until today, may suffice to illustrate the point. After Arjuna had 2 For this ethos and its implementation see Schmithausen 1999; on AÅ›oka op. cit. 55.

3 Schmidt 1968, 1997; Heesterman 1984; Bodewitz 1999. For a survey and bibliography of this discussion see Bodewitz 1999. Bodewitz concludes ( ibid. 41): One may rather assume that ahi Ë™

msÂ¯

a originally belonged to the ascetic antiritualism, which was especially represented by the heretics (Buddhist and Jains) and only hesitantly obtained a foothold in the older Vedic Upanis.ads, where, however, it [scil.

antiritualism] was never associated with ahi Ë™

msÂ¯

a.

4 Bodewitz 1999, 20:

Killing in war was a prescript for the relevant social class and therefore pacifism can be ruled out as a decisive factor in the development of at least the Hindu concept of ahim

. sÂ¯

a.

5 Schwab 1950, 474:

a qui va frapper en retour les

dÃ©tenteurs de la croyance: Gandhi demande Ã  TolstoÂ¨Ä± sa propre inspiration, et par lui retrouve sa voie vers la loi dâ€™amour et de passivitÃ©; lui Ã©crivant de Londres en 1909, il signe â€˜votre humble discipleâ€™, en reÃ§oit le conseil de lire la Lettre Ã  un Hindou, oÃ¹ la filiation Ã©tait le plus explicite, et dont il avouera lâ€™action dÃ©cisive sur sa mÃ©ditation.

via free access

478

Hans Bakker

expressed his reservations with respect to killing his kinsmen, the Lord himself has this to say in the BhagavadgÂ¯Ä±tÂ¯

a.

This embodied (soul) is eternally unslayable in the body of every one, son of Bharata; therefore all beings thou shouldst not mourn. Likewise having regard for thine own (caste) duty ( svadharma) thou shouldst not tremble; for another, better thing than a fight required of duty exists not for a warrior. Presented by mere luck, an open door of heavenâ€”happy the warriors, son of Pr.thÂ¯a, that get such a fight! Now, if thou this duty-required conflict wilt not perform, then thine own duty and glory abandoning, thou shalt get thee evil. 6

The continuity of the Indian tradition in this respect could not be better illustrated than by a speech given by Bal Gangadhar Tilak at the occasion of the Shivaji Festival in 1896, organized by him to strengthen Hindu solidarity against British Rule, but simultaneously directed against the Muslim community. In the Festival Shivajiâ€™s murder of the Mogul general Afzal Khan was particularly celebrated. Tilak addresses his audience as follows.

Let us even assume that Shivaji first planned and then executed the murder of Afzal Khan. Was this act of the Maharaja good or bad? This question which has to be considered should not be viewed from the standpoint of the Penal Code or even of the Smritis of Manu. [. . . ] The laws which bind society are for common men like you and me. [. . . ] Great men are above the common principles of morality.

These principles do not reach the place on which great men stand. Did Shivaji commit a sin in killing Afzal Khan? The answer to this question can be found in the Mahabharata itself. Shrimat Krishna preached in the Gita that we have a right even to kill our own guru and our kinsmen. No blame attaches to any person if he is doing deeds without being actuated by a desire to reap the fruit of his deeds.

[. . . ] If thieves enter our house and we have not strength enough in our fists to drive them out, we should without hesitation lock them up and burn them alive.

God has not conferred upon the foreigners the grant inscribed on a copperplate to the Kingdom of Hindustan. 7

Tilakâ€™s words eerily resound in the reports of what happened during the communal riots that were sparked off by the dispute over the Babri Masjid in AyodhyÂ¯

a one century later, when hundreds of Indians, mostly Muslims, were burnt alive when their houses were set ablaze by their fellow-villagers. 8

6 BhG 2.30â€“33 (translation by Franklin Edgerton). Elsewhere in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata (MBh

12.15.20) the principle of non-injury is downright declared to be impossible in the world.

Cf. Basham 1967, 123:

In several passages of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata, notably in the famous Bhagavad GÂ¯Ä±tÂ¯

a, the

evil and cruelty of war are referred to, and it is suggested that the life of the soldier is a sinful one. But such arguments are only put forward to be demolished by counterarguments, most of which are based on the necessities of this dark age of the world and on the dangers of anarchy. Positive condemnations of war are rare in Indian literature.

7 Quoted from Wolpert 1962, 86 f.

8 Bakker 1991a, 99 f.; above, p. 75

24 / The Hindu Religion and War

479

The rules of war

All this looks pretty grim, and no doubt India has had its share of carnage and distress caused by never ending wars between states and various communities, but the picture should not be made more gruesome than necessary. There were rules that regulated warfare and that limited its destructive potential.

The ArthaÅ›Â¯

astra lays down that, â€˜when attacking the enemy in the open battlefield or when storming a fort, care should be taken to see that the following categories of persons are not attacked: (1) patita, those who have fallen down, (2) parÂ¯

a Ë™nmukha, those who have turned their back on the fight, (3) abhipanna, those who surrender, (4) muktakeÂ´

sa, those whose hair are loose (as a mark of

submission), (5) muktaÂ´

sastra, those who have abandoned their weapons, (6) bhayavirÂ¯

upa, those whose appearance is changed through fear, and (7) ayu-dhyamÂ¯

ana, those who are taking no part in the fight.â€™ 9 These restrictions agree with the view expressed in the Moks.adharmaparvan which ordains that, A king should not hurt ( him

. syÂ¯

ad) children or elderly people, nor him who is exhausted, who is frightened, who has lost his weapons, who cries, who flees, who is without means, inactive, ill or begs for mercy. 10

These rules sound particularly humane and in some respects even seem to anticipate the Geneva Convention, though one may be sceptical about their implementation in actual battle as one may be of the Geneva Convention today.

Even without a statistical investigation one senses that the avowed chivalry was renounced, more often than not, also in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata itself.

The reports of Megasthenes and Ibn Bat.t.Â¯ut.a

However, unexpected though it may seem, this â€˜civilizedâ€™, or one should rather say â€˜ritualizedâ€™ form of warfare is confirmed by a foreign observer who lived in India in about the same period in which the ArthaÅ›Â¯

astra was beginning

to take form and AÅ›oka reported his conquests, namely by the Greek Megasthenes, ambassador of Seleucus to the court of Candragupta Maurya, AÅ›okaâ€™s grandfather. As is well known, Megasthenesâ€™ own book on India is lost, but much of it is preserved in Arrianâ€™s Indika which has the following to say on the issue.

The fifth caste among the Indians consists of the warriors, who are second in point of numbers to the husbandmen, but lead a life of supreme freedom and enjoyment.

They have only military duties to perform. Others make their arms, and others supply them with horses, and they have others to attend on them in the camp, who take care of their horses, clean their arms, drive their elephants, prepare their chariots, and act as their charioteers. As long as they are required to fight they fight, and when peace returns they abandon themselves to enjoymentâ€”the pay which they receive from the state being so liberal that they can with ease maintain themselves and others besides.

9 Kangle 1963â€“65 III, 259 f. (AÅš 13.4.52).

10 MBh 12.286.3â€“4. Cf. MBh 3.19.13â€“14.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

480

Hans Bakker

[. . . ] the second caste consists of the tillers of the soil, who form the most numerous class of the population. They are neither furnished with arms, nor have any military duties to perform, but they cultivate the soil and pay tribute to the kings and the independent cities. In times of civil war the soldiers are not allowed to molest the husbandmen or ravage their lands: hence, while the former are fighting and killing each other as they can, the latter may seen close at hand tranquilly pursuing their work,â€”perhaps ploughing, or gathering in their crops, pruning the trees, or reaping the harvest. 11

The picture is too good to be true, since, for instance, the destruction of crops in the country of the enemy seems to have been common practice; but even if Indian historic reality was less idyllic than Megasthenes wanted us to believe, the essence of his observations seems to be that within the traditional Indian constellation war was primarily conceived as a gallant pastime of kings, a kind of sport that was directed towards eliminating rival kings and acquisition of glory, land and riches, not towards the destruction of neighbouring countries that were hated. An unexpected confirmation of this chivalrous ethos is found in the Travelogue of Ibn Bat.t.Â¯ut.a, who stayed in India for 15 years (c. ad 1335â€“1349) and who tells us, when once he was in dire straits: I was afraid that they would all shoot at me at once if I fled from them, and I was wearing no armour so I threw myself to the ground and surrendered, as they do not kill those who do that. 12

Hence war could be viewed as perfectly within the precincts of the dharma and was generally not associated with evil ( pÂ¯

apa), though, admittedly, there were

grades of righteousness. The historic reality is reflected in Indian mythology, in which heroes and gods, if they are not practising self-mortification ( tapas), are continuously concerned with fighting each other, and in which monstrous atrocities are described with great gusto and approval. The epic by the mouth of Kr.s.n.a even openly defends the use of foul means in battle by holding up the gods as an example,

Enemies of superior number are to be killed falsely and by (foul) means. This path has formerly been followed by the gods when they slew the Asuras; and a path followed by the good ones may be followed by all. 13

This opportunistic and rather naive view of a privileged elite must have suffered serious blows when the kingdoms of northern India were confronted with foreign invaders. It may partly account for the fact that in these confrontations the Indian armies were often the losing party. The adversaries did not play the game by the same rules, while the Indian kings and generals appear to have been very reluctant to change them. On the other hand, when invaders came to stay they were accommodated to the Indian system and gradually dissolved 11 Arrianus, Indika 12.2â€“4, 11.9â€“10. Translation quoted from McCrindle 1877, 210 f.

12 Ibn Bat.t.Â¯

ut.a Vol. IV, 777.

13 MBh 9.60.61â€“62.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

24 / The Hindu Religion and War

481

therein. I am thinking, for instance, of the Åšakas (the Scyths), the Kus.Â¯an.as, and the HÂ¯

un.as.

The idea of a â€˜just warâ€™

War thus seemed to some extent to be a natural phenomenon and needed no justification; consequently the concept of a â€˜just warâ€™ did not arise. And the multifarious and sponge-like character of the Indian religions, lacking a central authorative agency, simply did not give rise to the idea of religious wars. 14 The ArthaÅ›Â¯

astra, on the contrary, recommends that a king adapts himself to the religious customs of the countries he has brought under his control.

After gaining new territory, he should cover the enemyâ€™s faults with his own virtues, his virtues with double virtues. He should carry out what is agreeable and beneficial to the subjects by doing his own duty as laid down, granting favours, giving exemptions, making gifts and showing honour. [. . . ] Hence he should adopt a similar character, dress, language and behaviour (as the subjects). And he should show the same devotion in festivals in honour of deities of the country ( deÂ´

sadaivata), fes-

tive gatherings and sportive amusements. [. . . ] And he should cause the honouring of all deities and hermitages, and make grants of land, money and exemptions to men distinguished in learning, speech and piety, order the release of all prisoners and render help to the distressed, the helpless and the diseased. [. . . ] And discontinuing whatever custom he might regard harmful to the treasury and the army, or as unrighteous ( adharmis.t.ha), he should establish a righteous course of conduct ( dharmavyavahÂ¯

ara). 15

Though this policy seems to have been practised by many Indian kings, it did not preclude that the possession of a holy place, temple or idol could be the target of a military campaign. Yet, we should be reluctant to designate such a campaign or war a â€˜religiousâ€™ or â€˜holy warâ€™, since its objective was to divert a religious asset to the use of the state rather than to enhance or defend the cause of religion itself.

The battle and the sacrifice

However, it will cause no surprise that in a culture that was entirely permeated by religion and that to some extent ritualized warfare, war was considered to be sanctified in another sense. The Sanskrit literature abounds in comparisons of the (ritual) battle and the sacrifice. Battlefields are seen as sacrificial grounds and the warriors killed are the sacrificial animals ( paÂ´

sus). Like the latter they

are believed to go straight to heaven. Thus Kr.s.n.a speaks to Arjuna: â€˜Either slain thou shalt gain heaven, Or conquering thou shalt enjoy the earth.â€™ 16 And like the instruments of sacrifice, the implements of war needed consecration.

To this end a lustration ( nÂ¯Ä±rÂ¯

ajanÂ¯

a) ceremony was traditionally performed at

14 Cf. above, pp. 56 ff.

15 AÅš 13.5.3-4, 7-8, 11, 14. Translation Kangle 1963â€“65 II, 491 f.

16 BhG 2.37 (translation Edgerton).

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

482

Hans Bakker

the end of the autumnal NavarÂ¯

atra festival, on the â€˜Tenth of Victoryâ€™ ( vijayÂ¯

a-

daÂ´

samÂ¯Ä±, DasarÂ¯

a), in which the â€˜Invincible Goddessâ€™ (AparÂ¯

ajitÂ¯

a) was worshipped

and the kingâ€™s arms, his soldiers, horses and elephants were purified before they took to the field. 17 The festival preceding this lustration of arms, the NavarÂ¯

atra, is dedicated to DurgÂ¯

a, who became also the Hindu goddess of war. 18

When VÂ¯

akpatirÂ¯

aja (first half of eighth century ad) in his GaÃ¼d

. avaha (vv. 285â€“

338) describes the worship of DurgÂ¯

a by his hero, YaÅ›ovarman of Kanauj, before

this king set out on his conquest, 19 this may refer to actual practice. All this, however, does not imply that the kings went to war because of this Goddess, or for the sake of religion. In this respect Hinduism differed fundamentally from the Abrahamic religions. I will conclude this essay with some observations on what actually happened, when these two types of religions came into conflict.

Hinduism and Islam

The conquest of northern India

From the eleventh century onwards North India was regularly confronted, perhaps for the first time, with an enemy that did not adapt itself to Indian customs and did not â€˜show the same devotion in festivals in honour of the deities of the countryâ€™. Instead that country was infested with marauding bands of Turus.ka warriors, after Sultan Mah.mÂ¯ud of Ghazni had pointed the way in his raid on Somnath (Gujarat) in ad 1024â€“1025. The reports in the KÂ¯amilu-t TawÂ¯arÂ¯Ä±kh by Ibn AsÂ¯Ä±r and the TÂ¯

a - rÂ¯Ä±kh-i AlfÂ¯Ä± inform us that in the defence of the temple of SomanÂ¯

atha fifty thousand Hindus were killed. 20 One would have expected that in the face of such catastrophy Hindu kings would have joined hands and made common cause to defend their country and their holy places. However, â€˜Indiaâ€™

was not conceived as an entity to be defended and Hinduism was not organized in such a way that it could offer a framework for its own defence. Hindu kings kept fighting amongst themselves and when at the end of the 12th century the CÂ¯

ahamÂ¯

anas, who had borne the brunt of the attacks of the Muslim armies, 17 KÂ¯

alidÂ¯

asa, Raghuvam

. Å›a 4.25â€“26:

The sacrificial fire, properly fed in the ceremony of the lustration of the cavalry ( vÂ¯

ajinÂ¯Ä±rÂ¯

ajanÂ¯

a), destined him (i.e. king Raghu) for victory, when, by resembling a hand as it were, its flames made the auspicious right turn ( pradaks.in.Â¯a). Leaving the centre and frontiers (of his realm) well-protected and his rear safeguarded (against inimical attacks), he marched at the head of the six units of his army, joined by fortune, impelled by desire to conquer the earth.

Cf. AÅš 2.30.51 and VarÂ¯

ahamihiraâ€™s Br.hatsam

. hitÂ¯

a 44.1â€“2, where this ceremony is pre-

scribed for the 8th, 12th or 15th day of the bright half of the lunar month of KÂ¯

arttika

or Â¯

AÅ›vina. See Kane 1930-62 III, 230 f., V, 188â€“194; Einoo 1999, 51 ff.

24 / The Hindu Religion and War

483

were on the brink of collapse, their eastern neighbours, the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯alas did

not come to their rescue. The army of the CÂ¯

ahamÂ¯

anas under king Pr.thvÂ¯Ä±rÂ¯aja

was destroyed in the second battle of Tarain (ad 1192). The Gangetic Plain lay open for conquest.

The case of VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an

. asÂ¯Ä±

It would be unfair to deny the Indian kings any foresight of the events to come.

It would seem that the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯ala kings, who had seized power in Kanauj,

until then the political centre of Northern India, made an effort to employ all available means to counter the Mlecchas, the Barbarians. Apparently in response to the â€˜Turus.kaâ€™, i.e. Muslim threat from the west, they moved their capital to VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±.

VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± had evolved into the most holy place of the country without being or developing into a political capital, and this appears to have been in conformity with the normal situation in South Asia, where sacred and political space customarily have different centres. 21 Hermann Kulkeâ€™s explanation of this phenomenon is that, if both were to coincide, rulers over the holy town would have to admit their enemies into their own political centre of power, due to considerations of dharma. 22 If territory coincides or is identified with sacred space, wars in defence or conquest of this territory could be defined as holy wars. Yet, as we have seen, the concept of religious, or holy war for that matter, was conspicuously absent in traditional Indian political thought and so was the idea of solidarity based on a common faith and the practice of propagating war by appealing to religious sentiments more general than those conforming to the sanctified principles of dharma. 23

Hence the question may be raised why the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯alas moved their actual

seat of power towards the sacred VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± rather than staying within the presti-

gious imperial capital Kanauj. 24 This might have been caused by the fact that Kanauj lay in ruins after having been sacked twice by the Ghaznavite invaders (ad 1018 by Sultan Mah.mÂ¯ud, ad 1086â€“90 by Prince Mah.mÂ¯ud, governor of the Panjab). But it could have been rebuilt, just as VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä± itself had recovered

from its first contact with Muslim forces. A more plausible explanation for the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯alasâ€™ deviation from customary practice in choosing VÂ¯arÂ¯an.asÂ¯Ä± as their power base may be sought in the circumstance that the nature of the enemy had changed, an enemy which held completely different views on territorial warfare as well as on religion. That the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯alas were well aware of this from the

beginning is shown by their levying of the â€˜Turks taxâ€™ ( turus.kadan.d.a), a war 21 Bakker 1993a and 1996a.

22 Kulke 1982, 15.

23 In this respect Hinduism does not differ from the other great Indian religion, Buddhism.

Cf. Schmitthausen 1999, 63: â€˜Finally, it should be pointed out that religious wars for the sake of spreading the Buddhist religion by force to non-Buddhist regions seem to have occurred very rarely, if at all.â€™

24 EI IX, 304; SI II, 280 f.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

484

Hans Bakker

tax that is without parallel in India. 25 In other words, the move to VÂ¯

arÂ¯

an.asÂ¯Ä±

may be viewed as part of the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯alasâ€™ reaction to the challenge of Islam,

a novel strategy to enhance prestige, boost morale and rally support. In all their inscriptions the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯ala kings proclaimed themselves â€˜protectors of the (North) Indian holy placesâ€™ ( tÂ¯Ä±rthas), to begin with those in KÂ¯

aÅ›i, and in

all of them they boast of their own piety. 26

However, if the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯alas had chosen VÂ¯arÂ¯an.asÂ¯Ä± as their capital in order to profit from the (religious) prestige that was connected with it, this strategy failed. It did not bring them the support of their neighbouring (Hindu) kings.

On the contrary, at the eastern border they were confronted with a new powerful enemy, the dynasty of the Senas, whose king Laks.man.asena (ad 1179â€“1206) claimed a victory over the king of KÂ¯

aÅ›i, a success that in all likelihood refers

to his conquest of MagadhÂ¯

a. 27 Just as the GÂ¯

ahad.avÂ¯alas for their part did not

come to the rescue of the CÂ¯

ahamÂ¯

anas, they themselves were not supported

by their eastern neighbours in their war against the Muslim invaders. Consequently they were defeated by the GhÂ¯

urÂ¯Ä± army at Chandawar, and Jayacandra,

â€˜RÂ¯

aja of Benares, the chief of idolatry and perditionâ€™ was killed on the battlefield. 28 According to the Chronicle of H

. asan Niz.Â¯

amÂ¯Ä± the victorious troops of

Qut.b al-DÂ¯Ä±n Aybak plundered the state treasury at Â¯

AsnÂ¯Ä± and,

Proceeded towards Benares, which is the centre of the country of Hind, and here they destroyed nearly one thousand temples, and raised mosques on their foundations; and the knowledge of the law became promulgated, and the foundations of religion were established. 29

It is perhaps one of the most remarkable, if not tragic qualities of holy ground that it holds a special attraction for believers of other religions. From the 13th century the Hindus had to share it with the Muslims, who selected the Hindusâ€™ most holy spots to build their mosques, and this has been a source of 25 Niyogi 1959, 180 f.

26 EI XIV, 197; Niyogi 1949, 36. The Vasantatilaka verse eulogizing Candradevaâ€™s pious and generous conduct is included in the standard text of all land grants (Sircar in EI XXXV, 202).

adhÂ¯

ainagar Copper-plate Inscription of Laks.man.asena (date illegible) in SI II, 127

For a critical assessment of the testimony of H

. asan Niz.Â¯

amÂ¯Ä±, the first part of which was

composed between ad 1205 and 1217, it is good to keep the following words of Dowson in mind ( op. cit. 210):

Beyond the praise which the author bestows upon his heroes, there is nothing to indicate that he was contemporary with the events which he describes, and the absence of all particulars, as well as a certain confusion and indistinctness about some of the dates, show that he was no active participator in any of his patronsâ€™ campaigns. It is singularly strange that he says nothing of the transactions of Qut.b al-DÂ¯Ä±nâ€™s actual reign, for the same short chapter records his accession and his death.

24 / The Hindu Religion and War

485

endless conflict until today. The mosque erected in the time of the first Mogul emperor Babur in 1528, the so-called Babri Masjid on the site in AyodhyÂ¯

a that

was believed to be the Birthplace of RÂ¯

ama, the RÂ¯

amajanmabhÂ¯

umi, is a case in

point. 30

Epilogue

We have seen that the notion of â€˜holy warâ€™ had not emerged within ancient India. And despite an uncompromising regime in northern India since ad 1200, which was hostile towards the quintessence of Hinduism, the temple cult, this idea was only very slow to develop, if at all. However, a constant infringement on central Hindu religious institutions must sooner or later have given rise to resistance that was inspired by religion and for which religion offered a justification; and, probably more important, it almost inevitably created a cause that could unify Hindus beyond caste, language and regional barriers.

Strangely enough though, such a cause took a rather long time to develop and gathered social momentum only after Muslim authority had considerably weakened.

Elsewhere I have discussed the outcome of this developmentâ€”the transformation of the utopian ideal of RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Rule ( rÂ¯

ama rÂ¯

ajya) into a political

programme of the extreme right and the movement to liberate RÂ¯

amaâ€™s Birth-

place in AyodhyÂ¯

a, which finally led to the destruction of Baburâ€™s Mosque on December 6 1992. 31

Yet, although the Babri Masjid/RÂ¯

amajanmabhÂ¯

umi case has made it clear

that a number of elements have crept into the Hindu religion which were not there before, a downright civil war in which Hindu and Muslim were taking up arms for the sake of their faiths failed to materialize. As such new elements in Hinduism one may distinguish:

1 The formation of an exclusive community of Hindus who share the desire for a common good.

2 The view that history has an ultimate, religiously defined goal, the Rule of RÂ¯

ama or rÂ¯

ama rÂ¯

ajya.

3 A tendency to see Islam and its adherents as agents of evil, implying a demonization of the enemy.

4 Regarding Hindus who perish during the conflicts as martyrs for the common weal. 32

To conclude, a religion that is aliveâ€”and Hinduism certainly is such a religionâ€”

changes continuously under the influence of shifting socio-economic conditions 30 Bakker 1986 I, 134. Above, p. 65.

31 Bakker 1991a; above, pp. 64 ff. For a survey and analysis of the AyodhyÂ¯

a issue (with an

extensive bibliography) the reader is referred to the Internationales Asienforum 3-4/94.

32 Bakker 1991a, 102; cf. above, p. 77.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

486

Hans Bakker

and the challenges posed to it by rival world-views. The impact of a secularized culture on the one hand and a world-wide tendency towards fundamentalism on the other are two factors that do not fail to alter the way in which Hindus conceive themselves and the way they experience their own religion vis-Ã -vis that of their Muslim countrymen. It makes the study of Hinduism such an engaging activity. For the inhabitants of India it is much more than that: the development of Hinduism shapes their lives and their future. We can only hope that the Hindus will not take example from the bloody history that joins the three great Abrahamic religions.

Åšiva Caturmukha

The myth of TilottamÂ¯

a

In chapter 203 of the Â¯

Adiparvan of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata we are told that, in order

to kill the Asuras Sunda and Upasunda, who could only be killed by each other, ViÅ›vakarman, ordered by BrahmÂ¯

a, creates a woman of unparallelled

beauty. The Grandfather tells her to go to the two demons and to seduce them in order that they may kill one and other in their rivalry over her. This beauty, named TilottamÂ¯

a, promises to do so and takes her leave of the gods by making a circumambulation. Among those gods is Bhagavat MaheÅ›vara, who sits to the south (scil. of BrahmÂ¯

a) with his face turned east, whereas the gods sit to

the north (of him) and the r.s.is all around (see below Textual Sources No. 2

(TS 2) v. 21). Only Indra and Bhagavat SthÂ¯

an.u (i.e. MaheÅ›vara) are able to

preserve their composure, but the latterâ€™s excessive desire to watch her ( dras.t.u-kÂ¯

amasya cÂ¯

atyartham

. ) leads to the coming forth of three more faces ( mukha), one directed towards the south, which is possessed of curling lashes ( aËœ

ncita-

paks.mÂ¯antam), one to the west and one to the north, the latter two not further qualified (TS 2 vv. 22â€“24). In this way SthÂ¯

an.u MahÂ¯adeva became four-faced

( caturmukhah

. ). Indra, on the other hand, issues forth eyes on all sides up to a thousand (TS 2 vv. 25â€“26).

The curling eyelashes apart, the myth in this form does not yet refer to different aspects of Åšiva that are represented by these faces, but his qualification of â€˜Postâ€™ ( sthÂ¯

an

. u) may hint at his ithyphallic nature. That the appellation

â€˜SthÂ¯

an.uâ€™ may have a phallic connotation emerges from the ambiguous and rather obscure nirukti in MBh 7.173.92 (TS 5 v. 92): â€˜Because he burns (/destroys) when standing erect, and, because his standing (erect) is the arising of the vital breath, and, because his phallus is always standing, therefore is he known as â€œPostâ€.â€™ 1

The myth of TilottamÂ¯

a is taken up in the AnuÅ›Â¯

asanaparvan, where signif-

icant iconographic features are added. An allusion to his ithyphallic nature

is absent here. Instead it is explained how Åšiva assumed a quadruple form ( caturmÂ¯

urtitva), which may not be exactly equivalent to â€˜a form with four headsâ€™ (TS 7 vv. 3â€“6).

Wherever she with beautiful teeth (i.e. TilottamÂ¯

a) came into my vicinity, there,

O Goddess, emerged a lovely head of mine. Wishing to watch her, I assumed a quadruple form with the help of yoga. Having become four-faced, while showing my own yoga, I exercise sovereignty ( indratva) with my eastern face, with my northern one I sport ( ramÂ¯

ami) with you, O blameless one (UmÂ¯

a); my western face

is gentle ( saumya) and conveys happiness to all living beings; my southern face, which has a terrifying appearance and is fierce ( raudra), destroys the creatures.

Translating this description into iconography, we may tentatively infer that the main head, which faces east, has the stern countenance of the yogin, that the southern face expresses the ferocious ( ugra) aspect, that the northern face ex-

âˆš

presses delight(

ram), whereas the western benevolent ( saumya) face, which bestows happiness to the world, may have, by virtue of this function, a regal appearance, which may be symbolized by the turban ( us.n.Â¯Ä±s.a), although the text does not explicitly specify this headgear. The MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata text seems

to assign these four aspectsâ€”asceticism ( yogin), ferociousness ( ugra/ raudra), benevolence ( saumya) towards the world (i.e. us.n.Â¯Ä±s.in), and delightâ€”to an anthropomorphic form of Åšiva MaheÅ›vara, who describes himself further as possessed of matted hair ( jat.ila), celibate ( brahmacÂ¯arin), with the PinÂ¯aka bow in his hand, and with a lustrous throat, Â´

srÂ¯Ä±kan

. t.ha (TS 7 vv. 7â€“8). It is this quartet

of aspects that seems to underly, admittedly with some variations, the early sculptural representations of Åšiva, no matter whether we are concerned with a caturmukhali Ë™nga (aniconic) or with an anthropomorphic image. This may be illustrated by some early examples.

Images of Â´

Siva in his quadruple form

In the statue found in Bhita, datable around the beginning of the Common Era, 2 Åšivaâ€™s main characteristic, viz. his ascetic, i.e. yogin nature, is represented by the central anthropomorphic figure, who is provided with matted locks ( jat.ila) and penis erectus (Plate 109). Unlike his description in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata quoted above this central figure does not carry the bow PinÂ¯

aka,

but rather seems to conform to devotional demands in that he carries the vessel ( kalaÂ´

sa) of amr.ta in his left hand, while the right hand seems to be raised in abhayamudrÂ¯

a. 3

This main deity is further characterized by four distinctive aspects symbolized by a â€˜girdleâ€™ of four heads around his waist, only partly in conformity with the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata description.

One of the heads clearly represents

The aspects represented by the remaining two heads of the Bhita sculpture, described by Kreisel as saumya and us.n.Â¯Ä±s.in, agree with the two other aspects assigned to MaheÅ›vara in the quoted MahÂ¯

arata passage, if we are allowed

to equate the face qualified as saumya by Kreisel with the one that in the MahÂ¯

arata is said to sport with UmÂ¯

a ( ramÂ¯

ami). The relation to the quar-

ters remains problematic however; evidently the orientation of the us.n.Â¯Ä±s.in and saumya faces were not yet fixed. On the basis of the text one would expect that the head with which he sports with UmÂ¯

a (said to face north), is placed opposite

of the ugra face (said to face south), which position in the Bhita sculpture, however, is occupied by the turbaned head, which, according to our interpretation of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata text, should face west. An us.n.Â¯Ä±s.in head in the western quarter is indeed found in an early caturmukhali Ë™nga to which we turn now.

The probably oldest Caturmukhali Ë™nga that

has been found is the MathurÂ¯

a li Ë™nga pre-

served in the National Museum Delhi (NM

65.172), which according to Kreisel is dat-

able to about ad 100 (Plate 110).7 Its faces

in eastern, southern and western directions

conform to the MahÂ¯

arata description in

that they express Åšivaâ€™s yogin, ugra and us.n.Â¯Ä±s.in aspects. The northern head deviates from the text as well as from the Bhita

sculpture in that it shows a shaven head

and as such may be denoted as mun

. d

. in.

This head replaces â€˜the one that sports with

UmÂ¯

aâ€™ of the epic, but again we are basically

concerned with a differentiation of four as-

pects.

Attempts to explain these earliest Åšaiva

images according to a fivefold scheme should

be considered as anachronistic (Bakker

1999). The li Ë™nga or central figure itself was, Plate 110

when Åšaiva theology developed, interpreted

MathurÂ¯

a: Caturmukhali Ë™

nga

as the â€˜fifthâ€™ (invisible) aspect in order to

bring the fourfold spatial arrangement into line with the non-iconographic fivefold division known from the TaittirÂ¯Ä±ya Â¯

Aran

. yaka (TS 1), which associates five

mantras, i.e. five cosmic dimensions or functions with SadÂ¯

aÅ›iva; the first word

of each mantra is explained by the commentator SÂ¯

( vaktra) of God (ParameÅ›vara), viz. SadyojÂ¯

and Â¯IÅ›Â¯

ana. 8 This synthesis of a spatial and a cosmological order postdates our earliest Åšaiva sculptures; it is, to the best of my knowledge, for the first time presented in the Vis.n.udharmottarapurÂ¯an.a 3.48.1â€“7 (TS 16). Plate 111

MathurÂ¯

a: Architrave with scene of li Ë™

nga worship

What, on the other hand, is very remarkable is the comparatively little attention paid to the li Ë™nga as a Åšaiva cult object in our early Sanskrit texts. There is ample evidence which demonstrates that aniconic Åšiva worship was widespread throughout the Indian continent at the beginning of the Common Era. Not only do we have, for instance, the testimony of the unequivocally phallic representation of Åšiva from Gudimallam, 10 which possibly dates from before the Common Era, but we also have an architrave from MathurÂ¯

a, datable to the late

Ks.atrapa period (middle of first century ad), which shows a li Ë™nga sanctuary (Plate 111). 11 To this may be added the late-Ks.atrapa Caturmukhali Ë™nga that we have just discussed and numerous li Ë™ngas pertaining to the Kus.Â¯an.a period

&c. 12

at.aka kings were brahmins and the majority of them MÂ¯aheÅ›varas, but their apparent reserve to patronize li Ë™nga temples tallies with the Sanskrit texts of this period, in which li Ë™nga worship is only reluctantly acknowledged.

Early Sanskrit sources of li Ë™

nga worship

The PÂ¯

aÂ´

supatasÂ¯

utra and its commentary

First of all, the authoritative text of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata sect itself, the SÂ¯

utras and

their commentary, do not mention li Ë™nga worship with a single word. On the contrary, the commentator Kaun.d.inya describes a manifestation of Åšiva ( mÂ¯urti) in iconic terms; his form ( rÂ¯

upa) is said to be characterized by the bull-banner etc.:

â€˜Imageâ€™ ( mÂ¯

urti): Either this ( yad etad) form ( rÂ¯

upa) that is perceived by him who is

standing at the right side of God, his face turned north, in (His) proximity, a form that is characterised by the bull-banner, the lance in hand, Nandin, MahÂ¯

akÂ¯

ala,

erect phallus etc., or to which ( yad vÂ¯

a) the laymen resort.

The sanctuary is â€˜of the Great Godâ€™ ( mahÂ¯

adevasya). This is the answer ( iti). There is the object to be worshipped. 20

The MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata

Though Rudraâ€™s phallic aspect is recognized in MBh 10.17.21, 12.160.46, and 13.17.74, there are only a few passages in the MahÂ¯

as such is acknowledged, the oldest of which may be the verses in Dron

Les relations de Kr.s.n.a et de Rudra le sont moins. 21

The MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata passages at issue run (TS 3 and 4):

Birth, karman, tapas, and yoga of these two (i.e. Nara and NÂ¯

arÂ¯

ayan.a) and of you

(i.e. AÅ›vatthÂ¯

aman) are eminent; God has been adored by these two in the phallus ( li Ë™

nga), by you in an image, during the various world-periods. He who adores the Lord in the li Ë™

nga, knowing Bhava to assume all forms, in him the disciplines concerning the self and the disciplines concerning learning are everlasting. For the gods and Siddhas and great seers, by worshipping in this way, strife to attain the highest in the world and the everlasting station. And this very KeÅ›ava (Kr.s.n.a) is a votary of Rudra, being born from Rudra; this Kr.s.n.a who is eternal is also to be worshipped with sacrifices. He who adores the Lord in the phallus, knowing Him to exist in all creatures, in him the One whose emblem is the bull (i.e. Åšiva) takes an extraordinary delight.

Because his phallus stands erect in perpetual celibacy and the people worship greatly ( mahayanti), (therefore) is he known as the Great Lord (MaheÅ›vara). Seers, gods, Gandharvas and Apsarases also have adored his phallus, and that one also stood erect. Therefore that Great Lord (MaheÅ›vara) rejoices when his (phallus) is worshipped; Åšam

. kara becomes happy and gratified and he is delighted.

The latter text is with some minor variants found again in AnuÅ›Â¯

asanaparvan

146.15-18 (TS 8), which may indicate that the Dron

. aparvan passage belongs

to an older stratum of the epic. An explicatory Â´

sloka, which is also found

in the Dron

. aparvan but in another context (MBh 7.173.94; TS 5), and which seems to echo MBh 7.172.87 and 90 (TS 3), has been inserted (MBh 13.146.16), somewhat disturbing the syntax, since the relative pronoun yo in 16a lacks a clear antecedent. 22 This verse unequivocally refers to the li Ë™nga as a particular cult object distinct from an iconic image ( vigraha). It says (TS 8 v. 16), 23

One who worships the body (i.e. image) of the magnanimous one (i.e. Åšiva), or otherwise his phallus ( li Ë™

nga)â€”the constant worshipper of the phallus shall obtain great prosperity.

. aparvan passage and its reprise in the

Åšiva is worshipped in an image there is an eye-opening rite, when in a li Ë™

anybody but Åšiva, Upamanyu answers (TS 6 vv. 100â€“102), What other reasons do you need, the Lord is the primary cause. It has not been revealed to us that the gods adore the phallus ( li Ë™

nga) of anybody else; of whom else

than MaheÅ›vara is the phallus worshipped by all gods, or has ever been worshipped?

Tell me if it has been revealed to you. Whose phallus BrahmÂ¯

a, Vis.n.u and you too

with the gods should always adore, that one is the chiefest for that reason.

The RÂ¯

ayan

. a

ayan

. a confirms the impression obtained from the MahÂ¯

arata:

though a later tradition ascribes to RÂ¯

ameÅ›vara

li Ë™nga, this is not found in the critical edition of the Â¯

AdikÂ¯

avya itself. 24 Li Ë™nga

worship is only ascribed to the RÂ¯

aks.asas led by RÂ¯avan.a (TS 9), who worships

with incense and fragrant flowers a golden li Ë™nga, which he had installed on an altar of sand on the bank of the NarmadÂ¯

a River. â€˜And after the worship he

sung and danced, waving and spreading his handsâ€™ (TS 9 v. 40). It may be significant that in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata passages great emphasis is laid on the fact

that gods and other divine beings also worship Åšivaâ€™s li Ë™nga, 25 which sounds like a sort of justification, whereas the RÂ¯

amÂ¯

ayan

. a confines li Ë™nga worship to

RÂ¯

aks.asas in a tone of scarcely concealed dismay.

Concluding observations

The overall impression that we may gather from the material surveyed is that, during the first centuries of the Common Era, the brahmanical elite, whether priest, king or renouncer, preferred to venerate MaheÅ›vara in iconic form and frowned upon li Ë™nga worship. 26 Its gradual acceptance in the 5th and 6th centuries by those circles that earlier rejected it may be illustrated again by the myth of TilottamÂ¯

a.

The evidence of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a

This myth recurs in what we think is the original SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, which we

date in the sixth or seventh century, and which may have been composed in PÂ¯

aÅ›upata circles. 27 Here explicit reference is made to Åšiva in his li Ë™nga form (TS 14): â€˜There arose amidst these celestials a li Ë™nga, solid, massive, a bundle of tejas as it were.â€™ From this li Ë™nga four faces emerged when TilottamÂ¯

a made her

circumambulation, the eastern one lustrous, with lips gracious as the bimba 24 Eck 1991, 62 f.

25 MBh 7.172.88; 7.173.84; 13.14.101 f.; 13.146.17.

26 Gonda 1960, 256: â€˜MÃ¶glicherweise ist dieser Phallus ursprÃ¼nglich nicht mit dem Åšiva-dienst verbunden gewesen, wie denn auch gebildete Kreise Ã¶fters Bedenken gegen dessen Verehrung getragen haben.â€™

27 See Bakker & Adriaensen & Isaacson 1994. Bakker 2014. Above, pp. 185 ff., p. 469.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

25 / Sources for Reconstructing Ancient Forms of Åšiva Worship 499

fruit ( prasannabimbaus.t.ha) and with three eyes ( tryaks.a) (TS 15 vv. 16â€“17); the southern one â€˜possessed of the colour of a languid cloud laden with water, having a ferocious voice, with dreadful teeth shining (in an open mouth), and the corners of the eyes bloodshot and glitteringâ€™ (v. 19); the western face was perfect ( anuttama) having three eyes, and the northern one was very full ( susam

. pÂ¯

urn

. a) and very gracious ( suprasanna) (vv. 21â€“24). Thus runs the oldest description of the Caturmukhali Ë™nga in the Sanskrit literature known to me, at least half a millennium after the Indian sculptors had begun to materialize the idea in stone (see also below, p. 521).

Conclusions

The various sources surveyed above lead to the following conclusions.

1 The historic reality of ancient Åšiva worship, which is taken here as a specimen of a wider issue, cannot be reconstructed by relying on one type of source only. If we would base ourselves on texts alone, we would hardly be aware that li Ë™nga worship was practised on a large scale throughout the Subcontinent during the first centuries of the Common Era. If, on the other hand, we would not have texts, we would be at a loss how to interprete the phallic stones provided with four heads of different countenances.

2 When the visual material is interpreted with the help of written sources it is of paramount importance that both sources date from about the same time. More often than not art-historians describe their visual material on the basis of textual material that dates from half a millennium later, such as when early sculptures are explained by having recourse to the iconographic treatise of the Vis.n.udharmottarapurÂ¯an.a or still later texts, while, as we have seen, contemporaneous descriptions are sometimes to be found in, for instance, the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata.

3 The incongruity that is frequently found between the archaeological material and textual descriptions may have its root in the different sections of the society to which these sources pertain. This makes us realize how tentative our assessments are and how little we actually know about the early history of the religions of India.

4 If these three conclusions are accepted it follows finally that, in view of the scarcity of sources at our disposal, we simply cannot afford to disregard any of them. When, however, we evaluate them and try to construe an integral picture of the past, we should never lose sight of their innate differences and we must proceed with the utmost caution, in the knowledge that the complexity of the historic reality of ancient India is far greater than we can ever hope to recover.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1
