At the Right Side of the Teacherâˆ—

Imagination, Imagery, and Image in Vedic and Åšaiva Initiation Then shall the King say unto them on his right hand,

Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom

prepared for you from the foundation of the world.

Matthew 25: 34 (cf. Ecclesiastes 10: 2)

Introduction

The transformation of the Vedic religion into new systems of belief and practice, early Hinduism for short, is a process of cultural change that, despite two centuries of research, has only partly been understood. The replacement of the sacrificial fire by images of wood and stone is among the most obvious innovations. As has been convincingly argued by Phyllis Granoff (2006), this innovation was only reluctantly accepted in some circles of brahmanic orthodoxy.

On the other hand, there can be little doubt that Vedic imagination informed the concept of God and His image ( mÂ¯

urti) in the newly emerging religions. It

found expression in the Sanskrit texts of early Hinduism. The confrontation of this textual evidence with the material images of the archaeologist is often perplexing, however.

An example of such a conundrum is the so-called Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti, mentioned in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata texts, the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata, and the later Åšaiva literature of the

MantramÂ¯

arga. In this essay, we will examine the Vedic origins of the imagery of the Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti. This mÂ¯urti appears first and foremost to be an ideal image embedded in the ritual of initiation. The Vedic upanayana ceremony laid the structural foundations for the initiation rites of the later religious orders. The Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti appears to be a token of the theistic transformation of the Vedic imagination. It illustrates how literate Åšaiva brahmins took the Hinduistic turn. At first material images played, if at all, only a secondary role in this transformation. However, in a religious world that was increasingly pervaded by material images of the divine, it was bound to happen that the visionary

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Granoff, Phyllis & Koichi Shinohara (eds.), Images in Asian Religions. Text and Contexts. UBCPress, Vancouverâ€“Toronto, 2004. pp. 117â€“48.

505

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

506

Hans Bakker

image became an archetype of visual representation, the Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti as an iconographic category. In this process, an essential characteristic of the vision of God as revealer was reinterpreted: His right side became interpreted as His southern face. The incongruity of this representation with the age-old religious idea of the south as being terrifying, inauspicious, 1 was to make a conundrum.

The sitting position of teacher and pupil in the Vedic Upanayana ritual

The Â´

SatapathabrÂ¯

ahman

. a

The ÅšatapathabrÂ¯

ahman

. a 11.5.4 is our earliest source for the ancient upanayana ritual; a brief summery may highlight its major features.

1 The pupil approaches a teacher and expresses the wish for apprenticeship by saying: I have come for brahmacarya ( brahmacaryam Â¯

agÂ¯

am). He commits

himself to be a brahmacÂ¯

arin.

2 The teacher ( Â¯

acÂ¯

arya) asks his name. The question implies the answer: â€˜whoâ€™

( ka) conceived as another name of PrajÂ¯

apati.

3 The teacher takes the pupil by the hand, implying that he accepts him as a student, saying indrasya brahmacÂ¯

ary asy, agnir Â¯

acÂ¯

aryas tavÂ¯

aham Â¯

acÂ¯

aryas

tavÂ¯

asÂ¯

av iti. Thus the Â¯

acÂ¯

arya and Agni are seen as homologous.

4 He consigns the student to PrajÂ¯

apati and Savitr. and to all beings in heaven

and earth.

5 He consigns him to brahman, that is, he makes him a brahmacÂ¯

arin by saying

brahmacÂ¯

ary asi, while he lets him sip water, which embodies the elixir of life ( amr.ta). Thus the pupil is initiated into the life eternal, and becomes a

â€˜wanderer in brahmanâ€™.

6 After this initiationâ€”with or without delay (see below n. 11 on p. 508)â€”the

Â¯

acÂ¯

arya teaches the Veda by making him repeat its quintessence, the SÂ¯

avitrÂ¯Ä±.

The importance attached to the position of pupil and teacher during the Veda instruction is apparent from the fact that it is singled out for specification in the BrÂ¯

ahman.a; there appear to be two different traditions. According to one tradition the student sits or stands at the right side ( daks.in.atas) of the teacher, who, as is understood, is facing east. The position of the pupil is characterised by the term bulva/bulba. This word, apparently a hapax legomenon, is given by Mayrhofer ewa s.v. as â€˜etwa â€œseitwÃ¤rtsâ€â€™ (with the remark: â€˜nicht klarâ€™).

Because of this sideway position, this tradition is rejected in the BrÂ¯

ahman.a,

which opts for the alternative: the student should sit opposite the teacher looking at him from east to west. 2

1 Cf. Bodewitz 2000, 22 f.

2 ÅšBr 11.5.4.14:

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

26 / At the Right Side of the Teacher 507

Which direction, we may ask, faces the pupil in the situation that is rejected?

The commentary of SÂ¯

ayan.Â¯acÂ¯arya does not resolve the question.3 There can be little doubt that the teacher, homologous to Agni, is facing east; 4 the student, on the other hand, may be thought to be looking at his teacher in profile, i.e.

he may be facing north, for that is the region of the gods, 5 the region of living men as opposed to that of the deceased. 6 Or, he may face the northeast, since standing towards that direction PrajÂ¯

apati created the creatures, there the gate

of heaven is believed to stand. 7 The northeast may be particularly appropriate in the present case, because it not only is the direction into which PrajÂ¯

apati

issued the beingsâ€”PrajÂ¯

apati to whom the student has just been consignedâ€”

but also is the point of the compass where the Sun (Savitr.) rises at the summer solstice to begin a new year, the Sun to whom the student has just as well been consigned and into whose mantra (SÂ¯

avitrÂ¯Ä±) he is actually being initiated,

that is, whose mantra he is reciting. If directed to the northeast, the student is seated obliquely, not transversely, with respect to the teacher. It is difficult to determine whether bulva means â€˜obliqueâ€™ or â€˜transverseâ€™.

Consequently, the first of the two alternatives discussed in the ÅšatapathabrÂ¯

ahman

. a, the one that is rejected by the BrÂ¯

ahman.a itself, namely that the

student is sitting at the right side ( daks.in.atas) of the teacher, allows for two interpretations: (1a) teacher is facing east and student is facing north, or (1b)

Â´

atha haÂ´Ä±ke daks.in.atÃ¡h. [ | ] tis.t.hate vÂ¯aÅ›Â¯Ä±nÂ¯aya vÂ¯aÅ„vÂ¯ahur nÃ¡ tÃ¡thÂ¯a kuryÂ¯ad yÃ³ hainam

. tÂ´

atra

brÂ¯

uyÂ¯

ad bulbÂ´

am

. nv Â¯

a

Ã¡yÂ´

am imÂ´

am Â´

ajÂ¯Ä±janata bulbo bhavis.yatÂ¯Ä±Â´tÂ¯Ä±Å›varÃ³ ha tÃ¡thaivÃ¡ syÂ¯at tÂ´

asmÂ¯

at purÂ´

astÂ¯

ad evÂ´

a pratÂ¯Ä±

Ä‡e samÂ¯Ä±

Â´ks.amÂ¯an.Â¯ayÂ¯aÅ„ubrÂ¯uyÂ¯at k 14 k

Now some recite (to the pupil) while the latter is standing or sitting at the right side (of the teacher). One should not do so. One would be able to say to him in that case:

â€˜Yes indeed, he (the teacher) has begotten him (the student) sideways, and sideways (i.e. wayward) he (the student) will beâ€™; and so, indeed, it will come to pass. Therefore he should recite to (the pupil) sitting in front of him, while the former is westwards looking.

3 SÂ¯

ayan

. a glosses:

ayam Â¯

acÂ¯

arya imam Â´

sis.yam atha bulvam

.

tiraÂ´

scÂ¯Ä±nam

.

prÂ¯

a Ë™

nmukham

ajÂ¯Ä±janat tathÂ¯

a cÂ¯

ayam

.

[ b] ulvah

. parÂ¯

a Ë™

nmukho bhavis.yatÂ¯Ä±ti er I take prÂ¯a Ë™nmukham, like bulvam

. tiraÂ´

scÂ¯Ä±nam

. , as an adverb qualifying ajÂ¯Ä±janat: â€˜ bulva, i.e. transversely, while facing forward/eastwards ( prÂ¯

a Ë™

nmukham), he has begotten (the pupil)â€™; this adverb, referring to the position of the teacher, serves to pronounce the contrast with the pupil, who will turn away ( parÂ¯

a Ë™

nmukha), will be adverse. Bulva thus means transverse ( tiraÂ´

scÂ¯Ä±na),

adverse ( parÂ¯

a Ë™

nmukha), which, again, suggests that teacher and pupil sit at right angles.

4 This is the default position. â€˜In the domestic rites the sacrificer stands to the west of the fire facing the eastâ€™ (Gonda 1980, 52). Cf. Bodewitz 2000, 25, 49.

508

Hans Bakker

teacher is facing east and student is facing northeast. (1b) is clearly a variant of (1a) and a combination of both is perfectly feasible: the pupil faces north, but, if appropriate, may look towards the northeast. 8

That the BrÂ¯

ahman.a prefers alternative (2)â€”teacher and pupil sitting opposite to one another, directed to the east and west respectivelyâ€”-may above all have practical reasons, since the teacher bestows more than only learning upon the neophyte at this occasion; a change of position may have been thought to be cumbersome. 9 The first alternative (1aâ€“b), on the other hand, because it makes sense in terms of the mystique of the quarters, may have preserved original traits. Moreover, the right side of the teacher has symbolic meaning.

â€˜There is ample evidence that the right hand or the right side of the body was decidedly preferred to the left.â€™ 10 We will return to this below.

The ÅšatapathabrÂ¯

ahman

. a does itself refer to earlier modalities of the ritual recitation of the SÂ¯

avitrÂ¯Ä±, when it reads: â€˜In former days, however, they recited that same verse (the SÂ¯

avitrÂ¯Ä±) at the end of the year ( sam

. vatsare), thinking

â€œbeing as old as a year, indeed, children are born; as soon as born, we impart speech to himâ€.â€™ 11 The appropriate direction in this ritual is, or so it seems, the northeast, in which direction PrajÂ¯

apati gave birth, PrajÂ¯

apati who is equated

with the year (Gonda 1984).

The Gr.hyasÂ¯utras

The two traditions indicated briefly in the ÅšatapathabrÂ¯

ahman

. a can be followed

in the Gr.hyasÂ¯utra literature. As one would expect, the only Gr.hyasÂ¯utra that 8 Gonda 1980, 54 gives a confusing rendering of this position: On the other hand, the brahman (priest) is placed or sits south. . . . The same position is prescribed to the boy who is to be initiated before a girdle is tied round his waist, which is to protect him against evil influences.

The boy is not said to sit in or face the south, but to sit at the right side of the teacher.

That this coincides with the south is secondary and as such does not play a symbolic role, as I will argue in this article (cf. Bodewitz 2000, 26).

9 According to the Gr.hyasÂ¯

utras the pupil receives, among other things, a girdle and a staff, to which the sacred thread may be added. All three items are missing in the ÅšBr account.

It seems that bestowing the yajËœ

nopavÂ¯Ä±ta upon the novice at this occasion is a relatively late addition (see Gopal 1959, 296). There is obviously a loss of symbolic significance in this second position of the pupil compared to the first alternative. Surveying the meaning of the western direction in Vedic ritual Gonda 1980, 55 observes: â€˜It follows that facing eastwards whilst standing in the west [as does the Â¯

acÂ¯

arya, H.T.B.] results

in a desired effect, so that in the west one can be prosperous; facing the west does not however produce results.â€™

10 Gonda 1977a, 624; Gonda 1980, 57â€“60. â€˜In the case of male beings the right side was auspicious, most probably because it was the â€˜maleâ€™ side. AtharvavedapariÅ›is.t.a 70 c 25, 5 a royal sacrificer seeing that the flame of a (sacrificial) fire points to the right will be victorious. The side of strength and auspiciousness is also widely regarded as that of benignity, allegiance, benedictionâ€™ ( op. cit. 60).

26 / At the Right Side of the Teacher 509

belongs, like the ÅšatapathabrÂ¯

ahman

. a, to the White Yajurveda, the PÂ¯

araskara-

gr.hyasÂ¯utra, follows the accepted tradition of the BrÂ¯ahman.a, though it mentions the alternative. The place where the teaching takes place is specified: north of the sacrificial fire.

After (the pupil) has made a pradaks.in.a around the fire he takes his seat. The teacher, touched (by the pupil), pours oblations of ghee into the fire; when the remains have been eaten, he instructs him: â€˜You are a brahmacÂ¯

arin, drink water,

do your service, may you not sleep in the daytime, restrain your speech, put fuel on the fire, drink water.â€™ Then he recites to him the SÂ¯

avitrÂ¯Ä±, north of the sacrificial

fire, while (the pupil) is sitting near him with his face turned west, looking (at him) and being looked at. Some: â€˜to him while standing or sitting to his right sideâ€™. 12

510

Hans Bakker

The other tradition, rejected in the ÅšatapathabrÂ¯

ahman

. a, we find in some

Gr.hyasÂ¯utras affiliated with the Black Yajurveda, though not in all.15 For an assessment of the upanayana ritual according to this tradition, we turn to the elaborate description in the BhÂ¯

aradvÂ¯

ajagr.hyasÂ¯utra. Its procedure may be epit-

omized (with cross-references to the Hiran

. yakeÅ›igr.hyasÂ¯utra).

The teacher prepares for the homa sacrifice by consecrating the implements etc. (BhGS 1.3). He prepares west of the sacrificial fire a seat of grass ( kÂ¯

urca),

of which the grassblades are turned to the north. There the teacher takes his seat, his face turned to the east; the pupil ( kumÂ¯

ara), who has put on the

yajËœ

nopavÂ¯Ä±ta and sipped water, takes his seat at the right side (of his teacher) ( daks.in.atas).16

The teacher performs the homa sacrifice (BhGS 1.4). Then he gives the pupil a new cloth, a girdle of muËœ

nja grass ( mauËœ

njÂ¯Ä± mekhalÂ¯

a), and a skin of the black

antelope ( ajina) (BhGS 1.5â€“6). Next (BhGS 1.7) (the teacher) strews to the west of the sacrificial fire darbha grasses, on which the two (teacher and pupil) take their stand, one facing east, the other west. The one facing east takes the hand of the one facing west and vice versa. A servant fills the aËœ

njalis of both

with water. By his aËœ

njali (the teacher) transfers the water into the aËœ

njali (of

the pupil). 17

A formal interview takes place in which the teacher asks for the name of the pupil and subsequently leads him ( upanayÂ¯

ami) to PrajÂ¯

apati (Ka) (BhGS 1.7).

Although the site of the teaching is said to be to the west side of the sacrificial fire, the pupil is said to sit opposite (i.e. east) of the teacher while facing west, that is he sits with his back towards the fire blocking the teacherâ€™s access to it. This evidently hybrid version of the ritual appears to be a conflation of the tradition of the White Yajurveda (and R

. g- and SÂ¯

amaveda, as we saw above) and the alternative tradition (see below). The GautamadharmasÂ¯

utra adds to the confusion when it declares that the student should sit at the right side of the teacher, but may face either east or north; in the former case he sits parallel to the teacher: prÂ¯

a Ë™

nmukho daks.in.atah. Å›is.ya uda Ë™nmukho vÂ¯a . . . (GauDhS 1, in Dutt 1988).

26 / At the Right Side of the Teacher 511

The teacher consigns the pupil to several other deities. The teacher asks him to step on a stone ( aÂ´

sman) and to put fuel on the fire (BhGS 1.8).

Then the pupil makes a pradaks.in.a around the fire, takes his seat at the right side ( daks.in.atas), scil. of the teacher, while he turns to the north, touches (the feet of the teacher), and asks: â€˜O lord, recite the SÂ¯

avitrÂ¯Ä±â€™. 18 The place where

the teacher is seated is not again specified, but presumably he is still seated west of the fire facing east, that is the place where he performed the homa sacrifice, took the interview accompanied by the aËœ

njalis, and consigned the

pupil to PrajÂ¯

apati etc. This is corroborated by the Hiran

. yakeÅ›igr.hyasÂ¯utra.19

The sitting position of the preceptor and his audience Veda study is of course not restricted to the brahmacÂ¯

arin. Outside the village,

retreated into the wilderness ( aran

. ya), brahmins devoted themselves to study

and, if they became known for their learnedness, attracted students. In this way we conceive of the origin of the different Upanis.ad teaching traditions and of other early Indian schools of philosophy (above, p. 230). The subject of study and teaching may have changed accordingly, but the setting is traditional and had a long life. We find such an idyllic setting, for instance, in the ÅšÂ¯

a Ë™nkhÂ¯

ayana-

gr.hyasÂ¯utra, where it describes â€˜the rules for the forest-dweller regarding his (Veda) studyâ€™. 20

For this study ( svÂ¯

adhyÂ¯

aya) the forest-dwellers should go to a pure spot in the northeast that is open at the eastern side. The site is circular or marked by a circle with an entrance to the east or the north. After some preliminary rites, they may take up their studies. 21

The next section describes the teaching situation.

512

Hans Bakker

teacher), according to rank; if this is impossible (i.e., if there is not enough space) they may face all directions. They should wait for the rising of the sun. And when they have seen it (rise) in all its splendour, they say: â€˜Sir, reciteâ€™, while touching with their right and left hands the hallowed feet of the teacherâ€”his right (foot) with their right, his left (foot) with their left hands. 22

The ÅšÂ¯

a Ë™nkhÂ¯

ayanagr.hyasÂ¯utra, which, as we have seen, agreed with the tradition of the White Yajurveda in opting for the face-to-face position of teacher and pupil north of the sacrificial fire in the upanayana ritual (see above n. 13 on p. 509), reserved the alternative position, in which the student sits at the right side of the teacher facing north, for the traditional school of the hermitage.

It is to be expected that this time-honoured traditional setting of religious education may be met again in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata. The practice to stand with

oneâ€™s face turned to the east when making a solemn pronouncement or to reveal a secret is attested in the great epic, as the following example may show.

But then, when Kr.s.n.a, haven of brahmins, heard the cause of PÂ¯arthaâ€™s (i.e. Arjunaâ€™s) sorrow, he touched water and stood still, his face turned to the east; and the mighty lotus-eyed one spoke this word for the benefit of PÂ¯

an.d.uâ€™s son, intent upon

killing the army of Jayadratha: â€˜O PÂ¯

artha, there is a supreme unfailing weapon

called â€œPÂ¯

aÅ›upataâ€, by which god MaheÅ›vara killed all the Daityas in battle.â€™ 23

However, I have not found in the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata an exact parallel of the situation

a Ë™nkhÂ¯

26 / At the Right Side of the Teacher 513

and Continuity in Indian Religion Jan Gonda elaborates the theme of the book with regard to the Vedic upanayana and the initiation ( dÂ¯Ä±ks.Â¯a) in the monastic orders.

Instead of upanayana and the renewable dÂ¯Ä±ks.Â¯a we find in the monastic orders an ordination properâ€”sometimes called dÂ¯Ä±ks.Â¯aâ€”which is to be preceded by a noviciate beginning with a ceremony which is a parallel of the upanayana, and in various Hindu sects and communities an admission to full membership, to priesthood or guruship, which is also known as dÂ¯Ä±ks.Â¯a. (Gonda 1965, 317) And describing the initiation ritual of ascetics, he makes the following remark.

. . . dÂ¯Ä±ks.Â¯a. This term is translated by â€˜consecrationâ€™ and â€˜renouncement of the worldâ€™. On this occasion one is inter alia given a new name. During important acts, such as study, confession, one has to turn east- or northward; as is well known these directions are of special importance in brahmanic rites, the â€˜door of heaven being in the northeastâ€™. (Gonda 1965, p. 385)

We shall confine ourselves here to the Åšaiva orders and investigate whether these traditional directions of teacher and student can actually be found in their early texts.

Initiation in the PÂ¯

aÂ´

supata tradition

The earliest text of a Åšaiva order that we have is the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utra with the

commentary of Kaun.d.inya. The initiation in the order is briefly described by Kaun.d.inya when he explains the future tense used in the first SÂ¯utra ( vyÂ¯

akhyÂ¯

asyÂ¯

amah

. , â€˜we shall expoundâ€™).

â€˜Shallâ€™ ( syÂ¯

a) refers to the time required, namely the time that is required (before the exposition can begin) by the Â¯

acÂ¯

arya, to consecrate a brahmin at

MahÂ¯

adevaâ€™s â€˜southern mÂ¯

urtiâ€™ with ashes that are consecrated with the (five) mantras, â€˜SadyojÂ¯

ataâ€™ etc., and to initiate him in the mantra, after he has made him relinquish the signs of his originâ€”a brahmin whose (antecedents) have earlier been screened, as follows from the word â€˜thereforeâ€™ ( atah

. ) in the SÂ¯

utra, who comes

(to him) from amongst the householders etc., and who has (already) engaged himself in fasting and observances. 24

being circumscribed by the knowledge of the five categories. The supreme guru is the lord MaheÅ›vara, who empowers the former. 28

If we turn to the Svacchandatantra, describing the samayadÂ¯Ä±ks.Â¯a, we find the above interpretation confirmed.

After he has performed the (preliminary) rites, he [i.e. the guru], rejoiced at heart, makes the pupil, whose eyes are full of joy, stand up and, taking him by his hand, leads him towards the â€˜southern mÂ¯

urtiâ€™: Having made a circle there into a seat

(consisting) of the syllable om with the help of a flower, he places the pupil upon it, his body erect, his face turned to the north. After the guru has installed himself whilst facing east, he performs the sprinkling and subsequent rites. 29

The Daks.in.Â¯

amÂ¯

urti

From the place of initiation where Åšiva manifests himself to the novice for the first time in that He assumes the form of guru, we now proceed to the public domain of the temple. In that context the word mÂ¯

physical object of veneration. This connotation underlies the T

. Â¯Ä±kÂ¯

Åšiva in the image as if He were there in His very person, and which means that,

Hans Bakker

Analogous with the situation of initiation, the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata envisages Åšiva in front

of him, this time, however, in the physical object of worship. It is towards this manifestation of God that the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata turns and in whom he is sunk,

an idea we also find in the following passage of the Southern Recension of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata where broad-minded VÂ¯

asudeva teaches.

The holy man who has reached Me (i.e. VÂ¯

asudeva) fixes himself upon My

body ( mÂ¯

urti), or on Rudraâ€™s Daks.in.(Â¯a)mÂ¯urti, especially on the fourteenth ( tithi). He, the great ascetic, while he is venerated by Siddhas, Brahmars.is and celestial folk, and while his praises are sung by Gandharvas and choirs of BhÂ¯

utas, he of great splendour enters either Me or Åšam

. kara. 31

We thus observe that the term mÂ¯

urti in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata context on the one hand

refers to the â€˜imageâ€™ (meaning bodily manifestation) and, on the other hand, when used in the locative (or when the locative is meant), refers to â€˜a particular spot near the imageâ€™, that is not to the image itself. Both meanings are, as we will argue, comprehended by the technical term daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti, literally â€˜south-ward/rightward image/body/figureâ€™.

This term is explained by Kaun.d.inya

when he comments on PÂ¯

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utra 1.9: mahÂ¯

adevasya daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urteh. |

â€˜Of the Godâ€™ (â—¦ devasya) is a genitive. This is a syntactic feature that expresses the relationship of owner and property; it signifies possession/ grace ( parigraha) only.

â€˜Southernâ€™ ( daks.in.Â¯aâ—¦) in the SÂ¯utra is in the sense of a specific point of the compass.

The sun divides the quarters and the quarters divide the mÂ¯

urti.

â€˜Imageâ€™ ( mÂ¯

urti): Either this ( yad etad) form ( rÂ¯

upa) that is perceived by him who is

standing at the right side of God, his face turned north, in (His) proximity, a form that is characterised by the bull-banner, the lance in hand, Nandin, MahÂ¯

akÂ¯

ala,

erect phallus etc., or to which ( yad vÂ¯

a) the laymen resort.

The sanctuary is â€˜of the Great Godâ€™ ( mahÂ¯

adevasya). This is the answer ( iti).

There is the object to be worshipped. 32

26 / At the Right Side of the Teacher 517

For the initiated PÂ¯

aÅ›upata like Kaun.d.inya the term daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti thus seems rather to refer to a situation or state than to a particular â€˜imageâ€™, namely the state in which God appears to him who sits or stands at His right side and sees Him in front of him (for instance in the temple image). It is the situation in which Åšiva reveals himself â€˜towards him who is at His right sideâ€™ ( daks.in.Â¯a),33

namely, by turning His auspicious, gracious side towards him who is facing northâ€”the sitting position of the novice since Vedic times.

The strength of this tradition obviously rests on the religious idea of the right side. To turn oneâ€™s right side upon someone is an auspicious act; in the case of God it is an act of grace in which He reveals Himself and His doctrine

â€˜unto them on his right handâ€™. It happens to the blessed ones in His proximity, that is in heaven on the Himavat, and as such to the initiated PÂ¯

aÅ›upata in his

yoga with God, who may be represented either by the image or by the guru. In sum, the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti is a state in which God reveals one quarter of Himself, the form to which He grants access, i.e. yoga; it is Åšivaâ€™s figure of grace. 34

In spite of the use of the word mukha, used here in figurative sense, I think the ÅšvetÂ¯

asvatara Upanis.ad 4.21 expresses this very idea:

â€˜Unborn is Heâ€™, so saying, Let a man in fear approach Him: O Rudra [show] thy right [auspicious] cheek, Protect me with it ever! 35

In the direct vision that is granted to the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata the ideal image of MahÂ¯

adeva

is visualized as being accompanied by his acolytes Nandin and MahÂ¯

akÂ¯

ala, the

mÂ¯

**urtir **nÂ¯

ama yad etad devasya daks.in.e pÂ¯arÅ›ve sthitenoda Ë™nmukhenopÂ¯ante yad rÂ¯

upam

upalabhyate vr

. s.adhvajaÂ´

sÂ¯

ulapÂ¯

an

. inandimahÂ¯

. yad vÂ¯

. d

. a after pratipadyante.

. ena (cf. MBh 1.203.21, above, p. 500) is equivalent to daks.in

bull-banner etc., in short, a â€˜tableau de la troupeâ€™.

The physical image in

the sacred compound is not defined. If our interpretation is correct, it may be any image, most often a li Ë™nga, considered by the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata laymen as â€˜the

imageâ€™ ( mÂ¯

urti) of MahÂ¯

adeva, a designation that for the initiate is true only in metaphorical sense. 36

The definition of Godâ€™s figure of grace

The concept of daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti thus comprises the manifested form ( rÂ¯upa) of God, the (physical) image or body ( mÂ¯

urti) in which it may be envisaged, and

the right side ( daks.in.e pÂ¯arÅ›ve), which indicates the PÂ¯aÅ›upataâ€™s position with respect to MahÂ¯

adeva and his embodiment. As such the term is applicable to every situation in which the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata enters into contact with his object of

worship. And this appears to have been the intention of the author of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utra when we read PS 1.8â€“9 coherently (as also the author of the T

. Â¯Ä±kÂ¯

a seems to have done: upahÂ¯

arasÂ¯

utra, above, p. 514): â€˜He should worship with

offerings of laughter, singing, dancing, bellowing, obeisance, and muttering to the figure of grace ( daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti) of MahÂ¯adeva.â€™37 The same idea underlies the Ratnat.Â¯Ä±kÂ¯a, where it says that the PÂ¯aÅ›upata should consecrate the ashes with mantras in the temple â€˜at Åšivaâ€™s Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urtiâ€™,38 or the SkandapurÂ¯an.a when it advises that one should offer rice pudding with ghee at the â€˜southern mÂ¯

urtiâ€™

during one year in order to become like Nandin. 39

It seems obvious that the same idea underlies the initiation rite, in which the place of the physical image, i.e. the mÂ¯

urti, may be taken by the guru who

36 This position conforms best with the view of images maintained in the NyÂ¯

which is generally believed to have had close links with the PÂ¯

this author describes Udayanaâ€™s point of view as follows: â€˜The rite does not specifically invest the image with a divine presence or power through a mechanical process, but occasions the conscious reflection, by deities, of themselves as being present in the image.â€™

In other words, Åšivaâ€™s presence in the Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯

urti is an act of grace ( parigraha).

26 / At the Right Side of the Teacher 519

represents Åšiva (as the Â¯

acÂ¯

arya represents Agni in the upanayana). In fact, it appears most likely that the concept of daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti originated from this ritual in which Åšiva as supreme teacher reveals himself. To this primordial figureâ€”a god who is facing towards the east, but who confers his blessings, that is his â€˜rightâ€™ side, on his creatures, be they gods, Siddhas, or worshippers in BhÂ¯

aratavars.aâ€”the pseudo-Åšam

. kara pays homage:

tasmai Â´

srÂ¯Ä±gurumÂ¯

urtaye nama idam

. Â´

srÂ¯Ä±daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urtaye k

This obeisance is to Him who has the form of the illustrious teacher, to the illustrious figure of grace. 40

The Daks.in.Â¯

amÂ¯

urti and iconography

Having thus established the original meaning of Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti, we may proceed to its current iconographic denotation.

Among the earliest texts that describe the daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti in iconographic terms may be the two UpajÂ¯

ati verses that are quoted by Gopinatha Rao, which

he ascribed to the Vis.n.udharmottarapurÂ¯an.a, but which are not found in the printed text of that name.

His right (lower) hand shows the ( jËœ

nÂ¯

ana) mudrÂ¯

a and in his (right) upper (hand)

he (holds) a white rosary; in his left (lower hand) he is holding a book comprising all the Â¯

Agamas and more, and with his upper (left hand) he holds the cup with nectar.

He is seated on a white lotus, his colour is white, powerful, with white cloth and ointment, and crowned by the crescent, teaching knowledge to the sages: that is what they call his Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti. 41

On this and other, predominantly late South-Indian texts Rao based his description, which was repeated without any significant change by almost all later indological writing on this subject. It may be significant to note, though, that in the above passage the southern orientation of the image is not mentioned.

To substantiate his view, however, Rao wrote:

One account gives an explanation regarding the etymology of this name; it states that because Åšiva was seated **facing **south when he taught the r.ishis yÂ¯oga and jËœ

nÂ¯

ana he came to be known as Dakshin.Â¯amÂ¯urti. This aspect of Åšiva is always invoked by students of science and arts. 42

. karaâ€™s authorship of this

520

Hans Bakker

Unfortunately, however, we are not informed about this â€˜accountâ€™, 43 but Rao, without any doubt, was following an Indian iconographic convention, which prescribes â€˜that in all Hindu temples, both Åšaiva and Vaishn.ava, the niche on the south wall of the central shrine should have the figure of Dakshin.Â¯amÂ¯urti enshrined in itâ€™. 44 Bruce Long, who devoted an article to the subject, relied heavily on Rao, but he put his finger on the problem, when he professed that he was puzzled,

As to why the southern direction, which is believed almost everywhere in India to be sinister and inauspicious, should in this instance be evaluated as auspicious and benign.

It is not beyond reason that we explain this curiously positive evaluation of the southern direction on the basis of the same religious principle by which the Furies in Greece came to be called the â€˜Eumenidesâ€™, and Rudra, the ferocious Howler, came to be addressed as Åšiva, the Auspicious. Perhaps the worshippers of Åšiva hoped that by having the Divine Preceptor face the southern direction, that area would, thereby, lose its sinister qualities and become benign. 45

Although I shall not deny that considerations such as the above may have played some role, at least in coming to terms with the apparent incongruity once established, it is important to recognize that, if they played a role, they did so in retrospect. The cause of the alleged incongruity, I would like to argue, is a reorientation of the tradition. A cult concept was transposed to iconography.

Part of the original meaning was retainedâ€”Åšiva as the source of knowledgeâ€”

part of it was reinterpreted, namely, the direction God faces when expounding His wisdom: His â€˜right sideâ€™ became his â€˜southern faceâ€™. The southern temple walls were consequently thought most suitable for showing images of Åšiva in his role of teacher. 46 Thus the daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti entered the textbooks of Indian architecture, for instance the Mayamata, which divided Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s vision into two.

A chacun des paliers des temples il faut disposer aux points cardinaux des (images des) dieux. Au rez-de-chaussÃ©e on place Ã  lâ€™Est les deux guardiens de la porte, Nandi et KÂ¯

ala; au Sud câ€™est la Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti, Ã  lâ€™Ouest Acyuta ou Li Ë™ngasambhÂ¯uta et au Nord PitÂ¯

amaha. 47

43 I could not find this â€˜accountâ€™ in the texts at issue presented in Raoâ€™s Appendix B (II.2, pp. 137â€“146).

44 Rao 1914 II.1, p. 273.

45 Long 1971, 69; ibid. n. 1.

46 Harle 1986, 301:

All the principal images of the Brahmanical pantheon are represented in South India during the Col.a period. There is a particular predilection for Bhiks.Â¯at.ana, Åšiva as the naked young ascetic, and for Åšiva as Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯

urti, the expounder of yoga, music and

the Å›Â¯

astras, who is always, where possible, facing south ( daks.in.a means â€˜southâ€™, and although there is no very convincing explanation of the name, it may account in part for the popularity of this image in South India).

26 / At the Right Side of the Teacher 521

The development of a cult concept into an iconic image Finally the question must be briefly addressed when and where this cult concept turned into an iconographic one. This development may actually have had two moments.

1 An anthropomorphic (iconic) representation of Åšiva who through attributes, a book for instance, a mudrÂ¯

a ( vitarka-, vyÂ¯

akhyÂ¯

ana-mudrÂ¯

a), or some other

gesture, or because he sits alongside a pupil, is identifiable as the supreme teacher. This image, or at least Åšiva as its main character, faces the east.

2 An anthropomorphic representation of Åšiva, two- or four-armed, with one or more of the attributes of (1), but whose main characteristic is that he is directed towards the south without showing the terrifying aspect.

The transition of 1 to 2 calls forth the â€˜incongruityâ€™.

This incongruity may be considered to have been solved when the image of the Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti began to evolve an autonomy of its own, next to and independent of that of Aghora/Bhairava. Given the fact that the central image in the garbhagr.ha is orientated towards the east, the image at the southern wall may be seen as an original â€˜visualisationâ€™ of the right side, expressing one aspect of the god enshrined, from whom it became spatially detached. Buddhist influences (e.g. the deer at Åšivaâ€™s feet, the tree above his head) are discernible in this process of iconographic composition. 48

The genesis of the iconic representation of the teaching Åšiva thus ended with his â€˜banishmentâ€™ outside the cultic sphere. The idea of the guru as the locus ( sthÂ¯

ana) or support of the divinity was transferred onto the central cult object in the sanctum, the li Ë™nga. Therewith the Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti on the southern outer temple wall lost its original ritual setting. It became part of the iconographic programme of the Åšiva temple.

The process of transformation from cult concept into an iconic image seems to have been completed (in South India at least) by the tenth century (i.e.

the early Col.a period), but may have started much earlier. An early textual testimony of this process is found in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a.

It tells the myth

of TilottamÂ¯

a that we discussed above, pp. 498 f. When the nymph bows to Åšivaâ€™s southern appearance ( daks.in.Â¯am

. mÂ¯

urtim

. ), the face of the guru of the

gods ( mukham

. suraguros) emerged, â€˜possessed of the colour of a languid cloud laden with water, having a ferocious voice, with dreadful teeth shining (in an open mouth), and the corners of the eyes bloodshot and glitteringâ€™ (SP 62.18â€“

19). The â€˜incongruityâ€™ is obviously not yet solved, since the description of this face suits the figure of Aghora/Bhairava, not that of the teacher or guru.

urvÂ¯

ayÂ¯

am

. dvÂ¯

To assess the above-sketched develop-

ment properly requires an art-historical

scrutiny of the available archaeological

material examined for the above fea-

tures; this cannot be done here. Mate-

rial representing moment 2 is not hard to

find. A relatively early example dating

from the late Pallava period (ad 875â€“

900) is illustrated in Plate 114. It shows

a four armed Åšiva as teacher on the outer

southern wall of the garbhagr.ha of the

VÂ¯Ä±rat.t.Â¯aneÅ›vara Temple in Tiruttan.i. His

hands show the vitarkamudrÂ¯

a combined

with rosary, abhayamudrÂ¯

a, book, and

lotus-stalk. 49

The question when and where exactly

this type of â€˜southern imageâ€™ is found

for the first time is more difficult to es-

tablish, partly for the same reasons as

why the material representing moment

1 proves so hard to identify. It is often

difficult to establish which direction the

Plate 114

Tiruttan

teaching Åšiva is facing, if the image or

. i: Daks.in

. Â¯

amÂ¯

urti

relief is no longer part of a spatial con-

struction or has been reemployed. It may even be doubted, whether our moment 1 is an historic reality at all; possibly, the teaching Åšiva, the Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti as an iconographic category, was from the beginning conceived of as facing the south.

A Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti on a crossbar found in NagarÂ¯Ä±

To conclude I wish to present an image that may alleviate our doubts somewhat.

It concerns a crossbar found in NagarÂ¯Ä± (Rajasthan) illustrated in Williams 1982, Pl. 216. On p. 140 f. this scholar gives the following description.

The most impressive carvings at NagarÂ¯Ä± are the remains of a gigantic gateway or toran

. a that must belong to the early sixth century on the basis of its relationship to works from Mandasor.

The lintel has sculptures on both sides. The reliefs on what appears to be the reverse (mistakenly said in op. cit. 141 to be illustrated in Pl. 216) are identified by Williams as scenes from â€˜the story of the encounter between Arjuna and the kirÂ¯

ata or hunterâ€™. After his fight with Åšiva incognito, Arjuna receives the 49 DumarÃ§ay & lâ€™Hernault 1975, photo 54. Cf. Encyclopaedia of Indian Temple Architecture I, plate 77. For the few images classified as Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯

urti found in Uttar Pradesh

see Singh 1976.

In a letter (e-mail d.d. 10-3-2001) Joanna Williams informed me that she â€˜wonders whether the scene at the left end of this face (below, Plates 145â€“146) might not represent the destruction of Daks.aâ€™s sacrificeâ€™. This proposition is further pursued in the present article, but an elaborate study of the crossbar by Bakker

& Bisschop 2016 intends to show that it is untenable after all. 52

Daks.aâ€™s sacrifice and his instruction in the PÂ¯aÅ›upata observance The story of Åšivaâ€™s destruction of Daks.aâ€™s sacrifice is told in MahÂ¯abhÂ¯arata 12

App. I No. 28 (= Northern Recension); it may be briefly recapitulated here.

VÂ¯Ä±rabhadra and BhadrakÂ¯

alÂ¯Ä± etc. destroy Daks.aâ€™s sacrifice in Ga Ë™ngÂ¯advÂ¯ara.

anubhyÂ¯

. gatvÂ¯

26 / At the Right Side of the Teacher

525

Long ago, O Daks.a, the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata yoga was created by me: that ( tat, scil. yoga) is the eminent reward of properly practising that ( tasya, scil. vrata), and that ( yoga) shall be yours, O blessed one. Throw off the fever of (your) soul!

In other words: MahÂ¯

adeva instructs/initiates Daks.a in the PÂ¯aÅ›upata observance; this is the boon that will lead him eventually to the end of suffering ( duh

. khÂ¯

anta), the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata yoga or union with God.

In view of the material discussed in the present article, it is obvious to see in the first panel from the right on the lintel (Plate 116; cf. Plate 156) an example of a Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti. If we assume that the toran.a was facing east and that this is the obverse side of the lintel, MaheÅ›vara, accompanied by his wife, 55 sits facing east, leaning towards the right, where his suppliant sits on his knees, facing north.

This interpretation is corroborated by our later study of the crossbar. However, although the two panels to the left (above, p. 524) initially suggested that the suppliant in question might be King Daks.a (Bakker 2004c, 133), there are good reasons to reconsider this interpretation and to see in the person who receives instruction, not Daks.a, but Arjuna.56

Plate 116

NagarÂ¯Ä±: a Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti

(cf. MBh 13.17.18). Yoga in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata system is defined by Kaun

. d

. inya ad PS 1.1

as â€˜union with godâ€™: ucyate yogam | atra Â¯

atmeÂ´

svarasam

. yogo yogah

. |

My interpretation

differs from that of Mertens 1998, 76 f., who assumes a conflation of concepts: â€˜Im selben Satz wird das pÂ¯

aÂ´

supatavrata als yoga bezeichnet (407); die beiden Begriffe tapas und yoga werden hier also synonym verwendet. FÃ¼r bestimmte Schichten des MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata ist die

Vermischung beider Begriffe Ã¼blich.â€™ However, no examples from the MBh are adduced to corroborate this contention.

55 Cf. MBh ibid. l. 410: evam uktvÂ¯

a mahÂ¯

adevah

. sapatnÂ¯Ä±ko vr

. s.abhadvajah

. |

56 Bakker & Bisschop 2016, 239 f.; below, p. 586.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

526

Hans Bakker

It thus appears that the central theme of both sides of the crossbar is the acquisition of a PÂ¯

aÅ›upata good: the instruction in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata observance

and the procurement of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata weapon. The toran

. a may have stood at

the entrance of a PÂ¯

aÅ›upata temple. The depiction of the instruction scene, the Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti or Åšivaâ€™s figure of grace, would therefore be appropriate, if our analysis is correct.

Thanesar, the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Order and the

SkandapurÂ¯

an.aâˆ—

Studies in the SkandapurÂ¯

an.a IX

The tradition of the four pupils of LÂ¯

agud

. i

By the middle of the sixth century the city of Kanauj seems to have emerged as the capital of the rising dynasty of the Maukharis under its king Â¯IÅ›Â¯

anavarman. 1

This town, in the Sanskrit tradition named KÂ¯

anyakubja/ Kanyakubja, is known

from the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, and from this text only, as the seat of one of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata lineages.

The SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a (SPS 167.123â€“29) informs us that the fourth pupil of LÂ¯

agud.i was a brahmacÂ¯arin who came from a distinguished family in the (Land of the) Kurus. 2 He received initiation in Kanyakubja and, as implied by SPS

167.130, established the fourth lineage of PÂ¯

aÅ›upata teachers there.

LÂ¯

agud.i

bestowed on him (and the other three pupils) â€˜His own doctrineâ€™ (and) yoga. 3

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Journal of Indological Studies 19 (2007), 1â€“16.

1 As far as I am aware, there exists no direct evidence for this statement.

There is

circumstantial evidence, though, which has led the majority of historians to accept it as the most plausible hypothesis. Tripathi 1964, 32â€“36; Majumdar in HCI III, 69 f.; Goyal 1967, 363; Thaplyal 1985, 19 f. Among this evidence is the clay seal-matrix, probably to be ascribed to Avantivarman, that was found in Kanauj (Thaplyal 1985, 153). The major argument for Kanauj being the Maukhari capital, at least at the time of Grahavarman, is based on the evidence of BÂ¯

an

. aâ€™s Hars.acarita (see Tripathi 1964, 32â€“36).

2 We deduce from this evidence that the name of the fourth pupil was unknown to the composer of the SP, but that there was a living tradition that connected him with the Kurus or Kuruks.etra. In order to supply a name for the founder of this lineage, this tradition later invented the name Kaurus.ya (LiP 1.7.51, 1.24.131, ÅšiP Åšatarudrasam

. hitÂ¯

a

5.49) or Kaurus.a (see above, n. 16 on p. 287).

The route along which the PÂ¯

between UjjayanÂ¯Ä± and Pus.kara (initiation of GÂ¯argya), 4) MathurÂ¯a (initiation of Mitra), 5) Land of the Kurus, 6) Kanyakubja (initiation of the Kuru). 4

The major city in the â€˜Land of the Kurusâ€™ in the 5th and 6th centuries was Thanesar. In his Hars.acarita BÂ¯an.a depicts Thanesar (SthÂ¯an.vÂ¯Ä±Å›vara) under (the legendary) King Pus.yabhÂ¯uti as a country completely devoted to MaheÅ›vara.5

It is therefore not impossible, at least it is suggested by the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, that

the PÂ¯

Some information about this â€˜Kuru lineageâ€™ seems to have survived the ages. The (Jaina) traditionâ€”preserved in Gun.aratnaâ€™s (fourteenth century) commentary on the S

LÂ¯

agud

. i

The idea of a guru with four pupils named LÂ¯

ayÂ¯

avataran.a (= KÂ¯arohan.a), who initiated only one pupil, KuÅ›ika, in the city of UjjayanÂ¯Ä±. 7 Nor does the name LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a, or any of its variants, occur in the MathurÂ¯

a Pilaster Inscription of Candragupta II, Year 61. 8 It may have been coined in the fifth century to refer to the (divine) teacher who carried a club ( lagud

. a), portrayed in several fifth-century images, and as such came to be attested in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a. 9

In the first half of the 6th century images of LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a surrounded by four pupils began to appear, such as the one in the YogeÅ›varÂ¯Ä± Cave near Bombay (below, Plate 128). 11

In short, at some stage in the process by which the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata movement

was gathering momentum, the avatÂ¯

ara of Åšiva/PaÅ›upati received the name

LÂ¯

agud.i/LÂ¯akulin/LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a. It became an article of faith common to various traditions, on the one hand serving to account for the spread of several guru lineages that claimed to go back to Åšivaâ€™s incarnation and, on the other hand, uniting these into one coherent religious movement.

The Kuru lineage

Pus.yabhÂ¯uti, a name spelled in some mss as Pus.pabhÂ¯uti, the legendary founder of the dynasty of Thanesar to which King Hars.avardhana belonged.13

Then, when the king is prepared to let him go because of his brahminhood, a goddess dressed in white, evidently Laks.mÂ¯Ä± (RÂ¯ajyaÅ›rÂ¯Ä±),17 emerges from the sword, annoints the king and grants Pus.yabhÂ¯uti to become the founder of a mighty dynasty. This dynasty is therefore believed to have acquired its legitimicy and authority over the land of Kuruks.etra thanks to the magic of the Åšaiva preceptor.18

agud.i himself.

The SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a reaches Nepal

It has been argued by Yokochi in the Introduction to SP III, taken up in Bakker 2014, 137 f., that a major new redaction of our text, the ancestor of the RA recension, came into being in the ninth century. 35

It is likely that before this major new redaction took place the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a had reached Nepal, where it became our S recension. This so-called S or â€˜Nepalese recensionâ€™ has a few particularities of its own.

The end of

chapter 167 in this recension features two remarkable passages in what is in all probability an accretion to the original text (SPS 167.163â€“187), two passages that may betray the background against which this recension S came into being: in one it is said that there are eight places in the country of MagadhÂ¯

a

where Lagud.Â¯Ä±Å›vara (LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a) roamed about together with his pupils (cf. below, p. 564), and in the other, at the end of this interpolation, PaÅ›upati in NepÂ¯

ala

is mentioned together with another sanctuary called Naikatu Ë™ngÂ¯

adhipeÅ›vara,

which calls forth associations with the king of Nepal, the lord supreme of many mountain peaks/thrones. 36 Could it be that there is a nexus that links both additions to the original text?

It has been argued by Yokochi that this interpolation in what would eventually develop into our â€˜Nepalese recensionâ€™ was made â€˜in an early text of the S

recension in northeastern India before it bifurcated and came to be transmitted to Nepalâ€™. 37 Since the earliest transmission to Nepal relates to an ancestor of our ms S , this transmission must, according to Yokochiâ€™s theory, have taken 1

place before ad 700.38

We know of a formal exchange between North India and Nepal in the decades before ad 700, namely when the grand-daughter ( dauhitrÂ¯Ä±) of the Laterâ€“Gupta 35 As noted in Bakker 2014, 138 n. 425 this is â€˜a slight modification of the date proposed for this redaction in the Introduction to SP II A, p. 54, where we had argued that it may have taken place in the eighth, possibly first half of the ninth centuryâ€™. The earlier date featured also in the original version of the present article, published in 2007.

king Â¯

a (3rd quarter 7th cent.), VatsadevÂ¯Ä±, married the

The Later Guptas of MagadhÂ¯

a, from whose family the princess stemmed, were

well familiar with the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata tradition. 41

This follows from an inscrip-

tion of the time of another grandchild of Â¯

Laterâ€“Gupta king Vis.n.ugupta. In this inscription we are told that the pilgrim Avimuktajja (Skt. AvimuktÂ¯

arya), 42 who had visited numerous Åšaiva holy places

inhabited by Siddhas ( anekaÂ´

a had traveled to Nepal, some of whom

may have reached it in the company of the Laterâ€“Gupta princess. 44

an

. a text was thus brought to Nepal, it had undergone

the two additions quoted above, (n. 36 on p. 537 f.) as part of a wider interpolation, in order to make good for what were, in the eyes of its conveyers and receivers, two neglected issues: the authenticity of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata tradition

within MagadhÂ¯

a, now said to have been founded by LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a himself, and the prominence of the holy state sanctuary of Nepal, PaÅ›upatinÂ¯

atha.

Matrimonial alliances and the spread of culture

Historians are used to judge royal matrimonial alliances by their political implications. If our reconstruction holds any water, the cultural implications may also have been significant and may have had a more lasting effect than the political ones. Next to their husbands, princesses on their way to the residences of their grooms were accompanied by a cortÃ¨ge of ladies-in-waiting and dignitaries of all sorts. Among these there may have been religious virtuosi and literati, who, in the train of the two newlywed queens, VÂ¯

asat.Â¯a and VatsadevÂ¯Ä±, brought

the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata order to Daks.in.a Kosala and the SkandapurÂ¯an.a to Nepal.

The Gospel of Kaun.d.inyaâˆ—

The Descent of God in Gujarat and the Practice of Imitating God Kaun

. d

. inyaâ€™s PaËœ

ncÂ¯

arthabhÂ¯

as.ya

KuÂ´

sika and the divine revelation

When we speak of the gospel of Kaun.d.inya, we call forth an association with texts which describe the birth, life, and deeds of a saviour, texts which are meant to bring good news, an evangelium, into the world. This evocation is deliberate. As a tribute to Jan Bremmerâ€™s life-long engagement, scholarly and otherwise, with gospels and kindred texts that have just failed to reach that status, I would like to show, that a text called â€˜The Five Topicsâ€™, PaËœ

ncÂ¯

artha,

which has the form of a commentary ( bhÂ¯

as.ya) on the SÂ¯utras of the PÂ¯aÅ›upata

school (the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utras (PS)), resembles a gospel in many respects. Not

only by the dramatic facts which it professes to report, but also by its apodictic style, and its pretence to communicate a divine revelation, presenting a unique path ( sÂ¯

adhana), which alone is able to promise and deliver hope and salvation to the faithful. Its author, Kaun.d.inya, who may have lived in the 4th century ad, puts himself in the lineage of preceptors that descends directly from the divine teacherâ€™s first disciple, KuÅ›ika. 1

It is generally accepted that this KuÅ›ika has been a historic person, who may have lived in the 2nd century ad. He is mentioned by name as the fountainhead of a lineage of ten teachers in the MathurÂ¯

a Pilaster Inscription of Candragupta

II, Year 61 (i.e. ad 380/81, or ad 388, according to Falk 2004, 173).2 Kaun.d.inya describes how and why this KuÅ›ika came to be elected to receive and spread the divine word. He begins by defining the nature of God.

And accordingly, since His nature is play ( krÂ¯Ä±d

. Â¯

a) . . . (it is certain that) the activity

of God is springing from play. And (His) activity, insomuch as this consists in proclaiming the doctrine, is for the sake of bestowing favour ( anugraha). (Kaun.d.inya ad PS 1.1)

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in Dijkstra, Jitse, Justin Kroesen, & Yme Kuiper (eds.), Myths, Martyrs, and Modernity. Studies in the History of Religions in Honour of Jan N. Bremmer. Brill, Leiden â€“ Boston 2010. pp. 517â€“529. Numen Book Series. Studies in the History of Religions 127.

1 Kaun

. d

. inya ad PS 4.10: kuÂ´

sikeÂ´

sÂ¯

anasambandhÂ¯

at. Cf. above, n. 6 on p. 529 and Bisschop

2006, 49 f.

2 CII III (1981), 240. See above, p. 287 and p. 494.

541

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

542

Hans Bakker

The emphasis Kaun.d.inya lays upon the true nature of God as play is to safeguard His sovereignty, His omnipotence ( prabhutva). This nature of God, here defined for the first time, will remain an integral feature of nearly all Hindu conceptions of god, and we will meet it again below in this essay. Bestowing favour is Godâ€™s free choice, not induced by anything outside Him. His absolute freedom is without beginning and end, but, in order to fulfil His wish, He takes birth.

So, on account of His ability to do whatever He wishes, and His being unborn, God, having taken upon Him a body of a brahmin, has descended in KÂ¯

ayÂ¯

avataran.a in

human form. And He has reached UjjayanÂ¯Ä± by foot. How do we know that? (We know that) on account of the authoritativeness of learned persons ( Â´

sis.t.a), and

because we (still) see and hear the proofs thereof. (Kaun.d.inya ad PS 1.1; above, n. 7 on p. 529)

This event is of a completely different nature as the mythic avatÂ¯

ara stories that

we know from the Vais.n.ava religion. Its measure is human and it has a ring of historicity. Imagine Vis.n.uâ€™s descent as the Boar or the Tortoise, going on foot from one historical site to another, a distance of 290 km as the divine aerial chariot ( vimÂ¯

ana) flies!

Kaun.d.inya continues by telling that this divine brahmin smeared himselves with ashes and selected a sanctuary in Ujjain as his place of residence. Unfortunately the name of the sanctuary is not mentioned and the later tradition of the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a locates this residence in the cremation ground ( Â´

smaÂ´

sÂ¯

ana) of

Ujjain.

Thereupon Lord KuÅ›ika arrived, impelled by God; he saw the signs of perfection, such as complete contentment, in the preceptor and the opposites thereof in himself; falling at his feet he informed him properly about his caste, gotra, Vedic affiliation, and his being free of debts; then, at an appropiate moment, (this) pupil, who was like a patient, consulted the preceptor, who had bided his time, and who was the doctor as it were: â€˜Lord, is there a remedy that is effective and final for all those pains which fate, the world and we ourself afflict upon us, or not?â€™

(Kaun.d.inya ad PS 1.1)

On this pertinent question, the holy brahmin, the incarnation of God, said: atha, â€˜wellâ€™. Kaun.d.inya explains:

Here the word â€˜wellâ€™ relates to what earlier had happened. In what way [a student may ask] ? He has said â€˜wellâ€™ in relation to the earlier question put by the pupil.

Thus this word atha (â€˜wellâ€™) signifies the answer to what has been asked: that end to suffering ( duh

. khÂ¯

anta) does exist. (Kaun.d.inya ad PS 1.1)

â€˜Wellâ€™ is the opening word of the gospel, being the first word of the first SÂ¯

utra.

It is followed by the word atah

. , for which see above, p. 513. Then follows the word paÂ´

supateh

. , â€˜of PaÅ›upatiâ€™, i.e. â€˜of Godâ€™. This expression Kaun.d.inya takes as the answer to a further question: â€˜due to what is this â€œbeing without sufferingâ€

reached?â€™ It is reached, Kaun.d.inya preaches, due to the grace ( prasÂ¯ada) of God, which initiates union ( yoga) with Him.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

28 / The Gospel of Kaun

. d

. inya

543

That (union), (according to some), comes about by the act of one onlyâ€”as in the case of a post and the falconâ€”because it is (said to be) effected by meditation, study etc. of a human being ( purus.a). [However, we believe that] it comes about by the act of bothâ€”as in the case of (two fighting) rams. (Kaun.d.inya ad PS 1.1) This mystical union, therefore, lies not entirely in the hands of the aspirant.

The difference, Kaun.d.inya observes, between his and other salvation doctrines is precisely this: only Åšivaâ€™s grace saves. In order that man may receive it, God has descended in an act of mercy and taught the doctrine as worded in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utras. In biblical terms: â€˜And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, full of grace and truthâ€™ (John 1:14). These SÂ¯

utras are therefore

seen as divine revelation and Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s task it is to proclaim and explain them, that is, like KuÅ›ika before him, to bring the good news.

When its

contents is fully understood and put into praxis ( viddhi), the believer becomes qualified ( adhikÂ¯

arakr.tatva) to receive that grace, which is concomittant with the removal of his separation ( viyoga) from God. United with God he shares in His omniscience and omnipotence, and all his suffering comes to an end. He experiences, in Byzantine terms, theË†

osis (

).

The power of the word

Intrinsically connected with the soteriological claim of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata faith is the

tradition that the holy word is passed down a lineage of accomplished teachers, who all, at the moment that they divulge the truth in the appropriate ritual setting, impersonate the divine incarnation, a doctrine not altogether different from Jesusâ€™ message to his apostles: â€˜For it is not ye that speak, but the Spirit of your Father which speaketh in youâ€™ (Matthew 10:20).

However, in my view the Indian type of religion, to which the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata

faith belongs, pushes this idea further than Catholicism, notwithstanding the Fourth Lateran Council and that of Trent on the Eucharist, and this has to do with its concept of primordial sound ( Â´

sabda). Despite some similarity, but

essentially unlike the evangelist Johnâ€™s logos, the revealed word, or rather its sound, is conceived of as an embodiment of divine power that has, we could say, the magic potency to actualize or reify the divine and to deify those by whose mouths it is pronounced. This feature of the Indian religions, the idea of Â´

sabdabrahman, is the legacy of the Vedic brahmins. It has given rise to much hocus-pocus, on the one hand, and to sublime monuments of spirituality on the other. 3

At the same time, this magic potency accounts for the fact that the revelation is not thought to be meant for everybodyâ€™s ears. After pronouncing the word 3 As an instance of the former I see the doctrine of the school of the Åšaiva SiddhÂ¯

anta,

which assumes that final release may be obtained through the ritual of initiation, in which the bodily and mental flaws are articulated and magically (i.e. through mantras) collected on a rope in order to be burnt in the sacrificial fire. As an example of the latter may pass Kashmir Saivism, which culminates in the work of the intellectual giant Abhinavagupta.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

544

Hans Bakker

â€˜wellâ€™ and promising to reveal the divine doctrine, the teacher performs the initiation ceremony of the pupil, who has to take off all his worldly insignia (above, p. 513). From now on he should go naked or with a loincloth only, smeared with ashes, and without any personal belongings. Only then the teacher will impart the revelation. This divides the community of Åšiva worshippers (MÂ¯

aheÅ›varas)

into two, just as in Buddhismâ€”which seems to have been a major source of inspiration to the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatas anyway: the laymen ( laukikas), whose task it is to gather merit by supporting the order of initiates and by worshipping God in the temple, and the elite group of consecrated ascetics. Only these ascetics are entitled to practise in order to obtain union ( yogavidhi), which is the main subject of the subsequent SÂ¯

utras.

The PÂ¯

aÅ›upata praxis

The imitatio dei

When we have thus seen the lofty religious ideals promulgated by Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s gospel, we may be in for a surprise, when we learn more about the specific practices by which these were believed to be realised. On the whole, these practices can be described as an ever steeper staircase to complete effacement of the phenomenal self. In this respect Kaun.d.inya shares many of the ascetic aims and practices that are known from other Indian religions. In all ascetic movements, whether in India or abroad, self-mortification serves to destroy the ego in the expectation that it makes one more susceptible to the divine. In the brahmanical tradition this is generally seen as the unveiling of a true Self, which is itself thought to be godlike. The PÂ¯

aÅ›upata doctrine is no exception to

this.

The first of five â€˜steps of ascension into Godâ€™ ( gradus ascensionis in Deum), to paraphrase Bonaventura, 4 requires that the initiated ascetic identifies himself with the deity of his devotion by imitating him, an imitatio dei that is enacted in the liturgy within the temple. This concerns some aspects of Åšiva that are known from the corpus of mythological Sanskrit texts, and this mythology clearly informs the conduct of the ascetic. In this corpus of mythology Åšiva often appears as a trickster god, whose loud laughter ( at.t.ahÂ¯asa) puts his subjects, including his wife, in their proper place.

But there is another side of Åšiva, more ancient, going directly back to the Vedic form of him as Rudra, namely his association with cattle and the bull in particular. PaÅ›upati, though in Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s gospel used as a metaphor for 4 Bonaventura, Itinerarium mentis in Deum, 1.5â€“6. The five steps in the career of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata ascetic are: 1) living within the precincts of a sanctuary and worshipping Åšiva, 2) moving about and seeking dishonour, 3) retreating within a lonely place for meditation, 4) living in the cremation ground until death, 5) the end of suffering through Godâ€™s grace.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

28 / The Gospel of Kaun

. d

. inya

545

â€˜Lord ( pati) of the bound human soulâ€™ ( paÂ´

su), literally means â€˜Lord of Cattle

( paÂ´

su)â€™. This is a god of nature and fertility, powerful and terrifying, who joined in with the indigenous phallus cult, which sophisticated brahminical thinking transformed eventually into the abstract li Ë™nga. In this aspect, Åšiva is associated with the bull, nay, he is the bull. This aspect of his character explains the, at first sight, puzzling injunction in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utras where

it says, that the initiate should offer, along with laughter, the sound hud

. um

.

(PS 1.8). Kaun.d.inya explains: â€˜The word hud.um

. : the auspicious noise which

resembles that of a bull and which originates from holding the tip of the tongue against the palate, that is what (is meant).â€™ 5

Just as serious is Åšivaâ€™s role as fons et origo of the fine arts, in particular of music and dance. 6 One of the Hindu gods best known to Western audiences is probably Åšiva, king of the dance ( nat.arÂ¯aja). A God who himself dances and sings, then we have really left the world of the Abrahamic religions! The imitatio dei practice of the aspirant consists in laughing loudly, bellowing, and singing and dancing in trance at the right side of the cult image in the sanctum in worship of God. 7 How could one worship Him better than by mimesis?

The temple worship of the initiated ascetic ends with complete absorption in God by the constant muttering of a prayer ( japya), which, seen as a mantra, is, as we have observed above, to be conceived of as His quintessence actualized in the form of sound. This prayer runs:

I resort to the Eternal, Primordial One, Who is Unborn ( sadyojÂ¯

ata), glory, glory

to the Eternal, Primordial One, Who is Unborn!

In existence after existence, not in too many existences, You should be merciful to me, You from Whom existence springs. 8

The seeking of dishonour

Although the initiate â€˜looses himselfâ€™, so to speak, in his mimetic worship, this is a temporary state. For the second stage of the asceticâ€™s career Kaun.d.inya prescribes a behaviour that deepens the effacement of the person by a process of self-mortification that goes further than most of the rivalling practices. I 5 Kaun

. d

. inya ad PS 1.8. This practice may go back to a Vedic govrata or anad

. udvrata; see

Acharya 2013.

6 BhÂ¯

aratÂ¯Ä±ya-NÂ¯

at.yaÅ›Â¯astra, chapter 4. Cf. Long 1971, 77.

7 For the significance of â€˜the right sideâ€™ in this context see Bakker 2004c; above, pp. 505 ff.

8 My translation follows Kaun

. d

. inyaâ€™s interpretation of PS 1.40â€“44:

sadyojÂ¯

atam

. prapadyÂ¯

ami sadyojÂ¯

atÂ¯

aya vai namah

. k

This verse (Anus.t.ubh) corresponds to TaittirÂ¯Ä±ya Â¯

Aran

. yaka 10.43. It has some variants

(see Bisschop 2006a, 7 f.), the most important of which is the reading bhavasva instead of bhajasva. The MahÂ¯

a-NÂ¯

arÂ¯

ayan

. a Upanis.ad 17.1 (Varenne 1960, 277â€“78) reads bhavasva.

This verse is translated by Varenne 1960, 71, with a little too much Cartesian flavour, as: â€˜Je cherge refuge auprÃ¨s du nouveau-nÃ©; hommage au nouveau-nÃ©! Hommage! Je suis! Je suis! Je nâ€™excelle pas! Sois pour moi! Hommage Ã  celui qui est lâ€™origine de lâ€™existence!â€™

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

546

Hans Bakker

refer to the notorious doctrine of seeking dishonour ( avamÂ¯

ana). To initiate

its discussion in his commentary on PS 3.3, reading â€˜despisedâ€™ ( avamatah

. ),

Kaun.d.inya quotes two verses which are in slightly modified form known from older sources, the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata (12.222.20â€“21) and the Manusmr.ti (2.162â€“

163).

The wise brahmin should seek dishonour as if it were ambrosia and he should always beware of honour as if it were poison. For, while being despised, he rests in happiness, excluded from all society; a sage should not think of the faults of the other, (but) always of his own evil. (Kaun.d.inya ad PS 3.3) Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s quotation of older sources in this context and the fact that this stage of the path to salvation dealing with dishonour disappears soon from the repertoire of Åšaiva soteriologial texts seem to indicate that we are here concerned with an archaic practice accommodated to the early PÂ¯

aÅ›upata move-

ment. 9 The practice involves that the aspirant seeks dishonour when, in public and without making himself known as a PÂ¯

aÅ›upata ascetic,

He should go about as a mad man, who snores, trembles, limps, leches, and acts and speaks improperly, so that he may come to be ill-treated. For a wise man, being ill-treated, accomplishes thereby all asceticism. (PS 3.11â€“19) 10

It is to the credit of Daniel Ingalls to have put this weird doctrine into a wider perspective by pointing out its similarity with the practice of dishonour (

)

of the Greek Cynics, in an article that appeared in the Harvard Theological Review in 1962, but which remained largely unknown outside a select group of indologists. As Ingalls points out,

Diogenesâ€™ [â€˜the Dogâ€™ (

)] favourite method of attracting attention and oppro-

brium, if we are to believe the anecdotes, was by performing in public those acts of nature which should remain hidden: spitting, defecation, and the act of sex.

By means of public censure the Cynics sought to attain hardness, apathy and freedom. 11

And we could go further along the path pointed out by Ingalls. I trust that the reader allows me to take him on a little excursus into the Realm of the Holy Fools, a realm explored most recently in a thesis by Jan Hofstra (2008).

Fools through the Ages

A letter of Paul to the Corinthiers is often seen as a point of departure of this phenomenon in Christianity:

9 Oberlies 2000 points out that this practice, as part of the wider context of the brahmodya, is already attested in the TaittirÂ¯Ä±ya BrÂ¯

ahman

. a 2.3.9.9 and that an influence of Cynicism

as argued by Ingalls (see below, p. 554) is very unlikely. Cf. Acharya 2013. In Bakker 2011 (below, p. 553 ff.) I argue that the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata doctrine, practice and iconography

(LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a) are to be conceived as orthogenetic.

10 Translation based on Ingalls 1962.

11 Ingalls 1962, 283. For an assessment of Ingallsâ€™ arguments see below, pp. 554 ff.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

28 / The Gospel of Kaun

. d

. inya

547

For I think that God hath set forth us the apostles last, as it were appointed to death: for we are made a spectacle unto the world, and to angels, and to men.

We are fools for Christâ€™s sake, but ye are wise in Christ; we are weak, but ye are strong; ye are honourable, but we are despised. (1 Corintheans 4:9â€“10) To what extremes this could evolve, we read, for instance, in the Life of Symeon the Holy Fool by Leontios, bishop of Neapolis, Cyprus (first half of 7th century ad):

His entry into the city of Emesa was as follows. Outside the city the illustrious one found a dead dog on a dunghill. He unleashed his cord, tied it to a leg of the dog, and tugged the animal behind him, while he was running through the city gate near the school. 12 . . . By everything he did he suggested to be mad or unbecoming. . . .

He made it his habit, sometimes to limp, sometimes to spring around, or to shuffle on his bottom, or to trip someone up. Sometimes he watched the sky at new moon, upon which he dropped to the ground and began kicking around; sometimes he acted as if he were raving mad. . . . He had become completely incorporeal and innocent with respect to what is appropriate among men. When he wanted to answer a call of nature, it often happened that he was ashamed of nobody and defecated at the market square in full view. . . . The blessed one had reached such a degree of purity and sacrosanctity that he often danced and sprung around, having a harlot on each hand. Etcetera. 13

Plate 120

Symeonsâ€™s entry into the city of Emesa

12 Contra Hofstra 2008, statement 3 (publicly defended at the University of Groningen on 18 September 2008), this scene cannot be explained from the Scala Paradisi 29/ 14, but is a tongue-in-cheek reference to the Cynics.

13 English paraphrase after the Dutch translation from the Greek by Aerts and Hokwerda 2006, 90, 92, 98.

548

Hans Bakker

We could continue to the yurodivyj (rodivyË˜

i) of the Russian Orthodox

Church, but it might be wise to return to the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata and to explain what is

common to its tradition of seeking dishonour ( avamÂ¯

ana) and apparently similar

practices in the Greek and Christian traditions, and what is different. Common to all traditions, it would seem to me, is the feeling of ecstatic power, when freedom from all forms of (social) bondage is experienced, when the social ego is destroyed. It is the

and

of which the Cynics speak, and

which, for modern man, has been worded brilliantly by Thomas Mann in his Magic Mountain (Der Zauberberg):

Da seine Betrachtungen dumpf und verworren waren, so ist es schwer, sie zu prÃ¤-zisieren. HaubtsÃ¤chlich schien ihm, daÃŸ die Ehre bedeutende Vorteile fÃ¼r sich habe, aber die Schande nicht minder, ja daÃŸ die Vorteile der letzteren geradezu grenzenlo-ser Art seien. Und indem er sich probeweise in Herrn Albins Zustand versetzte und sich vergegenwÃ¤rtigte, wie es sein mÃ¼sse, wenn man endgÃ¼ltig des Druckes der Ehre ledig war und auf immer die bodenlosen Vorteile der Schande genoÃŸ, erschreckte den jungen Mann ein GefÃ¼hl von wÃ¼ster SÃ¼ÃŸigkeit, das sein Herz vorÃ¼bergehend zu noch hastigerem Gange erregte. 14

Kaun.d.inya describes at length the supernatural powers that the aspirant attains in the course of his ascetic training. However, the SÂ¯

utras that form the

introduction to his treatment of dishonour run: â€˜He gives his bad karma to them and from them he takes their good karma.â€™ (PS 3.8â€“9). The provocations that apparently heap shame upon the practioner induce a transfer of merit: the provoked bourgeois, who is tricked into mistaking the ascetic for a madman, looses good karma due to his mistake, which karma is booked at the karma credit side of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata: a sort of credit swap avant la lettre. This highly individualistic motive, or should we say immoral, selfish ideology, although still well recognizable in its present-day forms, makes the gospel of Kaun.d.inya stand out amongst its sort.

The question arises whether this second stage of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata praxis is also

to be seen in the perspective of the imitatio dei, which so clearly informed the first one. I think this is possible, although the antinomian praxis evidently had a long history outside the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata movement. But antinomian behaviour suited

certain aspects of Åšiva very well. From Vedic times Rudra-Åšiva has been seen as an outsider, a dangerous god that should be kept at a distance. To propitiate him he was given the name â€˜the auspicious oneâ€™ (i.e. Â´

siva). His provocative

and nonconformist conduct is well expressed in one of the paradigmatic Åšaiva myths: â€˜Åšiva in the Pine Forestâ€™ (DevadÂ¯

aruvana). This myth differs significantly

in various sources, but I present here the epitome given by Oâ€™Flaherty: 15

Åšiva then wandered into the Pine Forest, and the wives of the sages there fell in love with him and followed him everywhere. Åšiva was naked, ithyphallic, dancing, and begging with a skull in his hand. The sages became furious and cursed his li Ë™

nga

14 Thomas Mann (1952), Der Zauberberg, 115.

15 Oâ€™Flaherty 1973, 32. Cf. below, p. 578.

28 / The Gospel of Kaun

. d

. inya

549

to fall to the ground. The li Ë™

nga fell but began to cause a terrible conflagration; BrahmÂ¯

a and Vis.n.u tried in vain to find the top and bottom of it, and peace was only restored when the sages agreed to worship the li Ë™

nga, together with their wives.

Antinomian conduct has remained a feature of Åšaiva ascetics until the present day.

Kaun

. d

. inyaâ€™s eschatology

Like the aspirant, we should leave this provocative, foolish phase in the discipline behind us and move on towards the final goal. The next step in the career of the practitioner is to retreat into solitude, which ends in his move to the cremation ground. By chosing this, for ordinary Hindus most pollutive and horrifying place, as his last residence on earth (while still alive), the accomplished PÂ¯

aÅ›upata saint proves his complete detachment from all earthly things.

Like God Himself, he has transcended the relative world of opposites, of pure and impure, of good and evil, and as a monad, steeped in meditation, he awaits the moment that Godâ€™s grace will fall upon him and his suffering comes to an end. This signals in the completion of the practice of imitation. With this, at the moment of death, the saint becomes god.

The PÂ¯

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utras finish when the divine speaker, that is Åšiva the author of the SÂ¯

utras, instructs the practitioner in the penultimate stage to meditate on Him by repeating the following prayer:

The Lord of all knowledge/ spells, the Master of all beings/ spirits; the Overlord of brahman, God (BrahmÂ¯

a), (who is) the Overlord of the demiurge

(BrahmÂ¯

a), Eternal Åšiva (SadÂ¯

aÅ›iva), He must be (for ever) auspicious ( Â´

siva) toward

me! 16

This is followed in the Calcutta manuscript by the syllable om

. , 17 which should

be seen in this context as a declaration of affirmation, amen, from the side of God. Kaun.d.inya too, although he apparently omits this syllable om., seems to take this prayer in an eschatological way. The fact that God Himself instructs the devotee to entreat Him to be gracious holds a great promise: the end of suffering is at hand; it will be realized at the moment of death (the last stage) and will be for ever. Typical for Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s style, this vision of hope is prompted by a question:
