550

Hans Bakker

â€˜Is it so that here (in this gospel), that is in this prayer, only the majesty of the Creator 18 with respect to the created world ( kÂ¯

arya) is considered, but not the as-

pirantâ€™s longing for or obtaining of (Åšivahood)?â€™ The answer is â€˜Noâ€™. Just because He sees that those who are not yet in His ultimate grace, due to their office of being aspirant, lack Åšivahood/blessedness ( aÂ´

sivatva), while those who have reached (the

ultimate) state of being without suffering possess Åšivahood/ blessedness, He proclaims this last SÂ¯

utra. The words in this SÂ¯

utra â€˜(He) must beâ€™ express a wish: he

wishes, he is longing, he pursues. . . . And because it is the Eternal Åšiva (SadÂ¯

aÅ›iva)

who gives the instruction, the state of being without suffering ( duh

. khÂ¯

anta) is eter-

nal. (Here) ends His office of Creator. Therefore it is certain: this end of suffering is for good. (Kaun.d.inya ad PS 5.45â€“47)

This doctrine, scholastic, technical, and elitist as it may be, of a personal gracious God, who has descended to earth in order to save all those from suffering who have the courage and stamina to give up their own person for the sake of attaining Him, was something of a religious revolution in the first centuries ad in northern India.

In one important aspect the imitatio dei of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata differs from other

practices of this sort in later Hinduism as well as in Christianity. The imitation of the ascetic is meant to efface all human individuality, to destroy the ego and all worldly sensual experiences. Along this path, accessible only to ascetic virtuosi, the imitatio ends in an aequatio. The human soul, the paÂ´

su, as such

ceases to exist; it has â€˜transubstantiatedâ€™ into god. As so many products of the Indian mind, this ideal has never vanished, but remained part and parcel of the Indian cultural heritage. However, it has become relatively marginalized and eclipsed by modern forms of mass devotion, in particular by Vais.n.ava bhakti.

Modern forms of Hindu devotion

I would like to finish with a few words on these modern forms of Hindu worship.

We may say that the idea of the imitation of god as a path to reach him has retained a normative value in Saivism, Vaisnavism and Hinduism in general, ever since its earliest formulation in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata religion. We have limited

ourselves here to an early Åšaiva movement, but instances of the imitatio dei practice within modern Vaisnavism are not hard to come by.

One could even maintain that the modern devotional schools of Vis.n.u worship are nothing but imitations of the divine play ( lÂ¯Ä±lÂ¯

a/ krÂ¯Ä±d

. Â¯

a), be it the sports

of RÂ¯

ama and SÂ¯Ä±tÂ¯

a in AyodhyÂ¯

a, or those of Kr.s.n.a and RÂ¯adhÂ¯a in Braj. In order

to enact the eternal lÂ¯Ä±lÂ¯

a, devotees make pilgrimages to the places where the mythology is believed to be topographically embedded. It is a strategy practised by hundreds of millions to remove the painful separation ( viraha) of the human soul and God. In contrast to what the Christian pilgrim may experience 18 I read kÂ¯

aran

. a instead of karan

. a.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

28 / The Gospel of Kaun

. d

. inya

551

on the Via Dolorosa in Jerusalem, the imitation of Kr.s.n.a in Braj and Vrindavan usually results in great exuberance. Modern Hinduism, in particular Vais.n.ava bhakti, is a religion celebrating the joys of life rather than its sufferings (cf.

above, p. 17). It is this character, unexpected as it may be to some readers, especially after reading this essayâ€”it is this life-affirming attitude, which seeks to imitate the sports of a happy god, that sat in the way of a warm reception by Christian missionaries. It made Hinduism in the eyes of many of them a shallow, silly, and naive religion, a too childish way of life to compare in earnest with the grave and deadly serious, revealed religion whose ceremonialism emphasized the doleful side of life and banished, like the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata faith, the end

of suffering to a realm beyond death.

Epilogue

Comparison is central to the systematic study of religion. The comparative method, however, carries a great risk.

As the scope widens, the collected

insights tend to become more shallow and this not infrequently results in an arid display of learnedness. A balance should be struck between collecting comparable phenomena in different religions and bringing to light the great divisions that do exist, despite superficial resemblances. It will not lead us to the essence of religion, but it will enhance our understanding and debunk absolute claims, since it is due to explode naive ethnocentricity and academic parochialism. Thus is the task of the historian of religion, and this task has been accomplished in an exemplary way by Jan Bremmer in his distinguished career as professor of religious studies.

Many scholars in the humanities today will agree that god as an entity is unwarranted. God is not an ontological category in the sense of an ens realissimum, but a human ideal, that is a mental, social and cultural figuration that gives meaning to life and guides the conduct of the community of believers. As such, the idea of god, which a community creates and sustains, is quintessen-tial to the culture of that community. For this reason the study of religion is such a rewarding enterprise: it allows us access to key notions of a culture. A comparative perspective may help to bring these notions into prominence.

I wrote, the conception of god guides the conduct of the believer, and nowhere is this more obvious than in the practice of imitating god.

Look

at the ritualized behaviour of the believers and you will find their idea of god.

Look at the idea of god and you will understand the behaviour. Imitation of god is at the heart of every traditional, religious society, of Christianity as much as of Hinduism. To emulate a happy god brings greater happiness among the faithful; to emulate a suffering god may offer more consolation in our dark-est hours, or, in the words of the Goncourt brothers (1 December 1860): â€˜La religion chrÃ©tienne sert quand on pleure.â€™ 19

19 Journal des Goncourt : MÃ©moires de la vie littÃ©raire, BibliothÃ¨queâ€“Charpentier, 1891.

Tome premier : 1851-1861. E-text: https://fr.wikisource.org/wiki/Journal_des_

Goncourt/I/Ann (accessed 3-12-15).

Origin and Spread of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Movementâˆ—

About Heracles, LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a and Symbols of Masculinity

LÂ¯

agud

. i

The study of the origins of organized Saivism received a completely new perspective with the publication of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utras (PS) and Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s com-

mentary thereon, the PaËœ

ncÂ¯

arthabhÂ¯

as.ya, by R. Ananthakrishna Sastri in 1940.

Research by Minoru Hara, Daniel Ingalls, Alexis Sanderson, Thomas Oberlies, Peter Bisschop, and Diwakar Acharya, to mention just the major players in this field, built on this new evidence and has paved the way for our present investigation, which draws heavily on their work. 1

For the last fifteen years we have also been fortunate to possess another source that comes from the same PÂ¯

aÅ›upata tradition and is chronologically not

too far removed from Kaun.d.inya. This text reflects the laymanâ€™s, laukika, view, rather than that of the initiated ascetic, who is the primary person treated by Kaun.d.inya. This text is the SkandapurÂ¯an.a (SP), whose composition we date between ad 550 and 650, which means that the text is probably about 200 years later than Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s commentary. Much had happened in India in those 200 years: it saw the rise and fall of the great Gupta Empire, the intrusion of Hunnic peoples, and the gradual recovery of centralized power in the new capital Kanauj (Kanyakubja) under the Maukharis and the great Hars.avardhana of Thanesar.

The first thing that strikes us, when we compare the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. aâ€™s account

of the well-known descent of Åšiva in KÂ¯

ayÂ¯

avataran.a (called KÂ¯arohan.a in SP and

known today as Karvan in Gujarat) with that given by Kaun.d.inya, is that the uniqueness of this mystical event is no longer maintained. Reflecting the general Hindu and Buddhist conception of the time, viz. that a Buddha or a god incarnates on earth again and again in various forms and persons, the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a makes Åšivaâ€™s descent in Gujarat a cyclic event: each world period

urvÂ¯

( yuga) had its own incarnation: BhÂ¯

arabhÂ¯

uti in the Kr.tayuga, Din.d.imun.d.a in

the TretÂ¯

a, Â¯

As.Â¯ad.hi in the DvÂ¯apara, and LÂ¯agud.i in our Kali Age.2

Another development that apparently took place or gained prominence in the 5th to 6th centuries is that the avatÂ¯

ara story in KÂ¯

arohan.a itself was revised.

God is said in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a to have been born into the house of a certain

SomaÅ›arman, who is said to belong to the lineage of the r.s.i Atri, father of Soma, the Moon. 3 This new tradition may have been invented to account for a lineage of PÂ¯

aÅ›upata teachers who traced their pedigree back to SomaÅ›arman, a topic that I have discussed in my paper SomaÅ›arman, Somavam

. Å›a and So-

masiddhÂ¯

anta (above, p. 283 ff.). The SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a is, in all likelihood, the

first extant text that attests the name LÂ¯

agud.i (variant: LÂ¯akulin), meaning

â€˜club bearerâ€™ ( lagud

. a/lakut.a: â€˜clubâ€™; see above, p. 529). However, this relatively late first attestation of the name â€˜club bearerâ€™ does not preclude the possibility that the association of this incarnation with the attribute of the club is much older. For this we have some indications.

Early images of a club bearing ascetic or teacher

To begin with, there is an image found in MathurÂ¯

a, 4 usually dated to the third

century ad on stylistic grounds, of a rather glum-faced, club-bearing ascetic.

This figure might represent, either an ascetic associated with the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata

sect, orâ€”less likely, because characteristic iconographic signs are absentâ€”the incarnation of Åšiva himself (Plate 121). 5

Secondly, the American scholar Daniel Ingalls, who compared the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata

sect with the school of the Greek Cynics, broke new ground in his paper Cynics and PÂ¯

aÅ›upata: the Seeking of Dishonor, when he conjectured that the name LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a, the LÂ¯

agud.i of the SkandapurÂ¯an.a, may have been derived from the Greek name Heracles,

, â€˜if it lost its first syllable in order to help out

a folk etymologyâ€™. 6 If this were correct, it might point to an (iconographic) influence of the Hellenistic school of the Cynics, whose patron saint was the club-bearing Heracles, on the movement of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata.

Ingallsâ€™ wider suggestion, namely that the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata practice of seeking dis-

honour may have originated under the influence of the Cynics, has been met with scepticism by contemporary scholarship. Thomas Oberlies (2000) argued in his Kriegslisten und ungeziemendes Benehmen: Die Askesepraktiken der PÂ¯

aÅ›upatas that antinomian praxis, as part of the context of the brahmodya, is already attested in the TaittirÂ¯Ä±ya BrÂ¯

ahman

. a (2.3.9.9); the influence of Cynicism

in this particular respect, something that was conjectured by Ingalls, is therefore not required to explain the phenomenon. Though it may indeed be the case that the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata antinomian praxis in the second stage of the asceticâ€™s 2 SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a S recension (SPS 167.112â€“117) in Bisschop 2006.

career is an orthogenetic Indian development, the eponymous attribute of the saint, the lagud

The lagud

. a or club

a. This sculpture

is understood to be an image of LÂ¯

a image (Plate 125): a Greek

symbol of masculinity encounters an Indian symbol of virility.

Elements of the syncretistic culture of Bactria reached western India with the entrance into the Subcontinent of Åšaka tribes, who built a kingdom from MathurÂ¯

a to southern Gujarat in the last decades before the Common Era.

That Heracles remained a popular figure there till Kus.Â¯an.a rule is attested, for instance, by the so-called Hercules-type of coins of the Åšaka ruler Rajuvula (1st quarter 1st cent. ad), some of which were found in MathurÂ¯a, 12 and a second-century ad image of Heracles and the Nemeian Lion, which was also found in MathurÂ¯

a (Plate 124). 13

Hans Bakker

The origin of the PÂ¯

aÂ´

supata movement

The PÂ¯

aÅ›upata movement originated under Åšaka hegemony in that part of India where the figure of Heracles was known at the time. If the iconography of Heracles had exerted some influence on, or had moulded the figure of the club-bearing divine teacher, we would have expected this to become apparent in the sources that date to the period in which both, the figure of Heracles and the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata teacher, existed side by side, viz. the first centuries of the Common Era. However, neither our oldest source, the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utras, nor Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s

commentary knows, either the club as an attribute, or the name LÂ¯

agud.i.14

Ingallsâ€™ hypothesis, therefore, which assumes that the Greek Heracles launched the Indian LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a, is just as unlikely as his assumption that the Hellenistic school of the Cynics influenced the development of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata practice.

An orthogenetic root of the club-bearing deity seems therefore to be more obvious. The AmarakoÅ›a (3.3.42) mentions lagud

. a as a synonym of dan

. d

. a. It

is but natural to conceive of the club as a variant of the traditional stick or staff ( dan

. d

. a) of the brahmin ascetic. The earliest PÂ¯

aÅ›upata monument known

to us, the MathurÂ¯

a Pilaster of Candragupta II of the Gupta Year 61, i.e. ad 380 (above, Plate 112), 15 depicts a naked three-eyed figure with a dan

. d

. a in his

right, and what is possibly a kaman

. d

. alu in his left hand (Plate 126). 16

Plate 126

Dan

. d

. apÂ¯

an

. i on MathurÂ¯

a pilaster, ge 61

abhÂ¯

arata knows the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata sect, its vow ( vrata), doctrine ( jËœ

nÂ¯

ana), and prac-

aÅ›upata weapon ( astra), which Åšiva gave to Arjuna; for this weapon see below, p. 567. LÂ¯

agud

. i/LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a is unknown to the MBh and so is his

club.

15 CII III (1981), 240.

16 The identity of this figure is disputed. That we are concerned with a divine figure follows from the third eye. Acharya 2005, 209 proposes to read the name of this deity as Can

. a.

My designation â€˜Dan

. apÂ¯

an

. iâ€™ is descriptive, it is not the proper name of the deity.

29 / Origin and Spread of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Movement

559

Admittedly, the origin of the word lagud

. a/ lakut.aâ€”attested, for instance, in Manusmr.ti (8.315) and MahÂ¯abhÂ¯arata (7.29.16) in the sense of â€˜cudgelâ€™ or

â€˜clubâ€™â€”remains as yet unclear. 17 But even if we do not accept Przyluskiâ€™s etymology that links the word to the Austroâ€“Asiatic lÂ¯

a Ë™ngula, meaning â€˜stickâ€™

or â€˜penisâ€™, 18 we may assume that phallic symbolism easily suggested itself to the Indian mind and came to be associated with this particular attribute. The phallic shape of the club in the earliest representations of the divine teacher, evident from the line pattern and its upright position (Plate 125), may have been prompted by the ithyphallic nature of this teacher and his prototype, Åšiva. Thus, the club may have replaced the ascetic dan

. d

. a, by virtue of its more

outspoken phallic, i.e. Åšaiva connotation. 19 The name LÂ¯

agud.i, â€˜club-bearerâ€™,

in SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a (SPS 167.129), Lagud.Â¯Ä±Å›vara in SPS 167.169 (interpolation), LÂ¯

akuli in NiÅ›vÂ¯

asamukha 3.19 (Kafle 2015, 149) and LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a, i.e. â€˜Lord of the club-bearersâ€™, in slightly later sources, e.g. the GuhyasÂ¯

utra (12.18) of the

NiÅ›vÂ¯

asatattvasam

. hitÂ¯

a, derive all from this eponymous attribute. 20

The four disciples

Another major development (in addition to the invention of the figure of LÂ¯

agud.i) that took place in the 4th to 6th centuries is also attested by the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a: KuÅ›ika is no longer the only disciple. The number of disciples that is said to have been initiated by LÂ¯

agud.i himself has increased to four.

These four are considered to have a semi-divine status; our text declares them to have sprung from the four faces of God (ParameÅ›Â¯

ana), out of His desire to

bestow grace ( anugraha) upon the world:

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

560

Hans Bakker

You four should descend to earth to become twice-born ascetics.

And after having led the brahmins to the supreme station, you, O masters of yoga, should return to Me. (SPS 167.120) The first disciple, KuÅ›ika/KauÅ›ika, is born in Ujjain and initiated there by Åšivaâ€™s incarnation himself, just as is in Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s version of the story (above, n. 7 on p. 529 and p. 542). But the venue has changed. The initiation according to the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a takes place in the cremation ground instead of a temple.

The Lord, smeared with ashes, is said to hold a firebrand ( ulmuka) in his left hand (SPS 167.127 f.). This seems appropriate for a cremation ground and may suggest that the initiation included branding. Although it is tempting to hypothesize that the asceticâ€™s club has been mistakenly interpreted for what was originally a firebrand, this hypothesis has to be discarded, not only because of what has been said above, but also, more importantly, because images of LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a with a firebrand have never come to light and the ulmuka is elsewhere never mentioned as one of his potential attributes. On the other hand, the firebrand as an attribute is found in some later images of Åšiva as a teacher, in his so-called â€˜Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urtiâ€™.21

The ancient cremation ground in Ujjain has been identified. Locally known as KumhÂ¯

ar T

. ekd.Â¯Ä±, this site was the subject of preliminary explorations by M.B.

Garde in the season of 1938â€“39. Discovered there were skeletons in sitting posture, reflecting the normal way of interning yogins. KuÅ›ika may have been one of them. 22 The specification of these four disciples in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a

allows us to catch a glimpse of the spread and ramification of the movement; it will be our subject in the final part of this essay.

29 / Origin and Spread of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Movement

561

Spread and ramification of the PÂ¯

aÂ´

supata movement

From the MathurÂ¯

a Pilaster of ad 380 we deduce that the PÂ¯aÅ›upata movement had spread from South Gujarat to MathurÂ¯

a before the end of the fourth cen-

tury. This is true for at least one tradition of gurus, the so-called â€˜Vaimalasâ€™, who traced their pedigree also directly back to KuÅ›ika. In an image found in MathurÂ¯

a that might be slightly later than the pilaster, the ithyphallic divine teacherâ€”who, to judge by his attribute, is to be identified as LÂ¯

agud.iâ€”is shown

with two disciples (above, Plate 118). 23 Evidently the KuÅ›ika lineage ( paramparÂ¯

a) as attested in Kaun.d.inyaâ€™s commentary needed to compete with one or more rival traditions that also claimed direct descent from Åšivaâ€™s incarnation. 24

The SkandapurÂ¯

an

. aâ€™s account of the four disciples of LÂ¯

agud.i, which would

become the standard, reflects this bifurcation, which may have started already in the 4th century, if not earlier. The earliest known image that shows four disciples seated around a divine teacher, however, comes only in the 6th century (Plate 128); it is found â€˜above the doorway in the east vestibule to the great cave at YogeÅ›varÂ¯Ä± near Bombayâ€™, which is dated by Walter Spink to c. ad 525.25

Plate 128

YogeÂ´

svarÂ¯Ä± Cave (Mumbai): LakulÂ¯Ä±Â´

sa with four disciples

23 Shah 1984, 97; Meister (ed.) 1984, Pl. 81.

24 Cf. above, n. 6 on p. 529 and p. 541.

25 Spink 1983, 243. Shah 1984, 88. The divine figure in the YogeÅ›varÂ¯Ä± Cave seems to be four-armed: the left upper hand holds the rosary, the left lower hand the club, the right lower hand seems to make a vyÂ¯

akhÂ¯

anamudrÂ¯

a, whereas the right upper arm is missing (cf.

Shah 1984, 98). This early Åšaiva monument, just as the monuments at Mandapesvar and Elephanta, shows the flourishing of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata movement in the middle of the

6th century, when the movementâ€™s home country came under the control of the early Kalacuris, who extended their rule to the northern Konkan, where these monuments are preserved (Spink 1983; cf. Mirashi in CII IV.1, xlvi f., cxlvii f.). The Kalacuri king Kr.s.n.arÂ¯aja in an inscription of his son (Åšam

. karagan

. a) datable to ad 597, is said to have

been devoted to PaÅ›upati from the day of his birth ( janmana eva paÂ´

supatisamÂ¯

. , CII IV.1, 41).

562

Hans Bakker

The account in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a tells us that the third disciple, who was

initiated in MathurÂ¯

a, was named Mitra. No doubt there were many Mitras in MathurÂ¯

a, but the mentioning of this name in this context may betray some historical awareness of the fact that the city of MathurÂ¯

a, before the coming

of the Åšakas, had been governed by a Mitra dynasty. 26 Making a (legendary) Mitra the fountainhead of a lineage of PÂ¯

aÅ›upata gurus in MathurÂ¯

a would only

add to the authenticity of this tradition.

The SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a suggests that before the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata teachers had settled

in MathurÂ¯

a, the movement had reached the city of JambumÂ¯

arga, to be located

between UjjayanÂ¯Ä± and MathurÂ¯

a. 27 In this city, the divine incarnation is said to

have initiated his second disciple GÂ¯

argya. The exact location of JambumÂ¯

arga is

unknown, but it must have been an important Åšaiva centre. Professor Tsuchida (Tokyo) has suggested to me that it may be the town called Mo-hi-shi-fa-lo-pu-lo, MaheÅ›varapura, visited by Xuanzang in the first quarter of the seventh century. The chinese pilgrim describes the place as follows.

The produce of the soil and the manners of the people are like those of the kingdom of UjjayanË†Ä±. They greatly esteem the heretics and do not reverence the law of the Buddha. There are several tens of DÃªva temples, and the sectaries principally belong to the PÃ¢supatas. The king is of the BrÃ¢hman caste; he places but little faith in the doctrine of Buddha. 28

The itinerary of the Chinese pilgrim suggests that MaheÅ›varapura lay on the route from Ujjain to the north through Chitor, that is on the axis Ujjain, Mandasor, Chitor, Pus.kara, MathurÂ¯a.29 The research of Elizabeth Cecil (2016, 150 ff.) has shown that the salt lake region north of Pus.kara, around Sikarâ€“

Sambhar, traditionally known as SapÂ¯

adalaks.a, in particular the excavation site

at Naliasar, 6 km from SÂ¯

ambhar (ÅšÂ¯

akambharÂ¯Ä±), may be another good candidate

for JambumÂ¯

arga.

In between Pus.kara and Ujjain is the village presently known as NagarÂ¯Ä±, corresponding to the ancient town of MÂ¯

adhyamika, which is located near Chitor

(Xuanzangâ€™s Chi-ki-to) in Rajasthan. Just as in MaheÅ›varapura, Xuanzang reports a strong Åšaiva presence in Chi-ki-to: â€˜There are about ten DÃªva temples, which some thousand followers frequentâ€™ (Beal II, 271). The archaeological remains in NagarÂ¯Ä± (MÂ¯

adhyamika) testify to its importance as a Åšaiva centre in the 5th and 6th centuries, predating Chitor. 30 We discuss the NagarÂ¯Ä± remains in more detail elsewhere. 31

26 Gupta 1989, 129â€“131.

27 Cf. Bisschop 2006, 209.

28 Xuanzang in Beal II, 271.

29 See also Deloche 1980 I, 60 & Fig. 8. This appears to be the same route that is described in the TÂ¯Ä±rthayÂ¯

atrÂ¯

aparvan (MBh 3.80.59â€“71). Another candidate for MaheÅ›varapura has been proposed by Michael Willis (1997, 17), who identifies this place with the village of Shivpur (Shivpuri/Sipri), c. 100 km west of Jhansi (MP), c. 240 km south of MathurÂ¯

a.

29 / Origin and Spread of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Movement

563

The route along which the PÂ¯

aÂ´

supata religion moved north

Combining the evidence and the above conjectures, tentative as much of it may be, we could try to reconstruct the route along which the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata reli-

gion moved north in the fourth century. Coming from Karvan in Gujarat, and after having established itself in Ujjain in Western Malwa (Madhya Pradesh), it moved northwards along the ancient caravan route that connected the port of Bharukaccha (Bharuch) at the mouth of the NarmadÂ¯

a River, through Uj-

jain, with Pus.kara in Rajasthan and the town of MathurÂ¯a further-on in Uttar Pradesh.

On this route JambumÂ¯

arga, MaheÅ›varapura, became a PÂ¯

aÅ›upata

stronghold like Ujjain and MathurÂ¯

a (Figure 15).

The movement did not end in MathurÂ¯

a. The SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a speaks of the

fourth disciple of LÂ¯

agud.i as a man born in the Kuru country, i.e. Kuruks.etra, but it stops short of mentioning him by name (see above, p. 527). This purus.a issued from the fourth face of Åšiva is said to have been initiated by LÂ¯

agud.i in

Kanyakubja, the city of Kanauj in Uttar Pradesh (SPS 167, 129). We take this as an indication that Kanauj had become another important centre of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata sect in the 5th or 6th century. The explicit mentioning of the birth of the fourth disciple in the Land of the Kurus strongly suggests that this region too, with its capital Thanesar (SthÂ¯

aneÅ›vara), had become a mainstay of the

new faith. The rise of the city of Kanauj as the political (and cultural) capital of Northern India in the 6th century, made that it became the base from where the movement spread over North India and beyond, into MagadhÂ¯

a, Nepal and

Southeast Asia (Cambodia).

The origin of a pan-Indian religion

The SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a describes the four disciples, after they had been initiated ( anugr.hya), as apostles of the PaËœncÂ¯artha doctrine.

LÂ¯

agud.i (the divine incarnation) bestowed on them â€˜His own doctrineâ€™ (SvasiddhÂ¯anta) and yoga, and spoke:

This is the final mystical teaching known as PaËœ

ncÂ¯

artha. It has been proclaimed

to you in order that you liberate the brahmins from the fetters of death. You should make the brahmins reach the highest station by initiating them (in this teaching). Your dwelling places shall be on sacred river banks, in holy sanctuaries, as well as in deserted houses and forests, excluded from society.

Having heard this word of Lord PaÅ›upati Himself, all these four disciples, being enlightened by God, did as they were told. 32

To pursue the further course of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata religion will remain a future task.

I would like to conclude by briefly illustrating how a possibly historic, and 32 SPS 167.129cdâ€“132. Above, p. 527 and n. 3 on p. 528.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

564

Hans Bakker

in many respects unique, mystical event, the religious enlightenment of the brahmin saint KuÅ›ika in Ujjain, developed into a pan-Indian cult of LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a.

The author Kaun.d.inya gives the impression of still being in direct touch with the origins of the movement. He relates how the divine incarnation reached Ujjain by foot, a touching detail, and suggests that the authenticity of this event can be confirmed by the still visible traces that have been left behind. 33 In the two hundred years between Kaun.d.inya and the composition of the SkandapurÂ¯a-n

. a great developments had taken place. There had risen a number of gurus, no doubt rivals with one another, who claimed that their respective lineages ( paramparÂ¯

a) hailed back to a disciple of the divine incarnation. To unite them, the idea of multiple disciplesâ€”first two, and then fourâ€”was invented.

In an orthogenetic processâ€”or, less likely, a heterogenetic one through the influence of the Hellenistic figure of Heraclesâ€”the divine incarnation who was believed to have initiated these four disciples somehow came to be called LÂ¯

agud.i

or LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a. Once the idea was accepted that this LÂ¯

agud.i had operated not

only in KÂ¯

arohan.a and Ujjain, but had initiated in Åšaiva centres such as JambumÂ¯

arga, MathurÂ¯

a and another as far off as Kanyakubja, there was no longer a reason not to claim that he had operated in other places as well. The last vestige of historicity vanished. It was replaced by the belief that there had been incarnations of Åšiva in all world periods: LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a was just one of them.

And why should God limit his range to western India? This new view is evident in a passage in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a that has been shown by Peter Bisschop to be

an interpolation in the earliest extant recension of the text, the one preserved in Nepal (SPS). 34 This passage runs as follows:

Tradition has it that there are eight holy places of Åšiva (ÅšaÅ›imaulin) in the land of MagadhÂ¯

a, through which Lagud.Â¯Ä±Å›vara wandered, surrounded by his pupils. When one has visited those, a man will be at once redeemed from sins. 35

Thus developed an elitist faith of ascetic virtuosi into a catholic religion. The anonymous saviour of Kaun.d.inya turned into just another manifestation of the divine, his worship into just another form of Åšiva devotion.

33 Kaun

. d

. inya ad PS 1.1. Sastriâ€™s edition pp. 3 f. Above, p. 542.

34 Bisschop 2006, 15â€“17. Above, p. 537.

35 SPS 167.169; above, n. 36 on p. 537.

The Quest for the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weaponâˆ—

The Gateway of the MahÂ¯

adeva Temple at

MadhyamikÂ¯

a (NagarÂ¯Ä±)

Hans Bakker & Peter Bisschop

Introduction

The village of NagarÂ¯Ä± is situated in the Chittorgarh District (Rajasthan), 11 km north of the famous fort. The present archaeological site lies to the south of the village on the right bank of the River Berach. The original citadel along the river extended further northwards and included the space presently occupied by the village (Plate 129).

Plate 129

The citadel of the old town of MadhyamikÂ¯

a

âˆ— The first version of this article was published in IIJ 59 (2016): 217â€“258. It was the outcome of the joint visit of Bakker and Bisschop to the village of NagarÂ¯Ä± in January 2016. We are much obliged to VÃ©ronique Degroot for preparing the drawings of the architraves illustrating this article.

567

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

568

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

The remains of the MahÂ¯

adeva Temple are found in the southern part of the

archaeological site (Plate 130).

Plate 130

The site of the MahÂ¯

adeva Temple

These remains consist of a reconstructed brick platform surrounded by some stray pieces of architecture: parts of a dhvajastambha (pillar), pillar capitals having bull and lion, a pedestal, an architrave of a toran

. a, a beam with gavÂ¯

aks.as

and makara, and a toran

. a post (Plate 131).

Plate 131

Remains within the precincts of the MahÂ¯

adeva Temple

The history of the NagarÂ¯

Inscriptions and coins

Many coins are reported to have come from NagarÂ¯Ä±. Bhandarkar found in his excavations sixteen legible punch-marked coins pertaining to the Åšibi-janapada.

This distinguishes the Åšibis of NagarÂ¯Ä± from those of the Punjab. Bhandarkar (and historians after him) had little doubt that MadhyamikÂ¯

of NagarÂ¯Ä± and also the district around itâ€™. 4

. kars.an.a and VÂ¯

ad.Â¯a), â€˜half a mile east of the village [NagarÂ¯Ä±]â€™. Bhandarkar found here, among other things, a stone with grafitto reading: Â´

srÂ¯Ä±vis.n.upÂ¯adÂ¯abhyÂ¯am

. in

seventh-century characters. 6

For our present purpose, the inscription reportedly found â€˜not far from the shrine of MahÂ¯

adevaâ€™ is of greater relevance. It is dated 481 in the Kr.ta (=

a brothersâ€™, SatyaÅ›Â¯

ura, Srugandha (ÅšrÂ¯Ä±gandha ?)

and DÂ¯

asa, and thus testifies to a Vis.n.u temple, established at or near the site of the MahÂ¯

aragupta. 7 At this

alava was under control of the feudatory Early Aulikara prince ( nr.pati) ViÅ›vavarman, who was ruling from DaÅ›apura (Mandasor), c. 100 km to the south of NagarÂ¯Ä±. 8

According to Bhandarkar it was

â€˜deposited in the Rajputana Museum, Ajmerâ€™. Although the line of the inscription that mentions the Kr.ta Era has been extensively discussed in CII III (1981), 192 ff., and the inscription clearly falls within the category of â€˜Inscriptions of the Early Gupta Kingsâ€™, the editors of the revised edition of Volume III of the CII (B. Chhabra & G.S. Gai) refrain from including and editing this inscription in their volume, nor do they give any more information about the inscription itself and its whereabouts. It shows again the limited value of this â€˜revised editionâ€™.

8 CII III (1880), 72â€“78; SI I, 399â€“405; Salomon 1989, 19 f.

9 Bhandarkar 1920, Plates XIV ( a), XV ( b).

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

via free access

30 / The Quest for the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon

571

and Gai in Epigraphia Indica 34 (1961â€“62). The second inscription attests to the building of a temple, which was, in all likelihood, dedicated to Åšiva, since the ma Ë™ngala verse speaks of â€˜the one who hides the moon in the pile of his curling, tawny matted locksâ€™. 10 Its construction seems to have been commissioned by a rÂ¯

ajasthÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä±ya or viceroy who was ruling in DaÅ›apura and MadhyamÂ¯

a.

The (Åšiva) temple is said to be located to the north of the (Vis.n.u) temple of ManorathasvÂ¯

amin. 11

MadhyamÂ¯

a has been identified with MadhyamikÂ¯

a, and the rÂ¯

ajasthÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä±ya, son

of Vis.n.udatta and grandson of VarÂ¯aha(dÂ¯asa), belonged to the powerful mer-chant (Naigama) family that kept the office of chief minister or viceroy under the Later Aulikara kings of DaÅ›apura, in particular PrakÂ¯

aÅ›adharman and

YaÅ›odharman (between ad 510 and 533).12 The two Chittorgarh inscriptions belong to this period and record the importance of the MadhyamÂ¯

a/Madhya-

mikÂ¯

a province within the kingdom of DaÅ›apura in the first four decades of the sixth century. They also testify to shifting religious affiliations amongst regional rulers: the Early Aulikaras, like their Gupta overlords, were Vais.n.avas; the Later Aulikaras, who came to power after the turbulent period that saw the fall of the Gupta Empire, were devotees of Åšiva. It would seem that the archaeological remains in NagarÂ¯Ä± reflect this revolution.

The fort of Chittorgarh dates from the post-Aulikara period, when DaÅ›apura and MadhyamikÂ¯

a had lost their prominence. It is conceivable that the inscribed stone slab came from nearby NagarÂ¯Ä± along with other materials, when the newly built fort provided safety to a successor state, possibly that of the Mori Rajputs (Mauryas) in the seventh century. 13

Archaeology

Excavations at NagarÂ¯Ä± were conducted by D.R. Bhandarkar in the â€˜second decade of the [20th] centuryâ€™, and after him by K.V. Soundara Rajan in 1962â€“

  1. 14 The archaeological situation is summed up by R.P. Sharma in A. Ghoshâ€™s Encyclopaedia of Indian Archaeology, volume II s.v. â€˜Nagariâ€™.

[. . . ] Three periods were distinguished, the first two being anterior to the stone fortification and seemingly without baked-brick structures, though limestone structures were known. They had both red and grey wares; the occurrence of the NBPW

was negligible, though associated red ware was available. The settlement seems to have originated in c. 400 B.C. [. . . ] Period III was marked by the presence of the Red Polished Ware. The other finds of the site include terracotta human and animal figures in Åšu Ë™nga and Gupta styles [. . . ] The fortification probably originated in Gupta times.

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

The main site of Bhandarkarâ€™s excavation was around the small MahÂ¯

adeva

Temple. This temple itself is of recent date, but the installed li Ë™nga may be old (Plate 134).

Plate 134

Li Ë™

nga of MahÂ¯

adeva Temple

The structure exposed in the excavations consists of a square brick platform (Plate 135).

Plate 135

Excavated brick platform in NagarÂ¯Ä±

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

30 / The Quest for the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon

573

It will be seen from the plan that the east side was unlike the other sides of the platform and shows that it and its superstructure faced that direction. The maximum height preserved of its moulded walls is 4â€™ [122 cm] and is found in the west wall. This seems to be nearly half of the original height of the platform. Though the upper half of its walls has fallen down, it appears from the terracottas picked up from the dÃ©bris, to have been covered with decorative tiles of at least three types, some of them probably arranged in string courses. One type is represented by what may be styled bird terracottas. [. . . ]

The centre of the platform was originally occupied by a superstructure, very little of which has now survived. It is 43â€™ 6â€ [13.30 m] square at the base. Immediately below each side of this square is a foundation wall, 6â€™ [1.80 m] thick. [. . . ] Of the superstructure only the lowermost moulding has been preserved, which is nearly two feet high. (Bhandarkar 1920, 135 f.)

The original temple of the Gupta period may have been of brick, but, as observed by Bhandarkar ( op. cit. 138), â€˜to the second period of additions characterised by the introduction of stone work, or possibly to a period slightly later, belong the remains of a stone toran

. a exhumed in front of the moundâ€™. It is this toran

. a which is the subject of this article.

The toran

. a of the MahÂ¯

adeva Temple

In describing this gateway Joanna Williams (1982, 140 f.) observed that, The most impressive carvings at NagarÂ¯Ä± are the remains of a gigantic gateway or toran

. a that must belong to the early sixth century on the basis of its relationship to works from Mandasor. The decorative side face of the post bears fluted bands and medallions [Plate 136], which elaborate upon forms found at Mukundara.

Passing through the temple gateway is entering a new world. The toran

. a as

such epitomizes the rite of passage and the symbolism of this rite informs the iconography of the gateway (below, p. 599). It begins with the gatekeeper and his trident at the bottom of the gate post, eastern side, at the entry of the temple compound, which is oriented toward the east (Plate 137). 15

15 That this is the eastern, that is entry side, follows from the fact that it has the figure of a DvÂ¯

arapÂ¯

ala, and because it fits only the eastern face of the architrave. The latter face is the eastern one, because it contains a Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯

urti, which would be without meaning

if it faced west (Bakker 2004c), and an image of Åšiva in meditation (YogeÅ›vara), which should likewise face east. It also seems to follow from the iconographic programme of the architrave itself, which begins, as we will see, in the panels at the entrance, that is the eastern side, and continues with the panels at the exit, that is the western side.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

576

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

The full length of the architrave must have measured about 4 metres, but the southern-most panel has broken off at one-third and the concluding sculpture of a garland bearer is missing at that end (Plates 141â€“142; cf. Plate 115). The whole architrave consisted, in our reconstruction, of two garland bearers on either end and six panels in between. The middle of the architrave must have been between the third and the fourth panel, which we deduce from the turn of the torsion in between the third and fourth panels in the garland at the bottom of the crossbar. The height of the architrave is 65 cm, its width 38 cm. The architrave is broken at two places: in the first panel at the northern end and in the middle, between the third and fourth panels. 19

The iconography of the eastern face of the architrave, seen by visitors when they entered the temple complex, has been discussed in Bakker 2004c, 131â€“

34, in particular its panel at the northern end, which, it was argued (above, p. 525), contained a Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti. The latter interpretation still stands, but the person who is instructed in this mÂ¯

urti has to be reconsidered.

At the time Bakker worked from a photograph kindly sent to him by Joanna Williams, which he re-published. 20 Williams (1982, 141) had observed that:

â€˜The subjects of the reverse [i.e. eastern face] of this same crossbar remain to be identified.â€™ In a letter to Bakker she added to this that she wondered â€˜whether the scene at the left end of this face might not represent the destruction of Daks.aâ€™s sacrificeâ€™.21 Bakker (2004, 132 ff.) accepted this suggestion and interpreted the Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti scene as representing the initiation of King Daks.a in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatavrata.

The present revision of this interpretation has been prompted by a visit to the excavation site at NagarÂ¯Ä± by Bakker and Bisschop and a study of the architrave in the field (15 January 2016). For it turned out that the panel at the southern end (E 1), although incomplete since it has broken off at one-third, 19 Bhandarkar 1920, 139 thinks that â€˜enough has been recovered to show that each broader side was originally divided into nine panels [including garland bearers]â€™. Bhandarkarâ€™s reconstruction in Plate XXIII shows that he conjectures that one complete panel plus garland bearer is missing at the southern end. In view of the turn of the torsion between the third and fourth panels (E 3â€“4, W 3â€“4), we think this is less likely. An argument against our assumption, as voiced by VÃ©ronique Degroot, is that the architrave panels show alternating indentation and protrusion: panels E 2/W 5, E 4/W 3 and (northern-most) E 6/W 1 are protruding and so, assuming symmetry, one might expect a southern-most panel to be protruding as well. Another argument, however, against a missing 7th panel, in addition to the change in torsion, seems to be that the breaking point in the southern-most panel (E 1/W 6) corresponds with the crack in the northern-most panel (E 6/W 1), the positions where the architrave supposedly rested on its two posts. The collapse of the toran

. a thus seems to have taken place by a break in the middle and at the two junctures. Six panels on each side makes sense according to the iconographical analysis offered in this article. If a 7th, lost panel was originally part of the architrave, the iconography of panels E 1 and W 6 that we conjecture may have been divided, broadly speaking, over two panels.

20 Williams 1982, Plate 216; Bakker 2004c, Figure 4.1 (above, Plate 115).

21 Letter dated 10 March 2001, quoted above, p. 524 (Bakker 2004c, 132).

aÅ›upata Weapon

577

actually contains significant information that had been invisible in the above-mentioned photograph. This evidence was spotted by Bisschop and debated in the field. It resulted in the acknowledgement that the earlier interpretation of the panels of the eastern face as depicting the Daks.a myth needed to be reconsidered.

The incomplete panel at the southern end (E 1) deserves a full discussion (Plate 143).

Two features of this sculpture catch the eye and suggest a new identification.

The pronounced ithyphallic character and the brush with peacock feathers, which is held in the asceticâ€™s left hand. It invites comparison to an image found at the bottom of the seventh-century doorpost built into the Deur Temple in Malhar, Chhattisgarh (Plate 144). 22

Lower-most panel in Malhar doorpost

As emerges from this and other panels of the same doorjamb, the Malhar panel depicts Åšivaâ€™s entry as a naked ascetic into the DevadÂ¯

aruvana. The earliest

account of this myth is found in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a. The description of his

appearance there matches the present panel:

The Trident-bearer once entered that forest for the sake of alms. The sages saw the Lord of Gods there with his phallus erect. 23

Like in the NagarÂ¯Ä± panel, Åšiva carries the ascetic attribute of a brush and is ithyphallic, while his left hand holds a begging bowl ready to receive alms. 24

These features do not figure in the Daks.a myth.

In the NagarÂ¯Ä± panel E 1 the protagonist carries something in his raised right hand. The elevated position suggests the object is significant, auspicious it would seem. It is held in such a way as if it is being shown to an audience 23 SPS 167.74: bhiks.Â¯

that populated the missing two-thirds of the panel. This interpretation of the gesture is reinforced by the two following NagarÂ¯Ä± panels (E 2 & 3), in which apparently the same object is raised, but in the left hand this time, in order to hold it away from the attackers, whereas the right hand now holds the ascetic brush. Moreover, the object seems to contain something in the first panel whereas it appears empty in the second and third, a difference that might have significance and which we will discuss below. A deer in the incomplete first panel (E 1) and a clearly visible tree in the third one (E 3) suggest a forest setting (Plates 143, 146).

Plate 145

Plate 146

Second panel from the left (E 2)

Third panel from the left (E 3)

That this forest in the NagarÂ¯Ä± panel is also the DevadÂ¯

aruvana, follows from

another significant difference between the first panel on the one hand and the second and third panels on the other: the protagonist in the latter two is no longer ithyphallic, or phallic at all. This is not due to damage, but seems to be an intrinsic part of the sculpture. This feature proves, in our view, that the myth depicted on the eastern face of the NagarÂ¯Ä± architrave is, like its Malhar counterpart, that of Åšiva in the Pine Forest:

Out of envy the bewildered sages felled the great li Ë™

nga of the god, O VyÂ¯

asa, in

the Pine Forest hermitage. 25

A problem remains: what is the object that Åšiva holds first in his raised right and then in his left hand? Erosion of the object in all three panels hampers its identification. The earlier view that saw in these panels the depiction of the Daks.a myth naturally interpreted this object as the sacrificial cake ( purod.Â¯aÅ›), seized from the sacrifice, but this could apply to the second and third panels only (E 2 & 3), not to the first one (E 1), in which the object is shown by Åšiva. 26

ayan

. a. In the present

scene, in which the male in the background is the seer in a pose of resignation, while his wife in front of him is full of admiration for the intruder.

In the fourth and fifth panels the NagarÂ¯Ä± and Malhar stories go separate ways.

The Malhar panels refer to the DevadÂ¯

aruvana myth as told in the

SaromÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya, in which Åšiva in the form of an elephant plays a central role in re-installing the li Ë™nga. 32 We will focus on the NagarÂ¯Ä± story.

When we pass from the third (E 3) to the fourth panel (E 4) we cross the middle of the architrave and therewith, it seems, we leave behind the DevadÂ¯

aruvana

myth proper. The right half of the architrave is rather concerned with the consequences of the events told in the myth: Åšiva is recognized as supreme god, who alone is capable of bestowing power ( siddhi), grace ( prasÂ¯

ada) and

deliverance from all suffering ( duh

. khÂ¯

anta). This is what the begging sages in

the third panel (E 3) realize; the fourth panel (E 4) shows this new insight. God is depicted sitting under a tree, deep in concentration, as the master of yoga, YogeÅ›vara (Plate 154). 33

Plate 154

Fourth panel from the left (E 4), NagarÂ¯Ä±

The reason that his YogeÅ›vara form and not the li Ë™nga is chosen to represent him may have its origin in the fact that the designer of the architrave wanted to 32 VmP SaromÂ¯

ahÂ¯

atmya 23.29â€“35. Cf. Donaldson 1986, pp. 53â€“54.

33 The iconography of Åšiva steeped in meditation underneath a tree is obviously derived from Buddhist examples.

via free access

584

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

tell another story. Realization of oneâ€™s aim in this world and the acquisition of (yogic) power is achieved by following the path ( sÂ¯

adhana) that he contemplates

and is ready to communicate to the world of men. The four acolytes around YogeÅ›vara may intimate the spread of this sÂ¯

adhana over the earth, since they

evoke the image of the four disciples:

And in the present age as well, when the Supreme Lord had seen the suffering in the world, He emitted four men ( purus.a) from His four faces and spoke to them, since it was His wish to bestow grace upon mankind:

â€˜You four should go to earth and become twice-born ascetics; O Masters of Yoga, return to me after you have led the brahmins to the highest station. 34

These purus.as, the SkandapurÂ¯an.a (SP) continues, will become the four disciples ( Â´

sis.ya) of Åšiva, whose own incarnation on earth is known as LÂ¯agud.i in the SP

or LakulÂ¯Ä±Å›a in later literature. This incarnation, characterised by his attribute the club ( lakula), is not depicted on the architrave, but any guru pertaining to the four param

. parÂ¯

as inaugurated by him, may be imagined to be implicitly involved in the last panel of the eastern face, since these Â¯

acÂ¯

aryas are believed

to impersonate Åšiva when they initiate and instruct their pupils. 35 The four acolytes around YogeÅ›vara perform different acts of veneration and they do not seem all to be of the same standing. The one at the viewerâ€™s lower right may be a householder, indicating that not only ascetics, but the whole world had come to recognize Åšiva as supreme god.

The following, penultimate panel (E 5, Plate 155) shows someone set on the path towards instruction in the doctrine, which is the subject of the last panel (E 6, Plate 156, cf. Plate 116).

The interpretation that conceived of these east-facing panels as depicting the myth of the destruction of Daks.aâ€™s sacrifice obviously saw in the central figure King Daks.a (Bakker 2004c). In our present understanding of the iconographic programme, however, this is no longer evident.

Of the three figures in a row, the one at the viewerâ€™s right seems to stand within a architectural structure of which roof and pillars are still partly visible.

In his left hand he carries something that looks like a quiver. If this is the case, we could expect that there would be a bow somewhere, but the panel is too much eroded to make it out. Twisted locks of hair fall from under his crown-like headgear. This feature recurs in the next panel in the kneeling figure and we infer that both depict the same person.

30 / The Quest for the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon

585

Plate 155

Fifth panel from the left (E 5), NagarÂ¯Ä±

The figure at the viewerâ€™s left seems to be of a different standing than the two persons to the right. He is naked and of plump build. His headdress seems plain and his right hand makes the â€˜do-not-fearâ€™ gesture. His left hand is something of a puzzle. It would seem that this hand is raised and holds an object at head height, if this is not the raised right arm of the central figure.

The tallest figure in the middle is clearly a senior person. His left hand holds the knot of his dhotÂ¯Ä±. His right arm, if it is not raised, appears to lean on the left arm of his companion to the right, while his hand seems to hold something; a stick? It is clear that he wears a high crown with an ornament.

As a working hypothesis we conjecture that the figure carrying the quiver and who reappears in the next panel is Arjuna, who is being dispatched by his elder brother Yudhis.t.hira, the figure in the middle, on the advise of VyÂ¯asa, who stands on the (viewerâ€™s) left side.

MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata 3.37â€“38 tells the story. 36 VyÂ¯

asa instructs Yudhis.t.hira to pass

on to Arjuna a spell, a vidyÂ¯

a named Pratismr.ti, also referred to as yogavidyÂ¯a or brahman, which will enable him to acquire the necessary weapons from Indra, Rudra, Varun.a, Kubera and Dharma.37 Yudhis.t.hira explains to Arjuna that their enemies possess mastery in the use of all sorts of weapons and therefore, for the PÂ¯

an.d.avas to win the war, it is necessary to obtain superior weapons.

He will initiate him into this secret knowledge (Upanis.ad) received from VyÂ¯asa, 36 Cf. KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya (KA) 3.10â€“29.

37 MBh 3.37.25â€“28.

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

thanks to which the whole world will become visible to him and through which he should seek the grace of the gods. 38

After these words the lord King Dharma (i.e. Yudhis.t.hira) taught him (i.e. Arjuna) that magic, when he was ritually consecrated and controlled in word, body, and thought; then the elder brother told his heroic brother to depart. 39

In the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata Indra is the first person that Arjuna visits on his quest, but the Åšaiva world view, which conceived this temple and architrave, shifted the VyÂ¯

asaâ€“Yudhis.t.hira line of initiation onto Åšiva, as we will see in the next panel.

It is Åšivaâ€™s help that is sought first, since only instruction in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata path

will enable Arjuna to reach his goal. This is the lesson that the seers on earth had learned in the DevadÂ¯

aruvana, illustrated in the first three panels. We move on to the last one (E 6, Plate 156).

identifies the figure to Åšivaâ€™s right ( daks.in.Â¯a), towards whom he slightly bends, as the same princely figure that we have tentatively identified as Arjuna in the preceding panel (E 5). Arjuna is on his knees now, facing north, receiving instruction. The scene is set on a mountain, in a forest. A powerful gan

. a-type

of figure stands behind him, bending the heroâ€™s arms behind his back by his front hands, or so it seems; his right back hand sticks up holding something above his head, whereas the contour of his raised left back arm is only vaguely visible. We will discuss below who this four-armed helper of Åšiva could be.

As we have argued earlier, this panel (E 6) shows a Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti in the original meaning of the term (Bakker 2004c, 132 f.; above, p. 525). The neophyte who is instructed or initiated in the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata doctrine is not Daks.a, according

to our present understanding, but the princely figure depicted in the penultimate panel E 5, who is there about to be dispatched by his elder brother and a saintly advisor.

The DevadÂ¯

aruvana myth that is told in the first three panels (E 1â€“3) does not immediately suggest a figure that would be the recipient of Åšivaâ€™s instruction, let alone the figure of Arjuna. Our tentative interpretation of this panel E 6, which sees in it Arjunaâ€™s instruction in the Åšaiva sÂ¯

adhana, needs further

underpinning. This will be furnished by the iconographic programme of the western face of the architrave, which will make clear that we should read both sides of the architrave as one continuous story.

Reconstruction of the architrave of the gateway, facing west The panels of the reverse side of the architrave (Plates 157â€“158), which faced west and were seen by visitors leaving the temple complex, have been indentified by Joanna Williams (1982, 141); they depict scenes from the KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya

myth. This interpretation has been accepted by Bakker 2004c and still stands.

aÅ›adharman, was responsible for the building of this temple and its gateway.

â€˜Nara and NÂ¯

armed. The scene is set in the mountains, where the rest of the KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya

myth takes place. A lion is visible in a mountain cave at the foot.

Despite the striking similarities between the Deogarh and NagarÂ¯Ä± panels, we are not convinced that the figure to the left of Arjuna is indeed NÂ¯

arÂ¯

ayan.a.

Instead we think it more likely that the person Arjuna is speaking to is â€˜the ascetic ( tapasvin), blazing with the lustre of brahman, tawny, with matted hair and leanâ€™, 42 who is no other than Indra in disguise. This brahmin asks Arjuna why he has come in full armour and requests him to leave behind his bow (MBh 3.38.32â€“34). The bow may indeed be visible in the present panel to Arjunaâ€™s right side.

After this brahmin failed to have Arjuna give up his resolve, he reveals his true identity and offers a boon. Arjuna replies:

I do not want wishes of worlds, or divinity, still less happiness, nor the sovereignty over all the gods, overlord of the Thirty! If I leave my brothers in the wilderness without avenging the feud, I shall find infamy in all the worlds for time without end. 43

These are the proud words of the Ks.atriya, the quintessence of the KirÂ¯atÂ¯arjunÂ¯Ä±ya. Confronted with so much self-confidence, Indra can think of nothing better than to refer Arjuna to â€˜the three-eyed, trident-bearing Lord of Beings, Åšivaâ€™. 44

The similarity of the NagarÂ¯Ä± panel with the one in Deogarh and other Naraâ€“

NÂ¯

arÂ¯

ayan.a representations is, however, not coincidence, but serves as a reminder to the onlooker that Arjuna is Nara. In BhÂ¯

araviâ€™s KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya (12.33) Åšiva

explains to the seers that Arjuna is in fact an incarnation of Nara, a part of the Primaeval Man ( Â¯

Adipurus.a). And, he says, there is Acyuta. Nara and Acyuta have been asked by BrahmÂ¯

a to go among men to protect creation by killing

demons, 45 but â€˜NÂ¯

arÂ¯

ayan.aâ€™ as such does not figure in BhÂ¯araviâ€™s work.

Nara is said to have been created by Deva NÂ¯Ä±lalohita in SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a 6.

He had issued from the mirror image of Vis.n.u, who was reflected in the blood that the latter had himself donated to NÂ¯Ä±lalohitaâ€™s begging bowl. This begging bowl is said in SP 6.1 to be BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™s Head ( brahman

. ah

. Â´

sirah

. ), that is, his fifth

one, which had been chopped off in SP 5 and was then used by Åšiva/NÂ¯Ä±lalohita on his rounds for alms. 46

After Deva (i.e. NÂ¯Ä±lalohita) has seen (Vis.n.uâ€™s) reflection in the liquid ( rasa) within the skull ( kapÂ¯

ala), he issues forth (a) man ( purus.a) resembling Vis.n.u in strength.

If we follow the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata story, the seers, afraid of Arjunaâ€™s ascetic

powers, go to MahÂ¯

adeva, who acknowledges Arjunaâ€™s mortifications and gives his approval:

The Great Lord said: â€˜Swiftly return in joyous spirit and unwearied whence you have come. I do know the intention that is lodged in his mind. He does not desire heaven, nor sovereignty, nor long life; this very day I shall accomplish what he desires.â€™ 49

We tentatively propose that it is this important moment of Åšivaâ€™s consent (and his resolve to put him to the test first) that has been depicted in this panel. It is also conceivable that the figure of Åšiva here is a representation of Arjunaâ€™s thought.

The figure seems to be four-armed, though only three are visible; his left back hand, if that is what it is, is raised and carries an object not unlike the mysterious object in the first three panels of the eastern face of the architrave (E 1â€“3). We postpone the discussion of this object and move on to the third panel (W 3), in which the test starts off.

The scene in this third panel from the left is without problems (Plate 162).

ata with his wife, a disguise that Åšiva and PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä±

had taken on. Arjuna and the hunter argue about whose arrow pierced the boar.

. kara

van Buitenen.)

We arrive at the dÃ©nouement in the sixth panel (W 6, Plate 165), at the southern end of the western face of the architrave.

The KirÂ¯

ata had been a form adopted by Åšiva to test his devotee Arjuna.

The latter is allowed a vision of the Great God. In the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata version

of the story MahÂ¯

adeva reveals himself as the god carrying the trident, dwelling in the mountains together with DevÂ¯Ä±; in the KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya he assumes â€˜his own

formâ€™, smeared with ashes and ornamented with the crescent. 51 Neither of these are visible to us, since, like its counterpart E 1, the panel is broken off at one-third. But we do see Arjuna, no longer as an ascetic, though, but as a princely figure, wearing his ornamental crown from which his locks fall down, very similar to his representation in the two panels at the end of the eastern face of the architrave (E 5 & 6). that the eastern and western faces of the architrave tell a continuous story, the story of Arjuna and his quest for the PÂ¯

The

story is Arjunaâ€™s quest for the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata

astra, the weapon which alone is powerful

and which leads its owner to victory over

If

it

to

wish, Bull-bannered God, then I wish

that divine weapon ( astra), the dreadful

aÅ›upata Weapon, my lord, which is called

aâ€™s Head ( brahmaÂ´

siras), gruesome

( raudra), of terrible power, which at the

horrible end of the Eon will destroy the

entire world. With it I may burn down

acas, Gandharvas,

and Snakes. From its mouth ( yatah

. ), when

ah

. ), issues forth

I shall embattle BhÂ¯Ä±s.ma, Dron.a, and Kr.pa,

and the always rough-spoken son of the

(W 6, southern end)

uta (Karn.a). This is my wish, my lord,

who took Bhagaâ€™s eyes, so by your grace I

may go forth competent! 52

Åšiva gives this powerful weapon to Arjuna, 53 but warns him to use it cautiously, since launched against a person of insufficient strength it may have apocalyptic consequences. If the panels of the architrave are to make any sense, this gift of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon must have been represented somehow. Aside from final release ( duh

. khÂ¯

anta), it is the ultimate boon for the MÂ¯

53 In the KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya 18.44 Åšiva gives Arjuna the Raudra Weapon, encompassed by flaming fire ( jvaladanalaparÂ¯Ä±tam

. raudram astram).

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

594

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

The PÂ¯

aÂ´

supata Weapon

If we work on the assumption that this boon must have been represented in the narrative of the architrave, we should answer the question how it has been depicted in its iconographic programme. The weapon ( astra) is called â€˜belonging to Rudraâ€™ or â€˜fierceâ€™ ( raudra), but more significantly: â€˜Head of BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™. This

may refer, as we have seen above (p. 589), to one of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata key myths,

namely the cutting off of the fifth head of BrahmÂ¯

a by Åšiva/NÂ¯Ä±lalohita. This

myth was known in the last phase of the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata composition, where Åšiva

is called BrahmaÅ›iropaharta (sic). 54

The full story is first told in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a.

Then, ordered by ParameÅ›vara, this lord NÂ¯Ä±lalohita, his (matted) hair coiled into a top-knot ( kapardin), took the Head of BrahmÂ¯

a.

After he had taken that shining head, he assumed a disguise, entered a playful state of yoga and started going around begging. 55

This â€˜Head of BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™ is Åšivaâ€™s begging bowl and, according to the

MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata, the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon seems to be just that, the Holy Grail of Saivism. 56 We should therefore look for a (begging) bowl, and this leads us to the mysterious object that we encountered in the first three panels of the eastern face (E 1â€“3) and in the second one of the western (W 2).

We return to E 1, the first, incomplete panel of the eastern face. What we see in Åšivaâ€™s right, raised hand could agree to the shape of a begging bowl or skull. The function of the bowl/skull shown here is not so much the collecting of alms, rather than exposing it to an audience. This makes sense only if the begging bowl is more than just that. We consider it a rebus, representing the word brahmaÂ´

siras in visual (iconographic) form.

54 MBh 13 App. I, No. 6 l. 45.

Yuko Yokochi (personal communication) has questioned

van Buitenenâ€™s translation of brahmaÂ´

siras with â€˜BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™s Headâ€™ in MBh 3.41.8a (above,

n. 50 on p. 523). Admittedly, there is no reference to the myth of the decapitation of BrahmÂ¯

a here. The BrahmaÅ›iras, like all divine weapons, is a mantra weapon and should be â€˜properly speltâ€™ ( anumantrita) to yield the desired result, that means that this skull of BrahmÂ¯

a ( kapÂ¯

ala)/begging bowl has the potency to issue forth the most powerful weapon.

As such the word may signify â€˜the foremost ( Â´

siras) of the Vedic mantras ( brahman)â€™. We consider it plausible that the ambiguity was deliberate and was made use of by the designer of the architrave.

30 / The Quest for the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon

595

If our analysis is correct, it represents the ne plus ultra, the power that devotees who pursue the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata sÂ¯

adhana aspire to obtain in this world: the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata

Weapon or â€˜Head of BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™, the Åšaiva equivalent of the pÂ¯

urn

. akalaÂ´

sa, the

source of life ( nara) and death ( antaka). 57 This equivalence is further expressed by the fact that in the first panel the bowl seemed to have been filled, whereas the bowl appears empty in the following two panels, when it is withdrawn.

The token that was held out at the beginning in the first relief (E 1) was thus finally obtained by Arjuna in the addorsed panel at the end of the architraveâ€™s narrative (W 6). It is the ks.atra or fighting spirit of Arjuna and his unswerving devotion to Åšiva that won him this award at long last, the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon,

and therewith the power to defeat all enemies. The MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata again de-

scribes the scene.

Hearing this, the PÂ¯

artha (Arjuna) hurriedly and attentively purified himself; and when he embraced the feet of the lord of the universe, the God said to him, â€˜Now learn!â€™ Then he taught the best of the PÂ¯

an.d.avas about the missile ( astra), along

with the secrets of its return, this missile that is Death incarnate ( mÂ¯

urtimantam

ivÂ¯

antakam). [. . . ]

When the moment came, there was an outcry of conches, drums, and kettledrums by the thousands, and a huge quake occurred. The Gods and the DÂ¯

anavas wit-

nessed how that fiercely burning dreadful missile stood bodily deployed ( mÂ¯

urtimat)

at the side of the boundlessly lustrous PÂ¯

an.d.ava. 58

And we believe the visitors to the MahÂ¯

adeva Temple in NagarÂ¯Ä± witnessed it

too. Arjunaâ€™s pose in the final panel (W 6) is one of vacillation. The ends of his cloth flutter. His knee is bent, as if he is taken aback. In front of him, we speculate, the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon may have stood in bodily form, next to Åšiva in all his glory. What the weapon may have looked like, we know from another sculpture telling the same story.

Joanna Williams discusses â€˜a pair of pillars found at Rajaona, 60 km east (and slightly north) of Rajgirâ€™, Bihar (Plate 166). Its subject matter, according to her, â€˜resembles that of the NagarÂ¯Ä± lintelâ€™. â€˜The remaining face shows Åšiva seated with PÂ¯

arvatÂ¯Ä± on his mountain, whilst in front Arjuna kneels before the chubby four-armed personification of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upatÂ¯

astra, the weapon that has

been his goal throughout the story.â€™ 59

Arjuna, however, is not on his knees in NagarÂ¯Ä±; in that pose he had been depicted when he was brought to Åšiva for instruction by a four-armed figure in the last panel of the eastern face (E 6).

Plate 166

Rajaona, column: the presentation of the PÂ¯

aÂ´

supata Weapon

We now conjecture that the four-armed figure in that panel E 6 (Plate 156) may be the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon personified, not waiting on the PÂ¯

an.d.ava hero,

but conducing him to deference. The vigorous way in which this seems to be done could point to the forceful nature of the allegorical figure. The object that he seems to hold above his head may have been the skull, although the sculpture is too much worn to be certain about it. But if so, it would make this four-armed â€˜chubby figureâ€™ in the Daks.in.Â¯amÂ¯urti panel a true Â¯ayudhapurus.a.

A similar allegorical figure must, if our theory is correct, have been depicted in the missing part of the final panel (W 6), this time, however, â€˜waiting on the great heroâ€™ ( upatasthe mahÂ¯

atmÂ¯

anam

. ). 60

The PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon thus seems to be the true subject of the NagarÂ¯Ä± architrave. It is represented as a begging bowl made of BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™s fifth head

(BrahmaÅ›iras), and in personified form as Â¯

ayudhapurus.a. In either form it

appears throughout the iconographic programme: in the eastern-face panels E 1â€“3, and E 6 (embodied), and in the western-face panels W 2 and W 6 (embodiment conjectured). A close comparison may illustrate this point (Plate 167).

30 / The Quest for the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon

597

The showing of the begging bowl or skull in the second panel of the western face (W 2) makes sense. It is not offered to Arjuna yetâ€”as it had been to the ascetics in the first panel of the eastern face (E 1), who, however, rejected it in their ignoranceâ€”but raising it in the back left hand means that it is displayed as a boon that will be awarded, if Arjuna stands the test.

Having reached this point in our analysis, we venture the suggestion that within the first panel of the western face (W 1) the figure of which only a head and a left forearm are visible (to the viewerâ€™s right, above the ascetic who is Indra in disguise), may be the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon, presenting itself in iconic,

that is bodily, and in aniconic form, as the begging bowl in his left hand (Plate 168). 61

Plate 168

W 1 (detail of Plate 159): the PÂ¯

aÂ´

supata Weapon?

Concluding observations

Like the composers of epic and puranic lore, the architect of the MahÂ¯

adeva

Temple and the designer of the iconographic programme of the toran

. a shared

in the universe of myths. Like textual composers, the designer made his selection from this universe to compose his narrative. And like written texts, his visual narrative is inevitably an incomplete rendering of the stock of myths that circulated in his days. Like a textual author he extracted from this stock, adapted it to his needs and in this way contributed to its evolution. A textual source that tells exactly the same narrative as the architrave and that would 61 An alternative sees in this figure the Yaks.a ( rÂ¯

ajarÂ¯

ajÂ¯

anucara, KA 3.30) who leads Arjuna

to Indra in BhÂ¯

araviâ€™s KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya.

Hans T. Bakker - 978-90-04-41207-1

Downloaded from Brill.com08/11/2022 02:12:07AM

via free access

598

Hans T. Bakker & Peter C. Bisschop

thus be considered to be its source is not likely ever to turn up. The narrative of the architrave is the text, and as such it shows instances of intertextuality, thanks to which we can try to understand its message.

Without doubt the designer was well acquainted with the MahÂ¯

abhÂ¯

arata,

whose story of the KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya was at the basis of his work. 62 He could not yet know the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, since we believe that its composition only began

in the second half of the sixth century, but the universe of Åšaiva myths had substantially expanded from the days that the composition of the great epic was coming to a close. The myth of BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™s decapitation by Åšiva, for instance, is

only referred to through an epithet of the Great God in an Appendix passage of the epic, but the full story must have been around in PÂ¯

aÅ›upata circles before

it was put down in the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a. The same is true of the DevadÂ¯

aruvana

myth. Familiarity with this lore is to be presupposed, not only for the designer, but for the general visitor at the time.

Arjunaâ€™s quest for the divine PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon and the DevadÂ¯

aruvana story

are both mythical in nature and as such convey general, timeless truths. As all myths, however, they may serve as templates for human action and their depiction in art may function as historical allegory.

It is appealing therefore to read the architrave as a metaphor and to speculate on its connection with the rÂ¯

ajasthÂ¯

anÂ¯Ä±ya, the Aulikara viceroy who ruled in

MadhyamÂ¯

a/MadhyamikÂ¯

a under PrakÂ¯

aÅ›adharman and YaÅ›odharman (between

ad 510 and 533), and who had, according to the Chittorgarh inscription (above, p. 570), commissioned the building of a MahÂ¯

adeva temple. The educated con-

temporary onlooker may have seen in its iconographic programme evidence of his governor or king embracing the Åšaiva religion by being instructed in its observances; other visitors may have seen only the template, the myth, an ambiguity inherent in Indianâ€”and not only Indianâ€”plastic art in general.

We have discovered the central theme of the NagarÂ¯Ä± architrave, the one that connects both faces. It appears to be the recovery of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon, which

alone was believed to secure victory in difficult times. It helped the PÂ¯

an.d.avas

to win back their kingdom, and it may have been thought to bring victory to the Later Aulikara kings PrakÂ¯

aÅ›adharman and YaÅ›odharman of DaÅ›apura

and their allies in MadhyamikÂ¯

a, when they were locked in a deadly conflict

with their archenemies, ToramÂ¯

an.a and Mihirakula, who were commanding the

dreaded armies of the Huns.

This theme also links the DevadÂ¯

aruvana myth to the KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya.

In

addition to Åšivaâ€™s stark naked and ithyphallic appearance, misunderstood and causing offence, it is the bowl made out of BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™s head and symbolizing the

Great Godâ€™s benevolence, that the seers failed to recognize in the first panel (E 1). Standing alone and being despised is, after all, the fundamental attitude 62 We have not found references specific to BhÂ¯

araviâ€™s KirÂ¯

atÂ¯

arjunÂ¯Ä±ya, which was being com-

posed at about the same time or slightly later (above, p. 588; cf. n. 61 on p. 597).

via free access

30 / The Quest for the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weapon

599

of the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata ascetic. 63 When the seers attack him in the next panel (E 2), he keeps it away from them.

In the earliest written version of the DevadÂ¯

aruvana myth that we possess, 64

SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a 167.72â€“80, the â€˜audienceâ€™ are the VaikhÂ¯

anasa hermits. It is quite

possible that only these or similar sages were depicted in the missing part of the first panel. The role of the wives of the sages may have come more to the fore in later versions, such as the narrative on the doorpost in Malhar, when the connotations of â€˜BrahmaÅ›irasâ€™ either were no longer recognized, as â€˜BrahmÂ¯

aâ€™s

Headâ€™ had subsided into just a bowl to collect alms, or had come into bad grace due to its association with the KÂ¯

apÂ¯

alikas.

The exclusive focus in the Pine Forest myth on the li Ë™nga may therefore have been the result of a development, which gradually replaced the idea that underlies the NagarÂ¯Ä± architrave. This would explain that the li Ë™nga as object of worship does not feature in the architrave. Instead, it was the supreme good that only Åšiva can bestow, object of his meditation in E 4, and symbolized in his BrahmaÅ›iras attribute, that took centre stage.

The irony that will not have been lost on the designer of the architrave and the educated PÂ¯

aÅ›upata visitor of the temple thus seems to be that, if we follow the SkandapurÂ¯

an

. a, Arjuna at the end of his quest recovers the fons et origo from which he, as Nara (above, p. 589), had once emerged, namely the Head of BrahmÂ¯

a. This cycle illustrates the superiority of the high god of the age, MahÂ¯

adeva.

When they passed through the temple gateway, the king and his subjects were reminded of the major realities of Åšivaâ€™s Worldâ€”asceticism, His benevolence, His revelation of the doctrine. After worshipping God, they saw, while they were leaving through the gate, the path which would lead to His grace and which held out to them the prospect of the acquisition of the highest good in this world, the PÂ¯

aÅ›upata Weaponâ€”through steadfastness, self-control and bravery.

It was this faith, embraced by the Later Aulikara kings and their court, that was imparted to the visitors of the MahÂ¯

adeva Temple in MadhyamikÂ¯

a, at the

moment that they came to be involved in the powerful World of the Great God.

aÅ›upatasÂ¯

utra 3.3: avamatah

. .

64 Bisschop 2006, 195 f. In MBh 13 App. I No. 4 ll. 66â€“67 it is only said that Åšiva â€˜sports with the daughters and wives of the sages, with bristled hair, with a great penis, naked, with distorted eyesâ€™. No doubt, an idea like this was the source of the Pine Forest myth.
